<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staining-of-spores">STAINING OF SPORES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-of-spores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The spore wall is resistant to stains but spores can be demonstrated with the application of heat to the preparation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malachite-green-stain-for-spores">Malachite Green Stain for Spores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malachite-green-stain-for-spores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>5% Malachite green in distilled water.</li>
<li>0.5% safranin in distilled water.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare a thin smear and allow to dry.</li>
<li>Fix with minimum amount of heat.</li>
<li>Flood the slide with the 5% malachite green solution. Heat until steam rises and leave for five minutes.</li>
<li>Wash well with water.</li>
<li>Counterstain with 0.5% safranin for 1/2 minute.</li>
<li>Wash with water, blot and dry.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Results</strong>
Spores: green
Vegetative bacteria: red</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fuchsin-nigrosin-spore-stain">Fuchsin-Nigrosin Spore Stain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fuchsin-nigrosin-spore-stain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Strong carbol fuchsin (Ziehl-Neelsen).</li>
<li>1% Nigrosin</li>
<li>5% sodium sulphite</li>
<li>10% Nigrosin</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>544 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Make a thin smear and allow to dry</li>
<li>Fix with heat</li>
<li>Flood slide with the carbol fuchsin, apply heat until steam rises. Leave for five minutes</li>
<li>Wash with water</li>
<li>Treat with 5% sodium sulphite for 10 to 30 seconds, or 1% nigrosin for 5-10 minutes</li>
<li>Wash with water, blot carefully and dry</li>
<li>Place a small drop of 10% nigrosin at one end of the slide and spread evenly over the stained smear with the edge of another slide</li>
<li>Allow to dry and examine</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Spores: bright red
Organisms: unstained against a dark grey background</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="staining-of-bacterial-cell-wall">STAINING OF BACTERIAL CELL WALL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-of-bacterial-cell-wall" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The composition of cell wall differs from bacteria to bacteria, therefore there are variations in the length of time for the stain and cell wall to interact. The staining method uses tannic acid as mordant and Congo red as a selective decolouriser while crystal violet stains the cell wall, leaving the cytoplasm unstained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>5% Tannic acid.</li>
<li>0.5% Aqueous crystal violet.</li>
<li>0.5% Congo red.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Make a thin smear and allow to dry. Do not fix.</li>
<li>Place the slide in tannic acid for 30-60 minutes.</li>
<li>Wash in tap water.</li>
<li>Flood the slide with 0.5% crystal violet for two minutes.</li>
<li>Wash with water.</li>
<li>Flood the slide with 0.5% Congo red for 2-3 minutes.</li>
<li>Blot, dry and examine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Outer cell wall and cross walls: Mauve</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="staining-methods-for-flagella">STAINING METHODS FOR FLAGELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-methods-for-flagella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Young cultures are used to demonstrate flagella. Chemically clean slides must be used and the smear made with proper care. All the methods are of silver impregnation techniques.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fontana-s-silver-method-for-flagella">Fontana's Silver Method for Flagella<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fontana-s-silver-method-for-flagella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>1% Osmic acid</li>
<li>Fontana's mordant</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>10% Tannic acid 10 ml</li>
<li>Saturated potassium alum 10 ml</li>
<li>10% Ferric chloride 1 ml</li>
<li>Mix and stand for three minutes before use. The solution does not keep.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Fontana's silver solution</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Dissolve 5 g silver nitrate in 100 ml distilled water.</li>
<li>Dilute 5 ml of concentrated ammonia with 45 ml distilled water.</li>
<li>Add 35 ml of the diluted ammonia solution to 90 ml of silver nitrate.</li>
<li>Continue to add drop by drop until the precipitate which is formed is redissolved.</li>
<li>Continue to add more until a faint opalescence is seen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Place one drop of 1% osmic acid towards one end of a very clean slide.</li>
<li>With a loop, gently transfer one drop of the water of condensation of an 18 hour old agar slope culture to the drop of Osmic acid and mix gently. Allow the drop to run the whole length of the slide.</li>
<li>Allow to dry in air.</li>
<li>Add Fontana's mordant for three minutes.</li>
<li>Wash in distilled water.</li>
<li>Heat Fontana's silver solution in a test tube and flood the slide. Leave for two minutes.</li>
<li>Wash in distilled water.</li>
<li>Dry in air and mount immediately.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Microscopic Examination of Bacteria 545</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Organisms: black
Flagella: light brown</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="loeffler-s-silver-method-for-flagella">Loeffler's silver method for flagella<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#loeffler-s-silver-method-for-flagella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Loeffler's flagella mordant</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>20% aqueous Tannic acid 100 ml</li>
<li>Ferrous sulphite crystals 2 g</li>
<li>10% alcoholic solution basic fuchsin 10 ml</li>
<li>Distilled water 4 ml</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Loeffler's flagella stain</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>10% alcoholic solution of basic fuchsin 20 ml</li>
<li>3% Aniline water 80 ml</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Make a thin smear and fix with gentle heat.</li>
<li>Flood slide with Loeffler's flagella mordant for five minutes.</li>
<li>Wash with distilled water.</li>
<li>Stain with heated Loeffler's flagella stain for three minutes.</li>
<li>Wash with distilled water, dry and mount.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bacteria: red</li>
<li>Flagella: pink.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Note: The smear for the staining of flagella should be prepared very gently to avoid breaking of flagella.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staining-method-for-spirochaetes">STAINING METHOD FOR SPIROCHAETES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-method-for-spirochaetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The usual and easier way of examining spirochaetes is with the darkfield microscope. They do not stain well with aniline dyes and because the spirochaete spirals are so thin, they are not easily seen by most other staining methods. However, they have the capacity to reduce silver nitrate to metallic silver, thus the demonstration of spirochaetes in smears can be achieved by the silver impregnation method.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fontana-s-method-for-spirochaetes">Fontana's Method for Spirochaetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fontana-s-method-for-spirochaetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Fontana's fixative</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Glacial acetic acid 1 ml</li>
<li>Formalin 2 ml</li>
<li>Distilled water 100 ml</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Absolute alcohol</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fontana's mordant: refer to Fontana's silver method for flagella</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fontana's silver solution: refer to Fontana's silver method for flagella</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Make a thin smear</li>
<li>Treat smear with Fontana's fixative three times for 30 seconds each.</li>
<li>Wash off the fixative with absolute alcohol and cover with absolute alcohol for three minutes.</li>
<li>Drain off the alcohol and carefully burn off the remainder until the film is dry.</li>
<li>Apply Fontana's mordant, heat until steam rises and leave for 30 seconds.</li>
<li>Wash well in distilled water and dry the slide.</li>
<li>Apply the Fontana's silver solution, heat until steam rises and leave for about 1/2 minute (the film turns brown in colour).</li>
<li>Wash in distilled water, dry and mount in neutral synthetic medium.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Spirochaetes: brownish black</li>
<li>Background: brownish yellow</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-d7f2ed52.jpeg" alt="img-12.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definitions">DEFINITIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definitions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Sterilisation</strong> Sterilisation may be defined as any process by means of which all forms of microbial life (bacteria, spores, fungi and viruses) are completely destroyed. The word ‘sterile’ denotes the complete freedom from, or absence of, all living microbes and other forms of life.</p>
<p><strong>Disinfection</strong> This is any process, chemical or physical, whereby harmful microbial agents are destroyed. Disinfection essentially destroys infectious micro-organisms but not necessarily their spores. Disinfection is applied on inanimate objects only. The common disinfecting agents (disinfectants) are chemicals, boiling water, flowing steam and ultraviolet radiation. Disinfectants are bactericidal.</p>
<p><strong>Antiseptic</strong> Antiseptics are substances which, when used on micro-organisms, will render them inactive by inhibiting their multiplication. The effectiveness of the antiseptic depends on the character of preparation or the method of application. Antiseptics are bacteriostatic and they can be applied on living tissues.</p>
<p><strong>Germicide</strong> This is any substance that will kill germs or microbes. Chemical agents are employed to kill pathogens but not necessarily their resistant spores; and they are used in solution form on living tissues as well as on inanimate objects. Other commonly used terms with similar definitions are bactericide, fungicide, viricide and sporicide. Most disinfectants are germicides.</p>
<p><strong>Bacteriostat</strong> This is a chemical agent that can inhibit the growth or multiplication of bacteria. Bacteriostatic action is reversible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basic-principles-of-sterilisation">Basic Principles of Sterilisation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-principles-of-sterilisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An important aim of all sterilisation and disinfection strategy is to prevent the spread of bacteria. In certain cases, all microbes are regarded as potential pathogens and therefore it is essential to eliminate all forms of microbial life. All microbiological techniques require appropriate and adequate sterilisation.</p>
<p>It therefore follows that sterilisation of materials and instruments are essential in certain circumstances, while in other situations, disinfection is just adequate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methods-of-sterilisation">METHODS OF STERILISATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods-of-sterilisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The various methods of sterilisation are designed to kill resistant spores. The vegetative cells can be destroyed with relative ease.</p>
<p>Methods of sterilisation can be divided into:</p>
<ol>
<li>Physical</li>
<li>Chemical</li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 4.1 is a summary of sterilisation methods.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Sterilisation 547</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0ecb71e9.jpeg" alt="img-13.jpeg">
Fig. 4.1 Summary of sterilisation methods</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-methods-of-sterilisation">PHYSICAL METHODS OF STERILISATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-methods-of-sterilisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="heat">HEAT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Heat is the most rapid, and best method of sterilisation. It is the method of choice if the material to be sterilised is stable enough to withstand the required temperature necessary to kill the microbes. The time needed for sterilisation depends on the initial number of organisms present (hence washed and clean items are easier to sterilise than dirty ones) and also on the temperature used. Higher the temperature, shorter the time needed. Heat kills bacteria by coagulation of their proteins. Different types of bacteria show differences in heat susceptibility. Spores need high temperatures while vegetative bacteria can be destroyed at lower temperatures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="dry-heat">Dry Heat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dry-heat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is the preferred method for sterilising glasswares, e.g., glass syringes and materials such as oils and powder which cannot be penetrated by water or steam. Dry heat is applied in the following ways:</p>
<ol>
<li>Flaming The articles are passed through the Bunsen flame. The articles need not become red hot. It is used for scalpels, mouths of culture tubes, glass slides and points of forceps. It is of limited immediate use as only the surfaces touched by the flame are sterilised.</li>
<li>Red heat Inoculating wire loops and needles are heated in the Bunsen flame until red hot. This is also of limited immediate use.</li>
<li>Incineration Micro-organisms exposed to open flames are burnt and killed. This is ideal for the carcasses of infected animals.</li>
<li>Hot air oven This is an oven that has a double walled chamber with a stout door, and it is electrically heated and thermostatically controlled. The oven contains a built in ventilator which disperses volatile matter during sterilisation. A built-in fan inside helps circulate air in the oven so that the materials are evenly heated. Sterilisation times of</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>548 Bacteriology</p>
<p>three hours at 140 °C, one hour at 160 °C and 30 minutes at 180 °C are commonly employed. The hot air oven is ideal for all dry glassware, non-absorbent cotton wool, paraffin oil, and powder.</p>
<p>It is not useful for culture media, liquids, rubber connections, glass to metal fitting and fabrics, e.g., masks, towels, or gowns.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="moist-heat">Moist Heat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#moist-heat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Water at 60–65°C At 60–65°C, water will kill most vegetative organisms. It does not fully sterilise but drastically reduces the number of pathogenic bacteria. This low temperature of water is useful mainly in the pasteurisation of milk and in the preparation of some heat killed bacterial vaccines. It is also employed as one of the wash cycles in laundry and dish-washing machines.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water at 100°C (Boiling) Boiling water at 100°C is frequently used in an emergency in the wards, to sterilise syringes, scissors and forceps. Most vegetative bacteria will die in 5–10 minutes when immersed in boiling water, but some spores will survive at this temperature for several hours. The addition of sodium carbonate enhances the sterilising power of water and helps to prevent rusting. Articles sterilised by this method cannot be stored for a long time. It should be remembered that the boiling point of water at a high attitude may be far below 100°C and so boiling must be undertaken for longer time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Steam sterilisation Steam sterilisation is the most effective technique of moist heat sterilisation and it can be applied in three ways.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) Steam at 100°C Steam at 100°C is usually achieved in the Koch steamer which is a vertical metal cylinder with a conical lid. It is fitted with a thermometer and has a small opening for the steam to escape. Atmospheric steam at 100°C is used for the disinfection of some large items of equipments such as animal cages, and in dairy industry for the disinfection of milk chums. Properly carried out, it should kill all vegetative organisms but not the spores.</p>
<p>Steam at 100°C is also employed to sterilise carbohydrate media. The procedure employed is called Tyndallisation after Dr. John Tyndell who devised the method. The materials are exposed in their final containers to free steam at 100°C for 30 minutes on each of three successive days. After steaming, the materials are left at room temperature until the following day when the process is repeated until three successive steamings have been done.</p>
<p>The principle is that all vegetative bacteria are killed by the first steaming. After 24 hours at room temperature, the surviving spores will have started to grow into heat sensitive vegetative forms. These will be killed by the second exposure. The third and final steaming is to ensure a total elimination of any remaining spores that may have germinated.</p>
<p>(b) Low temperature steam at 80°C Water will boil at less than 100°C if the atmospheric pressure is reduced. Steam at 80°C is used to sterilise such articles that cannot withstand the normal heat sterilisation procedures. Such articles include blankets, mattresses and certain surgical instruments. Special autoclave operating at reduced pressure is used to achieve this. To enhance sterilisation, formalin vapour is introduced into the autoclave during the processing cycle.</p>
<p>(c) High temperature steam (steam under pressure, autoclave) This is steam above 100°C and it is the most efficient means of sterilisation. It is routinely used for most heat-stable materials. An autoclave is used to achieve the high temperature steam. The boiling point of water is raised by increasing the pressure inside the autoclave. There are different designs of autoclaves in the market. But basically the autoclave is a double-walled or jacketed chamber that can withstand the high pressures required (Fig. 4.2). The autoclave has a steam inlet valve and a steam outlet valve. In addition, it is usually equipped with a safety valve (set to open at a pre-determined pressure), a temperature gauge and pressure gauge. The usual sterilisation temperature is 121°C at 15 lbs per square inch (psi) pressure for 15 minutes. Greater the pressure, higher the temperature and shorter the time of sterilisation. The cycle however</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Sterilisation 549</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8f0c474c.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg">
Fig. 4.2 Laboratory autoclave</p>
<p>depends on the volume of material to be sterilised and the amount of contamination expected. It is recommended that large volumes of material such as culture media or surgical dressings, be dispensed into small volumes or portions to reduce the time required for sterilisation and so decrease the chance of over cooking or damaging the material. Although autoclaving is a highly recommended method of sterilisation, its major drawbacks are that it may cause damage to heat-sensitive materials, and the load is not dried.</p>
<p>The domestic pressure cooker is the simplest form of autoclave. The steam displacement autoclaves which used to be the commonest type, are</p>
<p>becoming obsolete. A mastery of the operation of all types of autoclaves is essential to avoid major accidents due to explosion and to prevent over heating of the material.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="operating-an-autoclave">Operating an autoclave<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#operating-an-autoclave" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The load is loosely placed in the chamber and the door or lid securely shut. Both the inlet and outlet valves are open. Steam is introduced into the chamber to force air out from it, leaving only pure steam. (A rubber tubing attached to the outlet valve with the end dipped in a bucket of water will stop bubbling when all the air has been forced out). Close</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>550 Bacteriology</p>
<p>the outlet valve, the temperature and pressure will begin to rise. When the desired temperature and pressure are reached, close the inlet valve. Start to time the sterilisation cycle to the desired length of time. This period of actual sterilisation is known as the ‘holding time’. At the end of sterilisation, open the outlet valve slowly to avoid boiling over of liquid media. The steam begins to escape and at the same time the temperature and pressure begins to fall. Never open the autoclave until the pressure is completely down in order to avoid explosion.</p>
<p>The high vacuum autoclaves are fast and reliable. Before the admission of steam, 98 per cent of the air present in the chamber is rapidly removed by electric pump and sterilisation can proceed without delay. The cycle is short and heat penetration is efficient. Most of the newest models of autoclaves are fully automatic. The operator simply loads the autoclave, presses the start buttons and the autoclave is left unattended to till the cycle is completed.</p>
<p>Table 4.1 shows the relationship between time of autoclaving, pressure and temperature.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="testing-the-efficiency-of-the-autoclave">Testing the efficiency of the autoclave<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testing-the-efficiency-of-the-autoclave" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several methods of testing whether or not material is adequately sterilised. The four commonest methods are:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Brown’s steriliser control tubes These are tubes containing an indicator liquid and designed for steamer, hot air oven and autoclave. The liquid will change from red to green if the correct temperature time combination has been employed; if not, the liquid turns a reddish-brown colour. The tubes are placed in the area of least heat penetration.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Biological indicator Filter paper strips impregnated with a sporing organism such as <em>Bacillus stearothermophilus</em>, is enclosed in an envelope and placed at the centre of the load to be sterilised. On removal, the strip is cultured in a suitable medium and incubated at 55°C for one week. No growth indicates proper sterilisation. This method is good when time factor is not important because the organism requires long incubation to grow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Autoclave tapes There are many tapes based on the Bowie-Dick autoclave tape principle of uniform colour change. The tape indicates the degree of heat penetration. The tapes have a water resistant gummed side. When sterilisation is adequate and complete, the tape changes colour uniformly. While the Bowie-Dick tape does not test for adequate exposure to heat in terms of time and temperature, strips of tapes may be useful on individual packages as indicators of exposure to heat.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 4.1 Pressure, holding time and temperature for autoclaving</p>

<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Sterilisation 551</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Thermocouples The efficiency of an autoclave is best monitored by means of thermocouples which are placed within the contents and calibrated to show the temperature attained.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sterilisation-failure-in-the-autoclave">Sterilisation failure in the autoclave<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sterilisation-failure-in-the-autoclave" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sterilisation failures may be due to:</p>
<ol>
<li>Incomplete removal of air from the autoclave. Temperature of air/steam mixtures at a given pressure is lower than that of pure steam (Table 4.1).</li>
<li>Incorrect methods of packaging.</li>
<li>Careless loading into steriliser.</li>
<li>Failure to time correctly, the proper period of exposure (holding time).</li>
<li>Attempts to sterilise materials impervious to steam in an autoclave, e.g., oils.</li>
<li>Faulty equipment.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Inspissation</strong> This is the method of coagulating and further sterilising culture media that were initially prepared aseptically. The media should contain a coagulable protein such as serum or egg. It is ideal therefore for Loeffler’s medium or Lowestein Jensen’s medium. The inspissator is a double walled copper box with water flowing between the two walls. The inside is made in such a way that culture media bottles lie slopped. The temperature is controlled between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>75</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>80</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75^{\circ} - 80^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7574em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> thermostatically. Inspissation is carried out for two hours on each of three consecutive days. A higher temperature may denature the protein and cause bubbling of the surface of the media.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="radiation">RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Radiation used for sterilising purposes falls into two groups:</p>
<ol>
<li>Non-ionising radiation</li>
<li>Ionising radiation</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-ionising-radiation">Non-ionising Radiation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-ionising-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Non-ionising radiation is provided by ultra-violet and infra-red rays.</p>
<p><strong>Infra-red radiation</strong> They are of low energy type and are electromagnetic rays with wavelengths longer than those of visible light. It kills micro-organisms by oxidation as a result of heat generated. It is in fact a form of hot-air sterilisation. It is ideal for sterilising a large number of articles such as syringes in a comparatively short time. The articles are packaged in metal containers and passed through an insulated chamber and then exposed to infra red radiation where they are sterilised at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>190</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">190^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">19</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> for 10 minutes.</p>
<p><strong>Sterilisation control</strong> A type of Browne’s control tube is used to control the sterilisation. It changes from red to green after 12 minutes at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>180</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">180^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p><strong>Ultraviolet light</strong> Electromagnetic radiation with wavelength between 100 and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>400</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">400\mathrm{nm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">nm</span></span></span></span></span></span> is called ultraviolet (UV) light. The rays of wavelength between 240 and 280 are absorbed by nucleic acids. This energy absorption induces chemical changes that alter the structure of the DNA and leads to the death of the cell.</p>
<p>Most UV radiation does not readily penetrate glass, opaque solids or liquids. It is generally used to sterilise surfaces in work areas such as media pouring room and safety cabinets, or air in surgical rooms. Gram negative bacteria are more susceptible to UV radiation than Gram positive ones. Spores are highly resistant. Low pressure mercury vapour lamp can be used to produce UV light in the laboratory. The rays should not be allowed to come in contact with the eyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ionising-radiation">Ionising Radiation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ionising-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ionising radiation, unlike the UV radiation, penetrates non-living and living organisms readily. Sterilisation is achieved without appreciable rise in temperature. Therefore, it is also referred to as ‘cold sterilisation’. It is used to sterilise heat-sensitive medical supplies such as plastic syringes, drugs and a wide range of disposable items. Cathode rays and gamma rays (from cobalt 60) are the most effective ionising radiation. It is expensive and very dangerous.</p>
<p><strong>Sterility control</strong> Spores of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> are recommended for use for sterilisation control of ionising radiation.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>552 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="filtration">FILTRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Filtration as a physical means of sterilisation is effective and reasonably economical. It is used to sterilise heat-sensitive fluids, and air. It is particularly useful for solutions containing toxins, enzymes, drug, serum and sugars. Sugar solutions used for the cultivation of micro-organisms tend to caramalise during autoclaving and so they are best filter-sterilised. Filtration is also used extensively in beer and wine industries. Filter with known pore sizes sufficiently small to hold back bacteria are employed. Recently filters that can remove viruses as well are available.</p>
<p>Several types of materials have been found useful in microbial filters such as diatomaceous earth (in Berkefeld and Mandler filters), porcelain (in Chamberland filters), Sintered glass, asbestos (in Seitz and Hemmings filter) and cellulose ester (in membrane filters).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-candle-type-filters">1. Candle-type Filters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-candle-type-filters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="berkefeld-and-mandler-filters">Berkefeld and Mandler filters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#berkefeld-and-mandler-filters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These filters are made from diatomaceous earth and are also referred to as ‘candle’ filters because of their shapes. They are very ideal for domestic drinking water. Three grades are available V = Coarse; N = Normal and W = Fine.</p>
<p>These filters are made in the form of hollow candles open at one end. A metal nozzle is inserted and cemented in the open end. After use, they are autoclaved, then washed thoroughly with soap and water with a test tube brush. Pass 2% sodium hydroxide solution through the filter in the opposite direction to that which it was used. Follow up with N/1 HCl until the filtrate has a pH of 7.4. Rinse thoroughly with distilled water. Dry and wrap in a suitable wrapper, then sterilise in the autoclave. It is now ready for use again.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-porcelain-filters">2. Porcelain Filters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-porcelain-filters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common ones are:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="chamberland-doulton-filters">Chamberland Doulton filters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chamberland-doulton-filters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>They are made of unglazed porcelain. They are available in various grades: L1a = Coarse, L1a, L2 and L3 = medium; and L5 to L15 = very fine. They are shaped in the form of candles too and cleaned in the same way as described for Berkefeld and Mandler filters.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-sintered-glass-filter">3. Sintered Glass Filter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-sintered-glass-filter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is made of finely ground glass which is fused at the bottom and shaped like a funnel. It can withstand the high temperature of the hot air oven. It is also available in various grades of porosity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-seitz-filter">4. Seitz Filter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-seitz-filter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a satisfactory general purpose asbestos disk known as Seitz filter. It consists of an asbestos disk or pad, supported, rough side uppermost in a metal mount (Fig. 4.3).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="seitz-filter-set-up">Seitz filter set up<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#seitz-filter-set-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The filter is attached to a vacuum flask through a silicone rubber bung (the silicone rubber withstands repeated autoclaving). The side arm of the flask is plugged with non-absorbent cotton wool. The filter unit is wrapped with an appropriate wrapper and then sterilised at 121°C for 20 minutes. Filtration is carried out usually under negative pressure, the fluid being sucked through the filter into the receiving flask.</p>
<p>After use, sterilise if necessary, discard the asbestos pad, clean the metal mount, insert a fresh pad and sterilise by autoclaving. The asbestos disks are supplied in varying grades, e.g.,</p>
<p>HP/PYR = Removal of pyrogens
HP/EKS2 = Removal of minute organisms from heavily contaminated fluid
HP/EKS = For absolute sterility using controlled standard conditions
HP/EK = For sterility down to <em>Serratia marcescens/Chromobacterium prodigiosum</em></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-hemmings-filter">5. Hemmings Filter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-hemmings-filter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a small asbestos pad between two bijou bottles. The liquid in one bottle will be forced through</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Sterilisation 553</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-4ed49e06.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg">
Fig. 4.3 Seitz filter assembly</p>
<p>the pad during centrifugation into the other bottle. It is used for small volumes of fluids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-membrane-filters">6. Membrane Filters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-membrane-filters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are made of cellulose esters (cellulose nitrate or cellulose acetate) supported in a matrix of regenerated cellulose. They have more or less replaced other types of filters due to their versatility. Their advantages over other filters include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Ease of handling—they are relatively tough when wet.</li>
<li>Charged molecules are not taken out of solution like in other types.</li>
<li>They are fairly cheap to be used once only.</li>
<li>They have accurate grading of pore sizes over a wide range.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The membrane filter can also be used for bacterial count, for example, in water.</p>
<p>ter: A known volume of water is passed through a membrane filter. The filter is then removed and placed on an appropriate solid culture medium and incubated. The colonies which appear are counted to determine the number of viable bacteria in the sample of water. If these membrane filters are treated with immersion oil, they become transparent and so they can be stained for direct microscopy on the bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-air-filter">7. Air Filter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-air-filter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Air filtration is used in the laboratory to render safe the air withdrawn from an exhaust-ventilated safely cabinet. The air is freed from infection by passing it through High Efficiency Particle Arrester (HEPA) filter. This is also used in laminar flow cabinets employed for some microbiological work.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemical-sterilisation-disinfectants-and-antiseptics">CHEMICAL STERILISATION (DISINFECTANTS AND ANTISEPTICS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-sterilisation-disinfectants-and-antiseptics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Various disinfectants and antiseptics are used for chemical sterilisation. They are divided into a number of chemical groups for specific purposes. All chemical agents of disinfection take time to act. The rate of disinfection is approximately logarithmic, with a plot of the logarithm of the number of survivors against unit time giving straight line over most of the curve. This means that a constant proportion of surviving bacteria are killed per unit of time. The actual rate of kill varies due to certain factors, e.g., the nature of the disinfectant and concentration used. Environmental conditions also affect the efficiency of the chemical disinfectants, e.g., the presence of organic matter, the pH of solution and the possible inactivation of chemical compounds such as soap.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-action-of-chemical-agents">Mode of Action of Chemical Agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-action-of-chemical-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chemical agents act on microorganisms in the following ways:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>554 Bacteriology</p>
<ol>
<li>Interfering with the enzymatic system of the organism.</li>
<li>Coagulation of proteins.</li>
<li>Disruption of cell membrane.</li>
<li>Oxidative damage.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="70b554db">♦ MAJOR GROUPS OF DISINFECTANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#70b554db" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many different compounds are used as disinfectants, the major groups are:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="alcohols">Alcohols<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alcohols" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Alcohols act by denaturing proteins. Absolute alcohol is not a very effective disinfecting agent due to its poor penetrating power. When diluted with water to a concentration of 70 %, it has optimum activity as a skin antiseptic and it is commonly used prior to injection or venepuncture. It is used as an antiseptic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="aldehydes">Aldehydes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aldehydes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Formaldehyde Formaldehyde is supplied as 40% solution and known as formalin. It is highly bactericidal and active against spores. It is used in liquid form or in gaseous form when humidity must be around 50 %. Its extreme irritating and toxic property is the major disadvantage. It is useful for disinfecting rooms, safety cabinets (fumigation) and sometimes for aspirators and other anaesthetic equipments.</p>
<p>(b) Glutaraldehyde This is used as a 2% buffered solution (Cidex) and it is highly effective against all bacteria, tubercle bacilli and spores. It is much less irritant than formaldehyde but it is expensive. It has a low penetrating power but useful for items that cannot withstand heat such as endoscopes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="phenolic-compounds">Phenolic Compounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phenolic-compounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Phenol or carbolic acid is the oldest known disinfectant. Although, the original chemical is no longer used, some of the compounds derived from it constitute the phenolic substitutes. It is used usually at a concentration of 2–3 %. Phenolics are also effective against spores. Their unpleasant odour and tissue irritation preclude their use on the skin. Phenolics such as ‘Sudol’, ‘Hycolin’, and ‘Iral’ are however, widely used as good antiseptics when diluted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="chlorxylenols">Chlorxylenols<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chlorxylenols" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The best known of this group of disinfectants is dettol. They differ from other phenolic compounds by being non-irritating, and can be applied to skin and tissues. They are very active against Gram negative and Gram positive bacteria but not against tubercule bacilli and spores. They are moderately inhibited by organic matter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="salts-of-heavy-metals">Salts of Heavy Metals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salts-of-heavy-metals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Salts of heavy metals, e.g., mercuric chloride, are required in high concentrations to achieve any significant activity. They are slow acting and are mostly bacteriostatic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="chlorhexidine-hibitane">Chlorhexidine (Hibitane)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chlorhexidine-hibitane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a widely used skin disinfectant in alcoholic solution. It is very active against a wide range of organisms, but aqueous solutions are much less effective due to poor activity against spores, tubercule bacilli, and some Gram negative bacteria such as Alcaligenes, Flavobacteria and some Pseudomonas. It is usually used as hand cream in the laboratory after washing hands with soap and water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="halogens">Halogens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#halogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Hypochlorites These include such popular antiseptics as milton, chloros and domestics. They are derivatives of chlorine which is liberated from the solution during their action. As disinfectants, hypochlorites are bactericidal against vegetative bacteria, spores and viruses, but less active against</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Sterilisation 555</p>
<p>tubercule bacilli. They are relatively inactivated by organic matter.</p>
<p>(b) Iodophores These consist of iodine detergent complexes and include such well known brands as Wescodine, Betadine and Pevidine. They are much less irritant to the skin than free iodine and do not stain. They are used for cleaning wounds and as a general purpose laboratory disinfectant for discard jars.</p>
<p>(c) Iodine As alcoholic tincture of iodine, it is highly active against Gram positive organisms and so is used as a skin antiseptic. It stains the skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quaternary-ammonium-compounds">Quaternary Ammonium Compounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quaternary-ammonium-compounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include agents such as cetrimide, bromide and benzalkonium chloride. They have antibacterial and detergent properties and are active against Gram positive bacteria and slightly active against tubercule bacilli and spores. This antibacterial activity is antagonised by soaps and certain organisms, e.g., <em>Pseudomonas</em>. They are very useful in catering industry for washing cutlery, and in hospitals for cleaning wounds. Savlon, a popular antiseptic, is a mixture of cetrimide and chlorhexidine and is active against Gram negative bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gaseous-sterilisation">GASEOUS STERILISATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gaseous-sterilisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gaseous disinfectants (alkylating agents) are used for the sterilisation or disinfection of items of hospital equipment that is bulky or heat-labile. The most widely used gases are ethylene oxide and formaldehyde.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ethylene-oxide">Ethylene Oxide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ethylene-oxide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ethylene oxide has a boiling point of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10.8</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10.8^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>, so it is a gas at room temperature. It is highly inflammable and explosive in pure form, but is safe to handle when mixed with carbon dioxide. It is effective in the killing of all bacteria, including tubercle bacilli and spores.
