To be effective, however, the humidity and temperature must be carefully controlled within narrow limits. It is highly toxic on contact with the skin or mucous membrane. Materials that have been sterilised with ethylene oxide must be set aside in detoxification chambers for a few days to allow the gases to dissipate. It is frequently used to sterilise heart lung machines and plastic items, e.g., catheters.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formaldehyde">Formaldehyde<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formaldehyde" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is highly bactericidal. As gas, it is used as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> formalin with humidity at around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span>. It is highly irritant. It is used occasionally to fumigate rooms and disinfect respirators.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-evaluation-of-disinfectants">LABORATORY EVALUATION OF DISINFECTANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-evaluation-of-disinfectants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aim of evaluation of a disinfectant is to define the capabilities of the disinfectant and to determine reasonable and practicable concentrations for routine use. There are many factors that influence bactericidal activity, and so, conditions of testing must simulate practical usage conditions. A suspension test, the 'Rideal Walker' or the 'Phenol Coefficient test,' is an old method but hardly related to conditions obtainable in the laboratories. For this reason, it is not very satisfactory.</p>
<p>Other tests such as, 'In-Use Test' and 'Capacity Test' are quite satisfactory. All quantitative tests for bactericidal activity involve the serious technical difficulty of enumerating the few surviving organisms as disinfection proceeds.</p>
<p>The In-Use Test, which is simple and easy to perform, is outlined below:</p>
<p>In-Use test method This is the Kelsey Maurer's method.</p>
<p>Stage 1 1 ml disinfectant solution in use is taken from the jar with a sterile pipette.</p>
<p>Stage 2 The 1 ml sample is added to 9 ml diluent in a sterile universal container. The diluent should be selected according to the group to which the disinfectant belongs. This in effect means that the action of the disinfectant should be stopped using the</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>556 Bacteriology</p>
<p>appropriate inactivator. For general purposes, use 0.5 % 'Tween 80'</p>
<p>Stage 3 The bottle of diluted disinfectant is transported to the laboratory within an hour of the addition of the disinfectant. A separate sterile Pasteur pipette is used to withdraw a small quantity of the disinfectant/diluent/mixture and to place 10 drops, separately, on the surface of each of two well-dried nutrient agar plates. A 50 dropper pipette may be used in place of graduated pipette.</p>
<p>Stage 4 The two plates are incubated:</p>
<p>(a) One plate is incubated for three days at 32 or 37°C, whichever is more convenient. (The optimum temperature for most pathogenic bacteria is 37°C but those which have been damaged by disinfectants often recover more readily at 32°C.)</p>
<p>(b) The second plate is incubated for seven days at room temperature.</p>
<p>Stage 5 After incubation the plates are examined and bacterial growth is recorded.</p>
<p>In-Use test result The presence of bacterial colonies on one or both of a pair of plates is evidence of the survival of bacteria in the particular jar, from which the sample was taken. One or two colonies on the plate may be ignored. A disinfectant is not a sterilant. The presence of a few live bacteria is to be expected. The growth of five or more colonies should arouse suspicion and may be indicative of poor bactericidal activity.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nutrition-growth-and-metabolism-of-bacteria">Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutrition-growth-and-metabolism-of-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The major biological function of the microbial cells is growth. Growth is the orderly increase in mass and number of all the components of the cell. All living organisms require nutrients for their growth as well as for cellular maintenance and multiplication. The nutrients provide the energy required by the microbial cell to synthesise new cellular components and reproduce.</p>
<p>Bacterial cell consists chiefly of proteins, chromosomes, enzymes, membranes, cell wall and flagella. These components are made up of large (macro) molecules. The main function of the bacterial metabolism is the synthesis of macromolecules. These macromolecules are derived from their respective subunits: proteins from amino acid; nucleic acids from nucleotides; polysaccharides from simple sugars and lipids from glycerol, alcohols and fatty acids.</p>
<p>Bacteria differ greatly in their needs of nutrients. Basically, they obtain their nutrients from their environment. Bacteria (and fungi) are called osmotrophs because they obtain their food in solutions that diffuse through their plasma membranes. They cannot however, transport macromolecules such as proteins or polysaccharides through their membranes. These macromolecules are therefore first digested outside the cell by exoenzymes that are excreted by the cell to the external environment. For example, enzyme proteases will degrade protein into amino acids which are then absorbed (Fig. 5.1 a, b, c). The absorbed nutrients are metabolised to product energy-rich compounds, e.g., adenosine</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-866a114a.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 5.1 Function of exoenzymes in nutrient digestion</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>558 Bacteriology</p>
<p>tri-phosphate (ATP); and are then chemically converted to meet the specific nutritional requirements of the bacterium. The construction of the cellular components requires the ATP as the source of energy. Figure 5.2 shows the relationship between nutrient intake and metabolic activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutritional-requirements-of-bacteria">NUTRITIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF BACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutritional-requirements-of-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nutritional requirements of bacteria are often satisfied in different ways. Some bacteria are capable of synthesising their food from simple elements within their environment. Others, including most pathogenic bacteria, are not able to do this. They therefore depend on a free supply of ready made or organic compounds for their growth and metabolic activity. The essential nutritional requirements of bacteria include:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Water All metabolic functions of a bacterial cell are performed in aqueous environments. Bacterial cultivation and growth requires water, and any loss of water from the cell disrupts cellular functions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Energy source Bacterial cellular functions such as synthesis of new components, concentration of nutrients in the cell, or cell mobility require energy. Some bacteria obtain this energy from sunlight or from the oxidation of chemical compounds. The energy is converted into energy-rich compounds such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Those bacteria that obtain their energy from sunlight are called phototrophs, while those that obtain it from the oxidisation of chemicals are called chemotrophs. The phototrophic bacteria are divided into cyanobacteria and photosynthetic bacteria; the former are able to produce O₂ as a by product of photosynthesis.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Chemotrophic bacteria get their energy from the oxidation of organic and inorganic compounds such as glucose. These oxidations may be by fermentation or respiration.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Carbon requirements Carbon (C) atoms are essential in the nutritional requirements of bacteria since they take part in cellular metabolism. They</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c599ec70.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg">
Fig. 5.2 Nutrient intake and metabolic activities</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 559</p>
<p>participate in the biodegrading (catabolic) activities which result in the production of ATP, and the biosynthetic (anabolic) activities that result in the synthesis of cellular components.</p>
<p>Some bacteria derive their requirement of carbon from carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. These organisms are called autotrophs. They are mainly free-living bacteria. Those bacteria that depend on freely supplied organic molecules for their source of carbon are called heterotrophs. These bacteria are parasitic and have evolved to adapt to an environment. Most human pathogenic bacteria belong to this group. Autotrophs that obtain their energy from sunlight are called photoautotrophs. Those that obtain energy from the oxidation of chemical compounds are called chemoautotrophs. When phototrophs use organic compounds as their source of carbon, they are called photoheterotrophs; whereas chemoheterotrophs oxidise chemical compounds to derive their energy and require organic carbon.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Nitrogen requirements Nitrogen is necessary for the synthesis of essential amino sugars, nucleotides and vitamins. Micro-organisms are able to utilise the various nitrogenous compounds which are present in the structural components of the cell, to satisfy their needs. Some use macromolecules such as proteins or polypeptides to obtain their nitrogen. The macromolecules are first digested to aminoacids which are then chemically classified to other nitrogen-containing molecules. Most bacteria however satisfy their nitrogen requirements from inorganic salts of nitrate or ammonium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Growth factor requirements Some bacteria are not able to synthesise certain organic compounds which they require for growth. These organic compounds which cannot be synthesised by the cells are supplied from exogenous sources and are called growth factors. The growth factors include:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Amino acids Bacteria possess enzymes that degrade proteins (proteinases) to amino acids. They form an intra cellular pool from which the required aminoacids are withdrawn.</p>
<p>(ii) Puriness and pyrimidines: These are trace elements which are converted into nucleotides and nucleosides in the bacteria before their incorporation into DNA and RNA.</p>
<p>(iii) Bacterial vitamins: These vitamins cannot be synthesised by many pathogenic bacteria. They are required for the production of co-enzymes.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>Oxygen requirements Oxygen is a part of the amino acids, nucleotides and other molecules. It is generally taken into the cell as part of nutrients, e.g., proteins and lipids. In the form of molecular oxygen (O₂), it is required by most bacteria to generate energy for respiration.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Trace elements These are the several minerals required by bacteria for their enzyme activity. These minerals include potassium (K), cobalt (Co), magnesium (Mg), manganese (Mn), calcium (Ca) and iron (Fe). For example, iron is an essential component of cytochrome oxidase, catalase (enzyme that degrades hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂)). Because these minerals are required in very small amounts, they are referred as trace elements.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microbial-populations-and-cellular-growth">MICROBIAL POPULATIONS AND CELLULAR GROWTH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microbial-populations-and-cellular-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Living organisms are characterised by their ability to grow and reproduce in their environment. Bacteria grow by increasing their size (volume), an important process that results in cell division and so increase in number. To appreciate how bacteria perform their various functions including disease formation, it is necessary to know how they grow and multiply. Population growth is the increase in the number of cells in a population. Cellular growth is the increase in size of the bacterial cell. The rate of growth is largely dependent on the environment and factors such as heat, moisture and nutrient supply.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>560 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="counting-the-number-of-cells">COUNTING THE NUMBER OF CELLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#counting-the-number-of-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two ways of measuring the increase in the number of individual cells in a microbial population. They are (i) the direct microscopic count and (ii) the viable count.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-microscopic-count">Direct Microscopic Count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-microscopic-count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-using-the-petroff-haussen-counting-chamber">(a) Using the Petroff-Haussen counting chamber<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-using-the-petroff-haussen-counting-chamber" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This counting chamber consists of a platform with a grid (Fig. 5.3 a, b). The bacterial suspension is placed between the coverslip and the platform.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-263d7d27.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg"></p>
<p>The suspension is drawn into the chamber by capillary action and the bacteria distributed throughout the ruled area. The bacteria are counted using a compound microscope. The central area of the counting chamber consists of 25 large squares. The bacteria in all the squares are counted and the number multiplied by 50,000 to give the number of bacteria per ml of suspension.</p>
<p>This method counts both dead and living bacteria (total count). Ideally, the sample should be diluted so that one square contains only about 10 organisms. The bacteria may be stained before counting. Electronic counters such as Coulter counter (Fig. 5.4) used for blood cell counts can be adapted to count bacterial cells. As each bacterial cell passes through the slit in the Coulter counter, it causes changes in the conductivity. These changes are recorded and tallied automatically. The results are displayed on a screen and are accurate and reproducible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viable-counts">Viable Counts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viable-counts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Viable counts are based on the assumption that each cell can multiply repeatedly to eventually form a distinct colony on a solid medium. The two common methods used are the spread plate count (SPC) and the pour plate method.</p>
<p>Viable counts are usually performed by dispersing a known volume of bacterial suspension on a solid medium in a petri dish (Fig. 5.5a). The plate is then incubated at the appropriate temperature for a specified length of time. The sample should be diluted if suspected to contain too many bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-spread-plate-method">The spread plate method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-spread-plate-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Using a sterile spreader (a bent glass rod), spread 0.1–0.5 ml of diluted bacterial suspension over the surface of dry solid medium (Fig. 5.5a). Incubate plate upside down. Count colonies that appear on the agar surface and estimate the number of bacteria per ml.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-pour-plate-method">The pour plate method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pour-plate-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Mix a known volume (0.1–1.0 ml) of diluted suspension in 15–20 ml of cooled molten agar medium and pour into a petri dish. Rotate the plate to mix well. Allow to set and</p>
<p>Fig. 5.3 Petroff-Hausser counting chamber</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 561</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-28bd2405.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg">
Fig. 5.4 Coulter counter (Diagrammatic)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Spread plate method
<img src="assets/images/image-20251219-2cc1e8c1.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg">
Place 0.1 ml of diluted sample onto the surface of a nutrient agar plate
Spread evenly over the surface of agar with a glass spreader
After incubation, colonies appear on the surface of the nutrient agar. Viable count = No. of colonies X dilution</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pour plate method
<img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3da1e106.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg">
Place 0.1 ml of diluted sample into sterile Petri dish
Pour melted and cooled nutrient agar, mix well with the sample and allow to set
After incubation, colonies appear both on the surface and within the agar. Viable count = Total No. of colonies X dilution</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 5.5 Viable count methods</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>then incubate (Fig. 5.5b). Count colonies that appear throughout the medium. Multiply by the dilution factor to obtain the number of bacteria in the original suspension.</p>
<p>Miles and Mizra method This is also a surface count that is equally accurate.</p>
<ol>
<li>Dry nutrient agar in the incubator on the tilt for two hours. This prevents a drop of fluid from 'running' over the surface of the plate.</li>
<li>With a marker, divide the plate into eight segments, labelling them <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{-2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> etc.</li>
<li>With a 50-drop pipette, add 45 drops of nutrient broth to each of eight sterile <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75 \times 12</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">75</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span></span></span></span></span> mm tubes. With a fresh dropping pipette, add five drops of the bacterial suspension to tube 1. Discard the pipette.</li>
<li>With a fresh pipette, mix several times and add one drop to segment marked <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and five drops to tube 2. Discard the pipette.</li>
<li>With a fresh pipette, repeat the procedure with tube 2, add one drop to segment <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{-2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and five drops to tube 3 and so on.</li>
<li>Leave the plates for 30 minutes to allow the drops to be absorbed into the medium.</li>
<li>Incubate the plates for 18 hours at the appropriate temperature.</li>
<li>Count the segment containing about 20 colonies.</li>
</ol>
<p>Calculations For example, in the segment <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{-4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the count is 21 colonies.</p>
<p>Therefore <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>21</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mtext>no.&nbsp;of&nbsp;colonies&nbsp;in&nbsp;1&nbsp;drop&nbsp;of&nbsp;original&nbsp;suspension&nbsp;(1/50ml)</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">21 \times 10^{4} = \text{no. of colonies in 1 drop of original suspension (1/50ml)}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">21</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">no.&nbsp;of&nbsp;colonies&nbsp;in&nbsp;1&nbsp;drop&nbsp;of&nbsp;original&nbsp;suspension&nbsp;(1/50ml)</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>21</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>=</mo><mtext>no.&nbsp;of&nbsp;colonies/ml</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>500</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">21 \times 10^{4} \times 50 = \text{no. of colonies/ml} = 10,500,000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">21</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">no.&nbsp;of&nbsp;colonies/ml</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span></span></span></span></span> viable organisms/ml</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>To increase accuracy of this test, set up plates in triplicate and take the average count.</p>
<p>Electronic colony counters (Fig. 5.6a) can be used to count the number of colonies on the plate. Insert the plate in the counting platform. The colonies are electronically counted and the total count is displayed automatically. Alternatively, a manual colony counter, such as Quebec counter (Fig. 5.6b) can be used.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f8c37869.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg">
Fig. 5.6 (a) Electronic colony counter</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-1c29c5d0.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg">
Fig. 5.6 (b) Quebec counter</p>
<p>Turbidimetric measurements These are based on the principle that the number of tiny particles (e.g., bacteria) in a suspension is inversely proportional to the amount of light transmitted.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 563</p>
<p>Turbidity of liquid medium is evidence of bacterial growth. It is measured in optical density (OD) units using a photometer. The turbidity of a clear (uninoculated) liquid medium is measured and the photometer adjusted to read 100 % transmittance (T) (Fig. 5.7a). The turbidity of the bacterial culture is measured and the %T recorded (Fig. 5.7b). The %T is inversely proportional to the number of bacteria in the sample. This is used to estimate population size. To obtain the number of bacteria in the culture, the OD values should be converted to bacterial numbers by plotting a calibration curve of OD against viable count. Figure 5.8 shows the OD versus viable count calibration curve.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3cdf067d.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg">
Fig. 5.7 Turbidimetric method of measurement</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8f4efd2e.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg">
Fig. 5.8 Optical density versus viable count calibration curve</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>564 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-bacterial-growth">FACTORS AFFECTING BACTERIAL GROWTH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-bacterial-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The rate of growth of a bacterial population is greatly affected by chemical and physical factors in the environment. Some of these factors include:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Nutrient concentration The concentration of nutrient in a growth medium can affect either the bacterial population growth or the total yield of the culture. When the concentration of nutrients is low, there is not enough nutrients for the bacteria to reproduce at the maximum rate. But when the concentration is high, more of the nutrients are converted to cellular material and so result in the net increase in the number of cells in the culture (maximum yield).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Temperature There is a wide range of temperature within which all bacteria can grow. This range of temperature influences enzymatic activity. Too high a temperature results in the permanent denaturation of bacterial enzymes; and too low a temperature leads to metabolic activity being too slow or stopped entirely. The optimum temperature is that at which an organism grows most profusely. The maximum temperature is the temperature above the upper limit of range; and death usually occurs at this temperature. The minimum temperature is that below the lower limit of range; and death does not necessarily follow. Those bacteria that can grow between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20-50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> are called mesophiles. Those that grow between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>0</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>20</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}-20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> are the psychrophiles. The ones that grow between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>50</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>100</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> are the thermophiles (Fig. 5.9). Most of the pathogenic bacteria are mesophiles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hydrogen ion concentration (pH) The pH refers to the acidity or alkalinity of the solution or medium. A pH below 7 is considered acidic, while a pH above 7 is alkaline or basic. Most bacteria reproduce at a pH range of 6–8. A few organisms can grow at pH higher than 8.0, e.g., <em>Vibrio cholerae</em>, and some at pH lower than 5.0, e.g., fungi. Those that grow in acid pH are called acidophiles, those that grow in alkaline pH are referred to as alkalophiles while those grow between pH4–9 are the neutrophiles (Fig. 5.10).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>When bacteria reproduce, they produce waste products that may change the pH of their environment. Buffers may be included in a medium to minimise the adverse effect of pH changes resulting from bacterial growth.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Gaseous requirements Bacteria differ in their need for molecular oxygen for growth. Based</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-93a1746f.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg">
Fig. 5.9 Temperature growth range of microorganism</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 565</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c8baa859.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg">
Fig. 5.10 Relationship between pH and population growth rate</p>
<p>on these requirements, micro-organisms can be classified into five groups.</p>
<p>(i) Obligatory (strict) aerobes These are the bacteria that require free oxygen for growth. They are usually referred to as aerobes, e.g., <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em>.
(ii) Obligatory (strict) anaerobes These are the micro-organisms that will grow only in the absence of free oxygen. They have oxygen sensitive enzymes, e.g., <em>Clostridium tetani</em>.
(iii) Facultative anaerobes These bacteria can multiply either in the presence or the absence of free oxygen, e.g., <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>.
(iv) Microaerophilic bacteria These are aerobic bacteria that require low oxygen tension (Eh) to grow, e.g., <em>Campylobacter</em> species.
(v) Carboxyphilic (Capnophilic) bacteria: These bacteria require an atmosphere composed of oxygen and raised level of carbon dioxide, e.g., <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>. This organism grows best in an atmosphere enriched with 5–10% carbon dioxide. This atmosphere can be provided using a candle jar.</p>
<p>The candle jar consists of a large jar with a tight-fitting lid, e.g., a one-gallon jar, with a candle in it.</p>
<p>Place the cultures in the jar.</p>
<p>Light the candle.</p>
<p>Close the jar and incubate at the appropriate temperature.</p>
<p>The candle inside the jar burns until there is no more enough oxygen to maintain combustion. The jar thus contains a reduced level of free oxygen and extra carbon dioxide which is estimated to be about 5–10%.</p>
<p>There are incubators specifically designed for CO₂ incubation. CO₂ can also be generated by using the CO₂ generating GasPak kit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle-of-anaerobiasis">Principle of anaerobiasis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-of-anaerobiasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Obligatory anaerobes lack the cytochrome enzymes, catalase and peroxidase which are toxic to the bacteria. In the presence of free O₂ many bacteria produce hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂). However, aerobic bacteria possess the enzyme catalase which catalyses the breakdown of H₂O₂ to water:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⟶</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2 \longrightarrow 2 \mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O} + \mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Because anaerobes lack catalase, they are destroyed by the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. And since <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is not produced in the absence of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the anaerobes are able to grow in an atmosphere devoid of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. The growth is dependent on the oxidation reduction (redox) potential of the environment. To determine this, immerse an electrode in the solution and measure the electrical potential set up between the electrode and the solution. The potential is known as Eh and is expressed in millivolts. The level of Eh depends on how much oxidation is taking place. When the Eh is below a certain level, the strict anaerobes are able to grow in the medium. Chemical indicators such as methylene blue can be used as an alternative method to the electrical measurement of Eh. Complete decolourisation of the indicator means low Eh and optimum anaerobiasis for growth.</p>
<p>Anaerobiasis can also be achieved by using anaerobic jar system (Fig. 5.11).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-eb688d9e.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg">
Fig. 5.11 Anaerobic system</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-division">BACTERIAL DIVISION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-division" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacterial growth is the consequence of balanced or orderly increase in size and number of bacteria. This increase is fuelled by energy, usually in the form of ATP derived during metabolic activity. When a newly formed bacterium gradually increases in size to a certain stage, it begins to form a septum by binary fission, which begins the process of dividing into two daughter cells. This process is known as mitosis. The mitotic division is an asexual reproduction.</p>
<p>The mitotic cell division is a form of nuclear division in which the cell's entire set of chromosomes is duplicated and two new sets separate to form two identical daughter cells. The whole process of mitosis is a continuous orderly sequence of steps with each phase merging into the next phase. Figure 5.12 shows mitosis by bacteria. The mitotic division occurs in five steps:</p>
<ol>
<li>Interphase Between mitosis, the cells are said to be in the 'resting' stage. It is also the period that the organism is 'settling' down in the medium.</li>
<li>Prophase At this stage, the chromosomes condense into thread like structures and become visible later on as two chromosomes joined at the centre by a ring of protein called the centromere. At the same time, the centrioles migrate to opposite sides of the cell, and mitotic spindle begins to form between them.</li>
<li>Metaphase Here, the chromosomes appear to be attached by their centromeres to the spindle fibres. They are completely condensed and lined up in the equatorial region of the spindle which now stretches from one pole of the cell to the other. A division of the centromere of each chromosome occurs and makes the two daughter chromosomes in each set become completely separate.</li>
<li>Anaphase The anaphase is a short phase during which the daughter chromosomes move to either side of the cell, using the spindle fibres as guide rails.</li>
<li>Telophase At this stage, the two sets of chromosomes arrive at the two poles of the spindle. Now, there are two daughter cells from a single cell.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 567</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8b9c291d.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg">
Fig. 5.12 Mitosis</p>
<p>gle parent cell, and the daughter cells have the same number and kind of chromosomes and genes as their parent cell. The two cells eventually separate completely.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-growth-cycle">BACTERIAL GROWTH CYCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-growth-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If a single bacterium is transferred into a fresh medium, then by binary fission, the increase in number of bacteria in the medium is as follows: <span class="math math-inline"><span
