<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles of Culture Media 591</p>
<p>(ii) Incomplete mixing
(iii) Use of containers containing traces of alkali
(iv) Over-sterilisation.
(v) Hydrolysis of ingredients.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Precipitation</li>
</ol>
<p>Causes</p>
<p>(i) Non-removal of phosphates.
(ii) Chemical incompatibility of ingredients.
(iii) Prolonged holding of melted agar media at high temperature.</p>
<p>Storage of Culture Media</p>
<p>Dehydrated media and other dry ingredients such as agars, peptone, bile salts and carbohydrates should be kept in a cool dry place at an even temperature and away from direct sunlight. Containers must have tight-fitting caps.</p>
<p>Blood, serum, antimicrobials, urea, carbohydrate solutions and various growth supplements should be stored at 2–6°C. Aliquots of antimicrobial solutions in required amount are stored at –20°C and thawed when needed.</p>
<p>Plates and tubes of culture media should be stored at 2–6°C. Where possible, the plates can be sealed in plastic bags to prevent loss of moisture, especially if in the tropical region. All culture media should be protected from direct sunlight which has a denaturing effect on the media. Media contained in tight-screwed containers (e.g., Robertson’s cooked meat) can be kept at room temperature.</p>
<p>It is most important to clearly label the prepared media and date of preparation recorded. Where colour codes are used, an identification chart should be clearly displayed. Most plate culture media, if properly stored, have a shelf-life of about 7–10 days. Culture media should be checked for signs of contamination or changes in appearance before use. It is important to dry plate culture media before use.</p>
<p>◆ CULTURE METHODS</p>
<p>Methods of culturing bacteria vary and depend on the types of media being inoculated. Whatever medium is used, an aseptic technique must be used for two reasons:</p>
<ol>
<li>To prevent contamination of cultures and specimens in order to avoid interference with the interpretation of culture results.</li>
<li>To prevent contamination of the work area.</li>
</ol>
<p>In order to achieve these two objectives, the laboratory worker should:</p>
<ol>
<li>Flame wire-loops, straight wires and forceps before and after each use.</li>
<li>Flame the necks of specimen bottles, culture tubes, and test tube after removing and replacing caps or plugs.</li>
<li>Not let bottle tops or caps touch an unsterile surface. (Learn the technique of holding the top or cap when inoculating).</li>
<li>Always inoculate culture media before making smears.</li>
<li>Use the safety cabinet when treating hazardous pathogens.</li>
<li>When sterilising a wire loop, hold it in the blue part of the flame with the loop part facing down. This is to ensure quick and proper sterilisation of the wire loop; and prevent sputtering material from falling on the hand.</li>
</ol>
<p>Plate Culture Methods</p>
<p>The petri dish (plate) is universally accepted container for solid culture medium when colonial characteristics of an organism are to be studied. The petri dish is made of either plastic or heat-resistant soda-free glass. It is usually flat-bottomed, shallow, and the common one is usually 90 mm in diameter. The shallowness and its large surface area make it easy for the colonies of the bacteria to be studied macroscopically.</p>
<p>The plastic petri dishes are disposable and therefore cheaper than the glass ones which need to be sterilised before and after use. Reusable petri dishes which are heat-resistant are now being developed from polycarbonate plastics.</p>
<p>Inoculation technique The technique of inoculating media in petri dishes is called ‘plating out’.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>592 Bacteriology</p>
<p>In order to isolate single colonies, the surface of the medium must be 'dried' first. Usually 10 minutes at 45°C is enough with the flat surface of the lid into the incubator shelf, angling the media-containing dish on the edge of the lid, media downward (Fig. 7.1).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-a448ab03.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg">
Fig. 7.1 Method of drying plates</p>
<p>With a sterile wire loop or using the swab of a specimen, apply the inoculum (culture or specimen) to a small area 1 of the plate (Fig. 7.2). Sterilise the loop in the bunsen flame, when cool, streak or thin out the inoculum over area 2. Repeat the same procedure over areas 3,4 and 5. Then incubate medium at the appropriate temperature.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-a237851c.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg">
Fig. 7.2 Inoculation of whole plate</p>
<p>Note</p>
<ol>
<li>When streaking, care must be taken not to cross a previously inoculated area.</li>
<li>The 'streaks' should not touch the sides of the petri dishes so that colonies are not distorted by water of condensation which usually forms during incubation.</li>
</ol>
<p>A simple way of inoculating plates by non-laboratory persons such as clinicians and nurses at bedside, is shown in Fig. 7.3. It is sometimes sufficient to inoculate half-a-plate instead of a whole plate.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-e2e7cac1.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg">
Fig. 7.3 Bedside inoculation technique</p>
<p>The technique of using half-a-plate for inoculation is shown in Fig. 7.4.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3671b2b0.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg">
Fig. 7.4 Inoculation of half plate</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tube-culture-methods">Tube Culture Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tube-culture-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Though many tests devised to differentiate and identify microorganism require solid cultures, it is always necessary to propagate the organisms in culture media prepared in whole petri dishes. Slope cultures, deep cultures and roll tube cultures are prepared in tubes or bottles instead of petri dishes.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles of Culture Media 593</p>
<p>Tube culture media are used for specific identification tests and small volumes of the media are required for the tests. Tube culture media are not used to study colonial morphology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="slope-cultures">Slope Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slope-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Slope (or slant) cultures are tubes or bottles containing a small quantity of medium that has been allowed to set in sloped position. These cultures are generally referred to as 'slopes' or 'slants'. Examples of slopes are the Loeffler's serum agar, Dorset egg medium and Lowestein-Jensen medium. Culture media used for maintenance of isolated bacteria or for performing biochemical tests may also be sloped.</p>
<p>Inoculation Use a sterile straight wire to streak the inoculum down the centre of the slope and then streak the inoculum in a zig-zag manner as shown in Fig. 7.5. Inoculate slope and butt by using a sterile straight wire to stab into the butt first, then use the same wire to streak in zig-zag manner. (Fig. 7.6). If the butt of the slope is to be inoculated use a sterile straight wire to stab into the butt before inoculating the slope as described above.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5ba9de0f.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg">
Fig. 7.5 Inoculation of slope culture</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deep-cultures">Deep Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deep-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Deep culture media are prepared in tubes of about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150\mathrm{mm}\times 20\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> to a depth of about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>70</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 - 70\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>. These cultures which are also known as 'shake' cultures are valuable for the cultivation of</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9fbb510f.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg">
Fig. 7.6 Inoculation of butt and slope</p>
<p>anaerobic bacteria; and may also be used for viable count.</p>
<p>Inoculation The medium is melted and cooled to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>45</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. Using a sterile wire loop or straight wire, the medium is inoculated with the organism, and mixed by rotating between the palms of the hands until it solidifies. Incubate the culture. Anaerobic organisms will grow at the bottom of the tube. For viable count, the medium is melted, cooled, inoculated, mixed and poured into a petri dish before it solidifies. After incubation, a count is made of colonies growing in and on the medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stab-cultures">Stab Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stab-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To stab inoculate medium such as the Kohn's II medium or the motility medium, indole urea medium, inoculate through the centre of medium with a straight wire and withdraw the wire along the line of inoculum(Fig. 7.7).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-54f31ab3.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg">
Fig. 7.7 Stab culture</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>594 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="roll-tubes">Roll Tubes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#roll-tubes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The roll tube technique used to be useful for performing viable count. The method is virtually outdated as there are many other simpler ways of doing viable count. The medium is prepared in 150×15 mm tubes in 1–2 ml volumes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="inoculation">Inoculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The medium is melted, cooled to about 50°C. A known volume of a known dilution of test sample is added. The tube is tilted and rolled between finger and thumb under running cold tap water, so that the medium runs round all the sides of the lower half of the tube. The tube is inverted and incubated. The bacteria will grow on the sides of the tube and the colonies counted with relative ease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="inoculation-of-liquid-media">Inoculation of Liquid Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculation-of-liquid-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Inoculation of nutrient broth and other liquid culture media is carried out with the aid of wire loop, straight wire or Pasteur pipette, depending on whether the inoculum is colonial growth, liquid cultures or specimens. Blood culture media are inoculated with needle and syringes.</p>
<p>To subculture colonies into a liquid medium, pick the colonies with a sterile wire loop, hold the bottle or tube of medium at an angle, and rub the loop against the inner side of the container below the level of the liquid medium.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. All inoculated media must be labelled with the number of the specimen, and date of inoculation.
&gt; 2. Label a slope on the side with the medium so that growth is not obscured.
&gt; 3. Cultures for anaerobic incubation should be marked An or AnO₂, those for carbon dioxide incubation are marked CO₂, and those for aerobic incubation are marked O₂ or Aer.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 8</p>
<p>Principles and Procedures of Diagnostic Bacteriology</p>
<p>Diagnostic bacteriology entails two major functions:</p>
<ol>
<li>The isolation and identification of disease causing agents</li>
<li>The rational choice of antimicrobial drugs based on antimicrobial susceptibility tests.</li>
</ol>
<p>To label a microorganism as the cause of an infection, it should satisfy Koch’s postulates which briefly state that:</p>
<ol>
<li>The organism must be found in every case of the disease.</li>
<li>The organism must not be found in a healthy person.</li>
<li>It must be isolated and grown in pure culture.</li>
<li>Inoculation into an animal should reproduce the disease and the organism should be isolated from the animal.</li>
<li>Infection should produce circulating antibody specific for the infecting organism.</li>
</ol>
<p>In theory, these postulates are quite tenable but in practice it is virtually impossible to satisfy all of them. For example, healthy individuals may be carriers of certain virulent bacteria (e.g., <em>Salmonella typhi</em>); <em>Mycobacterium leprae</em> cannot be grown on artificial medium so a pure culture is out of question; and there are cross reactions between antigenically related bacterial species.</p>
<p>However, the laboratory cannot afford to depend on the lengthy and the academic approach of Koch’s postulates to diagnose a bacterial infection. Tests specifically designed for the diagnosis of infectious diseases must be able to</p>
<ol>
<li>demonstrate an infectious agent in the specimen obtained from the patient.</li>
<li>demonstrate a four-fold rise in antibody titre when an acute and convalescent serum samples are tested.</li>
<li>demonstrate a reasonable cell-mediated response to antigen associated with some infectious agents.</li>
</ol>
<p>The diagnosis of infectious disease by means of laboratory investigations is the primary function of the laboratory. An addition to this function is the capacity to demonstrate immunological responses to the infection.</p>
<p>Against this background, the role of the clinical microbiologist is naturally complex as it entails the characterisation of the thousands of causative agents of infectious diseases. It is this role which is further complicated by the ever expanding and changing microbial data base. The medical microbiologist must therefore be constantly aware of new technologies that may provide more rapid results at less cost.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="communication-between-clinician-and-laboratory">Communication Between Clinician and Laboratory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#communication-between-clinician-and-laboratory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is of great mutual benefit for both the physician and the laboratory to establish an open line of two-</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>596 Bacteriology</p>
<p>way communication. The methods of isolation and identification of pathogenic micro organisms vary greatly and may depend on the signs and symptoms, the anatomical site and the type of organisms being considered-viruses, bacteria, fungi or parasites. Clinical information is therefore of great essence to the microbiologist in the discharge of his duty. The physician should inform the laboratory (on the request form) of his provisional or tentative diagnosis. And since bacteriological investigation may take days or even weeks to complete, the physician may initiate chemotherapy aimed at the organisms being incriminated for the patient's ill health. This information must be available to the microbiologist.</p>
<p>It is equally very important that there is a constant flow of ‘feedback’ information to the physician from the laboratory. The physician should be informed of any useful findings at any stage of investigation so that he may re-evaluate his diagnosis.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5a81b50c.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg">
Fig. 8.1 Diagnostic cycle of information</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles and Procedures of Diagnostic Bacteriology 597</p>
<p>sis and treatment. Figure 8.1 shows a scheme of diagnostic cycle of information between the laboratory and the clinic or the physician. The laboratory must always be ready to help, and issue guidelines with regard to the collection, handling and transportation of specimens as well as the interpretation of laboratory results.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infection-and-safety-in-the-laboratory">INFECTION AND SAFETY IN THE LABORATORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infection-and-safety-in-the-laboratory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Microorganisms are ubiquitous, and infection can occur anywhere! The microbiology laboratory is a very fertile ground for infection of laboratory workers. Infections are usually acquired by inhalation or ingestion of harmful microorganisms.</p>
<p>Microorganisms which are released in the form of aerosols contribute greatly to infection by inhalation. Aerosols are minute, free-floating moisture droplets that may carry particles of pathogenic bacteria. They are created by culturing organisms, especially from fluid specimens or culture; by accidents, e.g., accidental breakage in the centrifuge; or by the dropping of culture. Aerosols however, can be contained by using safety cabinets for certain procedures in the laboratory.</p>
<p>‘Safety’ cabinets are used to carry out procedures which may involve the release of aerosols. They provide for the worker protection from the released aerosols. The safety cabinet is also known as exhaust protective cabinet. Each cabinet is supplied with an approved filter and exhaust chimney (vent).</p>
<p>The incidence of laboratory acquired infection will be much reduced if all members of staff should obey the simple safety rules put in place by the departmental Safety Officer. To minimise infection through the release of aerosols, centrifugation should be done with care, making sure that the buckets are balanced. The procedure should be performed in centrifuges housed in their own safety cabinet; more preferably, it can be done with sealed centrifuge buckets which are opened after centrifugation in a safety protective cabinet.</p>
<p>Mouth pipetting which used to be a major source of ingestion is now banned in the laboratory. Needle prick infection is usually as a result of trying to recap a needle after use. This practice is also banned. Open wounds and scratches, no matter how small, must be covered. All accidents must be reported to the Safety Officer or to the laboratory Chief.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-rules">Safety Rules<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-rules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following simple safety rules are very relevant to the microbiology laboratory and should be observed:</p>
<ol>
<li>Wear gloves and protective clothing when processing clinical specimens or handling cultures.</li>
<li>Do not lay a culture tube on the bench; always put it in the rack.</li>
<li>Process samples or culture which involve the risk of aerosols in the safety cabinet.</li>
<li>Always discard finished cultures into the appropriate discard containers which are sterilised later.</li>
<li>Do not smoke, eat or drink in the laboratory.</li>
<li>Do not lick gummed labels.</li>
<li>Handle all instruments and materials with care.</li>
<li>Always wash hands with soap and water after handling cultures and specimens and before leaving the laboratory.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="common-terms-used-in-the-diagnosis-of-infectious-diseases">COMMON TERMS USED IN THE DIAGNOSIS OF INFECTIOUS DISEASES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-terms-used-in-the-diagnosis-of-infectious-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Infection</strong> Invasion and multiplication of microorganisms in or on a host with or without a disease process.</p>
<p><strong>Infectious disease</strong> An infection causing structural and functional harm to the host with signs and symptoms.</p>
<p><strong>Opportunistic Infectious disease</strong> An infection caused by microorganisms that are normally harmless to the host.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>598 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Acute suppurative infection An infection in which pus is formed.</p>
<p>Chronic infection A long-standing infection involving the predominance of mononuclear inflammatory cells in its cellular response.</p>
<p>Subclinical infection An infection with no clinical symptoms and often detected by a rise in serum antibody titre or by a cellular immune response, e.g., skin test.</p>
<p>Nosocomial infection A hospital-acquired infection i.e. patient admitted into the hospital presenting an infection during his stay that was not present or was being incubated at the time of admission.</p>
<p>Inflammation A disease process of alteration of tissues or organs as a result of injury or tissue destruction that produces localised signs and symptoms such as swelling, pain or heat. It may also affect the whole body (systemic).</p>
<p>Pathogenicity Ability of a micro-organism to cause disease without any specification of conditions.</p>
<p>Opportunistic organism Normally a non-pathogen that may cause infection given the opportunity, e.g., in immunocompromised individuals.</p>
<p>Commensalism A relationship between a host and an organism in which neither derives benefit or harm. It is synonymous with colonisation.</p>
<p>Virulence The extent to which an organism can cause damage. The degree of pathogenicity is dependent on three major conditions: invasiveness, production of extracellular enzymes and toxigenicity.</p>
<p>Pathogenesis The route of establishing infectious disease by a pathogenic organism. To achieve this aim, the organism must:</p>
<ol>
<li>find a portal of entry in order to reach the host.</li>
<li>overcome the host defence mechanisms.</li>
<li>invade and multiply in the host tissues and produce virulence factors or toxins and enzymes.</li>
</ol>
<p>The organism may reach the host by</p>
<ol>
<li>exogenous routes: inhalation, ingestion, direct contact or inoculation</li>
<li>endogenous routes: break down of natural barriers, alterations in host defence mechanisms or change of role by 'normal flora' organisms (opportunism).</li>
</ol>
<p>Invasiveness Ability of the pathogen to invade (gain entry) and proliferate in the tissue.</p>
<p>Extracellular substances These are mainly enzymes which are capable of destroying some body defense systems. Some bacteria, such as streptococci and staphylococci produce an enzyme, leukocidin, which destroys phargocytes and opens the way for the invading microorganisms. Some bacteria (streptococci, staphylococci, clostridia</p>
<p>Table 8.1 Differences between bacterial endotoxins and exotoxins</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Endotoxins</th><th>Exotoxins</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Organism producing</td><td>Gram-negative</td><td>Gram-positive (exceptions: B. pertussis and Sh. dysenteriae)</td></tr><tr><td>Origin</td><td>Components of cell wall</td><td>Secreted by cell</td></tr><tr><td>Effect of heat</td><td>Heat stable</td><td>Generally heat labile</td></tr><tr><td>Effect of antibody</td><td>Partial, if any</td><td>Neutralized</td></tr><tr><td>Toxoids</td><td>Not formed</td><td>Formed</td></tr><tr><td>Pathological effect</td><td>All are similar</td><td>Specific (i.e. on bowel, skin, etc.)</td></tr><tr><td>Toxicity</td><td>Relatively weakly toxic</td><td>Generally highly toxic</td></tr><tr><td>Composition</td><td>Liposaccharide and conjugated protein</td><td>Protein</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles and Procedures of Diagnostic Bacteriology 599</p>
<p>etc.) also produce the enzyme, hyaluronidase, which attacks and dissolves hyaluronic acid—the ground substance of connective tissue. This action aids the diffusion and spread of the organism in the tissue. Many species of <em>Clostridium</em> produce proteolytic enzymes including collagenase which help in their spread. These extracellular substances aid and abet pathogenic organism in their harmful duty of producing infection in a host.</p>
<p><strong>Toxigenicity</strong> Bacterial toxins may be exogenous (exotoxins) or endogenous (endotoxins). Exogenous toxins are usually associated with Gram positive organisms and endogenous ones with gram negative bacteria. Table 8.1 shows the differences between exogenous and endogenous toxins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-flora">NORMAL FLORA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-flora" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal flora refers to the population of bacterial groups that normally inhabit certain parts of the body of a normal healthy person.</p>
<p>There are two groups of normal flora:</p>
<ol>
<li>The resident flora which are bacterial groups regularly seen in a particular area of the body; and</li>
<li>The transient flora which are present in mucous membranes or on the skin for hours, days or weeks and are derived from the environment.</li>
</ol>
<p>The resident flora are normally commensals, but transient flora may cause disease if the resident flora are disturbed, in which case they may colonise, proliferate and produce disease.</p>
<p>Though the role of the resident flora may be vital in some cases, their presence in the body is not essential to life since ‘germ-free’ animals can be reared. However, they help to maintain health. They form part of the defence mechanisms against infection. For examples, the lactobacilli help maintain the acidity of an adult vagina by the production of lactic acid which is harmful to most bacteria. The resident flora on the mucous membrane or skin assist in preventing colonisation by pathogens by depriving them of binding sites on the host and essential nutrients. Any disturbance, suppression or removal of the resident flora creates an opportunity for transient organisms in the environment or those from other parts of the body to take over and cause disease (opportunistic infection).</p>
<p>Equally true is the fact that the normal flora are themselves capable of producing disease. If they are removed from their normal resident sites to other areas, they may become invasive and cause disease. For example, the viridans group of streptococci are non-pathogenic resident flora of the upper respiratory tract. If they get into the blood stream during tooth extraction or tonsillectomy, they settle on deformed heart valve and produce infective (sub-bacterial) endocarditis.</p>
<p>Table 8.2 lists the various organisms considered normal flora from the different parts of the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specimen">SPECIMEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ability of the laboratory to correctly diagnose an infection very much depends on the quality of the clinical specimen. This is because the results of many laboratory tests are closely related to the selection, timing and method of collection of specimens. The following basic concepts should be taken into consideration when collecting specimens:</p>
<ol>
<li>The clinical specimen should be taken from the actual infection site. Here are a few guidelines:</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) Sputum specimen should be from the lower respiratory tract and not salivary.
(b) Mid-stream urine sample from a female patient should follow adequate cleaning of the perineum and other surrounding tissues.
(c) Depths of wounds and draining sinuses should be sampled without touching the adjacent skin.
(d) Deep abscesses should be aspirated with needles or cannulas.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Optimal times for specimen collection should be established.</li>
</ol>
<p>The recovery of certain bacteria is enhanced if optimal time of their release is known.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>600 Bacteriology</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genitalia">Genitalia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genitalia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>The following when mixed and not predominant: enterococci, Enterobacteriaceae and other gram-negative rods, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Candida albicans and other yeasts.</li>
<li>Anaerobes: the following may be important when in pure growth or clearly predominant: Bacteroides, Clostridium, Peptostreptococcus, and Peptococcus species.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles and Procedures of Diagnostic Bacteriology 601</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>The quantity of specimen must be adequate. A guideline as to what is sufficient amount of material should be established.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proper and sterile collection devices and specimen containers must be used. This is to avoid contamination. Containers should be made for ease of collection, e.g., narrow mouthed containers are not suitable for urine, sputum or stool collection. Tightly fitted caps or lids must be provided to prevent contamination and leakage during transportation.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Swabs are commonly used for collection of materials for culture. Swabs may be transported in transport medium to the laboratory; or they may be coated with charcoal or albumen to neutralise the toxic effect of the long chain fatty acids in the cotton wool.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>Prompt delivery of specimens to the laboratory is important.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obtain all the necessary specimens prior to the administration of antimicrobial drugs. This is particularly true if organisms such as <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>, Beta-haemolytic streptococci and <em>Haemophilius influenzae</em> are suspected.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The clinical specimen container must be properly labelled with</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Patient’s name</li>
<li>Type of specimen</li>
<li>Hospital number</li>
<li>Ward/clinic</li>
<li>Time and date of collection.</li>
</ul>
<p>A request form containing the above information and the type of tests required must accompany each specimen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="postal-specimens">Postal Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#postal-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are occasions when specimens have to be sent by post to a distant laboratory. There are rules and regulations governing the despatch of such specimens:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The specimen must be sent by letter post only.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It must be clearly labelled ‘Bacteriological Specimen’.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The specimen must be in a sealed container.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sealed container must be packed in a wooden or metal box which contains sufficient absorbent material such as cotton wool to prevent any possible leakage should the container be damaged.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The box should be taped round with hazard-sign tape, and with the warning ‘BACTERIOLOGICAL SPECIMEN’ clearly written on the box.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reception-of-specimens">Reception of Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reception-of-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-specimen-and-request-forms">1. Specimen and request forms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-specimen-and-request-forms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Check the specimen and the accompanying request form that they match in detail. Any anomalies should be sorted out before the specimen is ‘received’, i.e. logged in the register or in the computer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-leaking-or-contaminated-specimens">2. Leaking or contaminated specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-leaking-or-contaminated-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Wear gloves to handle leaking or contaminated specimens. Such specimens should be placed in a Class I safety cabinet for decontamination. If the specimen is leaking or contaminated badly and therefore cannot be salvaged, it should be discarded and the requesting physician or the nursing staff promptly informed. If the request form is contaminated, copy as much detail as possible onto a new request form and destroy the original.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-specimen-rejects">3. Specimen rejects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-specimen-rejects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The laboratory must draw a list of criteria for rejecting specimens and the list made available to the physicians and nurses. The list should include:
(i) badly leaking samples
(ii) when specimen and request form do not match
(iii) specimen collected in a wrong container</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="41e004bf">♦ A GENERAL SCHEME FOR EXAMINING CLINICAL SPECIMENS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#41e004bf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="macroscopic-examination">Macroscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#macroscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Few clinical specimens are subjected to macroscopic examination in bacteriological investigations. These may include:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>602 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(i) CSF and other body fluids—appearance and presence of clot
(ii) Sputum—appearance and presence of blood
(iii) Stool—Consistency, colour and presence of blood and mucus.</p>
<p>Microscopic examination is done on stained and unstained preparations of the specimen. The unstained preparation may be in the form of a wet mount preparation, e.g., when looking for cells and casts in urine. Gram staining is the single most useful stain in diagnostic bacteriology. Other special stains such as Ziehl-Neelsen stain for acid-fast bacilli and Albert’s stain for metachromatic granules in corynebacteria, may be useful and even diagnostic in some cases. Microscopic examination of the stained materials is not definitive but only suggestive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The definitive diagnostic procedure is culturing of organisms. Appropriate culture media depending on the nature and type of specimen are inoculated. It is necessary to use several media for what is termed ‘routine culture’. Blood agar is a most useful enriched medium that supports the growth of most non-fastidious bacteria, including the aerobic, facultative and obligatory anaerobic ones. Chocolate agar, with or without supplements, is a second necessary medium as some bacteria that fail to grow on blood agar, do grow on it. Also it is important to include a differential medium such as MacConkey or Cystein lactose electrolyte deficient (CLED) agar to complete the ‘routine culture’ set up. The nature of the specimen and the provisional diagnosis will determine the type of, if any, selective or enrichment media to be included. The inoculated media are incubated at the appropriate growth temperature and in the correct atmospheric environment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examination-of-cultures">Examination of Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examination-of-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After, usually, an overnight (16-20 hours) incubation, the cultures are examined for visible bacterial growth.</p>
<p>For solid (plate) cultures, careful and extensive notes are made of the following:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-gross-colony-characteristics">1. Gross colony characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-gross-colony-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Visual inspection of the colonial appearance is carried out in order to assess their gross characteristics. Examination of culture plate is a specialised skill acquired by working with a well-trained and experienced ‘bench’ bacteriologist. Inspection of the plate is done by holding the plate in one hand and observing any surface growth. The plate should be tilted in various angles under bright direct light. Some workers make use of hand lens or plate microscopes to observe tiny colonies and various forms of colonies present. Figure 8.2 shows the various forms and terms used to describe the morphology of the colonies. Note the following:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6f8c4a80.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.2 Terms to describe colony characteristics</p>
<ul>

</ul>

<ul>
<li>Colour-white, yellow, black, buff, etc.</li>
<li>Edge-entire, curled, etc.</li>
<li>Elevation-flat, raised, convex, etc.</li>
<li>Surface-glistening, dull, etc.</li>
<li>Density-opaque, transparent, etc.</li>
<li>Consistency-butyrous, brittle, sticky, etc.</li>
<li>Odour-experienced bacteriologist knows the specific smell of some bacteria, e.g., musty, ammoniacal, etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>Effect of the growth on the medium:</p>
<p>(a) Haemolysis on blood agar</p>
<ul>
<li>Alpha: Partial clearing of blood around colonies with green discolouration of the medium.</li>
<li>Beta: Zone of complete clearing of blood around colonies due to lysis of red blood cells.</li>
<li>Gamma: No change in the medium around the colonies—no lysis or discolouration of red blood cells.</li>
</ul>
<p>(b) Pigment production</p>
<ul>
<li>Water-soluble pigments discolouring the medium, e.g., pyocyanin.</li>
<li>Non-diffusable pigments limited to the colonies.</li>
</ul>
<p>(c) Changes in differential medium</p>
<ul>
<li>Usually, change of colour of medium serves as indicator of enzymatic activity or the utilisation of fermentable carbohydrate in the medium.</li>
</ul>

<li>Gram's stain reaction of the colonies</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Shape</li>
<li>Size</li>
<li>Arrangement</li>
</ul>
<p>Biochemical Reactions</p>
<p>The experienced bacteriologist collects all the data from his observations, and correlates them to the clinical information. At this stage, he may be able to speculate on the identity of the infectious agent. A preliminary report may be given to the physician so that treatment may be started or changed. The collected data will help to select other necessary differential biochemical and confirmatory tests to be done to complete the full identification.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity tests may be performed on the pure cultures of the isolated bacteria.</p>
<p>Serological Examination</p>
<p>The general scheme may include antigen-antibody (serological) reaction tests. These tests may be for diagnostic or confirmatory purpose. The serological test may involve testing an unknown antigen against a known antibody, e.g., slide agglutination test for Salmonella or Shigella organisms; or a known antigen against an unknown antibody, e.g., Widal agglutination.</p>
<p>Serological and immunological methods are discussed in Part 5 of this Section.</p>
<p>Final Report</p>
<p>Report only those pathogens which are isolated and duly confirmed together with antibiotic sensitivity result to the requesting physician. The final report must be verified by a senior member of the technical or medical staff of the laboratory before it is issued out.</p>
<p>A scheme of common bacterial infections, agents, specimens and media is shown in Table 8.3.</p>
<p>◆ ANAEROBIC CULTIVATION METHODS</p>
<p>The principle of anaerobiasis and the need for anaerobic culture has been discussed in Chapter 5. It is more difficult and time-consuming to cultivate and isolate anaerobic organisms than the aerobic ones. But the difficulty is overcome if the anaerobic technique becomes a routine procedure regulated to fit in with the rest of laboratory work. Some of the anaerobic cultivation methods have however become obsolete in the present day laboratory practice.</p>
<p>There are several ways of performing anaerobic cultivation:</p>
