<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-of-specimens">Collection of Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pus from an abscess is best collected at the time the abscess is incised and drained. Pus swabs collected into transport medium should reach the laboratory within six hours of collection. Pus or exudate from deep seated abscesses should be aspirated and collected in a sterile container.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Gram smear to check for pus cells and/or organisms</li>
<li>Inoculate:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Blood agar -O₂ incubation</li>
<li>CLED or MacConkey agar -O₂ incubation</li>
<li>Gentamicin blood agar -AnO₂ incubation</li>
<li>Robertson’s cooked meat medium</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Incubate all the plates and broth at 36–37°C for 18–24 hours. After overnight incubation, subculture the RCM onto:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>BA -O₂ incubation</li>
<li>BA -ANO₂ incubation</li>
<li>CLED or MacConkey</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 18–24 hours.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-tests">Additional tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Look for and note white, yellow, brown, red or black granules in the specimens. Presence of granules is indicative of actinomycosis or mycetoma.</li>
<li>Smear for Ziehl-Neelsen stain for acid fast bacilli if requested.</li>
<li>Lowestein Jensen medium if tuberculosis is indicated.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Reporting</strong> Report with sensitivities any organism in pure culture or any combination of two organisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3585101b">♦ CATHETER TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3585101b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Conventional pathogens</strong> <em>Staph.aureus</em>, <em>Staph. epidermidis</em>, <em>Strep.viridans</em>, <em>Diphtheroid bacilli</em>, <em>Coliform bacilli</em>, <em>Pseudomonas</em> species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Inoculate:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>BA -CO₂ incubation
(Roll the tip completely over surface of the plate)</li>
<li>Incubate in CO₂ at 36–37°C for up 48 hours.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Reporting</strong> Report any pathogen isolated with antibiotic sensitivities.</p>
<p>Mixed growth of more than two organisms may be ignored. <em>Staph.aureus</em> must always be reported.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1a23438a">♦ BLOOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1a23438a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Septicaemia is the infection of blood; and bacteraemia is the transient and often asymptomatic presence of bacteria in the blood. (Table 9.8). The two terms may be used interchangeably but septicaemia is usually more severe. The infectious agents multiply and release toxins in the blood stream. The common symptoms of septicaemia include fever, chills and shock. Pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO) is a loose term to describe symptoms of septicaemia.</p>
<p>Blood is normally sterile and so, there is no resident normal flora. Poor collection and handling techniques may however result in the specimen being contaminated with commensal bacteria usually from skin.</p>
<p>Septicaemia usually portends life threatening illness and so blood cultures do receive high priority attention in the laboratory. The recovery of micro-organism from blood is of great significance. It is important therefore that special care is taken in processing blood cultures to minimise contamination.</p>
<p>The following guidelines for the collection of blood should be followed:</p>
<ol>
<li>Use only sterile equipment and strict aseptic technique.</li>
<li>Apply a tourniquet and locate a fixed vein by touch.</li>
<li>Apply 2% tincture of iodine in widening circle to the site of proposed skin puncture. After the skin has been sterilised, do not</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 623</p>
<p>much the site except with sterile gloves.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Perform venipuncture and withdraw blood. The volume of blood will depend on (a) the system of blood culture and (b) if the patient is adult or child or neonate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add blood aseptically into the aerobic and anaerobic blood culture media through the rubber liner of the cap.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Take the specimens to the laboratory immediately. If there is to be any delay, keep the media bottles in an incubator at 37°C.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-culture-media">Blood Culture Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-culture-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood culture media should be able to support the growth of aerobic and anaerobic organisms. They are nutritionally enriched liquid media such as trypticase soy broth, brain-heart infusion broth or thioglycollate-broth. There are several blood culture systems available to the clinical bacteriologists. In most systems, a single blood culture consists of a pair of culture bottles, one aerobic and the other anaerobic. Few of them, like the Oxoid Signal, use only a single bottle of culture medium which is incubated aerobically. At present there are several computerised systems available, e.g., Bactec 460 system is now superseded by Bactec NR-600 model. The NR-600 which is based on infra red detection of CO₂, is easy to use because the manual manipulation required of the older models like the 460 model, is supplanted by automated methods controlled by computer modules. The advantage of the computerised systems is the early detection of positive cultures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-affecting-blood-cultures">Factors Affecting Blood Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-blood-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several factors that determine whether blood cultures will yield positive results:</p>
<ol>
<li>Volume of blood in the media</li>
<li>Dilution of blood in the media</li>
<li>Duration of incubation</li>
</ol>
<p>For most systems, 10–20 ml of blood from adults is obtained and distributed equally in the aerobic and the anaerobic blood culture bottles. However, each system indicates what volume of blood is required. To minimise the effects of antibody, complement, and other antibacterial substances present in the blood, an optimal dilution of blood in liquid culture media is necessary. Usually 1:10–1:20 dilution is adequate. The optimal dilution will also prevent the blood from clotting. Most of the blood culture media contain about 0.03–0.05% of sodium polyanethol sulphonate (SPS) which is commercially known as liquoid. It is used to neutralise the bactericidal effect of blood.</p>
<p>A diphasic medium (Castaneda’s method) is preferred by some workers. This medium consists of a slope of nutrient agar to which, usually, glucose broth is added. The exposed surface of the slope is examined daily for growth. By tilting the blood broth mixture over the agar slope each day, opening the bottle to subculture is avoided and so contamination is minimised.</p>
<p>The cultures are incubated at 37°C and for a minimum of seven days. Much longer incubation is necessary for slow growing organisms such as Brucella species and also for some infections, e.g., bacterial endocarditis. The cultures are checked daily for signs of growth but sub-cultures are made at 48 hours incubation and on the final (7th) day incubation. With computerised systems, subculturing is not necessary as positive cultures are indicated on the screen.</p>
<p>A preliminary report of growth or no growth should be made available to the physician at 48 hours.</p>
<p>A. Common pathogens isolated from blood Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Salmonella typhi, Other Salmonellae, Klebsiella species, Brucella species, Neisseria meningitidis, Escherichia coli and other coliforms, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Viridans streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>624 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Table 9.8 Blood: Disease conditions and their infectious agent</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agent</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Neonatal septicaemia</td><td>E. coli, staphylococci, Beta-haemolytic streptococcus group B, Coliform bacilli (occasionally enterococci, Listeria monocytogenes and Candida albicans)</td></tr><tr><td>Subacute bacterial (infective) endocarditis (SBE).</td><td>Viridae streptococci, enterococci, Staph.aureus, Strep.pyogenes, pneumococci, Staph.epidermidis, H. influenzae and Corynebacterium species</td></tr><tr><td>Typhoid fever (Entericfever)</td><td>Salmonella typhi</td></tr><tr><td>Septicaemic plague</td><td>Yersinia pestis</td></tr><tr><td>Undulant fever</td><td>Brucella species</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. Uncommon pathogens isolated from blood
Anaerobic cocci, Enterococci, Clostridium perfringens, Proteus species, Bacteriodes species, Yersinia pestis.</p>
<p>Collection of Specimen</p>
<p>Blood is collected aseptically, as described earlier, before antimicrobial therapy is initiated. The ideal time of collection is when the patient's temperature is beginning to rise. Blood is sent to the laboratory as soon as possible for immediate incubation.</p>
<p>Examination of Blood Cultures</p>
<p>After 24 hours incubation, check the cultures for any visible sign of growth (turbidity, haemolysis or gas production). The computerised system will automatically indicate a growth with a bleep sound or a print out.</p>
<p>For manual procedures, the blood cultures are subcultured on the 2nd and 7th (final) day of incubation. When there is growth, irrespective of the system in use, the blood is subcultured onto:</p>
<p>BA aerobic incubation
BA anaerobic incubation
Choc CO₂ incubation
CLED aerobic incubation</p>
<p>Incubate 36°C–37°C.</p>
<p>The method of examining blood culture will vary from laboratory to laboratory and depends on the system used. Gram stain smear is made directly from the blood culture bottle. The result of the Gram stain may necessitate a direct antibiotic sensitivity test being done. It is important to communicate the Gram stain result of the positive blood culture to the requesting physician or clinic.</p>
<p>Reporting Identify and report all isolates with the antibiotic sensitivities. It is important to be able to differentiate a contaminant growth from the true significant bacterial growth.</p>
<p>Contamination may occur during the time of blood collection in the clinic or ward, or later in the laboratory during processing.</p>
<p>Contamination is suspected when:</p>
<p>(1) An organism that should grow in both aerobic and anaerobic bottles is recovered from only one bottle.
(2) When a mixed growth is isolated.</p>
<p>Note</p>
<ol>
<li>Incubate blood cultures for 4–6 weeks if Brucellosis is indicated; and then subculture on appropriate solid media and incubate for 3–5 days.</li>
<li>Carry out subculture procedures in a safety cabinet.</li>
<li>Aspirated bone marrow is similarly treated as blood.</li>
<li>In some cases, e.g., infective bacterial endocarditis, 'pour plate' is</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 625</p>
<p>made with the patient's blood and nutrient agar as often the identification of any organism present can be done the next day.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Some blood culture systems have special culture bottles for neonatal specimens. Collect blood from a neonate from a peripheral vein and not from the umbilical vein. This is to minimise contamination.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerebrospinal-fluid-csf">CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebrospinal-fluid-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cerebrospinal fluid is normally sterile but contaminants can easily be introduced by non-application of aseptic techniques, both in the wards and in the laboratory (Table 9.9). Examination of CSF is an emergency, and specimens should be examined without delay. The preliminary results of tests i.e. Gram stain and cell count, should be reported to the physician or a senior nursing staff in the ward immediately.</p>
<p>Inflammation of the meninges (meningitis) is the main indication for the bacteriological examination of the CSF. Pathogens reach the meninges either through the blood stream or from nearby anatomic sites such as the middle ear or nasal sinuses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-classical-pathogens-of-csf">A. Classical pathogens of CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-classical-pathogens-of-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae (type B), Streptococcus pneumoniae, Listeria monocytogenes, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Treponema pallidum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-other-pathogens">B. Other pathogens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-other-pathogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Staphylococcus aureus, E. coli and other enteric Gram negative bacilli especially in neonates, Group B Streptococci in neonates, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Cryptococcus neoformans (Fungus), Treponema pallidum</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-there-is-no-resident-normal-flora-of-the-cns">C. There is no resident normal flora of the CNS.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-there-is-no-resident-normal-flora-of-the-cns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-of-csf">Collection of CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The collection of CSF requires strict aseptic precaution in order to prevent organisms being introduced into the central nervous system. The collection must be done by an experienced physician.</p>
<p>CSF is collected from the subarachnoid spaces between the 3rd and 4th or 4th and 5th lumbar vertebrae. A sterile wide-bore needle is inserted and the CSF starts to drip into a dry sterile container. Some workers prefer to collect samples of CSF into two containers, No. 1 and No. 2.</p>
<p>It is a good practice to inform the laboratory staff before a lumbar puncture is done. This is to enable the laboratory to be ready to receive and examine the specimen immediately.</p>
<p>Where two specimens No.1. and No. 2 are available, use the No 1 specimen for culture and No.2 for other tests such as microscopy, cell count and biochemical tests. This is because the No.1 specimen may be blood stained as a result of traumatic lumbar puncture, which may adversely affect cell count and biochemical estimations.</p>

<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agent</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Pyogenic meningitis</td><td>N.meningitidis, S.pneumoniae, H.influenzae.</td></tr><tr><td>Lymphocytic meningitis</td><td>Viruses, Myco. tuberculosis, C. neoformans, T. pallidum.</td></tr><tr><td>Eosinophilic meningitis</td><td>Helminths such as Angiostrongylus cantonensis, Dirofilaria immitis.</td></tr><tr><td>Neurosyphilis</td><td>E. coli, Group B streptococcus, Listeria monocytogenes.</td></tr><tr><td>Neonatal meningitis</td><td>Cryptococcus neoformans.</td></tr><tr><td>Cryptococcal meningitis</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="procedure-for-laboratory-examination">Procedure for Laboratory Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure-for-laboratory-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-describe-the-appearance-of-the-csf">1. Describe the appearance of the CSF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-describe-the-appearance-of-the-csf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal CSF is clear and colourless. The specimen, however may be turbid, blood stained or pigmented (e.g., Xanthochronic), or may show presence of clots. Blood in the CSF may be due to:</p>
<p>(a) Internal haemorrhage in the central nervous system.
(b) Trauma during the collection of the specimen.</p>
<p>Xanthochromia (yellow-red tinge) of the CSF is due to:
(a) Subarachnoid haemorrhage
(b) Jaundice
(c) Spinal constriction.</p>
<p>Turbidity in the CSF is due to:
(a) Increased number of blood cells
(b) Presence of bacteria
(c) Increased protein content</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>A grossly blood stained CSF may show a yellow supernatant after centrifuging. This may be serum and not a true Xanthochromia.</li>
<li>The presence of clots in the CSF indicates (a) an increase in fibrinogen due to spinal constriction, or (b) pyogenic meningitis. The clots can be broken by shaking the fluid with a few sterile glass beads.</li>
<li>A web clot may form on the surface of the CSF. This is due to much increased protein content in tuberculous meningitis. Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) may be seen in the clot.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-centrifugation">2. Centrifugation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-centrifugation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Aseptically transfer a volume of the CSF into a sterile centrifuge tube and centrifuge at 2000 rpm for five minutes (If the fluid is obviously clear and colourless, centrifugation may not be necessary). Use the deposit for culture and for making smears. The supernatant can be used for the detection of bacterial antigen if necessary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-cell-count">3. Cell Count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-cell-count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) With a fine tip pasteur pipette, aseptically charge one side of an assembled Fuchs-</p>
<p>Rosenthal counting chamber with the well-mixed CSF. Allow to settle for about two minutes.</p>
<p>(b) With the aid of a tally counter, count the white and red blood cells in each of five large squares as shown in Fig. 9.1.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-7dfe89c0.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg">
Fig. 9.1 CSF cell count using Fuchs-Rosenthal counting chamber</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>If the CSF is turbid or very blood stained, it may be necessary to dilute the fluid with a WBC diluting fluid which is usually 1% acetic acid with a tinge of crystal violet. The acetic acid will lyse the red blood cells while the crystal violet will stain the nuclei of the white blood cells, thus making them easy to count. However, some workers make use of isotonic toluidine blue or methylene blue. This solution will not lyse the red blood cells so that they can be counted; it will also stain the white cells.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The improved Neubauer counting chamber can also be used to perform the cell count if Fuchs-</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 627</p>
<p>Rosenthal chamber is not available. The count is performed as shown in Fig. 9.2.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0f6798c4.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg">
Fig. 9.2 CSF cell count using Improved Neubauer counting chamber</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>A differential white cell count is performed if the white cell count is raised. The predominance of either lymphocytes or polymorphonuclear cells may give a clue as to the type of meningitis. A quick differential count can be done by examining a methylene blue stained smear for lymphocytes and polymorphonuclear neutrophils.</li>
</ol>
<p>It can also be done from Leishman or Giemsa stained smear of the CSF. With experience, it is possible to recognise the various types of cells in an unstained preparation.</p>
<p>Reporting of total cell count If the Fuchs-Rosenthal counting chamber is used:</p>
<p>The sum of all the cells counted in the five large squares is expressed as number of cells per cubic mm.</p>
<p>For example, if 40 cells are counted, report as 40 white cells/cu.mm.</p>
<p>In SI units, this is reported as Number of cells/Litre. i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>6</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \times 10^{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> cells/L</p>
<p>If the count is high, the CSF may be diluted 1:2, 1:5 or 1:10 (1 drop of CSF to 1, 4 or 9 drops of the diluting fluid respectively)</p>
<p>Multiply the number of cells counted by the dilution factor.</p>
<p>For example, in 1:2 dilution,</p>
<p>The number of cells counted = 40</p>
<p>Final count = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \times 2 = 80</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span></span></span></span></span> cells/cu.mm or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>6</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \times 10^{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> cells/L</p>
<p>If improved Neubauer chamber is used Let the sum of all the cells counted in 4 large squares (Fig. 9.2) be N</p>
<p>The area of 4 squares = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Depth of the counting chamber = 0.1 mm</p>
<p>Therefore, volume of CSF in 4 large squares = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.4\mathrm{mm}^3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">0.4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mtext>Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;cells/mm</mtext><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>0.4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Number of cells/mm}^3 = \frac{\mathrm{N}}{0.4} = \frac{\mathrm{N} \times 10}{4} = \mathrm{N} \times 2.5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em; <p>If the specimen is diluted, multiply by the dilution factor</p>
<p>i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N \times 2.5 \times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> dilution factor per cu.mm</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> For details of counting areas of these chambers, refer to the Haematology Section.</p>
<p>White cell differential count The total white cell count must be at least 20 for a proper differential count to be done. If the count is less than 20, it may be useful to merely express the ratio of lymphocytes to neutrophils. The differential count is expressed as percentage of the total number of cells counted, e.g.</p>
<p>10% lymphocytes</p>
<p>90% polymorphonuclear neutrophils.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Biochemical tests The cerebrospinal fluid is routinely tested for any biochemical abnormalities. These tests include</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucose estimation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Total protein estimation and testing for raised globulin (Pandy's test).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chloride estimation.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>628 Bacteriology</p>
<p>These tests are best done in a biochemistry laboratory. An increase in the CSF protein level with a positive Pandy’s test is highly suggestive of bacterial meningitis (Refer to Section II).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-culture">5. Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Cerebrospinal fluid should be cultured as soon as possible after collection. If delay is inevitable, the CSF should be kept warm, preferably at 35–37°C. (Do not keep in the refrigerator).</p>
<p>A clear and colourless specimen should be cultured neat without centrifugation. A cloudy or turbid specimen should be centrifuged and the deposit used for culture and smear preparation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="inoculate">Inoculate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Blood agar</th><th>CO₂ incubation</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Chocolate agar</td><td>CO₂ incubation</td></tr><tr><td>Glucose broth</td><td>O₂ incubation</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Incubate all cultures at 36–37°C for 16–18 hours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6-staining">6. Staining<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-staining" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Make three thin smears from the centrifuged deposit.</p>
<p>Stain one smear by Gram’s method. Stain the second smear with methylene blue.</p>
<ol>
<li>If the total white cell count is raised, perform a differential count on the methylene blue stained smear.</li>
<li>Examine the Gram’s stained smear for the presence of bacteria.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="additional-tests">Additional Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Stain the remaining smear by Ziehl-Neelsen’s method (or auramine method) if requested, or if the differential count shows a predominance of lymphocytes.</li>
<li>Inoculate blood agar for anaerobic cultivation if the patient is a neurosurgical case.</li>
<li>Inoculate Sabouraud agar and perform an Indian ink wet preparation if Cryptococcus is indicated.</li>
<li>Inoculate a MacConkey or CLED agar if patient is a neonate or if Gram negative bacilli are seen in Gram’s smear.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="bacterial-antigen-test">Bacterial antigen test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-antigen-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This test is performed if the total cell count is high. It is a latex coagulucation test performed to detect bacterial antigens in CSF. The test is directed at the common infectious agents:</p>
<p><em>N. meningitidis, H. influenzae, Strep. pneumoniae, Group B. streptococcus and E. coli.</em></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Heat the supernatant of the centrifuged CSF in boiling water bath for five minutes.</li>
<li>Cool to room temperature.</li>
<li>Mix latex reagents thoroughly.</li>
<li>Add 40 μl of CSF to each circle of reaction card.</li>
<li>Add 25 μl of the respective test latex next to each drop of CSF. (These latex particles are coated with antibodies to the infectious agents mentioned above).</li>
<li>Mix latex and sample using separate mixing sticks.</li>
<li>Gently rock the card slowly for 2–3 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="result">Result<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#result" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Positive = Visible clumping
Negative = smooth milky appearance.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Group B streptococcus latex is tested against neonatal samples only.</li>
<li>Clumping within the reaction time may be large and fast or small and slow, depending on the amount of antigen present in the CSF.</li>
<li>A positive reaction should be confirmed by testing the sample against appropriate control.</li>
<li>The bacterial antigen kits are commercially available from various manufacturers.</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p><strong>Report on the cultures</strong> If there is no growth after 24 hours, reincubate all the plates.</p>
<p>In the presence of pus cells; report any organism in pure culture with sensitivity test result.</p>
<p>In the absence of pus cells and with negative be properly evaluated before being reported.</p>
<p>Established commensals such as Staph. epidermidis, diphtheroids and saprophytic Gram</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 629</p>
<p>negative bacilli may be reported in neonates, immunocompromised patients and patients with indwelling catheters, shunts or foreign body implants.</p>
<p>Table 9.10 shows CSF results in meningitis and other infections of the central nervous system.</p>
<p>In patients who are immunocompromised or with indwelling foreign bodies, e.g., CSF shunts, organisms like <em>S. epidermidis</em> and diphtheroids could be clinically relevant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effusions-fluids">EFFUSIONS/FLUIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effusions-fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fluid that collects in the body cavity is called effusion. Exudate is the fluid which collects as a result of inflammation; and transudate is the fluid which collects due to non-inflammatory condition. It is important to investigate exudates in order to rule out any infective aetiology. It is necessary to be familiar with the names and sites of the common fluids and effusions sent to the laboratory for investigation. (Tables 9.11 and 9.12).</p>
<p>These fluids are subjected to the same procedures as for cerebrospinal fluid, since like CSF, they are normally sterile.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="synovial-fluid">SYNOVIAL FLUID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synovial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most likely Pathogens <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>, <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em>, <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em>, <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>, <em>Neisseria meningitidis</em>, <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em>, <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em>.</p>
