<p>B. Other Pathogens Anaerobic streptococcus, Salmonella species, Escherichia coli and other coliforms, Pseudomonas aeruinosa, Bacteriodes species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8591bc89">♦ PLEURAL AND PERICARDIAL FLUIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8591bc89" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most likely pathogens Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzaem Bacteriodes species</p>
<p>B. Other pathogens Klebsiella species, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Some fungi</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f0dde26c">♦ ASCITIC FLUID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f0dde26c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most likely pathogens Enterococci, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Streptococcus pyogenes, Klebsiella species, Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The major differences between a transudate and an exudate are listed in Table 9.13.</p>
<p>Table 9.13 Difference between transudate and exudate</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Transudate</th><th>Exudate</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Appearance</td><td>Clear, pale yellow</td><td>Purulent, cloudy or blood stained</td></tr><tr><td>Clotting</td><td>Nil</td><td>Often clots</td></tr><tr><td>Cells</td><td>Few</td><td>Purulent. Numerous cells, mainly polymorphonuclear neutrophils, lymphocytes Non-purulent: Few or many.</td></tr><tr><td>Protein</td><td>Less than 3 g/L</td><td>More than 3g/L</td></tr><tr><td>Culture</td><td>Sterile</td><td>Positive</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 631</p>
<p><strong>Key</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Arthritis = inflammation of joints</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pleural effusion = non-purulent serous pleural effusion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Empyema = purulent pleural effusion when pus is present</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emphysema = air in the tissues</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ascitis = accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, causing the swelling of the abdomen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other pathogens Group B Streptococcus, Viridans streptococci, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacteriodes species, Clostridium perfringens.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hydrocoele-fluid">HYDROCOELE FLUID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydrocoele-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The microfilariae, <em>Wuchereria bancrofti</em> may be found in the fluid.</p>
<p><strong>Comments</strong> No normal bacterial flora is present.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-of-effusion">Collection of Effusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-effusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An experienced physician should perform the collection of synovial, pleural, pericardial, peritoneal or hydrocoele fluid. The aspirated fluid is aseptically dispensed into two screw-cap containers, one containing an anticoagulant. The anticoagulant prevents clotting of the exudates and this is used for cell count, protein estimation, microscopy and culture. The other portion is used to check whether clotting occurs. The samples are labelled accordingly and sent to the laboratory without delay.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The anticoagulant of choice is 3 % (w/v) tri-sodium citrate in a ratio of 9 ml effusion to 1 ml anticoagulant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedures-for-laboratory-examination">Procedures for Laboratory Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedures-for-laboratory-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-appearance">1. Appearance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Describe the appearance of the specimen</p>
<p>Colour:
a. Clear, cloudy or purulent
b. Blood stained
c. Presence of clot</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> 1. If the specimen is frankly purulent or cloudy or heavily blood stained, smears and cultures are made directly.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>If the fluid is clear, transfer a small volume to a sterile centrifuge tube and centrifuge at 3000 rpm for 10 minutes; use the deposit for smears and culture and the rest of the sample should be used for cell count and protein estimation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If there is no clot in the non-citrated sample, use it for cell count and protein estimation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell count A cell count is performed using the same method described for CSF. Do a differential count and report the cells as mainly polymorphonuclear neutrophils or lymphocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Protein estimation This estimation like in the case of CSF, is better done in the department of Biochemistry (see Section (II)).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Culture Use purulent or blood stained specimen, or the deposit of centrifuged citrated specimen to inoculate:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Blood agar -O2 incubation
Blood agar -AnO2 incubation
Chocolate agar -CO2 incubation
MacConkey (or CLED) agar -O2 incubation
Robertson’s cooked meat
-(RCM) medium -O2 incubation</p>
<p>Incubate all media at 36–37°C for 24 hours. The chocolate agar and blood agar should be reincubated if there is no growths after 24 hours.</p>
<p>Subculture the RCM onto blood agar (anaerobically) and chocolate agar (in CO2) incubate at 36–37°C for 24 hours.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Microscopic examination Make a thin smear directly from purulent or blood stained specimen or use the sediment from a centrifuged non-purulent sample. Fix the smear and stain by Gram’s method.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>632 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-tests">Additional tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Inoculate the sediment on a slope of Lowenstein-Jensen medium where tuberculosis is suspected. With the same sediment, make a smear and stain for acid-fast bacilli (AFB).</p>
<p>(ii) When gout or pseudogout is indicated, do a wet preparation of the joint fluid and examine for colourless extracellular or intracellular crystals using the polarised microscope.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Monosodium urate crystals are needle-like in shape, measuring about 8–10μm in length. They are seen in effusions of gout.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium pyrophosphate crystals which are rod-shaped in form, measure about 25 μm in length and with a line running through them. They are found in effusions of pseudogout.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Polarised-light microscopy: Calcium pyrophosphates under polarised light, are birefrigent (double refractive) and monosodium urate crystals are not.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>(iii) Mucin clot test (Table 9.14).</p>
<p>This is a simple test which is done only on synovial fluid. It helps to distinguish the various forms of arthritis and causes of joint effusions.</p>
<p>Add 4 ml of 2 % v/v acetic acid to a test tube. Add 1 ml of unclotted specimen. With a glass rod, slowly mix the effusion with acid until a firm clot or soft mass forms.</p>
<p><strong>Table. 9.14</strong> Interpretation of Mucin clot test</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Condition</th><th>Mucin clot</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Normal synovial fluid</td><td>Good</td></tr><tr><td>Traumatic arthritis</td><td>Good</td></tr><tr><td>Osteoarthritis</td><td>Good</td></tr><tr><td>Systemic lupus erythromatosus</td><td>Good</td></tr><tr><td>Infective arthritis</td><td>Poor</td></tr><tr><td>Tuberculous arthritis</td><td>Poor</td></tr><tr><td>Rheumatoid arthritis</td><td>Poor</td></tr><tr><td>Gout and Pseudogout</td><td>Poor/fair</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Reporting of the culture Report any isolated organism with sensitivities except for the obvious skin flora such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, diphtheroids and viridans streptococci.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stool-faeces">STOOL (FAECES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stool-faeces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal stool has numerous bacteria. These are the enteric resident faecal flora and they grow profusely on non-selective culture media (Table 9.15).</p>
<p>Gastro-enteritis is the inflammation of gastrointestinal tract (GIT). Gastro-enteritis and diarrhoea (with or without vomiting) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in those areas of the world where there is no adequate potable water and sanitation. Diarrhoea is not caused by bacteria only. It may be caused by intestinal parasites, e.g., Giardia lamblia; viruses, e.g., rotavirus, and non-infective agents, e.g., antibiotic or other drug therapy which alters the intestinal flora. Diarrhoea is also associated with malaria, acute malnutrition, pneumonia, hepatitis, cirrhosis of the liver, pancreatitis, tuberculosis of the intestine, previous surgery of the bowel, colitis and tumour of the intestinal tract. Death due to diarrhoea is as a result of loss water and electrolytes leading to dehydration and then death. Some bacteria cause diarrhoea by the toxins they produce.</p>
<p>Dysentry (passing of blood and mucus in stool) is caused by certain invasive bacteria.</p>
<p>Food poisoning caused by some bacteria is symptomised by diarrhoea or vomiting.</p>
<p>A. Conventional pathogens Salmonella species, Shigella species, Escherichia coli (enteropathogenic strains), Vibrio cholerae, Campylobacter species.</p>
<p>B. Casual pathogens Staphylococcus aureus, Parahaemolyticus, Clostridium difficile, Yersinia enterocolitica, Aeromonas species.</p>
<p>C. Commensals (faecal flora). Coliforms, Pseudomonas, anaerobes, lactobacilli, enterobacteria, Candida species.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 633</p>
<p>Table 9.15 Faeces: Disease conditions and their infectious agents</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agents</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Gastro-enteritis and diarrhoea</td><td>Salmonella species, E.coli, Campylobacter species,Yersinia enterocolitica.</td></tr><tr><td>Bacillary dysentery (Shigellosis)</td><td>Shigella species</td></tr><tr><td>Food poisoning</td><td>Staph.aureus, Cl perfringens, B.cereus, V. parahaemolyticus, Salmonella species</td></tr><tr><td>Enteric fever (Typhoid and paratyphoid)</td><td>Salmonella typhi, Salmonella paratyphi A, B, C</td></tr><tr><td>Pseudomembraneous colitis and diarrhoea</td><td>Clostridium difficile</td></tr><tr><td>Rice water diarrhoea (Excessive diarrhoea)</td><td>Virbio cholerae</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: Traveller's diarrhoea is usually caused by some strains of E. coli.</p>
<p>Collection of faeces. Faecal specimens, are best collected during the acute stage of diarrhoea. For blood containing specimens or when amoebic dysentery is suspected, the specimen should be delivered in the laboratory as soon as possible. This specimen should be fresh and warm to demonstrate a motile amoeba.</p>
<p>The specimen is collected and sent to the laboratory in a suitable clean wide-mouth leak proof container with a screw-capped lid. In the absence of a faecal specimen, an alternative method is to insert a cotton wool swab into the rectum for about 10 seconds and collect a rectal swab.</p>
<p><strong>Note 1.</strong> If a long delay is inevitable, the specimen can be preserved in Blair transport medium for up to 36–48 hours.
<strong>2.</strong> If specimen is for cholera investigation mix about 1 ml of faeces with 10 ml of sterile alkaline peptone water. The organisms are viable in this broth for up to eight hours.
<strong>3.</strong> If worms or tapeworm segments are seen in the specimen, transfer these with a pair of forceps to a separate container and send to the laboratory for identification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examination-of-stool-specimens-faeces">EXAMINATION OF STOOL SPECIMENS (FAECES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examination-of-stool-specimens-faeces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-macroscopic-examination">1. Macroscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-macroscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Appearance (colour): Normal faeces of adults is usually brown while infant stool is yellow-green or gray (Table 9.16).</p>
<p>Consistency: Whether the stool is formed, semi-formed (soft), or liquid. Normal stool is usually formed or semi-formed.</p>
<p>Whether the stool contains blood, mucus, worms or tape worm segments.</p>
<p>Table 9.16 Macroscopy of stool specimens in certain disease conditions</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Appearance</th><th>Possible conditions</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Unformed, containing blood and mucus</td><td>Shigellosis (dysentery), Campylobacter gastroenteritis</td></tr><tr><td>Unformed with blood and mucus (low pH.)</td><td>Amoebic dysentery</td></tr><tr><td>Unformed or semi-formed, often with blood and mucus</td><td>Schistosomiasis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(Contd)</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>634 Bacteriology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Appearance</th><th>Possible conditions</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Watery stool</td><td>Entero-toxicogenic <em>Esch.coli</em> (ETEC) infection, <em>Rota virus</em> infection.</td></tr><tr><td>Rice water stools with mucous flakes</td><td>Cholera</td></tr><tr><td>Unformed or watery and sometimes with blood mucus and pus</td><td><em>Salmonella</em> infection</td></tr><tr><td>Unformed, pale frothy, unpleasant smelling stool that floats on water (high fat content)</td><td>Giardiasis, other conditions that cause malabsorption, e.g., infective tropical malabsorption</td></tr><tr><td>Unformed or semi-formed black stool (occult blood test positive)</td><td>Gastro intestinal bleeding, Hookworm disease, Iron therapy</td></tr><tr><td>Formed or semi-formed stool with fresh blood</td><td>Haemorrhoids, ulcerative colitis, haemorrhagic colitis or malignancy of the intestinal tract.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-microscopic-examination">2. Microscopic Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-microscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The microscopic examination is performed to detect ova, cyst or parasites and pus cells and red blood cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="wet-preparation">Wet preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wet-preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Place a drop of normal saline on one end of a slide and a drop of iodine on the other end.</p>
<p>With an applicator stick or wire loop, mix a small amount of specimen with each drop.</p>
<p>Cover each drop with a cover slip.</p>
<p>Examine the preparation, first using the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> objective with the iris diaphragm closed to focus and scan the field, then the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> objective with iris sufficiently opened to identify the parasites seen.</p>
<p>Refer to Parasitology Section for stool microscopic examination details.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-culture">3. Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="routine-culture-for-stool">Routine culture for stool<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#routine-culture-for-stool" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Inoculate the following media</p>
<ul>
<li>Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA)</li>
<li>Hektoen agar</li>
<li>Campylobacter medium</li>
<li>Selenite F broth.</li>
</ul>
<p>If the stool is hard, it may be necessary to ensure it is sifted a piece in about 2 ml of peptone water and use it for inoculation.</p>
<p>Incubate the DCA, Hektoen agar and the Selenite broth at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> in air for 24 hours.</p>
<p>Incubate the campylobacter medium at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>42</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">42^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> in microaerophilic (Gaspak kit) condition for 48 hours.</p>
<p>After 24 hours incubation, subculture the selenite F broth culture onto DCA and incubate at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> for another 24 hours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-tests">Additional tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="inoculate">Inoculate:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Alkaline peptone water (pH 8.6) and thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) agar if <em>V. Cholerae</em>, or <em>V. parahaemolyticus</em> food poisoning is suspected.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Yersinia agar or MacConkey agar if <em>E. enterocolitica</em> is suspected; if the specimen is frankly blood stained, inoculate sorbitol, and MacConkey agar for <em>E. coli</em> 0157.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cystein lactose electrolyte deficient (CLED) agar or MacConkey agar if the patient is a child under 3 years of age. This is for the isolation of entropathogenic <em>E.</em></p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 635</p>
<p>coli (EPEC).</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Clostridium difficile agar if pseudomembranous enterocolitis is indicated.</li>
<li>Gentamicin blood agar if clostridium food poisoning is suspected and incubate anaerobically.</li>
<li>Mannitol salt agar if staphylococcal food poisoning is suspected.</li>
<li>Smear stained by modified Auramine or Ziehl-Neelsen methods if Cryptosporidium is suspected.</li>
</ol>
<p>There are other routine media for stool culture e.g. Xylose lysine desoxycholate (XLD) medium. Any combination of these media can be used.</p>
<p>Culture examination Suspected non-lactose fermenting colonies on DCA and/or Hektoen agar are identified by their biochemical reactions and confirmed with specific antiserum agglutination test. Sensitivity tests are done on all isolates.</p>
<p>Culture report Report any enteric pathogen isolated. Some laboratories release the sensitivities only on request. This is recommended to minimise the abuse of antibiotics since some of the diarrhoeal diseases are self-limiting and may resolve without chemotherapy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="urine">URINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Normal urine is sterile but it may be contaminated inadvertently by the bacterial flora of the peri-urethral skin that may come in contact with the urine during micturition. A simple culture regimen is often adequate to isolate an infective agent in the urine. There are different types of urine samples:</p>
<ul>
<li>Mid stream urine (MSU)</li>
<li>Clean catch urine (CCU)</li>
<li>Catheter specimen of urine (CSU)</li>
<li>Supra-pubic aspiration (SPA)</li>
<li>Urethric aspiration.</li>
</ul>
<p>Urinary tract infections (UTI) are common in humans. The UTI ranges from asymptomatic infections to serious kidney diseases which can lead to shock and death (Table 9.17).</p>
<p>The laboratory diagnosis of UTI is done by counting the number of bacteria in a freshly voided urine. The bacteria colonise the anterior urethra and move up to the kidney. Most UTI's are thus ascending infections: Urethra → bladder → Ureters → Kidney. Some bacteria may also invade via the blood stream to the urinary tract from other sites.</p>
<p>Bacteriuria (bacteria in urine) is a common occurrence in pregnancy. The incidence of UTI varies mainly with age and sex. In adult life, females are more prone to the infection. Urinary tract in</p>
<p>Table 9.17 Urine: Disease conditions and their infectious agents</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agent</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Acute urinary tract infection</td><td>E.coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, other coliforms</td></tr><tr><td>Post catheterisation</td><td>Pseudomonas, Proteus and Klebsiella species</td></tr><tr><td>Anterior urethritis (men)</td><td>Neisseria gonorrhoeae, chlamydia, staphylococci and streptococci</td></tr><tr><td>UTI in young women</td><td>Staph.saprophyticus</td></tr><tr><td>Enteric fever</td><td>Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi</td></tr><tr><td>Leptospirosis</td><td>Leptospira interrogans</td></tr><tr><td>Tuberculosis</td><td>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>636 Bacteriology</p>
<p>fections often start as a result of bad toilet habits, incontinence, or sexual habits.</p>
<p><strong>A. Common pathogens</strong> <em>Escherichia coli</em>, <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em>, <em>Proteus mirabilis</em>, <em>Enterococcus</em> (Strep. faecalis), <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em>, <em>Enterobacter aerogenes</em>, <em>Staphylococcus saprophyticus</em>, <em>Salmonella</em> species.</p>
<p><strong>B. Casual pathogens</strong> <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>, <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em>.</p>
<p><strong>C. Commensal flora</strong> Normal urine may be contaminated with skin or faecal flora, <em>Acinetobacter</em> species, <em>Staphylococcus epidermidis</em>, <em>Diphtheroids</em>, <em>Mycobacterium smegmatis</em>.</p>
<p><em>Note the following terms</em></p>
<p>Cystitis — infection of the bladder.
Pyelonephritis — Infection of the kidney (associated with obstruction of the urinary tract).
Pyuria — pus cells in urine
Haematuria — blood in urine
Dysuria — painful urination
Bacteruria — bacteria in urine</p>
<p><strong>Collection of urine</strong> It is preferable, if possible, to collect the first urine passed by the patient in the morning for examination. This is because the specimen is most concentrated and so the most suitable for culture, microscopy and other tests.</p>
<p>For bacteriological examination, mid stream urine (MSU) is collected as follows:</p>
<p>Supply the patient with a sterile, dry, wide mouthed, leak proof screw-capped container. Advise the patient to clean the surrounding skin of the urethral opening. For female patients, they should cleanse the area around the urethral opening with clean water, dry the area and then with labia held back with the fingers, the first portion of the urine goes into the toilet, the mid stream is collected, and last portion again into the toilet.</p>
<p>Collect about 20 ml of urine and immediately screw on the cap.</p>
<p>The specimen should be delivered to the laboratory without delay.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>If the patient is in kidney failure, or a young child, 20 ml of urine may be difficult to produce.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If delay is inevitable, the urine should be kept in the refrigerator at 4°C.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If delay of more than one hour is anticipated, the urine should be collected in a container with boric acid as a preservative. Specimens preserved in boric acid need not be kept in the refrigerator. Boric acid is used at a concentration of 1% w/v and cells and bacteria are well preserved. It does not interfere with the estimation of glucose and protein. Use 0.1 g/10 ml of urine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If renal tuberculosis is indicated, collect the first urine (entire specimen) passed an three consecutive days, into an adequate, clean, dry, leak-proof container. Preserve urine in the refrigerator until all the three samples have been collected.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The process of catheterisation has an inherent risk of infection, and so the trend is toward obtaining urine specimens without catheterisation.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urine-microscopy">Urine Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine-microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Microscopic examination of urine is performed to detect and estimate pus cells, RBCs, casts, crystals, parasitic and fungal elements in urine. This topic is treated fully in Clinical Chemistry Section under Urinalysis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-tests">Additional tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Gram’s Stain for <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em> in urine if gonococcal infection is indicated</p>
<p>In acute urethritis in male, there are usually numerous pus cells in the urine. <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em> can be excluded when a Gram stained smear of the centrifuged urine deposit is examined.</p>
<p>Centrifuge about 10 ml of urine. Discard the supernatant, and make a smear of the sediment on a slide. Stain by Gram’s method.</p>
<p>Examine the smear; if Gram negative intracellular diplococci in pus cells are seen, this is rhoeae.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 637</p>
<p>Some workers routinely do Gram's stain on smears of sediments of urine that show pus cells and bacteria in wet preparation. We do not find any advantage in this practice.</p>
<p>(ii) Darkfield microscopy if Leptospirosis is suspected. Make a wet preparation for dark-field examination and examine for leptospires.</p>
<p>(iii) Ziehl-Neelsen stain if renal tuberculosis is suspected.</p>
<p>Make a smear of the sediment from three centrifuged early morning urine specimens.</p>
<p>Examine for acid fast bacilli (AFB).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urine-culture">Urine Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some laboratories do not culture urines which are biochemically and microscopically normal (negative). Some other laboratories prefer to culture all urine specimens irrespective of the microscopy and biochemical results, especially so as not to misdiagnose asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy.</p>
<p>Urine culture must be done if the specimen contains pus cells, bacteria, casts, protein, or show high alkaline or high acid reaction. A direct sensitivity test may be set up along with the culture.</p>
<p>Pyuria was once considered a sure sign of bacteriuria. It has however been found that many patients with significant bacteriuria do not have pyuria or that the presence of pus cells is intermittent. Several methods have been devised to assess and determine significant bacteriuria. These are semi-quantitative culture methods.</p>
<p>It is generally accepted that a bacterial count of more than 100,000 (10⁵) per millilitre of urine is a significant count and indicates an infection. This is a true bacteriuria. A count of less than 1000 (10³) bacteria per millilitre is taken to be the result of contamination and therefore non-significant, or that the urine was taken after chemotherapy has been initiated. Counts between 10³ and 10⁵ bacteria per millilitre are of doubtful significance because they may be caused by delayed delivery of specimen to the laboratory or severe contamination or suppression by antibiotic therapy.</p>
<p>There are several cultural quantitative techniques for determining bacteriuria. These methods include:</p>
<p>(a) Pour-plate method
(b) Surface-drop method (Miles and Misra)
(c) Standard loop method
(d) Filter paper method and
(e) Dip-inoculum (slide) method.</p>
<p>(a) The pour plate method is an excellent method of performing bacterial counts. A known quantity of urine is diluted in cooled molten nutrient agar, poured into petri dishes, allowed to set and then incubated. The colonies in or on the medium are counted.</p>
<p>(b) The surface drop method (Miles and Misra) is too laborious and time-consuming to be adopted in the routine laboratory. It is not used for routine quantitative culture of urine. There are other cheaper and simpler methods to use.</p>
<p>(c) Standard loop method is the most popular. This is a semiquantitative method. It is simple and cheap. Holding a calibrated wire loop vertically, dip the loop into a well mixed uncentrifuged urine and inoculate the medium of choice, e.g., cystein lactose electrolyte deficient (CLED) medium or MacConkey agar. The swarming of Proteus, is prohibited by CLED and MacConkey agar due to their lack of salt. Incubate the cultures overnight and count the colonies. A single colony is accepted to represent one colony forming unit (CFU).</p>
<p>Calculation of significant bacteriuria Using 0.001 ml loop, if a loopful of urine produces 100 colonies, the number of bacteria/ml</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.001</mn></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1000</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn><mo>×</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{l}
= 100 + 0.001 \\
= 100 \times 1000 = 100,000 \times (10^5)
\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.4em; vertical-align: -0.95em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.45em;"><span style="top: -3.61em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">0.001</span></span></span><span style="top: -2.41em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.95em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Therefore, with this loop, 100 colonies or more represent significant bacteriuria.</p>
<p>Similarly, with 0.002 ml wire loop, 200 colonies represent significant bacteriuria and with 0.003 ml wire loop, 300 colonies represent significant bacteriuria (Table 9.18).</p>
<p>Calibrated Wire Loop A calibrated wire loop can deliver 0.001 ml, 0.002 ml or 0.003 ml of urine. Pre-calibrated wire loops are commercially</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Volume of urine inoculated</th><th>CFUs = 10^{3} orgs/ml</th><th>CFUs = 10^{4} orgs/ml</th><th>CFUs = 10^{5} orgs/ml</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>0.001 ml (1/1000 ml, 1 μL)</td><td>1</td><td>20</td><td>200</td></tr><tr><td>0.002 ml (1/500 ml, 2 μL)</td><td>2</td><td>30</td><td>300</td></tr><tr><td>0.003 ml (1/333 ml, 3 μL)</td><td>3</td><td>33</td><td>333</td></tr><tr><td>0.0033 ml (1/300 ml, 3.3 μL)</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>available. But if this is not available, the volume held by a loop can be determined: Weigh a small container, e.g., bijou bottle, of distilled water. Using a loop of about 3 mm internal diameter, remove 100 loopfuls of water onto a blotting paper. Reweigh the container and the water. Calculate the difference in weight. The volume held by the loop is the difference in weight divided by 100. Perform the procedure three times and take the average of the three results.</p>
<p>(d) The filter paper method is now completely superseded by the standard loop technique or the Dip slide method. The principle is same as the standard wire loop which is based on accepting that a single colony represents one organism.</p>
<p>(e) The Dip slide method uses a plastic slide with raised edges to give an even thickness of medium. The slide has a grid to facilitate the counting of colonies. The whole slide assembly includes a clear plastic container into which the slide is enclosed. The slide is fixed to a screw cap of the container (Fig. 9.3).</p>
<p>Usually one side of the slide is covered with cystein lactose electrolyte deficient (CLED) medium or MacConkey agar and the other side with blood agar.</p>
<p>To use the Dip slide, it is important that the urine is fresh or preserved by refrigeration for not more than 12 hours. Remove the cap of the container and the attached slide is dipped in the fresh urine specimen. Excess fluid is allowed to drain. Return the slide to the container and the whole assembly is incubated overnight at 36°C.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-63c5dc00.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg">
Fig. 9.3 Dip slide method from 'urine'</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Some laboratories include blood agar in the initial culture of urine specimen. It helps in the rapid identification of pathogens; and supports the growth of those Gram positive organisms that grow poorly or not at all on CLED or MacConkey medium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Some laboratories make use of 1/2, 1/3 or 1/4 of plate media in order to cut down on cost.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 639</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-cultures">Additional cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Lowenstein Jensen (LJ) slope if <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em> is suspected.</p>
<p>Collect early morning urine for three consecutive days.</p>
<p>Pool all the three samples together and centrifuge.</p>
<p>Resuspend the sediment and add an equal volume of sodium hydroxide solution (4g/L)</p>
<p>Stand for 10 minutes to decontaminate the urine.</p>
<p>Mix well; inoculate 200 µL on an LJ medium slope.</p>
<p>Incubate the slope at 36°C for 4–6 weeks.</p>
<p>(2) Selenite F broth if typhoid fever is indicated.</p>
<p>Centrifuge about 10 ml of the urine in a sterile tube at high speed for 10 minutes.</p>
<p>Resuspend the sediment and transfer to a container of selenite F broth.</p>
<p>Incubate at 35–37°C overnight.</p>
<p>Subculture on to DCA and incubate at 35–37°C overnight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interpretation-of-bacterial-count-urine-quantitative-culture">Interpretation of bacterial count (Urine quantitative culture)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interpretation-of-bacterial-count-urine-quantitative-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If a standard 1/300 ml loop is used; and culture yielded 333 colony forming units (CFU).</p>
<p>i.e. 1/300 ml of the urine yielded 333 CFUs</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>333</mn><mo>≡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mtext>&nbsp;cfu/ml&nbsp;or&nbsp;</mtext><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mtext>&nbsp;organisms&nbsp;/&nbsp;ml.</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300 \times 333 \equiv (10^{5} \text{ cfu/ml or } 10^{5} \text{ organisms / ml.}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">333</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≡</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;cfu/ml&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;organisms&nbsp;/&nbsp;ml.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Since 100,000 CFU per ml is accepted as significant bacteriuria, therefore any count of 333 and above is significant.</p>
<p>Less than 33 CFU = &lt; 10⁴ organisms / ml</p>
<p>333 CFU = 10⁵ organisms / ml</p>
<p>&gt; 333 CFU = &gt; 10⁵ organisms / ml.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reporting">Reporting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Using 1/300 ml standard loop:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>If less than 33 CFU of any organism and if the patient is not on any antibiotic, report as ‘No significant Growth’.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If 33–330 CFU with no pus cells seen:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) When pure, report as 10⁴ organisms/ml with antibiotic sensitivity if the patient is on antibiotic therapy or pregnant.</p>
<p>(b) When mixed, report as mixed growth of doubtful significance with no antibiotic sensitivity.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>&gt; 330 CFU and pure, report as &gt; 10⁵ CFU/ml (or significant Growth) with antibiotic sensitivity.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If mixed growth of two different organisms of equal number of &gt; 330 CFU in the presence of pus cells, report as &gt; 10⁵ CFU / ml or as significant growth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If mixed growth of more than 2 different organisms in numbers &gt; 330 CFU and in the presence of pus cells, report as mixed growth and request for repeat specimen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In supra-pubic aspiration (SPA) specimens, any isolate is treated as significant and reported with sensitivity.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urogenital-sites">UROGENITAL SITES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urogenital-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The urogenital sites under consideration here are the urethra, cervix and vagina. Most specimens from these sites are collected with swabs, but in some cases specimens may be fluid or pus from genital ulcers and buboes (Table 9.19).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urethral-swabs">Urethral Swabs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urethral-swabs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>C. Commensals usually encountered in urethral specimens <em>Diphtheroids, Acinetobacter</em> species, enterobacteria, Skin flora.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cervical-swab-non-puerperal">Cervical Swab (Non-Puerperal)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cervical-swab-non-puerperal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vaginal-swabs">Vaginal Swabs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vaginal-swabs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
