<p><strong>Medium</strong> Christensen’s medium. This may be solid or broth (Chapter 25).</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the entire surface of the Christensen’s urea slope.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C in the water bath or the incubator.</li>
<li>Examine at four hours if incubated in the water bath and after overnight if in the incubator.</li>
<li>Observe the red-pink colour of urease positive test.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong> If the test incubated in the water bath, the negative after four hours, then leave it overnight.</p>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
<em>Proteus vulgaris</em> - Positive
<em>E. coli</em> - Negative</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Identification Methods 657</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ce125a9a">♦ MOTILITY INDOLE UREA (MIU) MEDIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ce125a9a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This semi-solid medium is used to determine if an organism is motile or non motile; urease positive or negative, and indole positive or negative.</p>
<ol>
<li>Using a straight wire, inoculate a tube of sterile MIU sloppy medium with the test organism. Place an indole paper strip in the neck of the tube and stopper the tube.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C overnight.</li>
<li>Motility is shown by diffused turbidity in the medium.</li>
<li>Indole: Indole paper strip turns red if positive.</li>
<li>A red pink colour in the medium indicates positive urease production.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aea4e66b">♦ VOGES-PROSKAUER (VP) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aea4e66b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This test is employed to differentiate some enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Some bacteria ferment carbohydrates with the production of acetoin (acetyl methyl carbinol). Under alkaline condition, the acetoin is oxidised to diacetyl which gives a pink colour with the reagent.</p>
<p>The test is usually done in conjunction with the methyl red (MR) test. The production of acetoin usually results in inadequate acid concentration during fermentation to give an MR positive reaction. Therefore, an organism is either MR or VP positive.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> The same as for MR test</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<p><strong>Method I</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate about 2 ml of the medium with the test organism.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 48 hours.</li>
<li>Add 1 ml of 10% potassium hydroxide</li>
<li>Leave at room temperature for one hour.</li>
</ol>
<p>Pink colour -Positive</p>
<p>No colour change -Negative</p>
<p><strong>Method II</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate 2 ml of the medium.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 48 hours.</li>
<li>Add a pinch of creatine to the culture. Mix well.</li>
<li>Add 2.5 ml of 40% potassium hydroxide. Shake well.</li>
</ol>
<p>Pink colour -Positive</p>
<p>No colour change -Negative</p>
<p><strong>Method III</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the medium</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 48 hours.</li>
<li>Add 3 ml of 5% solution of alpha-naphthol in absolute ethanol.</li>
<li>Add 1 ml of 40% potassium hydroxide</li>
</ol>
<p>Bright pink colour in five minutes -Positive</p>
<p>No colour change -Negative</p>
<p><strong>Controls</strong></p>
<p>Klebsiella pneumoniae -Positive</p>
<p>Escherichia coli -Negative</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Optimum results are obtained if the cultures are incubated at 30°C instead of 37°C.</li>
<li>An organism belonging to the enterobacterial group is either methyl red positive and Voges-Proskauer negative or methyl red negative and Voges-Proskauer positive.</li>
<li>Creatine and alpha naphthol act as catalysts in the test.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="779c75cd">♦ DETECTION OF MOTILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#779c75cd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This test is performed to distinguish the motile organisms from the non-motile ones.</p>
<p>Motility is detected by microscopic examination or by culture in a semi-solid medium.</p>
<p>Microscopic examination for motility is described in Chapter 3.</p>
<p>In semi-solid agar medium, motile bacteria 'swarm' and give a diffuse growth that is recognisable with the naked eye.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>658 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Medium A semi-solid agar medium should contain 0.2–0.4% agar which is dissolved in nutrient broth or peptone water. Distribute in about 10 ml amounts and sterilise.</p>
<p>Test Using a straight wire, stab inoculate the motility medium with the test organism.</p>
<p>Incubate the test under the appropriate growth conditions.</p>
<p>Examine for motility at intervals of six hours up to 48 hours.</p>
<p>Result</p>
<p>Motility - diffuse hazy growth that spreads through out the medium, making it look opaque.</p>
<p>Non-motility - Growth is confined to the line of inoculation.</p>
<p>◆ NEW CONCEPTS AND DEVELOPMENTS IN THE IDENTIFICATION METHODS</p>
<p>In recent years, several systems for the identification of bacteria have been developed and are available. This new concept and approach enables the routine diagnostic laboratory to minimise, and in some cases, eliminate delays in the identification and speciation of isolated organisms. Essentially, some of these systems (e.g., API, Gibco) are a series of miniaturised usual biochemical tests. They are in the form of dehydrated substrates in plastic cups which are reconstituted when a suspension of the bacterium under investigation is added. After</p>
<p>24 or 48 hours of incubation, a numerically coded biochemical profile of the bacterium is obtained by reading positive and negative test results. The profile is scored in a numerical code which is then read from a profile index. Some of these systems are agar based, for example, Enterotube system, which consists of a plastic compartmentalised tube divided into 11 chambers each containing media substrate. Others, for example Minitek, make use of individually impregnated discs of paper with various substrates and combined in a plastic tray.</p>
<p>The API system is widely used. It consists of a plastic strip with miniaturised cups containing specific test media and reagents. A suspension of the organism in water or saline or specialised reagents is used to inoculate the test strips. One single organism can thus be speciated by various test parameters. The system is usually incubated at 35–37°C for 18 hours or in some cases, for 48 hours.</p>
<p>The other well known system is the Mast ID system which uses modified but traditional media supplied in sachets.</p>
<p>All the systems are able to provide identification of common pathogens such as staphylococci, streptococci, enterobacteria, non-enteric Gram negative bacteria and anaerobes. The systems are very convenient but expensive.</p>
<p>The newest identification tool for micro-organisms is the molecular assay techniques. The most commonly used techniques are: polymerase chain reaction (PCR), ligase chain reaction (LCR) and genetic probe assays.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 11</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="systematic-bacteriology">Systematic Bacteriology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systematic-bacteriology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The manipulation of bacterial colonies of organisms isolated from clinical specimens and their exact identification depend to a large extent, on the laboratory scientist knowledge of theoretical bacteriology. The scientist should have basic understanding of disease aetiology to guide him in the use of different techniques to help him interpret his findings. The general and specific characteristics of bacteria present valuable information for identification. Some of this information is gained from observation. The action of bacteria on various substrates derives from the possession by the bacteria, of specific enzymes that bring about decomposition and fermentation. The observed change in the identification test may be known but the result cannot be deduced and may lead to further identification tests. Many other facts and data of diagnostic importance are of necessity to be memorised. For example, the Gram's stain reaction and morphology of the most commonly encountered bacteria should be at the finger-tips of the bench scientist.</p>
<p>A biochemical reaction may be regarded as positive or negative. But within a species, it is possible that 90% of the strains are positive. Where only 50% of the strains are positive for a particular reaction, it is not considered a useful identification parameter; however, if less than 10% are positive it is traditional to regard the test as negative and so it becomes a useful parameter for that species.</p>
<p>Diagnostic tables of biochemical reactions of many genera and species, and percentage of strains of a species that give positive, negative or late reactions with variety of reagents are available in specialist textbooks. There are however, conventional signs to indicate biochemical reactions that a practising bacteriologist should be familiar with:</p>
<ul>
<li>= 90% are positive in 1–2 days</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>= &lt; 10% are positive in 1–2 days
(+) = a delayed positive reaction in 3–4 days
+/- = most strains are positive and fewer are negative
-/+ = most strains are negative and fewer are positive
d = variable reactions with different strains
+w = weakly positive</li>
</ul>
<p>For the bench bacteriologist to function effectively, it is worth trying to remember some important species or strain specific reactions e.g. the oxidase + reaction of Ps. aeruginosa, or the urease + reaction of Proteus species, or the coagulase + reaction of Staph. aureus or the non-motility of Shigella species. A knowledge of majority reactions is very useful in the systematic identification of bacteria. A few discriminative tests may easily help to differentiate between related species.</p>
<p>The systemic approach to the identification of an isolated bacterium is referred to as Systemic Bacteriology. The bench bacteriologist combines</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>660 Bacteriology</p>
<p>his general knowledge of bacteria and the clinical information (including the anatomical site of specimen) as contained in the request form to initiate a systematic identification of an isolate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-in-systematic-bacteriology">STEPS IN SYSTEMATIC BACTERIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-in-systematic-bacteriology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The first rule in bacterial identification is that the organism must be in pure culture. A single representative colony is picked and subcultured for purity and identification tests are done from the purified culture. If the culture is not pure, the tests are not valid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="colonial-morphology">Colonial morphology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#colonial-morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Usually, with careful observation of the colonial morphology of the organism, an experienced bacteriologist may know or have a good idea of the likely identity of the bacterium. Reaction on a differential medium may be helpful e.g. lactose fermenting or non-lactose fermenting colonies; haemolytic action or non-haemolytic action on blood agar. The presence of pigmentation is also taken into account. The practice of sniffing the culture to determine any specific odour is now frowned upon as bad laboratory practice for safety reasons. However, the characteristic odour of some bacteria is a useful diagnostic guide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="gram-stain">Gram stain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gram-stain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Gram stain is a very useful procedure in systematic bacteriology. For a beginner or an inexperienced laboratory scientist the first step in the arduous task of bacterial identification is the Gram stain. The Gram staining technique must be properly mastered. A badly stained smear can be very misleading. For instance, under decolourised gram negative bacilli become gram positive, while over decolourised gram positive cocci will be read as gram negative cocci. If the first step is wrong, the choice of subsequent tests may be wrong. Gram stain, when properly done, is a useful guide in the initiation of tests required for identifying an isolate.</p>
<p>Gram stain reaction will usually point to the next set of tests to be done. It is the rule not to name or identify any bacterium by the Gram stain result, especially for a beginner. The morphology of the stained bacteria, in many cases, is not definitive. Even a trained eye sometimes gets confused by the shape and size of the stained bacteria. However, an experienced hand, who, for example, recognises lactose fermenting colonies, may not need to do a Gram stain; he can confidently go on with the other tests. Figure 11.1 shows an example of identification scheme for Gram positive cocci.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biochemical-tests">Biochemical Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biochemical-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gram stain result determines the type of biochemical tests to be done. These tests can be in the form of any of the various identification systems such as the API.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serological-tests">Serological Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serological-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>From the results of the biochemical reactions, the identity of some bacterial species may need to be confirmed with a serological test. This is true of enteric pathogenes such as <em>Salmonella</em> and <em>Shigella</em> species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-guidelines">General Guidelines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-guidelines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The laboratory should keep among its reference books, a reference identification manual. It is most helpful where full identification of a bacterial isolate is carried out on a routine basis. The bench bacteriologist usually has a feeling of satisfaction when he successfully identifies a bacterium, especially if it is one of the rare organisms.</p>
<p>Systematic bacteriology is the core of the work of a clinical bacteriology laboratory. It requires patience and perseverance. It keeps the bacteriologist on the alert to always remember some specific remaining of bacteria, the laboratory scientist who is confused than others.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Systematic Bacteriology 661</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-338b417b.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 11.1 An example of identification scheme for Gram positive cocci</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 12 Gram Positive Cocci</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-83cbaf1f.jpeg" alt="img-71.jpeg">
Fig 12.1 Simple classification of Gram Positive Cocci</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aerobic-gram-positive-cocci">AEROBIC GRAM POSITIVE COCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aerobic-gram-positive-cocci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of organisms belong to two main families: <em>Micrococcaceae</em> and <em>Streptococcaceae</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="family-micrococcaeae">FAMILY MICROCOCCAEAE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#family-micrococcaeae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> Members of this family are Gram positive cocci in regular or irregular clusters, aerobic or facultative anaerobic, non-motile, non-spore forming and non-capsulated. There are two medically important genera: <em>Micrococcus</em> and <em>Staphylococcus</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-micrococcus">GENUS MICROCOCCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-micrococcus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Micrococci</em> are Gram positive cocci of irregular sizes in irregular clusters or tetrads. Generally, they are of little medical importance.</p>
<p><strong>Normal habitat</strong> Micrococci are found in soil, water as well as on the skin.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> They grow more slowly than the staphylococci. They are strict aerobes, and so do not ferment glucose anaerobically. They are novobiocin resistant.</p>
<p><strong>Pathogenicity</strong> They are saprophytes and commensals. They are known to cause a form of urinary tract infection in young women.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Positive Cocci 663</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-staphylococcus">GENUS STAPHYLOCOCCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-staphylococcus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Type Species</strong> <em>Staph. aureus</em></p>
<p><em>Staph. aureus</em> is the most medically important member in terms of pathogenicity of the group. Two other less important members are <em>Staph. epidermis</em> and <em>Staph. saprophyticus</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staphylococcus-aureus">Staphylococcus aureus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staphylococcus-aureus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Normal habitat</strong> Staphylococci are commonly present as parasites of man and they form part of bacterial flora of the skin, upper respiratory tract and intestinal tract. <em>Staph. aureus</em> is carried in the nose of 20–40% of healthy individuals.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> They are Gram positive cocci in clusters, pairs or singles. They grow readily on a variety of media and ferment many carbohydrates without gas. Colonies may be white, grey or golden yellow. The species name aureus is derived from the Latin word, ‘aureus’ meaning golden. They are halophilic (salt loving).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Staph. aureus</em> causes</p>
<ol>
<li>Abscesses, boils and impetigo: It is a common cause of secondary infection of ulcers, burns, wound, skin disorders and insect bites.</li>
<li>Conjunctivitis, especially in neonates.</li>
<li>Septicaemia, endocarditis and osteomyelitis</li>
<li>Pneumonia and empyema</li>
<li>Cross infections in hospitals</li>
<li>Food poisoning due to the production of enterotoxin B.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="toxins-and-enzymes-produced-by-staph-aureus">Toxins and Enzymes Produced by <em>Staph. aureus</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxins-and-enzymes-produced-by-staph-aureus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pathogenicity of <em>Staph. aureus</em> depends on its ability to multiply and spread widely in tissues, and on the production of many extracellular substances—toxins and enzymes. These substances include:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Exotoxin</strong> A thermolabile mixture that contains several haemolysins (lytic toxins) that destroy red blood cells and platelets.</li>
<li><strong>Leucocidin</strong> A soluble substance that kills exposed white blood cells. It is heatlabile.</li>
<li><strong>Enterotoxin</strong> A soluble material that is produced by about 30 to 50% of strains of <em>Staph. aureus</em>. It is a protein that can withstand boiling for about 30 minutes. <em>Staph. aureus</em> grows and forms the toxin in food stuff and causes vomiting and diarrhoea when such food is ingested. The toxin acts on the central nervous system (in the vomit centre) and not, like other enterotoxins, on the intestinal epithelium. There are four distinct antigen groups (A-D) of these enterotoxins.</li>
<li><strong>Coagulase</strong> <em>Staph. aureus</em> produces an enzyme, coagulase, which clots fibrinogen in plasma to form fibrin. The demonstration of coagulase is the best single test to identify a pathogenic <em>Staph. aureus</em>.</li>
<li><strong>Deoxyribonuclease (DNAse)</strong> This enzyme is capable of destroying deoxyribomucleic acid (DNA).</li>
<li><strong>Hyaluronidase</strong> This is a spreading factor that aids the <em>Staph. aureus</em> to invade the tissue.</li>
<li><strong>Staphylokinase</strong> This causes fibrinolysis.</li>
<li><strong>Beta-lactamase</strong> This is an enzyme that inactivates antibiotics such as penicillin resulting in penicillin resistance.</li>
<li><strong>Exfoliatin</strong> This substance causes skin to peel off in scalded skin syndrome.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staphylococcus-epidermidis">Staphylococcus epidermidis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staphylococcus-epidermidis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Staph. epidermidis</em> is generally non-pathogenic.</p>
<p><strong>Normal habitat</strong> <em>Staph. epidermidis</em> is a normal flora of the skin. It may also be found in the mouth and in dust.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> Like <em>Staph. aureus</em>, it grows readily on a variety of media. The colonies are usually whiter than those of <em>Staph. aureus</em>. For this reason, it was previously referred to as <em>Staph. albus</em> (from the Latin word “albus” meaning white).</p>
<p><strong>Pathogenicity</strong> <em>Staph. epidermidis</em> is commonly encountered as a contaminant or commensal in</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>specimens from skin lesions, wounds, burns, throat, sputum and faeces. However, in some special circumstances, they are regarded pathogenic when linked to peritonitis in patients on peritoneal dialysis; chronic septicaemia or endocarditis in patients having heart surgery or fitted with artificial heart valve; bacteraemia following infection of indwelling catheters, shunts and annulae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staphylococcus-saprophyticus">Staphylococcus saprophyticus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staphylococcus-saprophyticus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This species is widely distributed in the environment. It is usually associated with cystitis, pyelonephritis and acute urethritis in young women.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis-of-staphylococal-infections">LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS OF STAPHYLOCOCAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis-of-staphylococal-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include skin swab, pus, sputum or tracheal aspirate, blood culture, cerebero-spinal fluid.</p>
<p>When food-poisoning is suspected, faeces, vomitus and remains of food are also submitted.</p>
<p>Anterior nasal swabs are collected to detect <em>Staph. aureus</em> carriers.</p>
<p><strong>Stained smears</strong> Gram positive cocci of uniform size about 1µm in diameter, and in clusters, pairs or singly. (Fig 12.2).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c2ba5390.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg">
Fig. 12.2 Gram positive cocci in clusters in pus</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Staphylococci grow well on most routine bacteriological media aerobically in CO₂ enriched atmosphere and less well anaerobically. The optimum temperature of growth is 37°C but can grow in a range of 10–42°C. The colonies on most media are round, smooth, raised and measuring about 1–2 mm in diameter.</p>
<p><em>Staph. aureus</em> colonies are golden yellow to creamy-white; some strains are beta-haemolytic on blood agar. <em>Staph. epidermidis</em> (Staph.albus) colonies are white.</p>
<p><em>Staph. saprophyticus</em> colonies are white or yellow.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Some colonies develop pigment on prolonged incubation at room temperature (20–25°C).</li>
<li>Do not use colony pigmentation to differentiate <em>Staph. aureus</em> from <em>Staph. epidermidis</em>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="selective-media-for-staph-aureus">Selective media for <em>Staph. aureus</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-media-for-staph-aureus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Manintol salt agar: <em>Staph. aureus</em> produces yellow colonies.</li>
<li>10% salt cooked meat medium.</li>
<li>Lithium chloride and tellurite (Ludlam’s) medium. <em>Staph. aureus</em> reduces potassium tellurite in the medium to produce black colonies.</li>
</ol>
<p>These media are used to recover <em>Staph. aureus</em> from contaminated specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-media-for-staph-aureus">Identification media for <em>Staph. aureus</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-media-for-staph-aureus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNAse) agar.</li>
<li>Phenolphthalein phosphate agar.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnostic-tests-for-staph-aureus-and-the-expected-results">Diagnostic tests for <em>Staph. aureus</em> and the expected results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnostic-tests-for-staph-aureus-and-the-expected-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Catalase test = +</li>
<li>Coagulase test = +</li>
<li>Oxidation-Fermentation test = F</li>
</ol>
<p>(Fermentation)</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Manintol fermentation = +</li>
<li>DNAse test = +</li>
<li>Phosphatase test = +</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 12.1 shows the differential tests for</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-fd9e544c.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Positive Cocci 665</p>
<p>Table 12.1 Differential tests for Staphylococcus</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Staphylococcus aureus</th><th>Staphylococcus epidermidis</th><th>Staphylococcus saprophyticus</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Coagulase</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>D-Mannitol Fermentation</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>±</td></tr><tr><td>Phosphatase</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>±</td></tr><tr><td>Novobiocin</td><td>S</td><td>S</td><td>R</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>S = sensitive; R = resistant</p>
<p>Bacteriophage typing of <em>Staph. aureus</em> Phage typing of <em>Staph. aureus</em> is done to investigate cross infections in hospitals and staphylococcal food poisoning. Strains are generally distinguished by their patterns of susceptibility to lysis by any of the universally accepted set of 23 standard typing phages. Staphylococcal phage typing is by a pattern method:</p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the strain of <em>Staph. aureus</em> to be typed on nutrient agar to give a confluent (lawn) growth.</li>
<li>Apply the phages dropwise at their routine test dilutions (RTD) to the seeded plate.</li>
<li>Incubate overnight at 30°C.</li>
<li>Examine the culture plate for the degree of lysis by each phage. Some phages will not produce lysis at all.</li>
</ol>
<p>The phage type of the staphylococcal strain is reported as the combined designations of the phages which strongly lyse it. Thus, if the strain is lysed by 52, 52A and 80, it is expressed as 52/52A/80. Phage typing is usually carried out by a central reference laboratory.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Many strains of <em>Staph. aureus</em> produce the enzyme penicillinase (a beta lactamase) which inactivates penicillin and renders them penicillin-resistant. For such strains, chemotherapy is effected with methicilin, cloxacillin, flucloxacillin and the cephalosporins. Ordinarily <em>Staph. aureus</em> is sensitive to erythromycin, lincomycin, penicillins, vancomycin, fucidin, clindamycin, rifampicin, cephalosporins, ciprofloxacin.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>(i) <em>Staph. epidermidis</em> is usually more resistant to antibiotics than <em>Staph. aureus</em>.
(ii) <em>Staph. saprophyticus</em>, when considered pathogenic, is also more sensitive than <em>Staph. aureus</em>.
(iii) There is an emergence of strains of <em>Staph. aureus</em> which are resistant to methicillin. They are commonly referred to as ‘methicillin resistant <em>Staph. aureus</em> (MRSA).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="streptococci">STREPTOCOCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#streptococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="family-streptococcaceae">Family Streptococcaceae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#family-streptococcaceae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> Streptococci are Gram positive cocci arranged in pairs, short or long chains. They are facultative anaerobes, growth being enhanced in microaerophilic condition. These are non motile, non sporing and catalase negative. Some species produce haemolysis.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Catalase test is useful for differentiating streptococci from staphylococci, which are catalase positive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-streptococcus">GENUS STREPTOCOCCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-streptococcus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-strep-pyogenes">Type species <em>Strep. pyogenes</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-strep-pyogenes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="classification-of-streptococci">Classification of Streptococci<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-streptococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Streptococci can be classified into obligate anaerobes and the facultative anaerobes. The tra</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>666 Bacteriology</p>
<p>ditional classification depends on the type of haemolysis produced on blood agar media. Three types of haemolysis are recognised:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Alpha (α) haemolytic streptococci produce partial haemolysis which is indicated by green discolouration of the medium. They show small zone of partial haemolysis around the colonies about 1–2 mm wide. The discolouration is due to reduced haemoglobin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Beta (β) haemolytic streptococci produce well defined, clear zone of complete haemolysis (about 2–4 mm wide) around the colonies. Haemolysis is enhanced under anaerobic incubation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gamma (γ) or non haemolytic streptococci produce no change in the medium.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Most of the medically important streptococci are beta haemolytic and are generally referred to as 'haemolytic streptococci'. Most of the alpha haemolytic streptococci except <em>Strep. pneumoniae</em> are resident bacterial flora in the upper respiratory tract, though they are capable of causing opportunistic infections. They are generally referred to as the 'viridans' group. The gamma streptococci comprise the group generally referred to as the 'enterococcus' group which includes <em>Enterococcus faecalis</em>.</p>
<p>Lancefield groups of Streptococci In 1933, Lancefield classified the haemolytic streptococci serologically into groups based on the nature of specific carbohydrate (C carbohydrate) antigen on the bacterial cell wall. This antigen can be identified using group specific antiserum. The carbohydrate identification enables a strain to be placed in one of the 20 Lancefield groups designated A–V excluding I and J.</p>
<p>Table 12.2 shows differentiation of streptococci.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>S. pyogenes</th><th>S. agalactiae</th><th>S. pneumoniae</th><th>Viridans streptococci</th><th>E. faecalis</th><th>S. milleri</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Haemolysis</td><td>β</td><td>β</td><td>α</td><td>α</td><td>β/-</td><td>α/-</td></tr><tr><td>Soluble haemolysin (S)</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Reduced haemolysin (O)</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Bile solubility</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Bacitracin-sensitive (0.05 units/disc)</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Optochin-sensitive (5 μg/disc) (ethyl hydrocyprein)</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Heat-resistance</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Growth on 1% bile</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Growth on 10% bile</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>V</td></tr><tr><td>Growth on 40% bile</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>V</td></tr><tr><td>Inulin fermentation</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>V</td></tr><tr><td>Lancefield group</td><td>A</td><td>B</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>V</td></tr><tr><td>Nitrofurantoin resistance</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-(Q)</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>CAMP test</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>OK</td><td>D</td><td>ACFG</td></tr><tr><td>V = Variable</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Positive Cocci 667</p>
<p>The most important beta-haemolytic streptococci in terms of human infections belong to group A and they are referred to as Strep. pyogenes. The group A streptococci are further sub divided (Griffith typing) into over 60 strains based on the protein (M.T and R) antigens on the cell surface.</p>
<p>Normal habitat Streptococci are commonly found in water, dust, vegetation, milk and milk products.</p>
<p>Viridans streptococci and a few strains of groups A, C and G are found as commensals in the upper respiratory tract. Group D Streptococci form part of the normal flora of the intestinal tract, and group B streptococci may be present in the female genital tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Strep. pyogenes (Group A) Strep. pyogenes causes pyogenic infections with a tendency to spread locally, along lymphatics and through the blood stream. S. pyogenes causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Respiratory infections This species causes acute sore throat (tonsillitis and pharyngitis) and peritonsilar abscess (quinsy). Tonsilitis is common in children and young adults. 'Scarlet' fever is another form of upper respiratory infection that is caused by the erythrogenic toxin produced by Strep. pyogenes. This causes characteristic erythematous rashes. It is uncommon in the tropics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ear infections Otitis media and mastoiditis are suppurative complications as a result of spread of the organism from the throat.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Skin infections Strep. pyogenes causes a variety of skin infections—wound infections, cellulitis, burns, erysipelas and impetigo.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Puerperal sepsis (genital infections) Strep. pyogenes is a common cause of puerperal sepsis; the infection is usually introduced from outside the genital canal through carriers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Septicaemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Endocarditis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abscesses of organs such as brain, lung, liver and kidney.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-suppurative complications Acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis are two important complications of Strep. pyogenes infection. These two sequelae set in 1–3 weeks after the acute infection, the lesions are thus sterile and the organisms no longer detectable.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acute glomerulonephritis is the inflammation of the kidney due to the deposition of immune complexes in the glomeruli. It is a post skin and throat infection condition.</li>
<li>Rheumatic fever is a post respiratory streptococcal infection condition. It is a serious complication that may lead to chronic rheumatic heart disease if there is damage to the heart valve.</li>
</ul>
<p>Enzymes and toxins produced by Strep. pyogenes Strep. pyogenes produces several enzymes and (exo) toxins which enhance its virulence. These substances include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Haemolysins They are of two types:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Haemolysin O</li>
<li>Haemolysin S</li>
</ul>
<p>Haemolysin O is oxygen labile (i.e. inactivated by oxygen) and haemolyses red blood cells under anaerobic condition. It is antigenic and stimulates the production of antistreptolysin O (ASO) in the serum.</p>
<p>Streptolysin S is oxygen stable, responsible for the haemolysis seen on blood agar under aerobic conditions. It is non-antigenic.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Streptokinase (Fibrinolysin) causes lysis of fibrin. During infection, it breaks down the fibrin barrier around the lesions and so facilitates spread of infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyaluronidase breaks the hyaluronic acid of tissues. This favours the spread of the infection along the intercellular spaces. This enzyme is antigenic and specific antibody appears in convalescent serum.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>668 Bacteriology</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Deoxyribonuclease (streptodornase or DNAse) causes hydrolysis of DNA and there are four types, namely A, B, C and D. Type B is the most antigenic. The enzyme helps to liquefy thick pus and may be responsible for the thin serous character of streptococcal exudates.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diphosphopyridinenucleotidase (DPNase) which is now known as nicotinamide adenine dinuleotidase (NADase) acts on the co-enzyme DPN to release nicotinamide by killing the leucocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Erythrogenic (Dick) toxin causes erythematous skin rashes in scarlet fever. It produces local erythema on intradermal injection of small doses in man. It is heat stable and only inactivated after boiling for one hour. It is an antigenic protein that is specifically neutralised by antibodies present in convalescent serum. This is the basis of susceptibility and diagnostic test (Dick test) for scarlet fever.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Dick test</p>
<p>(i) Inject 0.1–0.2 ml of an adequately diluted preparation (test dose) of the toxin intradermally into one forearm.</p>
<p>(ii) Inject 0.1–0.2 ml of heat inactivated preparation of the toxin into the other forearm as a control.</p>
<p>(iii) An erythematous flush appearing within 8–12 hours on the first arm and fading after 24 hours is a positive result which indicates susceptibility to scarlet fever.</p>
<p>In individuals who have circulating antitoxin, the toxin is neutralised and so no local reaction occurs. The Schultz-Charlton reaction is a test designed to differentiate scarlet fever from other similar infections. The test which is now obsolete, consists of injecting 0.1–0.2 ml of antitoxin or convalescent serum from a case of scarlet fever, into the erythematous skin rash. Blanching occurs at the site of injection. This is due to the specific neutralisation of the erythrogenic toxin.</p>
<p>Strep. agalactiae (Group B) Group B streptococci are important pathogens of cattle in which they cause bovine mastitis. In humans, they cause the following diseases:</p>
<ol>
<li>In neonates—septicaemia, pneumonia, and meningitis</li>
<li>Septic abortion and puerperal sepsis</li>
<li>Otitis media, arthritis and urinary tract infection especially in children</li>
</ol>
<p>Group C This group causes mainly animal diseases but may cause the following infections in man:</p>
<ol>
<li>Pharyngitis and other respiratory diseases</li>
<li>Impetigo, wound infections</li>
<li>Puerperal sepsis and urinary tract diseases</li>
<li>Wound infections</li>
<li>Occasionally, urogenital infections</li>
</ol>
<p>Group D These organisms are normally found in the bowel. They cause:</p>
<ol>
<li>Urinary tract infections</li>
<li>Endocarditis</li>
<li>Ear infections</li>
<li>Suppurative abdominal lesions</li>
<li>Wound infections</li>
<li>Occasionally, meningitis</li>
</ol>
<p>Group F This group of organisms may cause:</p>
<ol>
<li>Wound infections</li>
<li>Deep abscesses</li>
<li>Sinusitis</li>
<li>Meningitis</li>
</ol>
<p>Group G Group G streptococci cause similar infections to Group C.</p>
<p>◆ LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS OF STREPTOCOCCAL INFECTIONS</p>
<p>Specimens Specimens include throat swab, pus, blood, ear swab, wound swab, CSF (from neonates) urine or any other specimen depending on the site of infection.</p>
<p>Stained smears Gram positive cocci in short chains, in pairs or singly (Fig. 12.3). Long chains are formed in fluid media.</p>
<p>Culture Majority of streptococci grow aerobically and anaerobically between 22°–42°C. The optimum temperature of growth is 37°C. Enterococci</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Positive Cocci 669</p>
<p>will grow between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>15</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>45</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15^{\circ} - 45^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7574em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. <p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-e68f0d0e.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg">

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="strep-pyogenes-group-a">Strep. pyogenes (Group A)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#strep-pyogenes-group-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>On blood agar, <em>Strep. pyogenes</em> is beta-haemolytic, and it produces wide zones of haemolysis. A provisional diagnosis may be done during primary incubation using bacitracin disc.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-test-for-group-a-streptococcus">Identification test for Group A Streptococcus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-test-for-group-a-streptococcus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A filter paper disc dipped in a solution of bacitracin (0.05 units/disc), and dried, is placed on the surface of the inoculated blood agar. After an overnight incubation a clear zone of inhibition is seen around the disc and this shows that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin. This test is only for the provisional diagnosis of Group A Streptococcus.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Beta-haemolytic activity is preferably done on blood agar prepared from sheep, horse or goat blood.</li>
<li>Haemolysis is enhanced under anaerobic incubation.</li>
<li>Strep. pyogenes does not grow on MacConkey or CLED agar.</li>
</ol>
<p>Selective medium for isolation of <em>Strep. pyogenes</em> Crystal violet blood agar. This is blood agar containing 1:50,000 crystal violet.</p>
<p>This dye will inhibit the growth of staphylococci and allow the streptococci to grow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="strep-agalactiae-group-b">Strep. agalactiae (Group B)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#strep-agalactiae-group-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>On blood agar, <em>Strep. agalactiae</em> produces beta haemolysis which is much enhanced when incubated anaerobically. The colonies are larger than those of Group A.</p>
<p>Few strains of <em>Strep. agalactiae</em> grow on CLED as well as on MacConkey agar.</p>
<p>Selective medium for <em>Strep. agalactiae</em> Gentamicin blood agar is used to selectively isolate Group B streptococcus from urogenital specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-test-for-strep-agalactiae">Identification test for <em>Strep. agalactiae</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-test-for-strep-agalactiae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The CAMP test is a specific identification test for the Group B streptococci. The CAMP test is described in Chapter 10.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="group-c-streptococci">Group C Streptococci<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#group-c-streptococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The colonial appearance of Group C streptococci on blood agar is similar to that of Group A. They are however resistant to bacitracin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="group-d-streptococci-enterococci">Group D Streptococci (Enterococci)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#group-d-streptococci-enterococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several species in this group of streptococci. On blood agar, they may show beta, alpha or gamma (no) haemolysis. They have a common antigen. Unlike other streptococci, they grow on MacConkey agar as small dark red colonies. Members of this group are divided into (a) enterococci and (b) non-enterococci. The enterococcus group includes species such as <em>Strep. faecalis</em>, <em>Strep. facium</em>, <em>Strep. durans</em>, <em>Strep. avium</em>. The non-enterococcus species include <em>Strep. bovis</em> and <em>Strep. equinus</em>. The enterococcus species are resistant to penicillin while the non-enterococci are sensitive to it.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>The current nomenclature of the <em>Enterococcus group</em> is listed in the Appendix.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>670 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests-for-group-d-streptococci">Identification tests for Group D Streptococci<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests-for-group-d-streptococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Growth in 6.5% salt (NaCl) broth:
Inoculate the broth and incubate at 35°C for 24–48 hours.
Growth is indicated by turbidity or a change of colour due to a bromocresol purple indicator in the medium. Only enterococci grow in this medium while the non-enterococci Group D do not.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bile-aesculin test (Chapter 10): All species in Group D are positive for this test.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Growth at 45°C: All species will grow at 45°C.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 12.3 shows differentiation of Group D streptococci.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viridans-streptococci">Viridans Streptococci<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viridans-streptococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of streptococci produces alpha haemolysis on blood agar. Members of the group include <em>Strep. salivarius</em>, <em>Strep. mutans</em>, <em>Strep. sanguis</em>, <em>Strep. mitis</em> and <em>Strep. milleri</em>. They are part of the resident normal flora of the throat and mouth. Though normally non-pathogenic, they are capable of causing sub-acute bacterial endocarditis (SBE) also known as infective endocarditis. They enter blood circulation through dental abscess or trauma such as tooth extraction and cause SBE in persons with predisposing factors such as valvular heart disease. Such transient bacteriania may not cause any harm in healthy individuals. They cause about 80% of cases of SBE and 50% of all cases of bacterial endocarditis.</p>
<p>On blood agar, they form colonies of varied sizes with zone of greyish-green alpha haemolysis around them.</p>
<p>Table 12.2 shows how the viridans group differs from other streptococci.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-test-for-strep-viridans">Identification test for Strep. viridans<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-test-for-strep-viridans" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Optochin sensitivity test: Seed a culture medium plate with the suspected alpha haemolytic Streptococci.</p>
<p>Place a 5 μg disc of optochin (ethyl hydro-cuperin hydrochloride) on the culture. Incubate overnight at 37°C.</p>
<p><em>Viridans streptococci</em> = resistant
<em>Strep. pneumoniae</em> = sensitive</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="431005bc">♦ LANCEFIELD GROUPING OF BETA-HAEMOLYTIC STREPTOCOCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#431005bc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The principle of the Lancefield grouping is the reaction of extracted streptococcal antigen (C-carbohydrate on the cell wall) with its specific antibody. When there is a reaction, there is a precipitation at</p>
<p>Table 12.3 Differentiation of group D streptococci</p>
