<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Positive Cocci 671</p>
<p>the interface between the two reagents. There are several procedures to extract and type the C-carbo-hydrate. The most widely used extraction methods are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Acid extraction method.</li>
<li>Fuller's formamide method.</li>
<li>Rantz and Randall autoclave method.</li>
<li>Maxted's enzyme method.</li>
</ol>
<p>The antiserum is produced by injecting a rabbit intravenously, with a daily dose of formalised streptococcal suspension containing about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2000</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>9</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2000 \times 10^{9}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">9</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> organisms/ml for four days and bleeding it for its serum four days later.</p>
<p>The trend now is to use commercial kits for streptococcal grouping. These are simple, convenient and reliable though expensive. There are several brands of these kits in the market. One of the most popular ones is the Streptex (latex) test kit. The antigen is agglutinated on a slide or tile using latex particles coated with antisera of groups A,B,C,D,F, and G. The whole procedure takes about 15-20 minutes to produce results. The full details about the technique are supplied with the kit.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Commercial identification systems such as the API system are useful in identifying majority of the members in the genus <em>Streptococcus</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Catalase activity</strong> Catalase test (Chapter 10) differentiates the genus <em>Streptococcus</em> from the genus <em>Staphylococcus</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serological-tests">Serological Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serological-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serological tests are used to diagnose or confirm primary infections; however they are more widely used to diagnose complications of post Group A streptococcal infections. These tests are preferably done with paired (acute and convalescent) sera to detect a rise in antibody to one or more of the extracellular toxins or products. This will help in obtaining a more meaningful interpretation of the result.</p>
<p>The anti streptolysin O (ASO) test is done to diagnose a complication of rheumatic fever, while the anti DNAse B test is useful for a post streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Specialist laboratories are usually equipped to carry out such other tests as anti-streptokinase (ASK) and anti hyaluronidase (ASH).</p>
<p><strong>Estimation of ASO</strong> Most of the complications of streptococcal infection appear when the organism can no longer be isolated.</p>
<p>Rheumatic fever usually induces a rise in ASO titre. This rise which starts in early stages of the illness reaches its highest levels within a short time after the onset of disease. Streptolysin O is haemolytic only in the reduced form. It is available commercially either in the reduced or unreduced form. There are two ways of estimating the anti streptolysin O titre:</p>
<ul>
<li>ASO latex slide agglutination test to screen for significantly raised ASO titres and if indicated, to semi quantify the antibody.</li>
<li>ASO haemolysis test using the micro titre plates or tubes.</li>
</ul>
<p>The two tests are described in the Immunology section.</p>
<p>These two test methods are commercially available.</p>
<p><strong>The International Unit (IU)</strong> The International Unit (IU) of ASO antibody is defined as the activity contained in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.0213</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.0213\mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.0213</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span> of the International standard. One IU is equivalent to 1.04 Todd units. The measurement of streptolysin O antigen is in terms of IU equivalents. One IU equivalent is the amount of streptolysin O antigen which is neutralised by one IU of ASO antibody under specified conditions.</p>
<p><strong>DNAse B antibody estimation</strong> The DNAse B antibody usually appears later than the ASO antibody. It is most useful for investigating acute glomerulonephritis following streptococcal infection.</p>
<p>There are test kits available commercially for performing the tests and they are supplied with instructions for use.</p>
<p>There are other commercial kits for slide tests for the ASO and the DNAse antibodies (streptozyme tests). The reliability of these slide tests is not fully established.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Penicillin and erythromycin are very active against <em>Strep. pyogenes</em> and <em>Strep. agalactiae</em>. Enterococci are sensitive to ampicillin but resistant to penicillin. The viridans group are usually sensitive to penicillin, erythromycin and co-trimoxazole.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pneumococci">PNEUMOCOCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pneumococci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pneumococci are also referred to as <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em>. It consists of capsulated, lancet-shaped Gram positive cocci mostly in pairs (diplococcus) or short chains. It is aerobic and facultatively anaerobic. It grows best in air or hydrogen with 5–10% CO₂ for which some strains have a strict requirement. The optimum temperature for growth is 37°C with a range of 25°C–40°C. It is catalase negative and oxidase negative.</p>
<p>Normal habitat Pneumococcus is a normal flora of the upper respiratory tract.</p>
<p>Pathogenicity Pneumococcus is a causative agent for the following:</p>
<ol>
<li>Lobar pneumonia, bronchopneumonia and bronchitis</li>
<li>Septicaemia and meningitis</li>
<li>Endocarditis and pericarditis</li>
<li>Middle ear infections, sinusitis and conjunctivitis</li>
<li>Peritonitis and arthritis</li>
</ol>
<p>Experimentally, mice or rabbits die within 18–72 hours following an intra peritoneal injection with pneumococcal culture. The organism can be isolated in pure culture from the peritoneal fluid or heart blood.</p>
<p>Enzymes and toxins of <em>Strep. pneumoniae</em></p>
<p>These include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Leucocidin</li>
<li>Hyaluronidase</li>
<li>Haemolysin</li>
</ol>
<p>On the whole, these enzymes and toxins play nominal roles in the pathogenesis of pneumococcal infections. Pneumococci cause disease because they are able to multiply in the tissues and their</p>
<p>virulence is a function of their capsule which prevents early ingestion by phagocytes. Pneumococci inhabit the respiratory tract. A predisposing factor for pneumococcal infection is when there is loss of the natural resistance of the respiratory mucosa. This loss may be due to</p>
<ol>
<li>Abnormal respiratory functions as a result of damage by viral infections, excessive accumulation of mucus preventing phagocytosis, or bronchial obstruction.</li>
<li>Respiratory damage due to alcohol or drug intoxication which reduces phagocytic activity.</li>
<li>Abnormal pulmonary functions e.g. heart failure.</li>
<li>Malnutrition, sickle cell anaemia or general debility.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens Specimens include blood for culture; sputum for microscopy and culture; and CSF for microscopy, culture and biochemistry.</p>
<p>Stained smear Gram stained smear shows Gram positive, elongated (lancet-shaped) diplococci with numerous polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Figure 12.4 shows a gram stained film from sediment of CSF.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c3d39717.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg">
Fig. 12.4 Pneumocci in CSF</p>
<p>Capsule swelling test (Quellung reaction) Freshly emulsified sputum or CSF sediment mixed with pneumococcal antiserum gives the capsule a swollen appearance (Fig 12.5) and this test is used for the identification of serotypes of pneumococci.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Positive Cocci 673</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-a5214e8f.jpeg" alt="img-76.jpeg">
Fig. 12.5 Quellung reaction</p>
<p>Capsule staining Capsule may be demonstrated as a clear halo in India ink, or 10% nigrosin preparations (Chapter 3) of pneumococcal culture.</p>
<p>Culture Pneumococci require enriched media to grow. It grows best on chocolate agar in an atmosphere of 5–10% carbon dioxide.</p>
<p>On blood agar, after an 18 hour incubation, the colonies are small (0.5–1 mm) dome shaped, and glistening with an area of greenish discolouration (alpha haemolysis) around them. After 48 hours incubation, they become flat with raised edges and central umbonation, so that concentric rings are seen when viewed from above; this is the draughtsman appearance. It is as a result of autolysis which the organism undergoes in culture. Some strains that produce capsular material (type 3) form large mucoid colonies especially when incubated anaerobically.</p>
<p>In liquid media such as glucose broth, the pneumococci grow with uniform turbidity but later readily undergo autolysis.</p>
<p>Tests to differentiate <em>Strep. pneumoniae</em> from other alpha-haemolytic streptococci</p>
<ol>
<li>Optochin sensitivity (ethyl hydrocuperin hydrochloride).</li>
<li>Bile solubility test. (Chapter 10)</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 12.4 shows the list of differential tests for the Pneumococcus and <em>Strep. viridans</em>.</p>
<p>Table 12.4 Differential tests for Pneumococcus and <em>Strep. viridans</em></p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Pneumococcus</th><th>Strep. viridans</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Morphology</td><td>Capsulated, lanceolate diplococci</td><td>Non-capsulated, oval or round cells in chains</td></tr><tr><td>Quellung test</td><td>Positive</td><td>Negative</td></tr><tr><td>Colonies</td><td>Initially dome shaped, later, ‘draughtsman’ colonies</td><td>Dome shaped</td></tr><tr><td>Bile solubility</td><td>Positive</td><td>Negative</td></tr><tr><td>Inulin fermentation</td><td>Positive</td><td>Negative</td></tr><tr><td>Optochin sensitivity</td><td>Positive</td><td>Negative</td></tr><tr><td>Virulence in mice</td><td>Fatal infection</td><td>Non-pathogenic</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>674 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity The organism is very sensitive to penicillin, erythromycin and cotrimoxazole. Few cases of penicillin resistance have been reported in many parts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaerobic-gram-positive-cocci">ANAEROBIC GRAM POSITIVE COCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaerobic-gram-positive-cocci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of strictly anaerobic organisms includes the genera Peptococcus, Peptostreptococcus, Ruminococcus and Sarcina, but only the Peptococcus and the Peptostreptococcus are briefly dealt with here. They are usually referred to as anaerobic cocci.</p>
<p><strong>Genus Peptococcus</strong> This organism is a strict anaerobe, gram positive coccus occurring in small clusters or singly. It is catalase negative.</p>
<p><strong>Genus Peptostreptococcus</strong> These are gram positive cocci in chains like streptococci, especially where grown in cooked meat broth or thioglycollate medium.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> The members of these two genera are found as commensals on the skin, mouth and the gastro-intestinal tract and in the female genital tract.</p>
<p><strong>Pathogenicity</strong> They are significant pathogens usually in mixed infections with Bacteriodes in intra-abdominal infections, brain abscesses, infections of the female genital tract (e.g. puerperal sepsis), bone and joint infections and deep infected wounds and ulcers. They can also cause septicaemia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimen</strong> Specimen will depend on the site of infection.</p>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Gram positive cocci of varying sizes, about 0.8–1 µm.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Slow growing and usually non-haemolytic on blood agar. After 24 hours incubation at 37°C, colonies are small, about 0.5–1.5 mm in diameter, round, convex, shiny and opaque.</p>
<p>They produce abundant gas (H₂S) which gives the culture the characteristic unpleasant smell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-and-antibiotic-sensitivity">Identification and antibiotic sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-and-antibiotic-sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The organisms are both sensitive to penicillin and metronidazole. However, peptococci are resistant to novobiocin while the Peptostreptococci are sensitive to it. Also, Peptostreptococci are inhibited by Sodium polyanethiol sulphonate (SPS or Liquoid) giving a zone of inhibition of more than 12 mm diameter with discs containing 100µg SPS/disc.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 13</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gram-negative-cocci">Gram Negative Cocci<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gram-negative-cocci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-aerobic-gram-negative-cocci">I. AEROBIC GRAM NEGATIVE COCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-aerobic-gram-negative-cocci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of organisms includes the genera <em>Neisseria</em> and <em>Branhamella</em> in the family of <em>Neisseriaceae</em>.</p>
<p>Group characteristics These are Gram negative cocci which occur in pairs (diplococci) with flattened or concave opposing sides. They are strict aerobes, non-spore forming, catalase positive, oxidase positive and attack carbohydrates oxidatively. They are non motile and generally fastidious in their growth requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-neisseria">GENUS NEISSERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-neisseria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus consists of two medically important species. <em>N. meningitidis</em> (meningococcus) and <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> (gonococcus). A host of other species that are mainly present in the upper respiratory tract are commensals.</p>
<p>Normal habitat <em>N. meningitidis</em> is found in the nasopharynx of up to 12% of healthy individuals. <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> is a parasite of man and inhabits male urethea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neisseria-meningitidis">Neisseria meningitidis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neisseria-meningitidis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pathogenicity The organism finds its way through the nasopharynx into the blood stream and the meninges. It causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Cerebrospinal meningitis, a serious pyogenic infection that is common in some tropical countries. The predisposing factor for the infection is over crowding like in the hostels or prisons: Epidemics of meningitis are usually caused by <em>N. meningitidis</em>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Meningococcal bacteraemia (meningococcaemia). This is usually accompanied by disseminated intravascular haemolysis and toxaemia leading to destruction of the adrenals; severe shock and coma (Waterhouse Friderichsen syndrome). There are typical petechial rashes on the skin and the condition can be acutely fatal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occasionally, chronic meningococcal arthritis and endocarditis.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens Specimens include cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), blood for culture, pus from an infected joint or aspirate from skin lesions.</p>
<p>Stained Smear Gram stained smear from the sediment of centrifuged CSF or any other specimen shows typical Gram negative intracellular and extracellular diplococci.</p>
<p>Culture The organism grows best on enriched medium e.g. chocolate agar and in a moist carbon dioxide enriched atmosphere (5–10% CO₂). The optimum temperature for growth is 36°C with a range of 25–42°C. <em>N. meningitidis</em> is very fragile and will die readily outside the body temperature; it should therefore be cultured without delay.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>676 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="selective-media">Selective media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Modified New York City medium</li>
<li>Modified Thayer–Martin medium</li>
</ol>
<p>Incubate culture for up to 48 hours. Colonial morphology: Colonies on chocolate agar after 24 hours incubation are small (about 1 mm in diameter), translucent, round, greyish with glistening surface and entire edge. They become larger on further incubation. They are butyrous in consistency but become rubbery after 48 hours. It grows less readily on blood agar and colonies are slightly smaller.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The routine biochemical tests done to identify <em>N. meningitidis</em> include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Oxidase test: Strongly positive.</li>
<li>Carbohydrate utilisation test: <em>N. meningitidis</em> attacks carbohydrates oxidatively. It utilises glucose and maltose with no action on lactose or sucrose.</li>
</ol>
<p>The CTA (Cystein Triticase Agar) is now the conventional carbohydrate utilisation medium (in place of the old serum sugars). CTA, a semi-solid medium, is supplemented with glucose, maltose, lactose and sucrose respectively, and then inoculated with the suspected organism to be identified. The medium should be incubated for up to 72 hours as some very fastidious neisseriae may not grow within 48 hours.</p>
<p>While the CTA based carbohydrate tests are considered the standard method, new rapid systems are beginning to supersede the CTA carbohydrate utilisation tests in most modern microbiology laboratories.</p>
<p>Identification systems are commercially available that takes care of the carbohydrate utilisation tests. The tests are rapid and results can be obtained in four hours, thus cutting down on the time of final report. Example: API NH</p>
<p>Table 13.1 shows the biochemical reactions of the neisseriae.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: Lactose utilisation differentiates <em>N. meningitidis</em> from <em>N. lactamica</em>. (Table 13.1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serology-of-n-meningitidis">Serology of <em>N. meningitidis</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serology-of-n-meningitidis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rapid latex tests for the detection of soluble meningococcal antigen in CSF are available. (Chapter 10).</p>
<p>Slide agglutination test using polyvalent and monovalent antisera against suspected meningococcal colonies (killed by heating) is also available. There may be cross reaction between some serotypes of <em>N. meningitidis</em> and <em>E. coli</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="serotyping">Serotyping<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serotyping" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>On the basis of agglutination and agglutinin absorption tests, the meningococci of pathological importance are classified into A, B, C, X, Y, Z. (29E) and W135. The polysaccharide antigen structures of these strains have been determined. Majority of pathogenic meningo-cocci fall</p>

<p>Gram Negative Cocci 677</p>
<p>into groups A, B and C. N. meningitidis specific vaccines against the serogroups A and C are available.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibiotic-sensitivity">Antibiotic Sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>N. meningitidis is highly sensitive to penicillin, ampicillin and a host of the cephalosporins. It is usually resistant to the polymyxins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neisseria-gonorrhoeae">Neisseria gonorrhoeae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neisseria-gonorrhoeae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This species causes</p>
<ol>
<li>Gonorrhoeae of the urogenital tract. The organism penetrates the mucosa of the epithelium and by means of pili, adheres to the surface of the columnar epithelial cells. The disease is sexually transmitted and highly infectious. The incubation period in men is 2–6 days.</li>
</ol>
<p>In men, gonococcus causes acute urethritis and dysuria with a purulent discharge that contains large numbers of gonococci and pus cells. The infection may spread to the prostate, seminal vesicles, bladder and epididymes. Orchitis and sterility are complications of chronic gonococcal infection.</p>
<p>In women, about 60% are asymptomatic. The initial infection involves the urethra and the cervix. The vagina is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium in the vagina is resistant to infection by N. gonorrhoeae and also the high acidity of the vagina is not conducive for the cocci to thrive. The infection may spread to Bartholin's glands, endometrium and fallopian tubes causing salpingitis (which may result in sterility) and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>It causes vulvovaginitis in prepubertal girls.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rectal infection (proctitis) in females is by direct contiguous spread. In men it usually is a result of anal sex by homosexuals.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gonococcal pharyngitis is a result of oral sexual practice.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gonococcal conjunctivitis in adults is usually due to autoinoculation by itching of the eyes with contaminated fingers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acute conjunctivitis of infants born of mothers with urogenital gonorrhoea is common. Infection occurs during passage of the baby through birth canal. This is known as gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum and can lead to blindness, if not treated promptly.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gonococcal bacteraemia may lead to gonococcal arthritis, ulcerative endocarditis but very rarely meningitis. Dissemination of infection manifesting symptomatically as fever, joint pains and rashes is more common in women.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Specimens include urethral and cervical exudates collected with cotton tipped swab for microscopy and culture. The cervical swab should be collected with the aid of a speculum. High vaginal swab is not ideal. In chronic infections where there is no discharge, a prostatic massage may yield enough fluid for examination. Eye swab is collected from infants with conjunctivitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stained-smear">Stained smear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stained-smear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Demonstration of Gram negative intracellular diplococci in smears from men is a good indication of gonococcal infection. This is not the case in women as some normal vaginal flora may show similar morphology and Gram reaction. Figure 13.1 shows N. gonorrhoeae in pus from urethral discharge.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-09fe17af.jpeg" alt="img-77.jpeg">
Fig. 13.1 Gonococci in pus from urethral discharge</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> N. gonorrhoeae has the same cultural requirements as N. meningitidis. Cultures must be</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>done without delay on pre-warmed culture media. The optimum temperature is also 36°C but has a range of 25–42°C. It is recommended to collect specimens into transport media for onward despatch to the laboratory. Usually, chocolate agar and modified Thayer-Martin medium are used for the isolation of gonococcus.</p>
<p>On chocolate agar, colonies after 48 hours incubation are convex, colourless, about 1–2 mm in diameter. The colonies are identified by colonial morphology and biochemical reactions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="selective-media">Selective media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Modified Thayer-Martin (MTM) medium.</li>
<li>Modified New York City (MNYC) medium.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biochemical-reactions">Biochemical reactions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biochemical-reactions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Oxidase test</strong> <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> is strongly oxidase positive.</p>
<p><strong>Carbohydrate utilisation</strong> Carbohydrates are attacked oxidatively. The carbohydrate utilisation test is used to differentiate the <em>Neisseriae</em> and <em>Branhamella catarrhalis</em> (Table 13.1). <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> utilises only glucose and has no action on maltose, lactose or sucrose.</p>
<p>Every isolate of <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> must be confirmed with the carbohydrate utilisation test. This is important from the medico-legal point of view.</p>
<p><strong>Rapid carbohydrate utilisation test for N. gonorrhoeae</strong> Phosphate buffered phenol red solution is dispensed into small test tubes in 0.1 ml amounts. A drop of the appropriate concentrated carbohydrate solution is added to each tube. The tubes are inoculated with a heavy suspension of the test organism. A change in colour from red to yellow after 4 hours incubation at 35°C indicates acid production.</p>
<p><strong>Identification systems</strong> These commercial systems are rapid and results are obtained within 2–4 hours. They are mostly composed of dehydrated carbohydrate substrates, buffer and phenol red indicator in a series of microcupules contained in a plastic strip. The cupules are inoculated with saline suspensions of the organism, covered and incubated at 35°C. Example: API NH</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>These kits are expensive. For making identification of pathogenic <em>Neisseriae</em>, the carbohydrate utilisation test is as follows:</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> In the past, several serological tests were attempted for the diagnosis and confirmation of gonococcal infection without much success. This was partly due to the heterogeneity of <em>Neisseria</em> antigens and partly due to lack of well-purified reagents. A direct fluorescent antibody test (FAT) is available to confirm <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> colonies from primary cultures. Cross reactions do occur with the test and so its usefulness is limited.</p>
<p>A slide agglutination test, Padebact Gonococcus test, is available from Pharmacia Diagnostics to identify colonies from preliminary cultures. This test is considered reliable but it is expensive.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>Biochemical tests and serological tests are best done on purified cultures on non-inhibitory media. Gonococcus colonies from MNYC selective medium can be used for carbohydrate utilisation test directly, but not those from MTM medium.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em>, like other neisseriae, is normally sensitive to penicillin, ampicillin, tetracycline and many other antibiotics. However, there are many strains producing <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> lactamase so penicillin is no longer the antibiotic of choice.</p>
<p><strong>Penicillinase producing</strong> <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> (PPNG) The treatment and management of the disease was fairly easy until the emergence of drug-resistant strains of <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em>.</p>
<p>In 1976, beta-lactamase (penicillinase) producing strain of gonococcus was isolated from an American service man returning from the South East Asia. In that same year, a similar strain was isolated from a British sailor after a trip to West Africa. Both strains showed high level of resistance to penicillin and related drugs. Within a few years, these two strains (they differ in the molecular</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Gram Negative Cocci 679</p>
<p>for weight of their plasmids and auxotyping) have almost completely supplanted all the sensitive strains. The emergence of these strains contributed to the difficulty of management and control of gonococcal infection. Three factors have contributed to the rapid spread of these drug resistant strains:</p>
<ol>
<li>Self medication with its attendant subtherapeutic dosages as a result of easy availability of antibiotics in some countries.</li>
<li>International travels (tourism and mobility of labour).</li>
<li>The use of inadequate treatment regimens by physicians.</li>
</ol>
<p>The World Health Organisation (WHO) in 1978, issued world wide guidelines for the treatment and management of gonococcal infections.</p>
<p>N. gonorrhoeae is very sensitive to the second and third generation cephalosporins; and spectinomycin and ciprofloxacin.</p>
<p>Testing for Beta-lactamase A simple screening parameter for beta-lactamase production is resistance to 25 µg ampicillin or 10 µg penicillin per disc.</p>
<p>There are three methods (or modifications of them) employed for the testing:</p>
<ol>
<li>Chromogenic cephalosporin (nitrocefin) method.</li>
<li>Iodometric method.</li>
<li>Acidometric method.</li>
</ol>
<p>These tests are commercially available. Only the acidometric method is described here because it can easily be prepared in the laboratory.</p>
<p>Rapid acidometric filter paper test for beta-lactamase activity</p>
<p>Principle When the enzyme, beta-lactamase (penicillinase) hydrolyses penicillin, penicillioic acid is produced. This reaction between the enzyme and the penicillin causes a drop in the pH of the medium and a change in colour of the bromocresol purple indicator from purple toyellow.</p>
<p>Reagent Crystalline penicillin bromocresol purple solution.</p>
<p>Benzyl penicillin, potassium salt 2 g
Phosphate buffer, pH 8.0 40 ml
Bromocresol purple (0.2 % w/v) 0.08 ml</p>
<p>Dissolve the penicillin in the buffer. Add the bromocresol purple indicator solution. Mix well. Dispense in 5 ml volumes, stopper and label. Store at -20°C for up to three months; or at 2–8°C for up to one month.</p>
<p>Test</p>
<ol>
<li>Place a strip of Whatman No. 1 filter paper in a petri dish.</li>
<li>Add a few drops of the reagent solution until the paper is almost saturated.</li>
<li>With a sterile were loop, transfer a few colonies from the plate to the filter paper.</li>
<li>Cover the petri dish and incubate at 36°C for 20–30 minutes.</li>
<li>Observe spots of colour change from purple to yellow.</li>
<li>Report as ‘beta-lactamase producing’ or ‘non-beta-lactamase producing’ organism.</li>
</ol>
<p>Note</p>
<ol>
<li>After the addition of the reagent solution, the strips of filter paper can be dried in the oven and then stored at -20°C. They are then used by rubbing a few colonies on the strip. The colour change occurs within a few seconds.</li>
<li>Always include positive and negative controls in the test.</li>
<li>This test is also suitable for other beta-lactamase producers such as Staph. aureus and Haemophilus influenzae.</li>
</ol>
<p>◆ COMMENSAL NEISSERIAE</p>
<p>There are several species of Neisseria which inhabit the respiratory tract and occasionally some are found in the genital mucosae. These groups of neisseriae are not fully characterised. Some of them resemble N. meningitidis in their appearance on selective media and in carbohydrate utilisation. They may be potential pathogens as some of them</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>(N. flavescens, N. subflava) have been reported to cause meningitis.</p>
<p>The differential characteristics of some of these commensal neisseriae are listed in Table 13.1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="branhamella-catarrhalis-moraxella-catarrhalis">Branhamella catarrhalis (Moraxella catarrhalis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#branhamella-catarrhalis-moraxella-catarrhalis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> They are Gram negative cocci about 0.8 µm in diameter, usually in pairs with adjacent sides, but sometimes in groups of four or in singles. They are oxidase positive, grow on nutrient agar and are unable to utilise carbohydrates.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> They are normally found in the nasopharyax.</p>
<p><strong>Pathogenicity</strong> They are mostly commensals in the upper respiratory tract; but may cause disease in the lower respiratory tract, especially in patients with impaired natural defences of the respiratory tract. A pure heavy growth from sputum or other specimens (e.g. transtracheal aspirate) from such patients, may be significant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include sputum, transtracheal aspirate and endotracheal catheter tips.</p>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Oval Gram negative cocci. Few of the cocci may be intracellular.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> B. catarrhalis grows on both enriched media and non-enriched media at 35°C in air and in 5–10% CO₂. It also grows on nutrient agar at 22–25°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Gram's stain - Gram negative diplococci</li>
<li>Oxidase test - strongly positive</li>
<li>Rapid carbohydrate - no fermentation</li>
<li>utilisation tests</li>
<li>DNAse test - positive</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 13.1 shows the differentiation of B. catarrhalis from the neisseriae.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> It is recently reported that some pathogenic strains of B. catarrhalis grow well on MTM selective medium, produce beta-lactamase and do not grow on nutrient agar at 22–25°C.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> B. catarrhalis is sensitive to a wide range of antibiotics. Some strains are beta-lactamase producers and therefore are resistant to the penicillins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-gram-negative-anaerobic-cocci">II. GRAM NEGATIVE ANAEROBIC COCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-gram-negative-anaerobic-cocci" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Veillonella pavula is the most commonly encountered species of this group in humans.</p>
<p>The organisms appear as Gram negative small cocci about 0.3–0.5 µm in size, usually in pairs. They are strict anaerobes.</p>
<p>On blood agar after 24 hours incubation, colonies are very small round, convex, shiny, opaque, light grey and non-haemolytic. They produce abundant gas in broth media.</p>
<p>The pathogenic role of the Veillonellae has not so far been fully established.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 14</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="enterobacteriaceae">Enterobacteriaceae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#enterobacteriaceae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The family Enterobacteriaceae consists of enterobacteria which inhabit the large intestines of man and animals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-characteristics">GENERAL CHARACTERISTICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Enterobacteria are Gram negative rods, facultatively anaerobic, non-sporing, non-acid fast. They grow over a wide range of temperature on ordinary nutrient agar. They are generally motile but few are non-motile. They ferment glucose and other carbohydrates, reduce nitrate to nitrite, and are catalase positive and oxidase negative. They may or may not have capsules. Most of the genera possess the following antigens:</p>
<p><strong>O (somatic) antigens</strong> They are found on the cell wall of the bacteria. They are used to subgroup some enterobacteria such as <em>Salmonella</em> and <em>Escherichia</em> species. The antigens are heat stable.</p>
<p><strong>K (surface, envelope) antigens</strong> They cover the cell wall and can interfere with O antigen reactions. Examples of K antigens are the Vi antigen of <em>Salmonella typhi</em> and B antigens of <em>Escherichia coli</em>. They are inactivated by heat.</p>
<p><strong>H (flagellar) antigens</strong> They are present in the flagella of motile bacteria. They are useful for the identification of <em>Salmonella</em> serovars.</p>
<p><strong>Endotoxin</strong> All members of the family possess an endotoxin. It is this toxin that is responsible for endotoxic shock in Gram negative bacterial septicaemia.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; There is a group of non-enterobacteria organisms closely related to the enterobacteria in their pathological roles, which is dealt with in this chapter. They include <em>V. cholerae</em>, <em>Pseudomonas sp.</em>, <em>Acinetobacter sp.</em> and <em>Campylobacter sp.</em></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-enterobacteria">CLASSIFICATION OF ENTEROBACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-enterobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Enterobacteria are a large complex group of bacteria. Within the family they show a wide biochemical and antigenic heterogeneity. This is illustrated in Fig. 14.1. The classification of the members of the group has been controversial, and there are continuous changes in their grouping and nomenclature.</p>
<p>It was initially easy to classify these bacteria in three groups based on their ability to ferment lactose.</p>
<p>(i) Lactose fermenters - e.g. <em>Escherichia</em>, <em>Klebsiella</em></p>
<p>(ii) Late lactose fermenters - e.g. <em>Shigella sonnei</em></p>
<p>(iii) Non-lactose fermenters - e.g. <em>Salmonella</em>, <em>Shigella</em></p>
<p>This original classification, though no longer recognised, is of practical value. Based on the use</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-d0dad6b1.jpeg" alt="img-78.jpeg"></p>
<p>682 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Fig. 14.1 Simple classification of enterobacteria based on some biochemical reactions and serology</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 683</p>
<p>of lactose in MacConkey agar popularly employed in the isolation of enterobacteria, most enteric pathogens are non-lactose fermenters while the lactose fermenters are usually the non-pathogens.</p>
<p>Two system of classification designed in the 1920s are now accepted and used. They are that of Bergey's Manual of Determinative Bacteriology (8th edition) and that followed by the Centre for Disease Control (CDC). Both systems classify the organisms into tribes, genera and species. The two systems are outlined in Tables 14.1 and 14.2.</p>
<p>We find the CDC modified system more comprehensive and this is followed in this book. The medically important species of enterobacteria have been selected and described. Table 14.3 shows the common tests used to identify the various species of enterobacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-escherichia">GENUS ESCHERICHIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-escherichia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-escherichia-coli">Type species Escherichia coli.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-escherichia-coli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> <em>E. coli</em> organisms are Gram negative straight rods measuring about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.4</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1-3 \times 0.4-0.7 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.7</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> and arranged singly or in pairs. They are motile by peritrichous flagella though few strains are non-motile. They possess capsules and fimbriae but no spores. They are facultatively anaerobic. They form gas from glucose, ferment lactose, are indole positive, methyl red positive,</p>
<p>Voges-Proskauer negative, citrate negative, urease negative, gelatin liquefaction negative and do not grow in KCN medium. Smooth to Rough (S → R) variations occur, especially following repeated subcultures. Some strains are beta-haemolytic on blood agar.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>E. coli</em> organisms form part of the normal bacterial flora of the intestines of man and animals. They may also be found in water, soil and vegetables.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infections caused by <em>E. coli</em> include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Urinary tract infections: cystitis, pyelitis and pyelonephritis. It is the commonest cause of cystitis.</li>
<li>Wound infection, peritonitis and infection of the gall bladder.</li>
<li>Septicaemia and meningitis especially in neonates.</li>
<li>Diarrhoea in children under three years and very elderly adults, also causes traveller's diarrhoea.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="toxins-produced-by-e-coli">Toxins Produced by <em>E. Coli</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxins-produced-by-e-coli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Like other Gram negative bacteria, <em>E. coli</em> produces endotoxin. In addition, some strains produce exotoxins; enteroxin and haemolysin.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenic-factors-of-e-coli">Pathogenic Factors of <em>E. coli</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenic-factors-of-e-coli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The diarrhoea causing strains of <em>E. coli</em> fall into four distinct groups; the enteropathogenic <em>E. coli</em> (EPEC), the enterotoxigenic <em>E. coli</em> (ETEC), the enteroinvasive <em>E. coli</em> (EIEC) and enterohaemorrhagic <em>E. coli</em> (EHEC) or vero-cytotoxin producing <em>E. coli</em> (VTEC) (Table 14.4).</p>
<p><strong>EPEC</strong> These strains were associated with outbreaks of infantile diarrhoea in bottle fed babies. Due to increased awareness of hygienic procedures, the incidence has diminished. Serotypes O111 : B4 and O55 : B5 were the first to be identified as causing diarrhoea. Today over 60 other serotypes have been recognised. The most common serotypes are O26, O55, O111, O86, O119, O128 and O142.</p>
<p><strong>ETEC</strong> The enterotoxin producing <em>E. coli</em> are the chief cause of acute watery diarrhoea in the tropics. They also cause traveller's diarrhoea. Two types of enterotoxins of <em>E. coli</em> are produced:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A heat stable toxin (ST) which is non-antigenic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A heat labile toxin (LT) which is antigenic.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>An ETEC strain may produce either one or both toxins. The toxins inhibit active intestinal absorption and activate the secretion of water and electrolytes into the lumen of the intestine that results in watery stool. Enterotoxin production is genetically controlled (plasmid mediated) and can be transferred from one donor strain of <em>E. coli</em> to a recipient strain. As well as the enterotoxin, the organism forms a colonisation factor antigen (CFA) which enables it to attach to the intestinal epithelium, multiply and colonise the intestine.</p>
<p>The demonstration of either toxin by ileum ligation is a general identification marker. This is not a routine test because it is very laborious. However, the LT may be identified by the agar diffusion tests using specific anti LT serum, by ELISA technique and by latex agglutination. There is also an ELISA kit for the ST.</p>
<p><strong>EIEC</strong> These strains of <em>E. coli</em> cause a dysentery-like diarrhoea with blood and mucus in stool like the shigellae. They penetrate and multiply within</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>

<p>the cells of the intestinal epithelium, destroy them and so cause ulceration. They do not form toxins.</p>
<p>The EIEC strains resemble the shigellae in their pathogenicity, biochemical reactions, their non-motility and antigenic activity. e.g. the somatic antigen of 0124 serotype of EIEC is identical with that of Shigella dysenteriae serotype 3.</p>
<p>EIEC These strains of <em>E. coli</em> cause haemolytic urealic syndrome (HUS) and haemorrhagic colitis (HC) associated with bloody diarrhoea. Most cases are caused by serotype O157:H7. It can be selectively isolated with sorbitol agar (10 g/L of sorbitol instead of lactose) on which it forms straw coloured colonies because this serotype does not ferment sorbitol.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antigenic-structure">Antigenic Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antigenic-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serotyping of <em>E. coli</em> is based on three types of antigens: O, K, and H antigens. There are over 160 types of O antigens, 100 of K and 50 of H antigens that have been identified. A serotype of strain is written as follows: e.g. O55: K59: H6.</p>
<p>The K antigens consist of L, A and B antigens that lie outside the cell wall and the O antigen. The A antigen is associated with a well marked capsule, and it is heat stable. The L antigen is heat labile. Boiling the bacterial suspension renders the bacteria agglutinable with O antiserum. The B antigen is also heat labile; it is numbered and included in the same series as the group K antigens so that sometimes their old and new numbers are shown in the designation of a strains serotype e.g. <em>E. coli</em> 55:K59 (B5): H6. However, some workers believe it is sufficient to limit the designation to the O and H antigens only and not include the K antigens since their full extent is not known. Thus O55:K59 (B5):H6 should be O55:H6. Some antisera manufacturers still use the group K or independent B antigen numbers in labelling their products.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include urine, stool, pus, or blood depending on the site of infection. Stained smear: Short Gram negative bacilli, about 2–3 μm in length.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> On blood agar after 24 hours incubation at 37°C, colonies are circular, smooth, convex and about 1–3 mm in diameter. The colonies may be mucoid and some strains are beta-haemolytic. On MacConkey agar, colonies are red to pink due to fermentation of lactose and are similar to those on blood agar. Some EPEC strains are late lactose fermenters or non-fermenters. On such selective media as deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA), and xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) and others, most strains of <em>E. coli</em> are greatly inhibited.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Lactose fermentation = Acid with or without gas</li>
<li>Methyl-Red test = Positive</li>
<li>Voges-Proskauer test = Negative</li>
<li>Indole production = Positive</li>
<li>Citrate utilisation = Negative</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 14.3 shows the common tests used to identify enterobacteria and other enteric organisms. Biochemical identification may be done by API 20E.</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> The isolate is tested by slide agglutination against polyvalent and specific antisera of the common serotypes.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>E. coli</em> is sensitive to most antimicrobial agents that are active against Gram negative organisms. Such agents include cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, cotrimoxazole, ampicillin, nitrofurantoin, nalixidic acid and tetracycline etc. Antibiotics are not usually of much importance in the treatment of <em>E. coli</em> diarrhoea. The primary goal is to rehydrate the patient.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-shigella">GENUS SHIGELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-shigella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> The shigella organisms are anaerobic. They are non-motile, mostly catalase, negative, oxidase, and fermentable. They are citrate and KCN respectively.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> The shigellae are found in the intestinal tract of man. They are strict human parasites.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 687</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="classification-of-shigella">Classification of Shigella<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-shigella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This group of organisms may be broadly classified into mannitol fermenters and non-mannitol fermenters. But the more acceptable classification is based on a combination of biochemical and serological characteristics. Four species or subgroups designated A, B, C and D are thus recognised:</p>
<p>A: S. dysenteriae with 10 serotypes
B: S. flexneri with 6 serotypes and 2 variants
C: S. boydii with 15 serotypes
D: S. sonnei with 1 serotype in 2 phases</p>
<p>Table 14.5 shows the distinguishing features of Shigella species.</p>
<p><strong>Shigella dysenteriae</strong> This species does not ferment mannitol, is indole negative and catalase negative. It forms exotoxins: neurotoxin (which causes paralysis and death in mice), enterotoxin and cytotoxin.</p>
<p><em>S. dysenteriae</em> 1 causes the most severe bacillary dysentery.</p>
<p><strong>Shigella flexneri</strong> This group is biochemically heterogeneous and antigenically complex. There are two ‘variants’ called X and Y, and they lack the type specific antigens. Serotype 6 is always indole negative and occurs in three biotypes: Boyd 88, Manchester and Newcastle. Table 14.6 shows the fermentation reaction of the biotypes of <em>S. flexneri</em> 6.</p>
<p><strong>Shigella boydii</strong> This group resembles <em>S. flexneri</em> biochemically. It has the highest number of serotypes (15).</p>
<p><strong>Shigella sonnei</strong> This organism is a late lactose and sucrose fermenter. It is indole negative. It</p>
