<p>occurs in two forms-phase 1 and phase 2. It is antigenically distinct from other species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Shigellae cause bacillary dysentery. Infection is by the faecal-oral (faeces to mouth) route. The term 'shigellosis' applies to the whole spectrum of diseases caused by the species as opposed to the term bacillary dysentery which implies acute severe fulminating dysentery.</p>
<p>The incubation period of bacillary dysentery is about 1–7 days, usually 48 hours. The main clinical symptoms are frequent passage of loose, scanty stool containing blood and mucus, along with griping pain. Fever and vomiting may or may not be involved.</p>
<p>The organism penetrates and multiplies in the epithelial mucosa of the large intestine. There is a high death rate from shigellosis especially among young children caused mostly by <em>S. dysenteriae</em> type 1. Some of the clinical features of <em>S. dysenteriae</em> 1 include toxaemia (enterotoxin), severe dysentery resulting in marked dehydration, inflammation and ulceration of the large intestine, bleeding, griping pain, usually with high fever. Renal failure or circulatory collapse results in death. Possible complications include arthritis, toxic neuritis and conjunctivitis.</p>
<p>Infection of <em>S. sonnei</em> is the mildest.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Shigellosis is most common among the low socio-economic group who lack proper sanitation, clean drinking water and proper personal and home hygiene.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Faeces, preferably fresh specimen, especially containing mucus. The specimen may be watery and contain little blood and mucus in the initial stages of infection, but later consists of almost entirely pus and blood mixed with mucus.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Saline wet preparation of the specimen shows large numbers of red blood cells and pus cells. The infection can be differentiated from amoebic dysentery which microscopically will show red blood cells, macrophages and few pus cells with amoebae.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Selective media/differential media for Shigella</p>
<ul>
<li>DCA</li>
<li>Hektoen enteric medium</li>
<li>XLD agar</li>
<li>MacConkey agar</li>
<li>CLED agar</li>
</ul>
<p>It is best to inoculate the media as soon as possible with mucus particles if present in the sample. Most laboratories use DCA and MacConkey agar for the isolation of Shigella. After overnight incubation at 37°C, non-lactose fermenting colonies are isolated and identified.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The colonies are primarily tested for:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxidase = Negative</li>
<li>Motility = Non-motile</li>
<li>Urease = Negative</li>
<li>Citrate = Negative</li>
<li>H₂S = Negative</li>
</ul>
<p>With the above test results, the colonies are further investigated by other biochemical tests (Tables 14.3 and 14.5). Biochemical identification may be done by API 2OE.</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Identification by biochemical tests is usually confirmed by serological tests. The tests are performed by slide agglutination with polyvalent antisera of <em>S. dysenteriae</em>, <em>S. flexneri</em>, <em>S. boydii</em> and <em>S. sonnei</em>. The polyvalent antisera for each species will react with all the serotypes contained in it. The specific monovalent antisera are then used for the final identification.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Shigella species are usually sensitive to ampicillin, chloramphenicol, cephelosporins and the aminoglycosides. However, most Shigella infections except the severe bacillary dysentery may not require antibiotic therapy. Uncomplicated shigellosis is a self limiting condition that resolves spontaneously.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 689</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="alkalescens-dispar-a-d-group">ALKALESCENS-DISPAR (A-D) GROUP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alkalescens-dispar-a-d-group" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are organisms that resemble the <em>Escherichia group</em> and are related to the shigellae. They can be easily confused with <em>Shigella</em> because they are non-motile, anaerogenic and can be non-lactose fermenting. The A-D group is now classified within the genus <em>Escherichia</em> even though they are non-motile and anaerogenic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-salmonella">GENUS SALMONELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-salmonella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> The genus <em>Salmonella</em> consists of organisms that are Gram negative rods, motile, and facultatively anaerobic. They are oxidase negative, catalase positive, KCN negative, usually citrate positive and H₂S positive. <em>Salmonellae</em> attack carbohydrates by fermentation.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> Most <em>Salmonellae</em> are parasites of man, animals (pigs, cows, goats etc) and birds (hens, duck etc). <em>S. typhi</em> and <em>S. paratyphi</em> are parasites of man only.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="classification-of-salmonella">Classification of <em>Salmonella</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-salmonella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The genus <em>Salmonella</em> includes about 1800 serotypes and biotypes according to the Kauffmann White classification. The classification is based on the detection of the O (somatic) and H (flagellar) antigens by slide agglutination tests with specific antisera. <em>Salmonellae</em> are grouped by their O antigens, and the groups are designated A to Z, and those discovered later are numbered 51–61, 64–66. The medically important types belong to groups A to S.</p>
<p>In each group, there is an O antigen factor common to all the members and not present in other groups. This common factor (O factor) like other antigens in the each type, is indicated by Arabic numerals. For example, common group O factor for Group A is 2 and for Group B is 4. <em>Salmonellae</em> are further serotyped by their H antigens. Many of them are diphasic (2 phases) phase 1 and phase 2. Antigens of phase 1 are indicated by alphabetical letters and those of phase 2 are either indicated by numbers or by letters if they are known to occur in both phases.</p>
<p>To give a final species status to each serotype, the phase 1 and phase 2 H antigens of the organism must be identified, except if the serotype is monophasic like <em>S. typhi</em> in which case the identification stops in phase 1.</p>
<p>The trend now especially in North America, is to classify <em>Salmonella</em> into three species (Ewing’s original classification):</p>
<ul>
<li><em>S. typhi</em></li>
<li><em>S. cholerae suis</em></li>
<li><em>S. enteritidis</em></li>
</ul>
<p>All others are considered serotypes (serovars) of <em>S. enteritidis</em>. The three species are separable by serology and biochemical activity. Some workers also divide <em>Salmonellae</em> into two broad groups based on their pathogenicity—the enteric fever group (those that cause enteric fever) and the food poisoning group (those causing food poisoning).</p>
<p>For epidemiological purposes, some important pathogenic <em>Salmonellae</em> are further typed by phage susceptibility, bacteriocin production and biochemical properties.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="antigenic-structure">Antigenic Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antigenic-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are three main antigens associated with <em>Salmonellae</em>. They are O, H and Vi antigens.</p>
<p><strong>O (somatic) antigens</strong> The O antigens are found on the body of the organism in both motile and non-motile strains. A species of <em>Salmonella</em> may have one or more O antigens. They are heat stable, alcohol and weak acid stable. They give less immunologic response than the H antigens.</p>
<p><strong>H (flagellar) antigens</strong> These are antigens found on the flagella. They may be in one or two forms phase 1 and phase 2. They are heat labile, and are destroyed by alcohol and not by formaldehyde. The antigen triggers off rapid immune responses and gives high titre following infection or vaccination.</p>
<p><strong>Vi antigen (Vi for virulence)</strong> The Vi antigen is present on <em>S. typhi</em>. The antigen forms a covering layer on the outside cell wall. When fully developed, it is agglutinable with the specific Vi</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>690 Bacteriology</p>
<p>antiserum and masks the O antigen. Antigens similar to the Vi antigens have been found in S. paratyphi C, S. dublin and a few other enterobacteria species. Agglutination with O antiserum can be performed after eliminating the Vi antigen: Boil saline suspension of the organism in a beaker or water bath for 20 minutes. Cool down and retest with O antiserum. Vi antigen is poorly immunogenic so that only low titres of antibody is produced following infection. The presence of Vi antibody is indicative of the presence of S. typhi in the individual. This may be symptomatic, or asymptomatic, signifying a carrier status.</p>
<p>Antigenic variation The antigens of salmonellae undergo antigenic variations.</p>
<p>O ↔ H variation Flagella and their antigens may be lost by mutation or by growing the organism on agar containing phenol (1:800). The latter loss is reversible by growing on a non-phenol agar.</p>
<p>Phase variation Phase 1 antigen may be either specific for a species or shared by a few others only. Phase 1 is termed the 'specific' phase and is designated by the small letters a to z, then z1, z2, z3 etc. Phase 2 antigens are referred to as 'group' or 'non-specific' phase and are widely shared by many species, and are given Arabic numerals 1, 2 etc. Certain phase 1 antigens are found in phase 2 and so are given e, n, x, z, l and w. A species that appears in two phases are said to be diphasic and that appearing in one phase (phase 1 only) is monophasic.</p>
<p>The definitive identification of a diphasic Salmonella requires the identification of both phases of the H antigens.</p>
<p>V-W variation When the Vi antigen (from fresh culture) agglutinates with the specific Vi antiserum, it is called the V form. But after prolonged subculturing, the Vi is lost and the O antigen is exposed to agglutinate with the O antiserum. This form is called the W form.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>S. typhi This species causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Typhoid (enteric) fever The route of infection is by ingestion of contaminated food or water.</li>
</ol>
<p>The organisms attach themselves to the epithelial cells of the small intestines, penetrate the submucosa, and pass from there into the blood stream via the lymphatics. A transient bacteremia follows and the bacteria seed the reticulate, dothelial system (liver, spleen, bone marrow) and the gall bladder and kidneys. The organisms re-enter the intestine from the gall-bladder where it involves the Peyer's patches, causing inflammation and ulceration.</p>
<p>The incubation period is about 15 days. The symptoms may include headache, malaise, anorexia, toxaemia, low pulse rate, enlarged spleen, abdominal discomfort with constipation or diarrhoea and sometimes mental confusion. 'Rose spots' rash on light coloured skin may be seen.</p>
<p>Ulceration may lead to intestinal haemorrhage and perforation. Epistaxis may occur. The other complications of typhoid include bronchitis, broncho-pneumonia, haemolytic anaemia and cholecystitis.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Nephrotyphoid This is an immune disorder of the kidney usually associated with typhoid in patients suffering from schistosomiasis. Its clinical features include fever, oedema, raised albuminuria and haematuria.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oseteomyelitis Patients, especially children with sickle-cell disease or thalassaemia, suffer from osteomyelitis (inflammation of the bone) and typhoid nodules may be found in the bone marrow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abscess of the spleen and liver. Enlargement of spleen.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="s-paratyphi-a-and-b">S. paratyphi A and B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#s-paratyphi-a-and-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The two species cause:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Enteric fever (paratyphoid fever) which resembles the typhoid fever.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gastro-enteritis: diarrhoea and vomiting and the entire bowel may be inflamed.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="s-paratyphi-c">S. paratyphi C<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#s-paratyphi-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Septicaemia: Paratyphi C causes mainly septicaemia.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 691</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Enteric fever (paratyphoid fever): It also causes paratyphoid fever. The infection of <em>S. paratyphi C</em> is usually more serious than those of <em>S. paratyphi A</em> and <em>S. paratyphi B</em>. Virulent and multi-resistant strains of <em>S. paratyphi C</em> are common in the Indian subcontinent.</li>
</ol>
<p>Other salmonellae Majority of the serotypes cause food poisoning. The onset of symptoms in food poisoning is within 6–24 hours. Food poisoning is by the hand to mouth route-ingesting contaminated food or water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens for the isolation of <em>Salmonella</em> include blood, faeces, urine, vomit, joint aspirates.</p>
<p><strong>Blood</strong> Bacteraemia occurs during the first 7–10 days of infection. Blood cultures are positive for about 90% of cases. The rate of isolation decreases after the first one week. Isolation of <em>Salmonella</em> is a definitive proof that the septicaemia is caused by <em>Salmonella</em>. The method for treating blood culture is described in chapter 9. In the absence of blood culture, clotted blood can be cultured to isolate <em>Salmonella</em>. Bone marrow is also very useful especially in cases of <em>S. typhi</em> infections.</p>
<p><strong>Faeces</strong> Faeces is the most common specimen requested for the isolation of <em>Salmonella</em>. The organism is present in the faeces in large numbers only during its secondary entry into the intestine. This is about the 10th–14th day of infection. The isolation of the organism from faeces is not as valuable as blood culture in diagnosis. This is because the organism can also be recovered from stools of carriers. The organism is recovered in stool till the 3rd week of the infection.</p>
<p>In the absence of faecal sample, rectal swab, though not very satisfactory, can be used. Faecal specimen is most useful for the diagnosis of food poisoning.</p>
<p><strong>Urine</strong> From the 2nd week of infection, it is possible to isolate <em>Salmonella typhi</em> from urine. Since the bacteria are not continuously excreted, several specimens of urine may be needed in order to effect isolation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pus-or-joint-aspirate">Pus or joint aspirate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pus-or-joint-aspirate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pus or joint aspirate is collected in case of abscess or arthritis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Wet preparation</strong> A wet preparation of typhoid faecal matter will usually show macrophages and red blood cells. Specimens from food poisoning cases usually show few pus cells and red blood cells.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> The routine media for the cultivation of the <em>Salmonella</em> organisms are combinations of various selective and enrichment media. The most commonly used combinations of media are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA).</li>
<li>MacConkey agar and</li>
<li>Selenite F broth.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some workers prefer the more recent enteric medium, Xylose-lysine deoxycholate agar (XLD), to DCA.</p>
<p>Inoculate the media and incubate at 37°C overnight.</p>
<p>On DCA, colonies are pale (straw-colour) and non-lactose fermenting.</p>
<p>On XLD agar, the colonies are red and black-centred.</p>
<p>Without mixing, subculture the selenite F broth culture onto DCA and incubate overnight at 37°C. Again examine the culture for the typical pale, nonlactose fermenting colonies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests-for-salmonellae">Identification tests for salmonellae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests-for-salmonellae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>With a straight wire, pick a portion of a suspicious non-lactose fermenting isolated colony and stab inoculate a motility, indole urea (MIU) medium; then use remaining portion of the same colony to inoculate peptone water. Incubate both media at 37°C for 4–6 hours. If urea becomes positive, discard the test and report as ‘No Salmonella isolated’.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reactions-suggestive-of-salmonella">Reactions suggestive of Salmonella<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reactions-suggestive-of-salmonella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrate-fermentation-tests">Carbohydrate fermentation tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrate-fermentation-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>With sterile pipette, inoculate one drop of the peptone water culture into each of the following peptone water sugars, a purity plate (MacConkey or CLED) and</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>a nutrient agar. Triple sugar iron (TSI) agar, Kligler iron agar (KIA) or Kohn's two tube medium may also be used for biochemical tests.</p>
<p>Read the results after overnight incubation at 37°C.</p>
<p>Reactions suggestive of Salmonella</p>

<p>Additional biochemical tests These additional tests will further identify the organism as a Salmonella.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>H₂S</th><th>: +</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Citrate</td><td>: +</td></tr><tr><td>Arginine dehydrolase</td><td>: +</td></tr><tr><td>Lysine decarboxylase</td><td>: +</td></tr><tr><td>Ornithine decarboxylase</td><td>: +</td></tr><tr><td>MR</td><td>: +</td></tr><tr><td>VP</td><td>: -</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>There are several approaches one can adopt to perform biochemical tests for Salmonella to cut down on time. Each laboratory designs its own rapid method based on available facilities and resources.</li>
<li>A good number of laboratories now tend to use the kit identification systems such as APIZ or API etc. It is still important, especially for teaching laboratories to prepare carbohydrate peptone waters so that trainees can appreciate better the chemistry that goes on in the tests.</li>
<li>S. typhi is an exception to the above test results—it is anaerogenic.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serological-tests-for-salmonella">SEROLOGICAL TESTS FOR SALMONELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serological-tests-for-salmonella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serological test commonly employed for the identification of a Salmonella species is the agglutination test. This may be the slide agglutination test or the tube (Widal) agglutination test.</p>
<p>Serological test is done to confirm and speculate a biochemically identified Salmonella.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="slide-agglutination-tests">Slide Agglutination Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slide-agglutination-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In these tests, a known antibody (in the antiserum) is tested against an unknown antigen (the isolated organism on the nutrient agar plate).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Place a drop of saline on each end of a clean grease-free slide.</li>
<li>From the nutrient agar plate culture, pick a colony of the test organism and emulsify to smooth emulsion in the drops of saline.</li>
<li>Add a drop of Polyvalent O (A-S) antiserum to one emulsion and a drop of polyvalent H (phases 1 and 2) antiserum to the other.</li>
<li>With a sterile wire loop, mix the suspensions and the antisera.</li>
<li>Mix further by tilting to and fro for about 30 to 60 seconds, while viewing under good light against a dark background with the naked eye.</li>
</ol>
<p>Distinct clumping in both O and H antisera is a positive agglutination test.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>If positive, perform the test with specific O group antisera e.g. group A (factor 2), B (factor 4), D (factor 9).</li>
<li>Having determined the O group, perform a slide agglutination with specific phase I antisera for the common species within the group.</li>
</ol>
<p>Consult the Kauffman-White scheme for Salmonella serotypes. If there is only one phase of H antigens (monophasic), then the identification may be considered as being complete.</p>
<p>If there are several similar serotypes, then a phase change has to be performed.</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>If after using all the available phase I antisera and the organism is not identified, it means that it is not one of the common</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 693</p>
<p>ones and should therefore be sent to a Reference Laboratory for full identification.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The Phase 1 antisera (except i) have been combined into three groups known as Rapid Salmonella Diagnostic (RSD) sera:
RSD1: b,d, E and r.
RSD2: b,E,K and L.
RSD3: d,E,G and K.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Table 14.7: Result pattern of the RSD agglutination tests.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Antigen</th><th>RSD Serum</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>b</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>d</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>E</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>K</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>L</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>r</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="3">
<li>Antigen i is tested separately.</li>
<li>The symbol G covers antigens g,m, and p.
L covers all types having the antigen i.
E covers all types having the antigen e.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 14.8 shows some medically important serotypes of salmonella.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="changing-phase-1-to-phase-2">Changing Phase 1 to Phase 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changing-phase-1-to-phase-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Craigie tube method The Craigie tube is a 150 × 15 mm test tube containing 5 ml of (sloppy) nutrient agar. A piece of glass tubing open at both ends is inserted into the agar (Fig. 14.2 a). A universal container can be used as well.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Melt the agar and cool to 45°C.</li>
<li>Add a few drops of phase 1 antiserum to the medium, both inside and outside the tubing.</li>
<li>Mix well and leave to cool.</li>
<li>Inoculate the culture into the tubing.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C overnight.</li>
</ol>
<p>The phase 1 serum will inhibit the motility of the phase 1 organisms. The phase 2 organisms which are in the minority, can then migrate, as they multiply, to the surface of the outer medium. From there the colonies can be subcultured and tested against phase 2 antiserum.</p>
<p>To change phase 2 to phase 1 Proceed as above except to add phase 2 serum to the medium to inhibit phase 2 organisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="jamelson-s-plate-method">Jamelson's plate method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jamelson-s-plate-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Make a 50 × 20 mm gutter in a nutrient or blood agar.</li>
<li>Place a strip of filter paper soaked in phase 1 antiserum across the gutter at right angles (or place the filter across the gutter to form a bridge and immediately add 1 or 2 drops of the antiserum on the paper). (Fig. 14.2(b))</li>
<li>At one end of the strip, place another small piece of sterile filter paper so that half is on the serum impregnated filter paper, and the other half on the medium.</li>
<li>Inoculate the other end of the filter paper with the broth culture of (the phase 1) organism.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C overnight.</li>
<li>Remove the smaller filter paper and drop it in glucose broth or peptone water.</li>
<li>Incubate for four hours.</li>
<li>Subculture onto nutrient agar (for use to perform slide agglutination test against phase 2 antigen). The nutrient agar is incubated overnight at 37°C.</li>
<li>Perform slide agglutination with phase 2 antiserum.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> In the absence of the plain filter paper, subculture few colonies from the edge of the soaked filter paper on to nutrient agar or blood agar (see Fig. 14.2b).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="widal-test-tube-agglutination-test-for-enteric-fever">Widal Test (Tube agglutination test for enteric fever)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#widal-test-tube-agglutination-test-for-enteric-fever" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to measure the O and H antibodies of typhoid and paratyphoid salmonellae in patient's</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-42c10276.jpeg" alt="img-79.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-86d65ef2.jpeg" alt="img-80.jpeg">
Fig. 14.2 Salmonella phase change</p>
<p>sera. If properly performed, the test is valuable for the confirmation and diagnosis of salmonellosis. In this test, known antigens are used against unknown antibodies in the patients serum.</p>
<p>Specimen Ideally, two specimens of blood should be collected. The first one is collected in the first week of illness (acute phase); and the second sample 10-14 days later (convalescent phase).</p>
<p>The patients serum is tested against the following antigen suspensions:</p>
<p>Typhoid antigens</p>
<p>O and H i.e. TO and TH</p>
<p>Paratyphoid A antigens</p>
<p>O and H i.e. AO and AH</p>
<p>Paratyphoid B antigens</p>
<p>O and H i.e. BO and BH</p>
<p>Paratyphoid C antigens</p>
<p>O and H i.e. CO and CH</p>
<p>Salmonella typhi Vi antigen</p>
<p>The method for this test is described under Immunology and Serodiagnosis.</p>
<p>Reporting of Widal test The agglutination titers are read after the tubes have been removed from the water bath and left at room temperature for about 30 minutes to one hour. The antibody titre is the highest dilution of the serum in which agglutination occurs.</p>
<p>H agglutination leads to the formation of loose uneven clumping at the bottom of the tube. The O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube. The supernatant fluid in both tests is usually rendered clear. If no agglutination occurs, report as follows:</p>
<p>TO titre less than 20.</p>
<p>TH titre less than 20.</p>
<p>Note</p>
<ol>
<li>The antibody titre will depend on the stage of the disease. The antibody titre increases from the end of the first week of infection till the third or fourth week, and thereafter declines gradually.</li>
<li>Usually a titre of 80 or more is considered significant. The results of a single test should be interpreted with caution. It is necessary to know the level of antibody distribution in local healthy people.</li>
<li>A more meaningful interpretation of the test is when there is at least a two fold rise in titre of antibodies. It is necessary therefore to take two samples the acute (at the end of first week) and the convalescent (about 10-14 days later) specimens. But if the first sample is taken late in the disease, there may be a fall, instead</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 695</p>

<p>696 Bacteriology</p>
<p>of a rise, in titre. There are a few patients with active typhoid that may not show any rise in O or H titres. This may be due to severe hypo-proteinaemia.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Antibodies may be present in the serum as a result of
(a) Chronic/previous infections such as schistosomiasis.
(b) Infection with other salmonellae.
(c) Chronic liver disease.
(d) Immunological disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, rheumatic fever, multiple myeloma, nephrotic syndrome.
(e) Immunisation with TAB or typhoid vaccine.
H antibodies persist longer in the body than the O antibodies.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A non-specific rise in antibody (anamnestic response) may be seen in individuals who have had prior infection or vaccination or an unrelated infection. Usually the anamnestic response shows only a transient rise in titre, while the rise is persistent in specific infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Typhoid cases treated with chloramphenicol show very low antibody titres.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The H antibody titre is raised more frequently than the O titre.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Vi agglutinations The Vi antiserum can be tested against an organism giving biochemical reactions of S. typhi. A positive slide Vi agglutination is diagnostic of S. typhi infection. Vi tube agglutination test is similar to the O and H antigens except that the doubling dilution starts from 1:5.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epidemiological-concerns">Epidemiological Concerns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epidemiological-concerns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carrier status It is important to detect carriers for epidemiological and public health reasons. Faecal carriers of S. typhi are detected by the isolation of the organism from faeces or bile. Carriers frequently shed the bacteria in faeces and urine. Tracing and screening for carriers requires repeated testing of samples.</p>
<p>Phage typing For epidemiological purposes, phage typing is used for intraspecies classification of S. typhi and S. paratyphic A and B and a few others. Salmonella phage typing is beyond the scope of this book. The student is referred to stand and bacteriology textbook.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity S. typhi and other salmonellae are very sensitive to chloramphenicol, cotrimoxazole and ampicillin. However, chloramphenicol resistant strains have been widely reported especially in the Indian sub-continent and South East Asia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-arizona">GENUS ARIZONA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-arizona" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-arizona-hinshawii">Type Species Arizona hinshawii<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-arizona-hinshawii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This group of organisms was originally classified as a subgenus of Salmonella because of their antigenic similarity. Arizonae are found mainly in reptiles and birds. They are also found in domestic animals and human patients with diarrhoea or septicaemia.</p>
<p>These organisms resemble the salmonellae in their colonial appearance and morphology. They however, show some important biochemical differences from typical Salmonella. Most strains of Arizona promptly ferment lactose and others ferment it very late, and so are ONPG positive. They do not ferment dulcitol, ferment malonate and liquefy gelatine after about 7 days incubation.</p>
<p>They are antigenically similar to the salmonellae and are also divided into numerous serotypes by differences in their O and H antigens.</p>
<p>Table 14.9 shows the major differences between the arizonae and the salmonellae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-citrobacter">GENUS CITROBACTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-citrobacter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-citrobacter-freundii">Type Species Citrobacter freundii.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-citrobacter-freundii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Citrobacter organisms are motile enterobacteria that are easily confused with E. coli or Salmonella species or Arizona species. Like the E. coli, the type species of citrobacter, C. freundii, is motile</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 697</p>
<p>Table 14.9 Differentiation of Salmonella, Arizona and Citrobacter species</p>

<p>and some strains readily ferment lactose (other strains are late fermenters) and their colonies on blood agar are not distinguishable from those of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> coli. But it is differentiated from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> coli in being citrate positive, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{S}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">S</span></span></span></span></span> positive, KCN positive and usually indole negative.</p>
<p>The three species in the genus are C. freundii, C. diversus and C. amalonaticus.</p>
<p>Table 14.9 shows the differentiation of Citrobacter species from Salmonella and Arizona.</p>
<p>The citrobacter organisms are usually opportunistic pathogens that are isolated from urine, blood, pus and other clinical specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-klebsiella">GENUS KLEBSIELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-klebsiella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Characteristics Klebsiella organisms are non-motile, Gram negative rods, ferment lactose, adonitol and inositol, produce gas from glucose, are indole negative, citrate positive, V-P positive, urease positive and KCN positive. They are non-sporing and some strains are capsulated.</p>
<p>Type species Klebsiella pneumoniae</p>
<p>Two other important species are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> ozaenae and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> rhinoscleromatis.</p>
<p>Habitat The organisms are normal inhabitants of the intestine and the upper respiratory tract; they are also present in soil, plants and water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> pneumoniae causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Pneumonia</li>
<li>Urinary tract infections</li>
<li>Septicaemia, which if not promptly managed, results in early fatality</li>
<li>Meningitis</li>
<li>Other pyogenic infections such as wound infections, abscesses etc.</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> ozaenae causes ozaena, a condition characterised by foul smelling nasal discharge.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> rhinoscleromatis causes:</p>
<p>Rhinoscleroma which is a chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of the nose, pharynx and other parts of the upper respiratory tract. This chronic inflammatory condition may lead to deformity of the nose (hebra-nose) or distortion of the respiratory tract. The bacilli are seen in smears of infected tissues or lesions as intracellular swollen cells with foamy cytoplasm (foam cells). The condition is</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>698 Bacteriology</p>
<p>prevalent in some parts of South Eastern Europe, Central America and India.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens, depending on the site of infection, include sputum, urine, pus and infected tissues.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong></p>
<p><strong>Stained Smear</strong> Gram's stained smear shows short thick Gram negative rods about 1–2 × 0.8 μm.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> The organisms grow well on ordinary nutrient and enteric media. They grow optimally at 37°C and over a range of 12°C–42°C. After overnight incubation, colonies on blood agar are usually large and mucoid, the degree of mucoidness depending on the amount of carbohydrate in the medium that determines the amount of loose slime produced. The colonies may be faintly pink on MacConkey agar due to the mucoid nature of the colonies.</p>
<p><strong>India ink preparation (Capsule staining)</strong> This may reveal a well defined polysaccharide capsule.</p>
<p><strong>Biochemical identification tests</strong></p>
<p>Table 14.3 shows the important biochemical tests for <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em> and Table 14.10 shows the differentiation of the <em>Klebsiella</em> species.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>It is being proposed to rename <em>K. pneumoniae</em> as <em>K. pneumoniae</em> sub sp. <em>pneumoniae</em> and <em>K. rhinoscleromatis</em> as <em>K. pneumoniae</em> sub sp. <em>rhinoscleromatis</em>.</li>
<li>An important species that is occasionally isolated from clinical specimens is the <em>K. oxytoca</em>. It is the only strain that is both indole positive and citrate positive, and may liquefy gelatin.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Serological identification of <em>Klebsiella</em> species is usually the work of Reference Laboratory. The identification is based on their O (body or somatic) antigens and K (capsular) antigens reacting with pooled antisera.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="table-14-10-differentiation-of-klebsiella-species">Table 14.10 Differentiation of Klebsiella species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-14-10-differentiation-of-klebsiella-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 699</p>
<p>Quellung reaction Klebsiellae are differentiated into 72 serotypes based on the identification of the capsular (K) antigens. The capsular identification is performed by microscopical demonstration of capsule 'swelling' (Quellung reaction) in wet films with the type specific capsular antiserum.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Most strains of Klebsiella are usually resistant to ampicillin and some are multi-drug resistant. Aminoglycosides and cephalosporins are invariably active against the klebsiellae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-enterobacter">GENUS ENTEROBACTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-enterobacter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Enterobacter organisms are Gram negative, motile rods that are non-sporing and non-encapsulated. They are lactose fermenting, indole and MR negative and VP and citrate positive.</p>
<p>Type species E. cloacae.</p>
<p>Other members of the group include E. aerogenes, E. agglomerans and the recently described species E. sakazakii and E. gergoviae. Table 14.11 shows the differentiation of the genera Enterobacter and Hafnia.</p>
<p>The organisms are found in the intestinal tract, soil, sewage and water. Enterobacter species are frequent opportunistic pathogens often associated with wound infections, urinary infections and septicemia.</p>
<p>Enterobacter species grow well on ordinary and enteric media. After 24 hours incubation at 37°C, the colonies on blood agar are similar to those of E. coli. In 48 hours, the colonies are large and resemble those of Klebsiella but without being so mucoid. Table 14.3 shows the features that distinguish them from other enterobacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-hafnia">GENUS HAFNIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-hafnia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-h-alvei">Type Species H. alvei<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-h-alvei" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Hafnia is considered by many workers as a late or even non-lactose fermenting species of the Enterobacter. The genus Hafnia has only one recognised species—H. alvei.</p>
<p>The organism is motile, late or non-lactose fermenting, indole and MR negative, citrate and VP positive.</p>
<p>Hafnia is found in human and animal faeces, sewage, soil and water. The organism grows best at 22–30°C. The best results of motility and biochemical tests are obtained when incubated at 25–30°C. They may be found as opportunistic aetiologic agents in infections, especially in persons already in poor health. Differentiation of Enterobacter and Hafnia is shown in Table 14.11.</p>

<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>700 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-serratia">GENUS SERRATIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-serratia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The serratiae are motile Gram negative enterobacteria, non-sporing and non-encapsulated. They rapidly liquefy gelatine, produce DNase, are indole negative and citrate positive. They are non-lactose fermenters.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species">Type Species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>S. marcescens</em>. Others members of the genus are <em>S. liquefaciens</em> and <em>S. rubidaea</em>. Table 14.12 lists the biochemical differences between the serratiae. The serratiae are found in water and soil.</p>
<p>The organisms are important opportunistic pathogens of pulmonary and urinary infections, hospital acquired infections, wound infections as well as septicaemia, endocarditis, meningitis and many other conditions. Usually, serratia infections are associated with underlying disease or immuno-compromised status.</p>
<p><em>Serratia</em> species grow well on blood agar and MacConkey agar, with optimum growth at 35°C. Some strains of <em>S. marcescens</em> produce a pink, red or magenta non-diffusible pigment (prodigiosin). This pigment is most strongly produced at low temperatures of 15–22°C.</p>
<p>Identification of the genus is based on the features listed in Table 14.3. <em>Serratia</em> species show multiple antibiotic resistance, being usually resistant to the cephalosporins and aminoglycosides.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-proteus-group-genera-proteus-morganella-and-providencia">THE PROTEUS GROUP: GENERA PROTEUS, MORGANELLA AND PROVIDENCIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-proteus-group-genera-proteus-morganella-and-providencia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of organisms has undergone considerable taxonomic changes in the last few years. The tribe now consists of three genera: <em>Proteus</em>, <em>Morganella</em> and <em>Providencia</em>. The three still share certain common features: They are Gram negative, motile, rather pleomorphic rods; non-capsulated, and non-spore-forming. They are non-lactose fermenting and grow well on ordinary nutrient and the usual enteric media. They are mostly MR positive, VP negative and elaborate phenylalanine deaminase to produce phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-proteus">GENUS PROTEUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-proteus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species">Type species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>P. mirabilis</em></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="characteristics">Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Proteus organisms are highly motile, Gram negative rods that vary in length. They are urease positive, H₂S positive, PPA positive, KCN positive, MR positive and VP negative. Lactose is not fermented. They grow very well on ordinary nutrient media and common enteric media. Many strains ‘swarm’ on blood or nutrient agar spreading over the surface of the plate in successive waves and form a thin layer in concentric circles. Cultures of <em>Proteus</em> have a characteristic putrefactive ‘ammoniacal’ odour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="habitat">Habitat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#habitat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>They are usually found in the intestines of humans and animal, in soil, sewage and water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The proteae were formerly classified into four species: <em>P. mirabilis</em>, <em>P. vulgaris</em>, <em>P. rettgeri</em> and <em>P. morganii</em>. <em>P. morganii</em> has been accorded an independent genus status of <em>Morganella</em>, and is called <em>Morganella morganii</em>. <em>P. rettgeri</em> is now classified along with the genus <em>Providencia</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The group causes:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6d0080c7.jpeg" alt="img-81.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 701</p>
<ol>
<li>Urinary tract infections.</li>
<li>Wound infections often as a secondary invader of ulcers, burns, pressure sores and damaged tissues.</li>
<li>Septicaemia, chest infections and infections of other sites.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include urine, pus, sputum and other specimens depending on the site of infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Gram stained smear shows Gram negative pleomorphic rods. No capsule is demonstrated.</p>
<p><strong>Wet preparation</strong> shows actively motile bacteria. Motility is more obvious at 25–30°C.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> After an overnight incubation aerobically at 35°C, on blood agar, most <em>Proteus</em> strains produce the characteristic ‘swarming’ growth over the surface and emit the distinctive odour. Swarming is inhibited on media devoid of sodium chloride (NaCl) and other electrolytes. On such media as CLED, MacConkey (without NaCl) and DCA, individual non-lactose fermenting single colonies are produced.</p>
<p>In a mixed growth of <em>Proteus</em> and another pathogen, e.g., <em>Staphylococcus</em> species, on blood agar, the pathogen can be separated by:</p>
<ol>
<li>Subculturing on CLED or MacConkey agar provided it is not inhibitory to the other pathogen.</li>
<li>Ether shake technique: A sweep of the mixed growth is suspended in about 2 ml of peptone water (or nutrient broth). Add three to four drops of ether to the suspension and then give a good shake. Leave undisturbed for about 10 minutes. Subculture onto blood agar and CLED agar and incubate at 35°C overnight. The ether will get rid of the swarming.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Ether is highly inflammable, handle away from naked flame.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Methods of preventing swarming of Proteus include:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Increasing the concentration of agar in the medium to about 6%.</li>
<li>Incorporation of chloral hydrate (1:500) in the medium.</li>
<li>Incorporation of sodium azide (1:5000) in the medium.</li>
<li>Incorporation of boric acid (1:1000) or other active surface agents.</li>
<li>By ditching (cutting out a narrow central strip) the medium is half blood agar plates and used for culturing.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> Table 14.13 lists the main biochemical reactions of <em>Proteus</em> species. Indole test is used to differentiate <em>P. mirabilis</em> from the other species. <em>P. mirabilis</em> is indole negative.</p>
<p>The rapid hydrolysis of urea by the <em>Proteus</em> species distinguishes them from other enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Strains of <em>P. mirabilis</em> and <em>P. vulgaris</em> have been classified by their O antigens into 49 O groups which are sub-classified based on their H</p>
<p>Table 14.13 Differentiation of the species of the <em>Proteus</em> group</p>
