<p>702 Bacteriology</p>
<p>antigens into several serotypes. This serotyping is mainly of epidemiological importance and so it is not a routine procedure of the clinical laboratory.</p>
<p>Some strains of <em>Proteus</em> possess antigens that are agglutinated by sera of patients suffering from rickettsial diseases. This reaction, the Weil-Felix reaction, is used for the presumptive diagnosis of rickettsial infections. The strains of <em>Proteus</em> used are the OX19, OX2 of <em>P. vulgaris</em> and OX K of <em>P. mirabilis</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>Proteus</em> organisms are usually sensitive to cephalosporins and aminoglycosides. They are usually resistant to tetracycline and polymyxins. <em>P. mirabilis</em> is sensitive to penicillin and ampicillin while others are resistant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-providencia">GENUS PROVIDENCIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-providencia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Providencia</em> has the same general characteristics as the <em>Proteus</em> except that they do not swarm (Table 14.13).</p>
<p><em>Providenciae</em> consist of three species: <em>Pr. alcalifaciens</em>, <em>Pr. stuartii</em> and <em>Pr. rettgeri</em>.</p>
<p>They are associated with the same infections as <em>Proteus</em>. <em>Providencia</em> species grow well on blood agar as well as on the usual enteric media.</p>
<p>They are:</p>
<p>Indole +</p>
<p>H₂S -</p>
<p>Cirate +</p>
<p>Urease - (except <em>P. rettgeri</em>)</p>
<p><em>Pr. alcalifaciens</em> produces gas from glucose.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: <em>Providencia</em> can swarm on soft agar media containing half of the usual concentration of agar.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-morganella">GENUS MORGANELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-morganella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus has only one species—<em>Morganella morganii</em>. It is closely related to the genera <em>Proteus</em> and <em>Providencia</em>. <em>M. morganii</em> is a Gram negative rod, some strains are motile and some are not. It is urease positive. Distribution in nature and pathogenicity are similar to the <em>Proteus</em> species. Table 14.13 shows the differentiating biochemical reactions of <em>M. morganii</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-yersinia">GENUS YERSINIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-yersinia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This genus has been recently included in the <em>Enterobacteriaceae</em>. Two species, <em>Y. enterocolitica</em> and <em>Y. pseudotuberculosis</em>, are considered enteric organisms. The other species in the genus are not considered here.</p>
<p>They are Gram negative coccobacilli, show bipolar staining; are facultatively anaerobic, and motile only at 22–25°C by peritrichous flagella. They do not ferment lactose and are urease positive.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>Y. enterocolitica</em> is a pathogen of a wide range of domestic and wild animals and is found in their gastrointestinal tract. Common sources of human infections include dogs, goats, pigs and cats.</p>
<p><em>Y. pseudotuberculosis</em> is found in domestic and wild animals and birds. Pseudotuberculosis and enterocolitis are zoonoses transmissible from animal to man through skin contact with the animal or contaminated water, or through ingestion of contaminated water, vegetables or other foods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Y. enterocolitica</em> causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Gastroenteritis with abdominal pain especially in infants and young children. Some strains produce heat stable exotoxin similar to that of enterotoxigenic <em>E. coli</em>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mesenteric lymphadenitis which affects both adults and children. Symptoms mimic appendicitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Septicaemia especially in patients with iron overload and among elderly.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Erythema nodosum and polyarthritis are complications of <em>Y. enterocolitica</em> infections.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 703</p>
<p>Y. pseudotuberculosis causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Acute mesenteric lymphadenitis which is more common in young males, resulting in lower abdominal pain.</li>
<li>Septicaemias which are more common and more fatal in animals than in humans.</li>
<li>Gastroenteritis which is rare.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note:</strong>
The disease caused by Y. pseudotuberculosis should not be confused with the so called pseudotuberculosis caused by Corynebacterium ovis and C. muris in sheep and mice respectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimen of faeces is collected for culture. For Y. pseudotuberculosis, specimens include infected lymphnode and blood for culture. Patient's paired sera can also be tested serologically.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Gram stained smear shows the typical small oval Gram negative rods which may show the 'safety pin' appearance due to bi-polar staining reaction. Motility is observed when grown at room temperature (22°C).</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> The two species grow on nutrient and blood agar. Optimum growth temperature is 22-29°C and growth at 35°C is poor. After 24 hours incubation, colonies on blood agar are non-haemolytic, smooth, translucent and measuring about 2-3 mm in diameter. On MacConkey agar, growth is visible after 48 hours incubation. The colonies are pin point in size and non-lactose fermenting. Variation in colonial morphology is common.</p>
<p>A selective medium for Y. enterocolitica is available.</p>
<p>Identification tests for both Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis:</p>
<p>Catalase +
Oxidase -
Glucose +
Maltose +
Mannitol +</p>
<p>Differentiation within the genus and as well as from Proteus species and Shigella species is shown in Table 14.14.</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Y. enterocolitica is classified into a large number of serotypes based on 34 antigen groups or factors; and five biotypes. Most human infections are caused by the 3, 8 and 9 serotypes. Y. pseudotuberculosis is divided into 6 serotypes and 4 biotypes. Serological test is usually performed by a Reference clinical Laboratory.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Some strains of Y. enterocolitica are sensitive to the aminoglycosides, tetracycline, nalidixic acid and chloramphenicol.</p>

<p>704 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-erwinia">GENUS ERWINIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-erwinia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Erwinia</em> has characteristics that relate it to the genera <em>Citrobacter</em> and <em>Enterobacter</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>E. herbicola</em>.</p>
<p><em>Erwinia</em> organisms are motile Gram negative rods, catalase positive; oxidase negative, urease negative and PPA positive. They are aerobic and facultatively anaerobic; and they attack carbohydrates by fermentation, usually with no gas production. They are classical plant pathogens but there are strains found in humans and animals that are also pathogenic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-related-enteric-bacteria">OTHER RELATED ENTERIC BACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-related-enteric-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These groups of organisms do not belong to the family <em>Enterobacteriaceae</em> and are varied in several ways. Some of them cause enteric diseases while others are closely related to enterobacteria by their morphology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-vibrio">GENUS VIBRIO<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-vibrio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> The genus <em>Vibrio</em>, a prominent member of the family <em>Vibrionaceae</em>, consists of curved Gram negative rods, motile by single polar flagellum and breakdown carbohydrates with the production of acid and no gas. They are asporogenous and mostly non-capsulated. They are indole positive, oxidase positive and liquefy gelatine. Some species are halophilic. Vibrios are aerobic and facultatively anaerobic.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; The name <em>Vibrio</em> is derived from the peculiar vibratory motility (from Latin vibrae meaning to vibrate). The most important species is <em>V. cholerae</em> ‘classical’ O1 and its biovar el Tor. The two are non-halophilic. The El Tor vibrio is a common cause of outbreaks of cholera. They share the same antigen, O1, which is limited to them only.</p>
<p>The other non-halophilic species are referred to as ‘non-cholera vibrios (NCV)’ or non-agglutinating (NAG) vibrios. They share the H and not the O antigens with <em>V. cholerae</em>. They are also known as non-O1 <em>V. cholerae</em>.</p>
<p>The halophilic species include <em>V. parahaemolyticus</em>, <em>V. fluvialis</em>, <em>V. vulnius</em>, <em>V. mimicus</em>, <em>V. vulnificus</em> and <em>V. alginolyticus</em>. These are also called marine vibrios.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>V. cholerae</em> can be found in fresh and slightly salty water, shellfish and other sea foods. Other species that are pathogens of man may be found in surface water, marshes, river delta, warm coastal water, shellfish and sewage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>V. Cholerae</em> causes the classical cholera disease which is symptomised by severe, almost continuous watery diarrhoeal stool known as ‘rice water’ stools. The stools contain vibrios, epithelial cells and mucus. The diarrhoea is accompanied by vomiting. Cholera is a disease of man. <em>V. cholerae</em> enters by ingestion of contaminated food or drink. It survives the gastric acidity and multiplies in the alkaline contents of the intestine. <em>V. cholerae</em> adheres to the epithelium of the intestinal wall without invading it. It produces a powerful exotoxin (enterotoxin) which activates the enzyme adenylcyclase. This results in the active secretion of large volumes of fluid and electrolytes into the lumen of the intestine, causing profuse diarrhoea and vomiting. As a result of the rapid loss of body fluid, there are muscular cramps, severe dehydration, acidosis, haemoconcentration (resulting in raised packed cell volume (PCV) and blood urea), shock, and reduced volume of urine which may contain albumin and casts. If not treated properly, the disease can be rapidly fatal. A few strains of <em>V. cholerae</em> do not produce toxin and are regarded as non-pathogens.</p>
<p>Factors contributing to the transmission of cholera include poor sanitation, low personal and food hygiene and ingestion of uncooked or inadequately cooked sea food.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 705</p>
<p>Non-Cholera vibrios These strains of <em>V. cholerae</em> cause small outbreaks of cholera like diarrhoeal disease. Some of them produce cholera enterotoxin.</p>
<p>Halophilic vibrios <em>V. parahaemolyticus</em> causes food poisoning as a result of ingestion of contaminated sea food such oysters and crabs. This disease has been reported from several countries in the Far East, Central America, West Africa and the Indian subcontinent. <em>V. alginolyticus</em> causes opportunistic infection of the wound, ear and eye.</p>
<p><em>V. fluvialis</em> causes dysentery and enteritis in many parts of the world. There are two biovars of the species—biovar 1 is involved with human infection and biovar 2 is non-pathogenic.</p>
<p><em>V. mimicus</em> causes food poisoning. It resembles <em>V. cholerae</em>, except for a few biochemical differences.</p>
<p><em>V. vulnificus</em> causes fatal septicaemia, especially in patients with liver disease. The organism is also found in wound infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> These include faecal samples for the isolation of <em>V. cholerae</em> and other enteritis causing strains; pus and wound swabs for the isolation of <em>V. alginolyticus</em> and <em>V. vulnificus</em>. It is necessary to preserve the faecal specimen at 4°C or in an appropriate holding medium if there is to be delay in processing. Faecal samples can be transported or preserved in Cary-Blair medium for long periods.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong></p>
<p><strong>Wet preparation</strong> For rapid diagnosis, the characteristic ‘darting’ motility of the organism can be observed under the dark ground or phase contrast microscope, using fresh stool. The motility can be inhibited by adding <em>V. cholerae</em> polyvalent antiserum. This is presumptively diagnostic of <em>V. cholerae</em>.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Dilute the antiserum 1:10 so that the preservative in the serum does not kill the organism.</p>
<p>The stool sample can also be inoculated into alkaline peptone water and examined for motility after six hours incubation.</p>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Gram stained smear shows Gram negative, mostly curved rods about 3–4 × 0.5 μm. Some strains exhibit pleomorphism. Figure 14.3 shows the typical morphology of vibrios.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-fed868e6.jpeg" alt="img-82.jpeg">
Fig. 14.3 Gram stain of Vibrio cholerae</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Alkaline peptone water (pH 8.6) containing 10 g/l sodium chloride is a good enrichment medium for <em>V. cholerae</em> and other vibrios.</p>
<p>Inoculate and incubate for 4–6 hours at 35–37°C. Growth occurs on and just below the surface of the medium. Growth will also occur at room temperature.</p>
<p>(2) Thiosulphate-citrate-bile salt sucrose (TCBS) agar is a good selective medium for <em>V. cholerae</em> and <em>V. parahaemolyticus</em>. The medium supports the growth of other <em>Vibrio</em> species from faecal specimens after prior enrichment in alkaline peptone water.</p>
<p>After overnight incubation at 35–37°C, colonies of <em>V. cholerae</em> and other sucrose fermenting strains and species are yellow, about 2–3 mm in diameter.</p>
<p><em>V. mimicus</em>, <em>V. parahaemolyticus</em>, <em>V. vulnificus</em> produce greenish-blue non-sucrose fermenting colonies about 2–5 mm in diameter.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>706 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Another selective medium for <em>V. cholerae</em> is the Monsur's tellurite medium. This medium is not easy to prepare and does not differentiate the colonies of the various strains.</p>
<p>Salt loving strains, e.g., <em>V. mimicus</em> do not grow in salt free peptone water.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> Tests performed to identify <em>V. cholerae</em> O1 and other species include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth on TCBS (sucrose fermenting (yellow) and non-sucrose fermenting (green) colonies).</li>
<li>String test: Emulsify a colony of <em>V. cholerae</em> in 0.5% sodium deoxycholate. After about 45-60 seconds, the colony clings to the loop to form a string when the loop is lifted up.</li>
<li>Haemagglutination with chicken red cells: A drop of 2.5% washed red cells of chicken is mixed with emulsified colony on a slide: <em>El Tor</em> biovar is positive for agglutination of red cells while classical <em>V. cholerae</em> is negative.</li>
<li>Motility test positive</li>
<li>Oxidase test positive</li>
<li>Fermentation of L-arabinose positive</li>
<li>Growth in peptone water containing 0%, 8% (80 g/L), 10% (100 g/L) sodium chloride.</li>
<li>Immobilisation in distilled water (Distilled water motility test).</li>
</ol>
<p>This test indicates an organism to be a <em>Vibrio</em> species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distilled-water-motility-test">Distilled water motility test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distilled-water-motility-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Mix a loopful of growth from nutrient agar in a drop of sterile distilled water on one end of a slide.</li>
<li>Mix another loopful of growth in a drop of peptone water on the other end of the slide.</li>
<li>Cover each preparation with a cover slip and seal.</li>
<li>Examine under the microscope with the 40X objective or by dark ground microscopy. All <em>Vibrio</em> species are immobilised in distilled water but motility is not affected in peptone water. Other Gram negative enteric organisms are not immobilised by distilled water except <em>Campylobacter</em> species which does not grow on TCBS.</li>
<li>Agglutination by <em>V. cholerae</em> O1 polyvalent antiserum.</li>
<li>VP test</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 14.15 shows differentiating tests for the <em>Vibrio</em> species.</p>
<p>The classical and El Tor biovars of <em>V. cholerae</em> are differentiated as shown in Table 14.16.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serology">Serology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The important species of <em>Vibrio</em> are subdivided by their O antigens.</p>
<p><em>V. cholerae</em> There are over 84 serovars (serovariants, sero groups) of <em>V. cholerae</em>. Serovar O1 strains are agglutinated by the <em>V. cholerae</em> O group I (polyvalent) antiserum and so are called <em>V. cholerae O1</em>. The remaining strains of <em>V. cholerae</em> make up the serovars O2–84. These are the non-O1 <em>V. cholerae</em>.</p>
<p>There are three sub types of <em>V. cholerae O1</em>: <em>ogawa</em>, <em>inaba</em> and <em>hikojima</em>. They are identified by agglutination of the anti-ogawa and anti-inaba antisera. The inaba and ogawa strains are agglutinated by the respective antisera where as hikojima is agglutinated by both.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>V. cholerae</em> is sensitive to tetracycline, ampicillin, kanamycin and streptomycin. The essential treatment of the disease is by oral rehydration.</p>
<p>A cholera vaccine which gives only about six months protection against infection is available.</p>
<p><strong>Phage-typing</strong> Cholera is endemic in some parts of the world and outbreaks of the disease are fairly frequent in some developing countries. <em>Vibrio</em> phage typing is a useful tool for epidemiological purposes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-aeromonas">GENUS AEROMONAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-aeromonas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Aeromonas</em> organisms are closely related to the <em>vibrios</em>. They are Gram negative motile rods, oxidase positive and are generally non-pathogenic.</p>
<p>They are found in water and soil. The organisms usually become opportunistic pathogens, causing wound infections, diarrhoea, septicaemia and meningitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="type-species-a-hydrophila">Type Species <em>A. hydrophila</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-a-hydrophila" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It produces beta haemolysis on blood agar and grows well on CLED or MacConkey and sometimes on TCBS agar. Most strains are generally sensitive to the cephalosporins, aminoglycosides and tetracycline.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-pseudomonas">GENUS PSEUDOMONAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-pseudomonas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> The genus <em>Pseudomonas</em> consists of strictly aerobic, non-sporing, Gram negative bacilli, motile (except <em>Ps. mallei</em>) by polar flagella. They attack carbohydrates by oxidation, are catalase positive, oxidase positive (except <em>Ps. maltophilia</em>), arginine hydrolysis positive, H₂S negative, indol negative, MR negative, VP negative and reduce nitrate to nitrite. They grow on simple media with characteristic smell and may be pigmented. They are psychrophiles.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>Pseudomonas</em> species are found in water, soil, sewage and in warm moist areas such as sinks and humidifiers. <em>Ps. pseudomallei</em> occurs in rice paddy fields, river bank mud and surface stagnant water.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>Ps. aeruginosa</em> (formerly known as <em>Ps. pyocyanea</em>)</p>
<p>The other important species include <em>Ps. pseudomallei</em>, <em>Ps. mallei</em>, <em>Ps. putida</em>, <em>Ps. fluorescens</em>, <em>Ps. maltophilia</em>, <em>Ps. cepacia</em> and <em>Ps. stutzeri</em>.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>708 Bacteriology</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Ps. maltophilia is referred to as Xanthomonas maltophilia, but more recently it is known as Stenotrophomonas maltophilia and Ps. cepacia as Burkholderia cepacia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ps. aeruginosa causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Urinary tract opportunistic infections, usually associated with catheterisation or in patients with urinary abnormalities.</li>
<li>Wound infections, skin infections (especially at burn sites), ulcers and pressure sores.</li>
<li>Respiratory infections especially in immunosuppressed individuals.</li>
<li>External ear infections.</li>
<li>Eye infection.</li>
<li>Nosocomial infections.</li>
<li>Septicaemia especially in immunosuppressed persons.</li>
</ol>
<p>Ps. pseudomallei causes melioidosis, a glanders-like disease, (primarily a disease of rodents), in humans and animals. The disease is found in South East Asia where paddy rice farming is practised. Man is infected usually by eating food contaminated with infected rodent excreta or by direct contact with the animals or through inhalation. The disease is characterised by acute septicaemia with respiratory involvement and multiple abscess formation. In the chronic form, there is localisation in several tissues and internal organs, producing caseous or suppurative foci. Acute melioidosis has a high fatality rate.</p>
<p>Ps. mallei causes glanders, a disease characterised by the formation of nasal abscesses and cutaneous and lymphatic nodules, in horses. Human infection is by direct contact and so it is a great occupational hazard for handlers of horses. Human disease may take the form of an acute fulminant febrile disease or chronic indolent infection with abscesses in the respiratory tract or skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-pseudomonas-species">Other Pseudomonas Species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-pseudomonas-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are also opportunistic pathogens in blood, CSF, pus, sputum and urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Type of specimens will depend on the site of infection and include pus, urine, sputum and exudates for microscopy and culture.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Specimens for the isolation of P. mallei and P. pseudomallei should have the biohazard labels on them, and they should be processed in the safety cabinet.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Ps. pseudomallei shows bipolar staining in Gram and Giemsa stained smears. Ps. mallei are small Gram negative rods or coccobacilli. Ps. aeruginosa and other species are Gram negative rods.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Ps. aeruginosa is strictly aerobic. Growth temperature range is 4°–43°C with the optimum at 37°C. On simple or enriched routine agar media, the colonies are large, flat, (tending to spread), opaque and irregular with a peculiar ‘grape like’ or musty smell. This is due to the production of 2-aminoacetophenone.</p>
<p>Ps. aeruginosa is easily recognised by the yellow green pyocyanin pigment it produces. It also produces fluorescein pigment which fluoresces green in ultra violet light (Ps. fluorescens and Ps. putida also produce this pigment). The yellow green pyocyanin colour becomes more intense at room temperature.</p>
<p>Ps. aeruginosa grows well on routine enteric media. Cetrimide agar is selective for Ps. aeruginosa if it is to be isolated from faeces.</p>
<p>Ps. pseudomallei grows well at 42°C and produces a brown pigment on nutrient agar. It produces non-haemolytic small distinctive ‘corrugated’ (ringed and striated) colonies on blood agar. It has an ammoniacal smell and forms a pellicle in both cultures.</p>
<p>The other Pseudomonas species also grow well on routine simple and enriched media at temperatures ranging from 5°–40°C. Ps. aeruginosa, Ps. pseudomallei and Ps. stutzeri grow at 42°C.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 709</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests for Pseudomonas</strong> With the exception of <em>Ps. maltophilia</em> and <em>Ps. mallei</em>, all other <em>Pseudomonas</em> species are oxidase positive.</p>
<p>Table 14.17 shows the differentiating features of the medically important <em>Pseudomonas</em> species. Table 14.3 shows the biochemical reactions of <em>Ps. aeruginosa</em> compared with those of enterobacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="brief-consideration-of-other-medically-important-species-of-pseudomonas">Brief Consideration of Other Medically Important Species of <em>Pseudomonas</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brief-consideration-of-other-medically-important-species-of-pseudomonas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Ps. fluorescens</em> It is found normally in soil or water. It produces fluorescein pigment with poor growth at 37°C. It is an occasional opportunistic pathogen and produces an endotoxin which may cause fatal reaction.</p>
<p><em>Ps. putida</em> It is similar to <em>Ps. fluorescens</em> and produces the same fluorescein pigment, but it is gelatinase negative.</p>
<p><em>Ps. maltophilia (Xanthomonas maltophilia)</em> It is found widely in nature. It is frequently isolated in the laboratory. Colonies on blood agar are yellow or tan with ammoniacal odour. <em>Ps. maltophilia</em> is oxidase negative and is a non-pigment producer on routine media. It is associated with opportunistic infections.</p>
<p><em>Ps. cepacia (Burkholderia cepacia)</em> It is widely distributed in nature. Colonies are greyish white or yellow and later become reddish purple. It has been demonstrated in hospital environment in distilled water, detergent solutions, incubators, respirators etc. Few strains are pigmented.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>Pseudomonas</em> species are resistant to most routine antibiotics, but they are usually sensitive to the aminoglycosides, polymyxins, some penicillins and some cephalosporins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-alcaligenes">GENUS ALCALIGENES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-alcaligenes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Alcaligenes</em> species are Gram negative aerobic rods that are motile by peritrichous flagella. The organisms live widely in nature. They grow well on blood agar and MacConkey agar as small colonies that may be haemolytic. They are oxidase and citrate positive, and urease and indole negative. They do not attack carbohydrates.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>A. faecalis</em>. The other important ones are <em>A. odorans</em> and <em>A. denitrificans</em>.</p>
<p><em>A. odorans</em> produces a dark green colour on blood agar. They are opportunistic pathogens and may be isolated from pus, urine, blood, CSF and</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-campylobacter">GENUS CAMPYLOBACTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-campylobacter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Campylobacter</em> organisms are small spirally curved Gram negative bacteria. Some appear in ‘S’ form and are sometimes described as ‘Winged’ due to their resemblance to the wings of gull. They are microaerophilic, motile, oxidase positive and catalase variable. Some of them are thermophilic.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>C. jejuni</em> with 2 biotypes, 1 and 2. The other species of medical importance are <em>C. coli</em> and <em>C. fetus</em>. Other members of the group are mainly human and animal commensals, a few of which are opportunistic pathogens.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>C. jejuni</em> and other species are naturally found in cattle, goats, pigs, sheep, dogs, birds and chickens. Human infection is as a result of ingesting contaminated food, water and unpasteurised milk.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Campylobacter fetus</em> was first known to cause abortion while <em>C. jejuni</em> caused diarrhoea in cattle and sheep. They are, however, now recognised as a cause of acute enteritis especially in children under 3 years of age. The symptoms of the disease include abdominal pain, fever, headache and malaise. The infection in adults may be asymptomatic.</p>
<p>The organisms invade the intestinal wall and cause acute inflammation with blood and pus being passed in the faeces. <em>C. jejuni</em> produces an enterotoxin which is similar in action to that of <em>V. cholerae</em>. The illness is usually short lived lasting for about 3–5 days. There is usually no serious complications but septicaemia may occur in immunocompromised patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimen</strong> Fresh stool is preferably required for culture.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> A wet preparation of the faecal material shows actively motile bacteria, exhibiting the active darting motility similar to that of <em>V. cholerae</em>.</p>
<p>A Gram stained smear shows small Gram negative S shaped bacilli (Fig. 14.4)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-94e1e4e9.jpeg" alt="img-83.jpeg">
Fig. 14.4 Gram stain of <em>campylobacter</em> species</p>
<p>A faecal smear stained with dilute carbol fuchsin for five minutes reveals the typical morphology. This is a quick diagnostic method of <em>Campylobacter</em> enteritis.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Selective media listed below are used to isolate <em>Campylobacter</em> from faecal specimen. The culture media are made selective by the inclusion of a mixture of antibiotics during their preparation. Any of the following media is used:</p>
<p>(i) Skirrow’s medium containing vancomycin, polymixin B and trimethoprim.
(ii) Butzler medium containing bacitracin, novobiocin, cyclohexamide, colistin and cefazolin.
(iii) Blaser’s medium containing vancomycin, polymixin B, trimethoprim, cephalothin and amphotericin B.</p>
<p>Vancomycin, bacitracin and novobiocin inhibit Gram positive bacteria; colistin and polymixin B inhibit Gram negative bacteria, trimethoprim and the cephalosporins prevent the growth of <em>Proteus</em></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Enterobacteriaceae 711</p>
<p>species and amphotericin B and cyclohexamide inhibit fungi.</p>
<p>The selective culture media for Campylobacter must be protected from direct sunlight as blood agar is toxic for the organism in sunlight. Do not over dry the culture media. Campylobacter is affected by drying.</p>
<p>Inoculated culture media are incubated in a microaerophilic atmosphere at 43°C for 48 hours. The microaerophilic condition may be provided by the candle extinction jar, or generated by a microaerophilic gas generating kit, similar in principle to that used for anaerobic cultivation.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: C. coli also grows well at 37°C.</p>
<p>After 48 hours incubation, Campylobacter produces flat or spreading drop like colonies. The colonies are non-haemolytic on blood agar.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong>: There are very few biochemical tests to identify the Campylobacter. The following criteria are used to identify the organism.</p>
<ol>
<li>Colonial morphology (as described above)</li>
<li>Oxidase test: positive</li>
<li>Stained smear: Characteristic morphology of 'gull wing' appearance</li>
<li>Catalase test: C. jejuni and C. coli are positive while C. fetus is negative.</li>
<li>Temperature of growth: The pathogens and a few commensals are thermophilic.</li>
<li>Nalidixic acid sensitivity: C. jejuni and C. coli are sensitive to nalidixic acid.</li>
<li>Hippurate hydrolysis: Only C. jejuni is positive. Biotype 2 of C. jejuni is Hydrogen sulphide (H₂S) positive in an iron containing medium; biotype 1 is negative.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong>: The pathogenic Campylobacter species are sensitive to nalidixic acid, gentamicin, erythromycin, chloramphenicol and tetracycline. They are resistant to penicillin, most cephalosporins, polymixin B, novobiocin and trimethoprim.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-helicobacter">GENUS HELICOBACTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-helicobacter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Helicobacter organisms were originally placed in the genus Campylobacter. Phylogenic studies have shown that they are not related to the group and have been classified as a new genus Helicobacter. The organisms are small 'S' shaped Gram negative bacteria. They are microaerophilic, catalase, and oxidase, rapidly Urease positive.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong>: H. pylori</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>H. pylori is associated with gastritis and duodenal ulcer. It produces large amounts of urease which protects the organism from the effects of the gastric acid. It elaborates several cytotoxins whose roles have not been properly established.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong>: The most important specimen is the gastric/duodenal biopsy. The specimen is placed in sterile normal saline and sent to the laboratory without delay.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong>: Homogenise the tissue in a sterile mortar in a little sterile saline. Make a smear and use the remaining for the culture and urease test. Gram stained smear shows the typical 'S' shaped organism.</p>
<p><strong>Rapid urease test</strong>: Place a drop of the specimen suspension in a urea medium. Observe a rapid change of colour of a positive reaction. This test is diagnostic.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong>: H. pylori grows well on chocolate agar and blood agar. Skirrow's Campylobacter medium is also selective for H. pylori.</p>
<p>Incubate the inoculated media in a microaerophilic atmosphere at 37°C for 3–5 days. The colonies are small about 1–2 mm, transparent and non-haemolytic on blood agar.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Gram stain: Typical morphology
(2) Oxidase test: Positive</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>712 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(3) Urease test Rapid reaction
(4) Catalase test Positive</p>
<p>A serological diagnosis using ELISA can also be performed.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>H. pylori</em> is sensitive to erythromycin, gentamicin, tetracycline, ciprofloxacin and clindamycin. It is resistant to sulphonamides, nalidixic acid and trimethoprim.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-flavobacterium">GENUS FLAVOBACTERIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-flavobacterium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>F. meningosepticum</em></p>
<p>Flavobacterium species are normally found in water and soil.</p>
<p>The organisms are Gram negative aerobic, non-motile rods. They are oxidase and DNAse positive. They oxidise or weakly ferment carbohydrates and are weakly indole and ONPG positive and gelatinase positive. They grow well on nutrient agar and MacConkey agar and produce yellow colonies.</p>
<p>The species are opportunistic pathogens which can cause meningitis and septicaemia in neonates, especially the premature ones.</p>
<p><em>F. meningosepticum</em> is commonly associated with nosocomial infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-acinetobacter">GENUS ACINETOBACTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-acinetobacter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This genus consists of strictly aerobic, short, non-motile Gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli (often diplococcobacilli). They grow well on simple media. They are oxidase and indole negative, catalase positive and do not reduce nitrate.</p>
<p>They are normally found in water and soil and they also form part of the resident flora of the skin, respiratory tract and intestinal tract. They are recognised as opportunistic pathogens in nosocomial infections such as meningitis, lower respiratory tract infection, wound infection and septicaemia.</p>
<p>The only species is <em>A. calcoaceticus</em> with two variants: <em>A. calcoaceticus var anitratus</em> and <em>A. calcoaceticus var lwoffi</em>. A major difference between the two variants is that <em>A. calcoaceticus var anitratus</em> produces acid oxidatively from dextrose and other sugars whereas <em>A. calcoaceticus var lwoffi</em> does not. <em>A. calcoaceticus var lwoffi</em> used to be known as <em>Mima polymorpha</em> or <em>Moraxella lwoffi</em>.</p>
<p><em>A. calcoaceticus</em> is oxidase and indole negative; catalase positive and does not reduce nitrate. Colonies are whitish smooth, with an entire edge. Some strains are haemolytic on blood agar. The <em>Acinetobacter</em> organisms are resistant to many antibiotics.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 15</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="small-gram-negative-rods">Small Gram Negative Rods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#small-gram-negative-rods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-moraxella">GENUS MORAXELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-moraxella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Moraxella organisms are short stout Gram negative rods or coccobacilli, typically appearing in pairs which makes them look like gonococci. They are aerobic, non-motile and inactive against carbohydrates. They are oxidase positive.</p>
<p>Moraxellae are normally found as commensals in the urogenital tract.</p>
<p>Culture should be done on protein enriched medium such as serum agar (e.g. Loeffler's serum or Dorset egg medium). They grow poorly on blood agar and not at all on MacConkey agar. They produce liquefaction (pitting) in a protein enriched medium.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>M. lacunata</em>. Other important species are <em>M. atlantae</em> and <em>M. liquefaciens</em>.</p>
<p><em>M. lacunata</em> causes a form of purulent conjunctivitis classically presenting as an angular blepharoconjunctivitis. It also causes respiratory infections.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: Branhmella catarrhalis is now included in the genus as <em>M. catarrhalis</em>.</p>
<p>Moraxella organisms are sensitive to penicillin and this distinguishes them from the <em>Acinetobacters</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-pasteurella">GENUS PASTEURELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-pasteurella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Pasteurella</em> contains many related organisms grouped under a common species named <em>P. multocida</em> which was formerly called <em>P. septica</em>. This organism causes a severe fatal haemorrhagic septicaemia in many species of animals and birds. In the past, these infections were named according to their species of origin e.g. <em>P. aviseptica</em> (in birds), <em>P. boviseptica</em> (in cattle), etc.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong>: The organism is normally in the respiratory tract of a variety of animals such as dogs, cats, rats, cattle and sheep. It is also found as a commensal in the human respiratory tract.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopic examination</strong>: <em>P. multocida</em> is a small Gram negative coccobacillus, non-motile and non-acid fast.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong>: <em>P. multocida</em> is aerobic and facultatively anaerobic and grows optimally at 37°C. It grows well on nutrient and blood agar forming small, circular, non-haemolytic and sometimes blue coloured colonies of 0.5–1 mm in diameter after an overnight incubation. It does not grow on MacConkey agar, Deoxycholate agar and other routine bile salt based media.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>P. multocida</em> causes respiratory infections, septicaemia, meningitis, abscesses, ulcers, and osteomyelitis. These infections occur following animal bites or trauma.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong>: The identification tests for <em>P. multocida</em> include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxidase = Positive</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>714 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Indole = Positive
Urease = Negative
Catalase = Positive
VP = Positive
Sugars = Fermented slowly with acid and gas production.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>P. multocida</em> is sensitive to penicillin, tetracycline, erythromycin and chloramphenicol.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-francisella">GENUS FRANCISELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-francisella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Type Species</strong> <em>F. tularensis</em> (formerly called <em>Pasteurella tularensis</em>).</p>
<p><em>F. tularensis</em> is a small Gram negative, non-motile, capsulated bacillus.</p>
<p>It is the causative agent of tularemia in rodents especially rabbits. It is transmitted by the bite of infected blood-sucking ticks and other orthopod vectors, by direct contact with infected rodent, by ingesting the organism in infected food and water, or by inhalation of infected aerosols.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Human infections caused by <em>F. tularensis</em> include: fever, ulcers, eye infections, typhoid like illness, respiratory tract infections, peritonitis, pericarditis and meningitis.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> <em>F. tularensis</em> is a fastidious organism which is cystine dependent and also requires blood or tissue extract to grow. It is a slow growing organism requiring about 2–5 days incubation at 37°C in 10% CO₂ atmosphere, for minute colonies to appear. The colonies are transparent and mucoid.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> <em>F. tularensis</em> produces acid and no gas in glucose and maltose.</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxidase = Negative</li>
<li>Indole = Negative</li>
<li>Urease = Negative</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Patient’s serum is tested for specific antibodies by slide and tube agglutination tests, haemagglutination or complement fixation tests.</p>
<p>Antigens and antisera for <em>F. tularensis</em> slide and tube agglutination are commercially available.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>F. tularensis</em> is usually sensitive to chloramphenicol and streptomycin. Tetracycline is only effective in large doses (2g/day for 14 days).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-yersinia">GENUS YERSINIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-yersinia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-y-pestis-formerly-pasteurella-pestis">Type species: Y. pestis (formerly Pasteurella pestis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-y-pestis-formerly-pasteurella-pestis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This species belongs to the genus <em>Yersinia</em>. Two prominent species of the genus—<em>Y. enterocolitica</em> and <em>Y. pseudotuberculosis</em> are described under enterobacteria.</p>
<p><em>Y. pestis</em> is the cause of wild sylvatic plague in many species of wild rodents which are the natural reservoirs of the organisms. The organisms infect domestic rodents which in turn infect the fleas that parasitise them. Human plague arises through the bites of infected rat fleas, <em>Xenopsylla cheopis</em> and <em>Xenopsylla brasiliensis</em>, or through handling infected animals and by inhalation of the organisms in airborne droplets from infected persons.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> <em>Y. pestis</em> is a short-oval Gram negative bacillus or coccobacillus about 1.5 × 0.7 μm. It is non-motile, capsulated and shows bipolar staining especially when stained with Giemsa or methylene blue (Fig 15.1). It is facultatively</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-d2f7de94.jpeg" alt="img-84.jpeg">
Fig. 15.1 Gram stain of <em>Yersinia pestis</em> showing bipolar staining</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Small Gram Negative Rods 715</p>
<p>anaerobic. It grows on ordinary media. Growth temperature ranges from 14–37°C with the optimum for primary isolation at 27°C. It is catalase positive, ONPG positive, oxidase, indole and urease negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Y. pestis causes three types of plague: Bubonic, septicaemic and pneumonic.</p>
<p>Bubonic plague (rat plague): The organism is carried from the site of flea bite through the lymphatics to nearby lymph nodes (axillae, groin or neck) resulting in the formation of painful swellings called bubos. This results in markedly raised leucocyte count with neutrophilia.</p>
<p>The organism enters the blood stream, causing the septicaemic plague. From the blood, the bacilli spread to the lungs from where it is coughed out and may be inhaled as droplets, causing the pneumonic plague. The bloody mucoid sputum (due to haemorrhage in the lymphatics) that is coughed out contains the organisms in large numbers. The pneumonic plague is highly infectious and if not treated, also very fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> These include bubo aspirates, blood and sputum. Clinical specimens must carry the biohazard label and processing of specimens should be performed in the safety exhaust cabinet. Serum for serological tests may also be made available.</p>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Gram stained smear shows Gram negative oval rods or coccobacilli. Methylene blue or Giemsa stained smears exhibit the typical bipolar staining appearance.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> After 24–48 hours incubation at 27°C, Y. pestis produces small, shiny, non-haemolytic colonies on blood agar. It grows well on the routine enteric media, producing non-lactose fermenting colonies.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong></p>
<p>Catalase = positive
Oxidase = Negative</p>
<p>H₂S = Negative
Indole = Negative
Glucose = Acid with no gas</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Serology tests for Y. pestis are carried out in reference laboratories and are employed to detect antibodies in the blood.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Due to its rapid progression, early treatment of Y. pestis infection is important. Tetracycline is the first drug of choice. Streptomycin is effective though a few resistant strains have been encountered, especially in the South East Asia. The organism is also sensitive to chloramphenicol and some cephalosporins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-haemophilus">GENUS HAEMOPHILUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-haemophilus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> Haemophilus organisms are small, non-motile., non-sporing pleomorphic Gram negative rods or coccobacilli. They are uniquely characterised by their requirement of one or both of two growth factors X and V. Some strains are capsulated.</p>
<p><strong>Type Species</strong> Haemophilus influenzae.
Other species of medical importance are H. ducreyi, H. aegyptius, H. parainfluenzae, and H. aphrophilus, less important species include H. haemolyticus and H. suis.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> Some species of Haemophilus are normally found in the upper respiratory tract as part of the normal flora.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>H. influenzae</strong> This species is the cause of some very serious infections in young children. Most of the infections are due to capsulated serotypes (a-f), especially type b which is responsible for about 96% of all H. influenzae infections. The infections include:</p>
<p>(i) Meningitis This is the most serious infection caused by H. influenzae in young children (most common in ages 2 months to 3 years). The bacilli get to the meninges from the nasopharynx through the blood stream and cause purulent meningitis.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>716 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(ii) Acute epiglottitis This is an acute inflammatory swelling of the epiglottis and surrounding tissues which may result in fatal obstruction of the larynx. If not treated promptly, septicaemia may follow and may result in death.</p>
<p>(iii) Pneumonia Haemophilus pneumonia is usually accompanied by empyema.</p>
<p>(iv) Pyogenic arthritis, cellulitis and osteitis</p>
<p>(v) Ear infection, conjunctivitis and pneumonia.</p>
<p>(vi) Bronchitis Non-capsulated strains of <em>H. influenzae</em> are important pathogens associated with pneumococci in cases of chronic bronchitis in adults.</p>
<p><em>H. aegyptius</em> (Koch-Weeks bacillus) This species causes acute conjunctivitis (pink eye) which is very contagious. It is fairly common in the tropics and may occur as an epidemic.</p>
<p><em>H. aegyptius</em> is very similar to <em>H. influenzae</em> and is designated now as <em>H. influenzae</em> biotype 3.</p>
<p><em>H. ducreyi</em> This species is named after Ducrey, who in 1890 demonstrated the bacillus in chancroid lesions.</p>
<p>It causes chancroid or soft sore characterised by soft, painful, non-indurated, irregular dirty ulcers on the genitalia. Chancroid is a sexually transmitted disease which remains localised, spreading only to the regional lymph nodes.</p>
<p><em>H. parainfluenzae</em> This species is a resident flora of the upper respiratory tract. It has been reported as causing respiratory infections, endocarditis and pyogenic arthritis.</p>
<p><em>H. suis</em> This species is a pathogen of swine but not a human pathogen; capsulated and non-capsulated strains occur.</p>
<p><em>H. aphrophilus</em> This species has been reported to cause septicaemia, endocarditis, meningitis, brain abscess, sinusitis and pneumonia. It is believed that dogs are the source of human infection.</p>
<p><em>H. haemolyticus</em> This species is a commensal in the upper respiratory tract. It is actively haemolytic and colonies may be mistaken for those of beta haemolytic streptococci on blood agar.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>For <em>H. influenzae</em>, specimens include CSF, blood, pus, sputum and nasopharyngeal swabs.</p>
<p>For <em>H. ducreyi</em>, penile ulcer swab or aspirate from buboes is collected.</p>
<p>For <em>H. aegyptius</em>, eye swab is required.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: Do not refrigerate the specimen when Haemophilus is suspected. It does not survive at low temperatures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stained-smear">Stained Smear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stained-smear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The smear shows small Gram negative rods or coccobacilli. Long filamentous forms of <em>H. influenzae</em> may be seen. Figure 15.2 shows <em>H. influenzae</em> and pus cells in Gram stained smear of CSF.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-2e518cd8.jpeg" alt="img-85.jpeg">
Fig. 15.2 Haemophilus influenzae in CSF</p>
<p>The capsules of <em>H. influenzae</em> can be demonstrated serologically by the Quellung reaction using a type specific antiserum.</p>
<p><em>H. ducreyi</em> bacilli appear as a ‘school of fish’ in smear. This appearance is typical of <em>H. ducreyi</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>H. influenzae</em> This organism is fastidious and requires growth factors to grow. Specimens must be cultured as soon as possible. <em>H. influenzae</em> grows better aerobically and growth is enhanced when incubated in a moist CO₂ enriched atmos-</p>
