<p>there. It grows best at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35 - 37^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> and some strains do grow at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>30</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>H. Influenzae grows scantily or not at all on blood agar. The isolation media must contain the accessory growth factors named X and V. The X factor is a heat stable iron-porphyrin haematin (or other haemins) and is freely available in blood agar. It is necessary for the synthesis of catalase and other enzymes involved in aerobic respiration. The V factor is a heat labile substance present in red blood cells and in many other animal and plant cells. It is synthesised by some fungi and bacteria (e.g. Staph. aureus) and released into the surrounding medium. The V factor can be supplied as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) or its phosphate (NADP). It acts as the hydrogen acceptor in the metabolism of the cell.</p>
<p>On ordinary blood agar, growth of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> influenzae is poor because the V factor is not freely available, being contained inside the RBCs. Staph. aureus, streaked on blood agar, can act as a source of V factor. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> influenzae will form large colonies in the vicinity of the growth of Staph. aureus, where both X and V factors are maximally available. The colonies become smaller further away from the Staph. aureus. This is the phenomenon known as 'satelitism'. (Fig. 15.3) Satelitism is the simplest way of recognizing <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> influenzae routinely.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-b33ae913.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg">
Fig. 15.3 Satelitism</p>
<p>Haemophilus isolation media include chocolate agar with without antibiotics (such as bacitracin) and or Levinthal's medium. After overnight incubation, capsulated strains of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span> influenzae produce mucoid colonies of about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 - 2\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> in diameter. The organism does not grow on nutrient agar.</p>
<p>The X and V growth factors requirements of Haemophilus are shown in Table 15.1.</p>
<p><strong>Notes</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>V factor is also synthesised by Pneumococcus, Neisseria species and some diptheroids.</li>
<li>The demonstration of satelitism and no growth on nutrient agar is highly indicative that the organism is H. influenzae.</li>
<li>Paper discs or strips impregnated with X and V growth factors are commercially available and can be used to identify Haemophilus species cultured on nutrient agar (The V paper disc or strips are not very stable and controls must be included in the test).</li>
<li>On a transparent medium such as Levinthal's medium, capsulated strains of H. influenzae show iridescence which is due to the capsular layers.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Table 15.1 Differentiation of Haemophilus species</strong></p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Test</th><th>H. Influenzae and H. aegyptius</th><th>H. parainfluenzae</th><th>H. haemolyticus</th><th>H. aphrophilus</th><th>H. ducreyi</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>X factor requirement</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>V factor</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>β-haemolysis</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Catalase</td><td>+</td><td>d</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>718 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="h-ducreyi">H. ducreyi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#h-ducreyi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This species is difficult to isolate. It is best grown on 5% sheep or goat blood agar with 3μg/ml vancomycin and isovitalex growth supplements. It is possible to recover it by using chocolate agar containing vancomycin and isovitalex.</p>
<p>The colonies are buff in colour, about 1.5 mm in diameter and can be moved intact across the surface of the medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Biochemical tests are not very useful in the identification and classification of <em>Haemophilus</em> species. Fermentation reactions are not reliable. Some produce indole and some reduce nitrates to nitrites. Indole, urease and ornithine decarboxylase reactions have been used to identify six biovars of <em>H. influenzae</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="serology">Serology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>There are six recognised serogroups (a-f) of <em>H. influenzae</em>. Most of the pathogenic strains belong to type b, though serogroups a, e and f can also cause meningitis. Identification of <em>H. influenzae</em> in cultures and specimens is by agglutination methods or Quellung reaction. The bacterial antigen can be detected in CSF by latex agglutination and coagglutination tests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="quellung-reaction-of-h-influenzae">Quellung reaction of <em>H. influenzae</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quellung-reaction-of-h-influenzae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Place a drop of CSF, broth culture or saline suspension of the organism on each end of a slide.</li>
<li>Mix a loopful of type b antiserum with one drop.</li>
<li>Mix a loopful of saline with the other drop.</li>
<li>Place a coverslip on each preparation.</li>
<li>Focus with 10x objective, then place a small drop of oil on top of each coverslip.</li>
<li>Examine with 100x objective.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="result">Result<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#result" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The organism is <em>H. influenzae</em> type b if the antiserum preparation shows bacilli or coccobacilli surrounded by well defined capsules when compared with the saline preparation.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. The visibility of capsules in the antiserum preparation is due to antibody being deposited on the bacterial cell.
&gt; 2. The test is difficult to interpret if too many organisms are present. Ideally the field should contain about 20–50 organisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="antibiotic-sensitivity">Antibiotic sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>H. influenzae</em> is usually sensitive to chloramphenicol, ampicillin, erythromycin and cotrimoxazole and usually resistant to penicillin.</p>
<p>Some strains of <em>H. influenzae</em> are beta-lactamase producers. It is advisable to test all isolates for beta-lactamase production.</p>
<p><em>H. ducreyi</em> is usually sensitive to sulphonamides, streptomycin and several other drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-gardnerella">GENUS GARDNERELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-gardnerella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species">Type species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>G. vaginalis</em> (formerly known as <em>Haemophilus vaginalis</em> or <em>Corynebacterium vaginale</em>).</p>
<p><em>G. vaginalis</em> is a small Gram negative or Gram variable non-motile, no capsulated rod. It is a facultative anaerobe. It is catalase negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>G. vaginalis</em> is present in small numbers in 50% of healthy adult vagina. It causes anaerobic vaginosis in conjunction with other anaerobic bacteria in the vagina. The infection is sexually transmitted; there is a yellowish foul-smelling discharge of pH 4.5–5.0. It is nearly always found in the urethra of male sexual partners of the infected women.</p>
<p><em>G. vaginalis</em> is sometimes incriminated as a cause of bacteriuria, post-partum bacteraemia and neonatal sepsis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimen">Specimen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Vaginal swabs are required for microscopy and culture.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Clue cells: In saline wet mount of vaginal discharge, many small bacilli are seen attached to the epithelial cells (clue cells) with little or no pus cells.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Small Gram Negative Rods 719</p>
<p>In Gram's stained smear, the picture of the small Gram negative bacilli covering the whole surface of or near to the epithelial cells is clearer. Usually, the presence of the clue cells and the clinical history are diagnostic of <em>G. vaginalis</em> vaginitis.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> <em>G. vaginalis</em> grows best in anaerobic environment enriched with 5% CO₂. The optimum temperature of growth is 35–37°C and the optimum pH is 6.0–6.5. Incubation is up to 48 hours.</p>
<p>Colonies on blood agar after 48 hours incubation are small (less than 0.4 mm in diameter), round and dome shaped. They show beta haemolysis on human and rabbit blood but not sheep blood. They grow well on chocolate agar. Columbia nalidixic acid agar is a selective medium for <em>G. vaginalis</em>. On peptone starch medium, <em>G. vaginalis</em> produces white colonies with slightly darkened centres and surrounded by clear zones as a result of starch utilization. It does not grow on MacConkey agar.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> This organism is catalase, oxidase and urease negative. It's starch utilisation and hippurate hydrolysis are important identification features. It ferments glucose, maltose and glycogen with acid and no gas production.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>Gardnerella</em> is sensitive to metronidazole and it is the drug of choice. It is also usually sensitive to penicillin, ampicillin, vancomycin, clindamycin and erythromycin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-bordetella">GENUS BORDETELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-bordetella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> <em>Bordetella</em> organisms are small Gram negative coccobacilli which are strictly aerobic. They do not ferment carbohydrates and require complex media for primary isolation. They are H₂S, indole and VP negative, catalase positive.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>B. pertussis</em>; other species of importance are <em>B. parapertussis</em> and <em>B. bronchiseptica</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>B. pertussis</em> and <em>B. parapertussis</em> are parasitic in the respiratory tract of man and <em>B. bronchiseptica</em> is found in animals, especially dogs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>B. pertussis</em> is the causative agent of whooping cough (pertussis), an infection that is limited to the respiratory tract. The infection is in 3 phases:</p>
<p><strong>Catarrhal phase</strong> The patient shows low grade fever and catarrhal symptoms with dry irritating cough.</p>
<p><strong>Paroxysmal phase</strong> The cough increases in intensity and the patient is subjected to violent spasms of continuous coughing followed by a long intake of air into the almost empty lungs with a characteristic ‘whoop’.</p>
<p><strong>Convalescent phase</strong> The frequency and intensity of coughing becomes gradually decreased. The disease lasts for about 6–8 weeks.</p>
<p>Complications of infection may be due to lung damage with emphysema, bronhopneumonia, bronchiectasis, convulsion and occasionally brain damage (which may result in permanent sequelae such as epilepsy, paralysis, mental retardation, blindness and deafness).</p>
<p><em>B. parapertussis</em> causes a milder form of whooping cough.</p>
<p><em>B. bronchiseptica</em> is pathogenic to animals. It has been found to cause whooping cough like infections and wound infections in humans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Nasopharyngeal secretions are collected with pernasal swabs or by aspiration or by cough plate.</p>
<p><strong>Cough plate method</strong> A plate containing the medium of isolation is held about 10–15 cm in front of the patient's mouth during a bout of coughing so that droplets from the cough fall on the medium.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> <em>B. pertussis</em> is a small, non-motile, capsulated Gram negative coccobacillus. It may show bi-polar staining with methylene blue. <em>B. parapertussis</em> and <em>B. bronchiseptica</em> are similar to <em>B. pertussis</em> morphologically but <em>B. bronchiseptica</em> is motile.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>720 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="selective-media">Selective media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Bordet-Gengou medium.</li>
<li>Charcoal, cephalexin blood agar (CCBA).</li>
</ol>
<p>These two media are good for primary isolation, thereafter the organisms are able to grow on blood agar.</p>
<p><em>B. pertussis</em> is slow growing. Incubation is at 35°–37°C for 2–6 days in a moist aerobic condition. Colonies are small, raised, shiny (mercury-like or rain drop-like), and usually mucoid.</p>
<p><em>B. parapertussis</em> grows on blood and nutrient agar. It is a faster grower and produces slightly larger colonies than <em>B. pertussis</em>.</p>
<p><em>B. bronchiseptica</em> grows well on blood agar and nutrient agar. It produces small beta haemolytic colonies on blood agar after 2–3 days incubation at 35°–37°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Table 15.2 shows the differentiating characteristics of the <em>Bordetella</em> species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="serology">Serology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>B. pertussis</em> is divided into six serovars on the basis of three surface antigens. The typing is done with the antisera by slide agglutination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="antibiotic-sensitivity">Antibiotic sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>B. pertussis</em> is sensitive to erythromycin, chloramphenicol, tetracycline and ampicillin. Ideally treatment should start within the first 10 days of the disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-brucella">GENUS BRUCELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-brucella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Brucella</em> consists of very small, non-motile, aerobic, non-sporing, non-capsulated Gram negative short-rods or coccobacilli which may appear in singles or short chains and they may be intracellular. Brucellae do not ferment carbobydrates, are oxidase, catalase and urease positive, and citrate, indole, MR and VP negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species">Type Species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>B. melitensis</em>; other species of medical importance include <em>B. abortus</em> and <em>B. suis</em>. Some species of less importance include <em>B. ovis</em>, <em>B. neotomae</em> and <em>B. canis</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="habitat">Habitat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#habitat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>Brucella</em> organisms are pathogens of animals.</p>
<p><em>B. melitensis</em> is found mainly in goats and sheep.</p>
<p><em>B. abortus</em> is found mainly in cattle;</p>
<p><em>B. suis</em> is found mainly in pigs;</p>
<p><em>B. canis</em> is found in dogs;</p>
<p><em>B. neotomae</em> in wood rats;</p>
<p><em>B. ovis</em> in sheep.</p>
<p>Animals such as camels, horses, wild rodents can also be infected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="classification-of-brucella">Classification of Brucella<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-brucella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Classification of <em>Brucella</em> into different species is based on CO₂ requirements, sensitivity to dyes (basic fuchsin and thionin), H₂S production, agglutination by non-specific sera, phage typing and oxidative action on carbohydrates. There are three biotypes of <em>B. melitensis</em>, nine of <em>B. abortus</em> and four of <em>B. suis</em>.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: Biotype 8 of <em>B. abortus</em> is no longer recognised.</p>
<p>Table 15.3 shows the differentiating features of the <em>Brucella</em> species and biovars.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>722 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(1) Acute brucellosis This is the real undulant fever accompanied by prolonged septicaemia. It is mostly caused by <em>B. melitensis</em>. It is characterised by irregular fever which shows undulations of pyrexia. The symptoms include muscular pains, nocturnal drenching sweat, exhaustion, anorexia, constipation, chills and irritability.</p>
<p>(2) Chronic brucellosis This is usually a low grade infection and with the absence of bacteraemia. The clinical manifestations include sweating, joint pains with little or no fever.</p>
<p>(3) Latent brucellosis There are no clinical signs and symptoms. Diagnosis is based only on serological evidence.</p>
<p>Human infection results from ingesting unpasteurised infected milk and meat products. The organisms may also enter the host via damaged skin or through the mucous membrane of the eye; or by inhalation of air borne particles. Blood sucking insects also help in transmission from animal to animal or animal to man.</p>
<p>Brucella organisms spread from the initial site of infection through the lymphatic channels to the local lymph nodes in the reticuloendothelial cells of the spleen, liver, kidneys and bone marrow. From here, they spill over into the blood stream and are disseminated throughout the body.</p>
<p>Brucellosis is distributed worldwide, being endemic in some parts of the world. Human infections are caused by different species in different regions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include blood for blood culture, serum for antibody testing, bone marrow, lymph node biopsy, joint aspirates, cerebrospinal fluid and abscess swab.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Specimens for Brucella culture should carry the biohazard label and should be processed in the safety exhaust cabinet.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Stained Smear</strong> The organisms are Gram-negative coccobacilli and may show bi-polar staining.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Blood culture is the most definitive method of diagnosis of acute brucellosis. The organisms grow very slowly and need prolonged incubation. <em>B. abortus</em> requires 5–10% CO₂ enriched atmosphere for primary isolation and so all blood cultures should be incubated in CO₂. Brucella blood cultures must be incubated at 37°C for at least 4–6 weeks before being reported as ‘No organisms isolated’.</p>
<p>The Castaneda method of blood culture was most popular for the isolation of Brucella species. The medium is diphasic, consisting of an agar slope and broth. The blood is inoculated into the broth and the bottle incubated in upright position. Colonies grow on the slant. This method minimises the risk of contamination and infection. Blood cultures are positive only for about 40% of cases. <em>B. abortus</em> is not difficult to isolate.</p>
<p>Serum-dextrose agar and tryptone soya agar are widely used to isolate Brucella. Tryptone soya agar containing various concentrations of dyes such as basic fushsin and thionin is used in the differentiation of the Brucella species (Table 15.3).</p>
<p>Colonies on solid media are small, moist, and glistening. In liquid media growth is uniform, but in old cultures a powdery deposit is formed.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> Brucellae do not ferment carbohydrates but they possess oxidative capacity. Only a few biochemical tests are routinely used to identify the species:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Catalase</th><th>+</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Oxidase</td><td>+ (B. neotomae and B. ovii are negative)</td></tr><tr><td>Nitrates reduction</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>Citrate</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Indole</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>M R</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>V P</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Small Gram Negative Rods 723</p>
<p>The differential features of <em>Brucella</em> species and <em>bryopyces</em> are listed in Table 15.3.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serology">Serology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Since cultures are not always successful, serological testing for antibodies is very useful in the diagnosis of brucellosis. Several serological tests are employed: rapid slide agglutination, standard agglutination (tube agglutination test), 2-mercaptoethanol titration test, complement fixation test (CFT), antihuman globulin test (Coomb's test) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).</p>
<p>The somatic antigens of <em>Brucella</em> species contain two main determinants called A and M. The amounts of A and M antigens in the three major species vary. <em>B. abortus</em> contains about 20 times as much A as M, <em>B. melitensis</em> contains about 20 times as much M as A; and <em>B. suis</em> contains an intermediate pattern. Absorbed A and M monospecific sera are used for the species identification of <em>Brucella</em>.</p>
<p>In <em>Brucella</em> infection, IgM followed by IgG antibodies appear in the blood within 7–10 days after the onset of the disease. Antibody response in acute brucellosis is in the form of high levels of IgM. The IgM levels gradually fall as the disease progresses, but IgG antibodies persist or increase in titre. This persistence is pronounced in chronic brucellosis or as a result of immunisation from drinking infected milk.</p>
<p>Following successful treatment, however, The IgG antibodies gradually disappears over a period of several months while the IgM antibody titre falls rapidly and disappears within a few weeks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="agglutination-tests">Agglutination tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#agglutination-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Slide test The slide test is a screening test which is employed in high risk areas to cut down on materials and time. However, all positive slide tests should be confirmed by the tube agglutination test.</p>
<p>It is in the first instance a qualitative test in which stained <em>Brucella</em> antigen suspension is mixed with a drop of the patient's serum. A slide titration test is possible but the titre obtained is regarded as a general guide as to whether the antibody value is high or low.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Brucella stained antigen suspension is available commercially The same antigen suspension is used for both slide and tube agglutination.</p>
<p>(2) Standard agglutination test (SAT) This is the tube agglutination test in which serial doubling dilutions of the patient's serum are made in phenol saline in 1 ml volumes for <em>B. abortus</em> and <em>B. melitensis</em>. A drop of stained respective antigen suspension is added to each dilution and then incubated at 37°C for 24–48 hours. Positive and negative control sera must be run along with the test.</p>
<p>Some sera contain ‘blocking’ or ‘non agglutinating’ antibodies (which are usually IgA), which cause agglutination to occur only in higher dilutions and not in lower ones. This is known as Prozone reaction or phenomenon. The following is an example of an agglutination test showing prozone phenomenon.</p>
<p>|  Dilutions
Agglutination | 1:20
– | 1:40
– | 1:80</p>
<ul>
<li>| 1:160</li>
<li>| 1:320</li>
<li>| 1:640</li>
<li>|
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |</li>
</ul>
<p>The prozone effect can be eliminated by</p>
<ol>
<li>Pre-heating the serum at 56°C for 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Using 5% phenol saline as diluent for the test.</li>
<li>Extending the serum dilutions up to 1/1280.</li>
<li>By performing the Coomb's antihuman globulin test.</li>
</ol>
<p>For more details on the agglutination tests for <em>Brucella</em>, you are referred to Immunology section.</p>
<p>(3) 2-mercaptoethanol agglutination test This test is performed in a similar manner as the tube agglutination test except that the diluent used is 0.05M 2-mercaptoethanol phosphate buffered saline. The IgM antibodies are selectively destroyed by the 2-mercaptoethanol. Therefore, any agglutination test is performed.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>724 Bacteriology</p>
<p>nation occurring is due to IgG antibodies which are not affected by the 2-mercaptoethanol.</p>
<p><strong>Testing for <em>Brucella</em> antibodies in milk</strong>Brucella* bacilli are excreted in the milk of infected cows and goats. The milk also contains antibodies which are detected by:</p>
<p>(1) <strong>Milk ring test</strong> A sample of whole milk is mixed well with a drop of haematoxylin stained <em>Brucella</em> antigen (a concentrated suspension of killed <em>B. abortus</em>) and incubated at 37°C for about 50 minutes. If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to the top and form a blue ring, leaving the milk unstained. If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly coloured with no blue ring at the top.</p>
<p>(2) <strong>Whey agglutination test</strong> To 2 ml of milk sample in a conical flask are added 100 ml of renin and 10 ml chloroform, mixed well, and incubated at 37°C for two hours. The milk clot is then centrifuged to obtain the liquid whey for testing. The whey agglutination is carried out just like the serum agglutination.</p>
<p>A titre greater than 20 is indicative of infection of the individual animal, provided there is no history of recent vaccination.</p>
<p><strong><em>Brucella</em> bacteriophage</strong> There are several bacteriophages that lyse <em>Brucella</em> strains. The reference phage is the Tblisi (Tb) phage which at Routine test dose (RTD) does not lyse <em>B. melitensis</em> but will lyse <em>B. abortus</em>, <em>B. suis</em> is lysed at 10,000 RTD.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>Brucella</em> species are sensitive to tetracycline, streptomycin and cotrimoxazole. For acute brucellosis, tetracycline is the drug of choice.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 16</p>
<p>Mycobacteria</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-mycobacterium">GENUS MYCOBACTERIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-mycobacterium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mycobacteria are slender, straight or slightly curved, non-motile rods; are aerobic, non-capsulated and non-sporing. They do not stain easily but once stained, they resist decolourisation with dilute mineral acids. They are therefore referred to as acid fast bacilli (AFB). Mycobacteria are aerobic, non-capsulated and non-sporing. They comprise obligate pathogens, opportunistic pathogens and saprophytes.</p>
<p>Type species <em>M. tuberculosis</em> (tubercle bacilli). More than forty species of mycobacteria are recognised.</p>
<p><em>M. tuberculosis</em> complex is the term used to describe <em>M. tuberculosis</em>, <em>M. africanum</em> and <em>M. bovis</em> collectively.</p>
<p>Atypical mycobacteria Saprophytic mycobacteria which are non-tubercle bacilli and isolated from a number of environmental sources are loosely grouped under the term ‘atypical’ or anonymous mycobacteria. Most of these organisms have now been speciated and the term atypical or anonymous is no longer used; instead they are referred to as environmental mycobacteria. However, some workers still make use of Runyon’s classification which divides the organisms into groups (i)-(iv).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mycobacteria-of-clinical-importance">Mycobacteria of Clinical Importance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mycobacteria-of-clinical-importance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Pathogens</th><th>Diseases</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>M. tuberculosis</td><td>Tuberculosis</td></tr><tr><td>M. africanum</td><td>Tuberculosis</td></tr><tr><td>M. bovis</td><td>Tuberculosis</td></tr><tr><td>M. leprae</td><td>Leprosy</td></tr><tr><td>M. ulcerans (M. buruli)</td><td>Skin ulcers</td></tr><tr><td>(Buruli ulcer).</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="opportunistic-pathogens">Opportunistic pathogens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#opportunistic-pathogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="af201ee6">Runyon’s Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#af201ee6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mycobacteria grow on protein enriched culture media. The only exceptions to this statement is</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>726 Bacteriology</p>
<p>M. leprae which does not grow on any artificial culture media. Some saprophytic species such as M. fortuitum and M. chelonei are able to grow on nutrient agar. Mycobacteria require CO₂ enriched atmosphere for improved growth.</p>
<p>Cultural differentiation of mycobacteria is based on:</p>
<p>(1) Rate of growth.
(2) Temperature of growth.
(3) Production of pigments in light and darkness.</p>
<p><strong>Rate of growth</strong> The organisms grow slowly. Appearance of colonies may be delayed for up to 6–8 weeks. M. fortuitum and M. chelonei and many saprophytic species, however, produce colonies within 2–5 days.</p>
<p><strong>Temperature of growth</strong> The optimum temperature of growth for most mycobacteria is 35–37°C. A few species e.g. M. ulcerans, M. fortuitum, can grow at 30–32°C.</p>
<p><strong>Pigment production</strong> Some mycobacteria species can produce pigments when incubated in darkness or light; and the following terms are used to describe the various pigment productions:</p>
<p>(i) Photochromogen (Runyon Group I) A Mycobacterium species that produces pigment only when exposed to light.</p>
<p>Examples: M. kansasii, M. marinum, M. simiae (M. habana).</p>
<p>(ii) Scotochromogen (Runyon Group II) A Mycobacterium species that produces a pigment when grown in the dark and in the light. This pigment is usually yellow or yellow orange becoming deeper in colour as growth progresses.</p>
<p>Examples: M. scrofulaceum, M. szulgai.</p>
<p>(iii) Non-chromogon (Runyon Group III) This is a Mycobacterium species that does not produce pigment in the light or in darkness.</p>
<p>Examples: M. tuberculosis, M. bovis, M. fortuitum, M. chelonei.</p>
<p>(iv) Rapid Growers (Runyon Group IV) These mature from small inocula at room temperature in 2–7 days. They are usually non-pigmented. Examples are M. smegmatis, M. phlei.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture-media-for-mycobacteria">Culture Media for Mycobacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture-media-for-mycobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) glycerol medium This is the recommended medium for human type of tubercle bacilli. The malachite green in the medium is inhibitory to organisms other than mycobacteria, and also provides a colour contrast which makes it easy to recognise colonies even when they are small. Glycerol in the medium enhances the growth of M. tuberculosis but not that of M. bovis which may fail to grow on it.</li>
</ol>
<p>The colonies of M. tuberculosis on LJ medium are rough, tough, buff to yellowish in colour and luxuriant (eugonic growth).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Lowenstein Jensen (LJ) pyruvate medium This medium is used for the isolation of M. bovis because glycerol in the standard medium is inhibitory to it.</li>
</ol>
<p>The colonies of M. bovis are tiny and transparent, later becoming white. Growth is poor even when confluent (dysgonic growth).</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Dorset egg medium This simple medium is suitable for the growth of laboratory strains of tubercle bacilli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dubo’s medium This is one of the earliest liquid medium that gives uniformly dispersed cultures used for sensitivity tests and biochemical tests.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Selective Kirchner medium This enrichment medium is ideal for specimens other than sputum and should be used in parallel with LJ medium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Middlebrook 7H9 broth This medium is used for the isolation, cultivation and identification of mycobacteria.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staining-characteristics">Staining Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mycobacteria are known for their acid fastness: When they are stained with carbol fuchsin in the Ziehl-Neelsen’s(ZN) method, the bacilli are able to retain the red colour of the stain after being treated with mineral acid solution. The reasons for this is because the organisms contain a thick cell wall which is composed of waxes and lipids with high content of mycolic fatty acids. The heated</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 727</p>
<p>stain is able to penetrate the thick cell wall. Because they resist decolourisation with mineral acids, the organisms are referred to as 'acid fast' bacilli. They stain poorly with Gram's method, appearing as Gram positive (shadow cells). The degree of acid fastness varies from species to species. M. leprae for example, is much less acid fast than M. tuberculosis. For such species like M. leprae, a weaker acid solution is used for decolourisation.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nocardia species and some Corynebacterium species are also acid fast.</li>
<li>Routinely acid alcohol is used for decolourisation in the ZN technique for tubercle bacilli because it gives a clearer background. Some workers use the term acid-alcohol fast, even though the alcohol is not essential in the technique.</li>
<li>Most bacteria are readily destroyed by acids and alkalis while mycobacteria show resistance. For this reason, some specimens e.g. sputum and urine, are decontaminated with acid or alkali before culturing for M. tuberculosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="criteria-for-the-identification-of-mycobacteria">Criteria for the Identification of Mycobacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#criteria-for-the-identification-of-mycobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The criteria for the identification of mycobacteria are based on the result of some identification tests together with the cultural characteristics and positive ZN stain.</p>
<p>Identification features for mycobacteria are shown in Table 16.1.</p>
<p>The usual identifications tests for mycobacteria are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth on medium containing 500 µg/ml para-nitro-benzoic acid.</li>
<li>Growth on medium containing 10 µg/ml thiacetazone.</li>
<li>Nitrate reduction.</li>
<li>Arylsulphatase test.</li>
<li>Tween 80 hydrolysis test.</li>
<li>Catalase-peroxidase test.</li>
<li>Niacin test.</li>
<li>Urease production.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="161d2741">♦ MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS (Human Tubercle Bacilli)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#161d2741" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is the major cause of tuberculosis in man. Other causative agents of tuberculosis include M. bovis and M. africanum. M. tuberculosis was originally referred to as Koch's bacillus after Robert Koch who first identified it in 1882.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> M. tuberculosis is found in infected humans and is transmitted to primates, dogs and other animals that are in close association with man. M. bovis is the causative agent of tuberculosis in cattle and is transmissible to man, primates, pigs and domestic animals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>M. tuberculosis causes tuberculosis in man, primates and dogs. The disease is contagious.</p>
<p>The main route of the bacilli entering the body is by inhalation of droplets or dust particles containing the bacilli. Factors such as dose, virulence, age and immune status of the host, contribute to determine the course of the disease. Thus, tuberculosis can occur in different forms:</p>
<p><strong>Pulmonary tuberculosis</strong> In primary infection, the bacilli lodge in the pulmonary alveoli and the surrounding lymph glands resulting in lesions characterised by acute inflammatory reaction with accumulation of fluid and white blood cells around the bacilli. The lesions may heal by resolution; or advance to the productive stage. This stage results in liquefied destruction and breakdown of infected lung tissue into a cheese-like mass (caseation). This is a productive type of lesion as the yellow pieces of caseation material containing large number of the bacilli are coughed out in sputum by the patient. The infection creates cavities in the lung making breathing difficult.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
