<p>trimoxazole and nalidixic acid. It is very resistant to penicillin and ampicillin due to its beta-lactamase production.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-streptomyces">GENUS STREPTOMYCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-streptomyces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>Streptomyces somaliensis.</em></p>
<p>It is non-motile and non-sporing. It is Gram positive in reaction. It may produce spores in culture and these spores (chlamydospores) are acid fast.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> It is normally found as a saprophyte in soil but can cause human infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Occasional infections with <em>S. somaliensis</em> have been reported. It causes mycetoma in Somalia, Sudan and other central African countries, South America and Cuba.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Pus from draining sinuses. The pus may contain yellow-brown granules.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> In smears, the branches are Gram positive and non-acid fast. The spores are weakly acid fast.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> The organisms grow readily on Sabouraud agar. Temperature of growth is 25°C–37°C. The colonies are creamy in colour with a heaped appearance.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> <em>S. somaliensis</em> is urease negative but hydrolyses casein.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Only a few strains of <em>Streptomyces somaliensis</em> are sensitive to penicillin or ampicillin because majority of them produce beta-lactamase. In certain cases, surgical intervention is required as the only form of treatment of the disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-actinomadura">GENUS ACTINOMADURA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-actinomadura" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The species in this group of organisms used to be included in the genus <em>Nocardia</em>. There are two species of medical importance:</p>
<ul>
<li><em>Actinomadura madurae</em></li>
<li><em>Actinomadura pelletieri</em>.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> They are found in soil as saprophytes but are pathogenic to man.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The two species cause mycetoma in man.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Pus from draining sinuses.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Like other genera of <em>Actinomycetes</em>, these organisms are non-motile, non-capso</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Actinomycetes 741</p>
<p>lated and non-sporing. They are Gram positive filamentous, bacillary or coccoid organisms. They are non-acid fast.</p>
<p>A. madurae produces whitish pink granules which are soft and show club shaped forms around the colony.</p>
<p>A. pelletieri produces small dark red granules less than 0.5 mm in diameter.</p>
<p>Culture The two species grow well on Sabouraud agar. Temperature of growth is 25°C–37°C. The colonies are creamy.</p>
<p>Identification tests A. madurae and A. pelletieri hydrolyse casien but are urease negative.</p>
<p>Table 17.2 shows differentiation of Nocardia and Actinomadura species.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity They are sensitive to cotrimoxazole, dapsone, streptomycin and rifampicin. Some strains are resistant to penicillin due to beta-lactamase production.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 18
Aerobic Gram Positive Rods</p>
<p>The aerobic Gram positive rods include the genera <em>Corynebacterium</em>, <em>Listeria</em>, <em>Erysipelothrix</em>, <em>Lactobacillus</em> and <em>Bacillus</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-corynebacterium">GENUS CORYNEBACTERIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-corynebacterium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This genus consists of species that are Gram positive straight or curved rods, that may be club shaped at one pole and may contain volutin granules (intracytoplasmic polyphosphate bodies). They are non-motile, non-acid fast, non-sporing and may stain irregularly and so appear beaded or barred.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> These organisms are normally found in soil, plants and animals. Non-pathogenic strains form part of the resident flora of the skin, upper respiratory tract, urinary tract and conjunctiva.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>C. diphtheriae</em></p>
<p><em>C. diphtheriae</em> has three biovars — <em>C. gravis</em>, <em>C. intermedius</em> and <em>C. mitis</em>.</p>
<p>Other species of importance include <em>C. ulcerans</em>, <em>C. haemolyticum</em>, <em>C. pyogenes</em>, <em>C. ovis</em> (<em>C. pseudotuberculosis</em>) and the JK group of organisms (<em>C. jeikeium</em>). The important commensals are <em>C. hofmanii</em> and <em>C. xerosis</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-diphtheriae">C. DIPHTHERIAE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-diphtheriae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>C. diphtheriae</em> causes nasal, nasopharyngeal and tonsilar diphtheria. Young children are most vulnerable.</p>
<p>Infection with <em>C. diphtheriae</em> is by inhalation of infected droplets or by contact with contaminated objects. Carriers are a major source of spread since they secrete large numbers of the bacilli in the nose. Virulent strains of <em>C. diphtheriae</em> produce specific exotoxins which are absorbed into the mucous membrane, destroying epithelium and resulting in the fibrinous exudates containing bacteria, leucocytes, erythrocytes and disintegrating epithelial cells. All these combine to form a grey pseudomembrane that is characteristic of diphtheric infection. Diphtheria is a toxaemic infection. The organism usually remains at the site of infection.</p>
<p>The pseudomembrane can mechanically obstruct the passage of air in the larynx and cause death by asphyxia. Other major complications of diphtheria are:</p>
<ol>
<li>acute circulatory failure which may be peripheral or cardiac</li>
<li>septic conditions such as pneumonia and otitis media.</li>
<li>postdiphtheric paralysis which may resolve spontaneously.</li>
</ol>
<p>Cutaneous (skin) diphtheria is as a result of infection of open wounds by <em>C. diphtheriae</em>. This infection is generally milder than respiratory infection.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Aerobic Gram Positive Rods 743</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="toxigenicity">Toxigenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxigenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Strains of all the three biovars produce specific toxins. In the past, types of toxins were named according to the severity of the disease they caused. This is no longer valid clinically. All isolates of <em>C. diphtheriae</em> are subjected to the toxigenicity (virulence) tests. The test is either done by in vitro (gel precipitation) or in vivo (subcutaneous or intradermal) methods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="elek-gel-precipitation-test-in-vitro-test">Elek gel precipitation test (in vitro test)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elek-gel-precipitation-test-in-vitro-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Aseptically, soak a strip of filter paper in a solution of diphtheria antitoxin (750–1000 units/ml). Allow the strip to drain.</li>
<li>Place the strip on the surface of 20% calf serum agar in a petri dish while the medium is still molten.</li>
<li>Allow the agar to set and dry at 37°C for about 20 minutes.</li>
<li>Using a sterile wire loop, heavily inoculate test and control organisms (toxigenic and non-toxigenic strains) by streaking at right angles to the strip of filter paper as shown in Figure 18.1.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6328d611.jpeg" alt="img-90.jpeg">
Fig. 18.1 Elek gel precipitation test</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Incubate the plate at 37°C for 24–48 hours.</li>
<li>Using transmitted light and with the culture held against a dark background, observe fine lines of precipitation which may join to form an arc of identity.</li>
</ol>
<p>The toxin produced by the bacterial growth will diffuse into the agar, and where it meets the antitoxin at optimum concentration, will form arrow head lines of precipitation. The presence of these precipitin lines indicate that the strain is toxin producing.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<p>i. Use good quality peptone such as proteose peptone to prepare the medium.
ii. Rabbit or horse serum can also be used in preparing the medium.
iii. It is helpful to position the test organism next to a known toxigenic strain, to demonstrate the joining of lines of precipitation which indicates identity of toxins.
iv. Nearly all strains of biovars gravid and intermedius, and 85–90% of biovar mitis are toxigenic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="animal-inoculation-in-vivo-test">Animal inoculation (in vivo test)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#animal-inoculation-in-vivo-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Emulsify an overnight growth from Loeffler’s slope in 2–5 ml nutrient broth.</li>
<li>Inject 0.8 ml of the emulsion subcutaneously into each of two guinea pigs (identical size), one of which has been protected with 500 units of antitoxin a day before.</li>
<li>In four days the unprotected animal will die if the strain is a virulent one.</li>
</ol>
<p>The test is wasteful and it is no longer performed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intradermal-test">Intradermal test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intradermal-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Protect one of two guinea pigs (identical size) with 1000 units of diphtheria antitoxin.</li>
<li>The next day, inject each animal intradermally with 0.2 ml of the bacterial suspension (prepared as described above).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="unprotected-animal">Unprotected animal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#unprotected-animal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Virulent strains, in 24–48 hours will give a well defined red area about 12 × 18 cm in diameter; in 48–96 hours, a necrotic patch with scab develops.</p>
<p>Non-virulent strain—No reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="protected-control-animal">Protected (control) animal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protected-control-animal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Virulent strain, in 24–48 hours, will give a raised red papule which begins to fade at 48–96 hours.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>744 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Non-virulent strain—No reaction.</p>
<p>Schick test This is a skin test to demonstrate circulating diphtheria antitoxin produced in response to current infection or previous vaccination. It detects susceptibility and hypersensitivity to diphtheria toxin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens Usually, diagnosis of diphtheria is made clinically so that the role of the laboratory is to confirm the clinical diagnosis. The specimens required for this include throat, nasal or nasopharyngeal swab. Skin swab is collected when cutaneous diphtheria is suspected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Gram stain: Gram staining of the specimen is not useful because it is not possible to differentiate <em>C. diphtheriae</em> from non-pathogenic corynebacteria which are a part of the normal flora in the upper respiratory tract. In Gram's stained smear made from Loeffler's slope, the <em>C. diphtheriae</em> biovars are seen and described as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>biovar gravis very pleomorphic with some coccoid forms and tend to stain evenly.</li>
<li>biovar intermidius very pleomorphic with irregular bands.</li>
<li>biovar mitis long pleomorphic rods.</li>
</ul>
<p>Generally, it is not possible to differentiate these strains from Gram's stained smear. They are all pleomorphic, with club shaped ends, and are arranged in palisades or the typical 'Chinese lettering' forms.</p>
<p>(ii) Albert's stain This is a special stain to demonstrate volutin or metachromatic granules. The organisms stain green while the granules are darkly stained.</p>
<p>The organisms are also well demonstrated with methylene blue (granules stain dark blue) or toluidine blue (granules stain dark red).</p>
<p>Figure 18.2 (a) and (b) show the morphology of <em>C. diphtheriae</em> in Gram's stained and Albert's stained smears.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9eb518ef.jpeg" alt="img-91.jpeg">
Fig. 18.2 (a) <em>C. diphtheriae</em> in gram stained smear (b) <em>C. diphtheriae</em> stained with Albert's showing metachromatic granules</p>
<p>Albert's stain is also not diagnostic as most of the <em>Corynebacterium</em> species produce metachromatic granules. The presence of the metachromatic granules should however be reported if diphtheria is suspected clinically.</p>
<p>Culture Media used in the isolation of <em>C. diphtheriae</em> are blood agar, Hoyle's tellurite medium and Loeffler's serum slope, although the organisms do grow on other media.</p>
<p>Blood agar is used to exclude haemolytic <em>Streptococcus</em> which may cause similar lesions. Hoyle's tellurite medium is selective for <em>C. diphtheriae</em>. It reduces tellurite and produces grey to black colonies <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5 - 2\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> in diameter after 48 hours.</p>
<p>Loeffler's serum agar enhances the production of volutin granules. This medium promotes the growth of <em>C. diphtheriae</em> within 4–6 hours. Non-pathogenic corynebacteria require 18–24 hours to produce visible growth.</p>
<p>All cultures are incubated aerobically at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>. On Hoyle's medium, the colonial appearance of <em>C. diphtheriae</em> biovars are as follows:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Aerobic Gram Positive Rods 745</p>
<p>Biovar gravis large (1–2 mm) convex, dark grey colonies; rarely haemolytic on blood agar.
Biovar intermedius small (0.5–1 mm) flat, jet black glossy colonies; non-haemolytic on blood agar.
Biovar mitis large (1–2 mm) dark grey to black glossy colonies; beta-haemolytic on blood agar.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Other useful selective media are Tinsdale’s medium and Downe’s medium.</li>
<li>Dorset egg medium can be used in place of Loeffler’s serum agar.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong>
Biochemically, <em>C. diphtheriae</em> ferments glucose, and maltose, and is catalase and nitrate positive, (biovar gravis alone ferments starch and glycogen). All the strains are urease negative.
Table 18.1 shows the differential tests for <em>Corynebacterium</em> species.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Fermentation tests for <em>C. diphtheriae</em> are performed in Hiss’s serum sugar media.</li>
<li>API CORYNE is available for the biochemical identification of <em>C. diphtheriae</em>.</li>
</ol>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>C. diphtheriae</em> is usually sensitive to penicillin, erythromycin and lincomycin. Antitoxin is used in therapy to neutralise <em>C. diphtheriae</em> toxin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-ulcerans">C. ULCERANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-ulcerans" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This organism is primarily a parasite of animals. It causes mastitis in cattle. In man it may cause lesion similar to diphtheria. It produces an exotoxin which shows partial identity with that of <em>C. diphtheriae</em>. The toxic illness should therefore be treated with diphtheria antitoxin.</p>
<p><em>C. ulcerans</em> grows well on Hoyle’s medium, blood agar and Loeffler’s serum agar. The colonies are similar to those of biovar gravis of <em>C. diphtheriae</em>. It produces a narrow zone of haemolysis on blood agar. Biochemically, it is distinguished from <em>C. diphtheriae</em> by its ability to liquefy gelatin and hydrolyse urea.</p>
<p><strong>Table 18.1 Differentiation tests for <em>Corynebacterium</em> species</strong></p>
