<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Gas gangrene group</strong> <em>C. perfringens</em>: A Gram stained smear shows stout Gram positive bacilli with straight, parallel sides and rounded or truncated ends, about 4–6 μm × 1 μm, usually in singles, in chains or small clusters. Spores, which are absent in smears from culture or specimens, are central or subterminal and can be induced on special media such as Ellner’s medium. Figure 20.1 shows Gram stained smear of <em>C. perfringens</em>.</p>
<p><strong>C. septicum</strong> The smear shows pleomorphic Gram positive rods with irregular staining. Spores are oval and subterminal.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>758 Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f9437f9f.jpeg" alt="img-93.jpeg">
Fig. 20.1 Gram stained smear of Clostridium perfringens</p>
<p>C. oedematiens These are large bacilli with parallel sides and rounded ends; and the spores are large, oval and subterminal.</p>
<p>C. histolyticum It's morphology is similar to that of C. oedematiens but filamentous forms with no spores are seen when grown aerobically.</p>
<p>The other gas gangrene species are morphologically similar with oval, central or subterminal spores (Table 20.1).</p>
<p>C. tetani These are long, slender Gram positive rods with round spores at one end giving the classical 'drum stick' appearance as shown in Fig. 20.2. It is motile (except type 6) and non-capsulated. Older cultures are easily over decolourised.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3e13ec72.jpeg" alt="img-94.jpeg">
Fig. 20.2 Clostridium tetani with terminal spores</p>
<p>C. botulinum It is a pleomorphic Gram positive rod, non-capsulated, and motile. It produces oval subterminal bulging spores. The spores survive boiling at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>100</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> for three hours.</p>
<p>C. difficile It is a long slender Gram positive rod that is easily over decolourised. It has large oval and subterminal spores.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clostridium species are either obligate anaerobes or facultative anaerobes. The pathogenic species grow best at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35-37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Media used for the isolation of clostridia:</p>
<ul>
<li>Gentamycin blood agar</li>
<li>Plain blood agar</li>
<li>Cooked meat broth</li>
<li>Litmus milk</li>
<li>Lactose-egg-yolk-milk agar</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-perfringens">C. perfringens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-perfringens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is an anaerobe but may grow under microaerophilic conditions. Growth temperature is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20-50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> with the optimum at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>It grows well in Robertson's cooked meat (RCM) broth and turns the meat pink without digesting it.</p>
<p>In case of food poisoning, boil a small portion of the faeces in RCM broth for one hour and then incubate overnight.</p>
<p>In litmus milk, lactose is fermented with acid production which is indicated by the change in colour of litmus from blue to red. The acid coagulates the casein of the milk (acid clot). The clotted milk is broken up due to large amount of gas production. This phenomenon is known as 'stormy clot'.</p>
<p>On blood agar after 24 hours incubation, colonies of most strains show double haemolysis resulting from a narrow zone of complete haemolysis and a much wider zone of incomplete haemolysis (Fig. 20.3). This pattern of haemolysis may fade on longer incubation.</p>
<p>On lactose-egg-yolk milk agar, it produces opalescence and ferments lactose.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Anaerobic Gram Positive Rods 759</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-19f1c033.jpeg" alt="img-95.jpeg">
Fig. 20.3 Double zones of haemolysis of clostridium perfringens on blood agar</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-septicum">C. septicum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-septicum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a strict anaerobe. Optimum temperature is 35–37°C.</p>
<p>On blood agar, colonies are large, irregular, and beta-haemolytic with filamentous edges. It is sacchrolytic in action and produces abundant gas, and may ferment lactose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-oedematiens-c-novyi">C. oedematiens (C.novyi)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-oedematiens-c-novyi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a strict anaerobe. It produces beta haemolytic, irregular colonies on blood agar. (Type C, the non-human strain does not produce haemolysis).</p>
<p>On lactose-egg-yolk-milk agar, Type A produces opalescence and pearly layer with no lactose fermentation; Types B and D produce opalescence, no pearly layer, no lactose fermentation. Type C shows no change in the medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-histolyticum">C. histolyticum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-histolyticum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This species is aerotolerant and some strains do grow aerobically. Colonies on blood agar are haemolytic and irregular, about 1–2 mm in diameter; colonies are smaller when grown aerobically.</p>
<p>It is actively proteolytic. On lactose-egg yolk agar, it produces clearing of the medium with no lactose fermentation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-tetani">C. tetani<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-tetani" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a strict anaerobe and the optimum temperature is 37°C. It grows on ordinary media but growth is enhanced by blood or serum. It produces a thin transparent film of growth which tends to swarm over the surface of the agar. This swarming is best seen if it is cultured at the bottom of blood agar slope where the delicately filamentous advancing edge can be observed.</p>
<p>It grows well in RCM broth with turbidity and gas formation. The meat is not digested but is turned black on prolonged incubation.</p>
<p>On blood agar, alpha haemolysis is produced, which later develops into beta haemolysis.</p>
<p>On lactose-egg yolk-milk agar, there is no opalescence, proteolysis or lactose fermentation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-botulinum">C. botulinum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-botulinum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a strict anaerobe. Optimum temperature is 35°C but some strains are psychrophilic. It grows well on ordinary media.</p>
<p>On blood agar, colonies are large, irregular semi-transparent with smooth centre and curled or fimbriate edges. Some strains are beta haemolytic.</p>
<p>On lactose-egg-yolk-milk agar, there is opalescence and pearly layer with non-fermentation of lactose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-difficile">C. difficile<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-difficile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a strict anaerobe and it is non-haemolytic on blood agar. It is only weakly saccharolytic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests">Identification Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tests which are valuable in the identification of clostridia include fermentation of various carbohydrates (especially lactose), lecithinase C, lipase, proteinase and urease activities. Other tests are indole production and gelatin liquefaction. The reactions of these tests are shown in Table 20.1.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>760 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Lecithinase, lipase, lactose and proteinase reactions are all demonstrated by using lactose-egg-yolk-milk agar but the medium should be incubated anaerobically for more than 24 hours (up to 72 hours) to detect proteolytic activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lecithinase-c-phospholipase">Lecithinase C (Phospholipase)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lecithinase-c-phospholipase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the lecithin in the egg yolk is broken down by lecithinase C (Phospholipase) produced by the organism, an opacity is seen in the medium.</p>
<p>This enzyme is produced by <em>C. perfringens</em>, <em>C. oedematiens</em> and a few others.</p>
<p>The lecithinase C (alpha toxin) produced by clostridia can be inactivated by specific antitoxic serum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nagler-reaction">Nagler reaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nagler-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>C. perfringens</em> produces opacity in medium containing lecithin as a result of lecithinase C activity. If specific antitoxin serum is applied to the medium, the opacity can be inhibited. This phenomenon is known as Nagler reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Prepare a Nagler plate: 20% serum agar, or 5% egg-yolk agar or lactose-egg-yolk-milk agar. (The lactose-egg-yolk-milk agar in addition differentiates <em>C. perfringens</em> by its lactose fermentation from other Nagler positive clostridia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>With a sterile swab, cover one-half of the plate with <em>C. perfringens</em> antitoxin. Allow to dry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inoculate the test organism at right angles to the centre line moving from the antitoxin free side to the antitoxin covered half. Similarly inoculate a non-toxin producing control.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubate the plate anaerobically at 37°C overnight.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="result">Result<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#result" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If the test organism is <em>C. perfringens</em>, opacity will occur around the inoculum in the half containing no antitoxin, while there is no opacity in the other half containing antitoxin. This is due to the production of enzyme, lecithinase by <em>C. perfringens</em> causing the lecithin present in the serum or egg yolk to precipitate. The antitoxin neutralises lecithinase C and prevents precipitation in the other half.</p>
<p>A positive Nagler reaction is shown in Fig. 20.4.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. The whole surface of the medium can be inoculated with the test organism, in which case a positive reaction is not limited only to the line of inoculum.
&gt; 2. <em>C. bifermentans</em> will also give positive Nagler reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lipase-hydrolysis-lipolysis">Lipase hydrolysis (lipolysis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipase-hydrolysis-lipolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lipase hydrolysis is detected as the pearly layer of fatty acid which</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c2d55ada.jpeg" alt="img-96.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 20.4 Diagrammatic representation of Nagler reaction shown by Clostridium perfringens</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Anaerobic Gram-Positive Rods 761</p>
<p>covers the colonies and sometimes extending into the medium around the colonies. C. bolutinum produces lipase.</p>
<p><strong>Proteinase activity (Proteolytic activity)</strong> When enzyme proteinase breaks down the casein in milk to produce zones of clearing beneath and around the colonies, this indicates proteolytic activity. The medium is incubated anaerobically for 48–72 hours.</p>
<p>This activity is also shown when the meat particles in the cooked meat medium are digested to form dark red or grey sludge at the bottom of the container. A foul odour is often produced. C. botulinum, C. histolyticum and a few others have proteolytic activity.</p>
<p><strong>Saccharolytic activity (Carbohydrate fermentation)</strong> Saccharolytic activity is shown by the organism's ability to ferment glucose, lactose, maltose and sucrose.</p>
<p>Saccharolytic activity can also be demonstrated by the reddening of the meat in the cooked meat-medium, possibly due to the reduction of haematin.</p>
<p><strong>Gelatin liquefaction</strong> Most species, especially the gas gangrene and food poisoning species, liquefy gelatine.</p>
<p><strong>Gas liquid chromatography (GLC)</strong> The gas liquid chromatography techniques can be applied to detect anaerobic bacteria in pus or exudate. The technique is not routinely used.</p>
<p><strong>The reverse CAMP test</strong> The reverse CAMP test is a specific test for identifying C. perfringens. It is based on the production of enhanced haemolysis when Group B streptococci and C. perfringens are grown together.</p>
<p><strong>Technique</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Prepare 5% tryptose blood agar using sheep blood.</li>
<li>Streak suspected C. perfringens suspension at right angles to streaks of Group B Streptococcus, leaving a gap of about 5 mm at their closest points.</li>
<li>Incubate the plates anaerobically at 37°C overnight.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Result</strong> C. perfringens will give a bullet-shaped zone of enhanced haemolysis at the site in which the inoculum streaks are closest.</p>
<p><strong>Commercial identification systems</strong> The API system is routinely used by some laboratories. It is easy to use and saves time. The Minitek II system is another useful system used for the identification of anaerobic bacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Clostridium species are usually sensitive to penicillin, metronidazole, clindamycin, tetracycline and erythromycin. Most species are resistant to the aminoglycosides.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-propionibacterium">GENUS PROPIONIBACTERIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-propionibacterium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Propionibacterium</em> consists of organisms that were formerly classified as anaerobic corynebacteria. They are Gram positive thin rods that are anaerobic, slightly aerotolerant, non-motile, and non-sporing.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> P. acnes.</p>
<p>The other species of note is P. granulosum. They are both part of normal skin flora. They may be found in blood cultures and other cultures when they are often considered as contaminants.</p>
<p>P. acnes is associated with the skin disease, acne. They may also be significant under certain conditions such as septicaemia in the immunosuppressed patients. They can also cause infections of prosthetic implants e.g. endocarditis in patients with prosthetic valves or arthritis in prosthetic joints. It is not right therefore, to dismiss such bacteria as contaminants. If more than one culture is positive, then P. acnes can be suspected.</p>
<p>On blood agar incubated anaerobically at 37°C, P. acnes produces small whitish pink colonies.</p>
<p>The definitive identification of the organisms can easily be performed using the API-A system. P. acnes is indole and catalase positive, and produces propionic acid from carbohydrate fermentation. An anaerobic Gram positive, thin, slightly curved rod that is catalase and indole positive, is almost certainly P. acnes.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 21
Spirochaetes</p>
<p>The term 'Spirochaete' was first used to describe large flexible motile organisms found in water. The term is now used to describe a family of bacteria, <em>Spirochaetaceae</em>, whose members are long, motile and twisted spirally round a long axis. They are found in water, soil and decaying organic matter.</p>
<p>They vary in size, some may be as long as 20 µm and others as short as 5 µm. They can move forwards and backwards by bending and rotating the body. They divide by transverse fission and there is no definite nucleus. They are not easily stained. Many of them are saprophytes and commensals but some are pathogens for man and animals.</p>
<p>The spirochaetes of medical importance belong to three genera:</p>
<p><em>Treponoma</em>
<em>Borrelia</em>
<em>Leptospira</em></p>
<p>Table 21.1 shows the basic differences between the three genera.</p>
<p>Table 21.1 Basic differentiation between the spirochaete genera: <em>Borrelia</em>, <em>Treponema</em>, <em>Leptospira</em></p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Borrelia</th><th>Treponema</th><th>Leptospira</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Length</td><td>8–16 µm</td><td>5–18 µm</td><td>6–20 µm</td></tr><tr><td>Width</td><td>0.25–0.3 µm</td><td>0.25–0.3 µm</td><td>0.1–0.2 µm</td></tr><tr><td>Ends</td><td>Terminally tapers to fine filaments</td><td>Pointed; may have terminal filaments</td><td>One or both ends in semicircular hooks</td></tr><tr><td>Spirals</td><td>4–8 (loose)</td><td>6–14 (regularly angular)</td><td>Many, fine and tight</td></tr><tr><td>Motility</td><td>Lashing, cork-screw like</td><td>Rotating undulating, flexible</td><td>Spinning and undulating</td></tr><tr><td>Cultivable</td><td>Readily (anaerobic)</td><td>Very difficult (anaerobic)</td><td>Readily, microaerophilic</td></tr><tr><td>Staining</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Aniline dyes</td><td>Yes</td><td>No</td><td>No</td></tr><tr><td>Giemsa</td><td>Yes</td><td>Yes</td><td>Yes (difficult)</td></tr><tr><td>Silver impregnation</td><td>Yes</td><td>Yes</td><td>Yes</td></tr><tr><td>Dark ground microscopy</td><td>Yes</td><td>Yes</td><td>Yes</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Spirochaetes 763</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-treponema">GENUS TREPONEMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-treponema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The genus <em>Treponema</em> consists of numerous species. Two main groups are recognised within the genus: The commensal treponemes that are normally found in the mouth, gastrointestinal tract, and urogenital tract of humans; and the treponemes pathogenic to man.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> Treponemae are small, slender, flexible anaerobic organisms measuring about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-18 \times 0.2 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.2</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> with 6–12 evenly sized coils. They have a slow bending and rotating motility. The spirals are fine with low refractive index and so they cannot be seen with the ordinary light microscope; the dark field microscopy is used. They cannot be stained by the usual bacteriological stain but can be stained by silver impregnation techniques.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>T. pallidum</em>. Other species of medical importance are <em>T. pertenue</em>, <em>T. carateum</em>, <em>T. cunicola</em>.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; T. pallidum and T. pertenue are now classified as subspecies of Treponema pallidum. Thus, they are T. pallidum subspecies pallidum and T. pallidum subspecies pertenue respectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>T. pallidum</em> subspecies <em>pallidium</em> causes syphilis which may be acquired sexually or congenitally.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="syphilis">SYPHILIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Syphilis can be discussed under the headings:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="sexually-transmitted-syphilis">Sexually transmitted syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sexually-transmitted-syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This form of syphilis is transmitted by sexual intercourse. The disease occurs in three stages: primary, secondary and latent stages.</p>
<p><strong>Primary syphilis</strong> About 2–4 weeks after infection, ulcer develops, usually around the genital areas. This ulcer is known as chancre. The chancre is a hard, painless relatively clean, circumscribed, indurated, superficially ulcerated lesion. It is also referred to as hard chancre to differentiate it from the painful soft chancre caused by <em>Haemophilus ducreyi</em>. The chancre fluid is rich in treponemes, and the regional lymph nodes are enlarged. The lesion may spontaneously heal up without treatment in 10–40 days. Primary syphilis is highly infectious.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; The chancre may also be seen around the mouth and the nipple.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="secondary-syphilis">Secondary syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>About 2–8 weeks after the primary lesion has healed, skin eruptions may occur, resulting in red rashes with papules. This is due to widespread multiplication of the spirochaetes and dissemination in the blood. Treponemes are abundant in the lesions. The patient is highly infectious and can transmit <em>T. pallidum</em> in his blood. The secondary stage is also accompanied by malaise, fever and generalised lymphadenopathy. About 30% of patients develop flat genital lesions called condylomata. This stage may last from ten days to one year. Relapses may occur between two and four years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="early-latent-syphilis">Early latent syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#early-latent-syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is the inactive period following the secondary stage. About 70% of patients will show no signs of disease. This stage is generally regarded as a non-infectious stage, though the foetus of an infected pregnant woman can be infected. This period is about one to two years after the secondary stage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="late-tertiary-syphilis">Late (tertiary) syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#late-tertiary-syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This stage may appear at least three years after the secondary stage in an untreated patient. Progressive inflammatory lesions of any organ or tissue may develop, but the central nervous system and the cardiovascular system are involved. Other complications of the late syphilis include gummas or granulomas of skin or bone, liver damage, eye impairment or ear dysfunction. Neurosyphilis may appear as acute meningitis or meningovascular involvement of the CNS. This condition is generally referred to as the ‘general paralysis of the insane’. The late stage is non-infectious except to the foetus of infected pregnant mother.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>764 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Congenitally acquired syphilis A pregnant mother with untreated syphilis may infect her infant. This is by transplacental transmission. Congenital syphilis causes foetal death in about 40% of cases. If the infection of the foetus occurs early in the pregnancy, abortion may result. Clinical symptoms in live born babies may not appear until about one year after birth. The most common signs are skin eruptions (rashes), jaundice, painful limbs, ascitis, anaemia and the infant may develop ‘Saddle’ nose.</p>
<p>Non venereal syphilis The disease may be acquired as an occupational hazard by doctors, nurses and laboratory workers; or through blood transfusion. The organism gains entry into the body through abraded skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-treponemal-infections">Other Treponemal Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-treponemal-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>T. pertenue causes yaws (also known as framboesia and buba), an endemic disease of humid hot tropical countries, pathologically resembling syphilis but differing mainly in its contagious and non-venereal character. It produces ulcerating papules on the skin, particularly of legs, feet, hands and face. It may involve the external lining of the bones with considerable pain especially during the later stages.</p>
<p>T. carateum causes pinta (also known as carate, and mal del pinto) an endemic disease in Mexico, South America and the Philippines. The disease gives rise to a non-ulcerating papule which during later stages, may involve cardiovascular and central nervous systems.</p>
<p>T. cunicola causes rabbit syphilis and morphologically looks like T. pallidum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis-of-syphilis">Laboratory Diagnosis of Syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis-of-syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Fluid from the lesion is collected for microscopy during the primary and secondary stages. Blood is collected for serological tests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="collection-of-specimen-from-the-primary-chancre">Collection of specimen from the primary chancre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-specimen-from-the-primary-chancre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>With clean gauze soaked in warm saline, clean the lesion.</li>
<li>Gently scrape the margins of the lesion, thus abrading the superficial epithelium.</li>
<li>Gently apply pressure to the base of the lesion and collect the fluid. The fluid may be collected with a pasteur pipette, or by touching the fluid (if scanty) with the corner edge of a cover slip.</li>
<li>Promptly, make a wet film with the fluid and place a thin cover slip on it.</li>
<li>Examine using the dark field microscope at 40 x magnification. Repeated examinations are necessary before negative results are reported since a high level of expertise is required for accurate performance and proper interpretation of results.</li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 21.1 shows T. pallidum under the dark ground microscope.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5c6747ef.jpeg" alt="img-97.jpeg">
Fig. 21.1 Treponema pallidum under dark ground illumination</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Phase contrast microscopy may be also useful for the examination of the wet preparation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stained-preparation">Stained preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stained-preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The organisms do not take up ordinary stains. They can however be demonstrated with the silver impregnation techniques, and a few other staining methods. None of these methods is routinely used in the diagnosis of syphilis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>T. pallidum together with other pathogenic species, has not yet been successfully cultured in artificial medium. It is possible to maintain the organism in a complex fluid medium under</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Spirochaetes 765</p>
<p>anaerobic condition for about 10–14 days. A non-pathogenic strain, the Reiter's strain, is cultivable. The Nichol's strain of <em>T. pallidum</em> has been maintained by a serial passage in adult rabbit testes since its isolation in 1912 from the brain of a fatal case of general paralysis of the insane.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serological-tests-for-syphilis-sts">Serological Tests for Syphilis (STS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serological-tests-for-syphilis-sts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serological tests for syphilis are classified on the basis of the type of antigens used. They are categorised into:</p>
<ol>
<li>Non treponemal (non specific) tests and</li>
<li>Treponemal (specific) tests.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Non-treponemal tests</strong> These tests are not immunologically specific for syphilis. The antibody response is a non-specific autoantibody known as ‘reagin’ which is produced within 2–3 weeks of treponemal infection due to tissue damage. The tests use lipoidal antigens consisting of alcoholic extract of ox heart muscle to which cholesterol and lecithin have been added. It is used to detect the ‘reagin’ antibody. The ‘reagin’ antibodies belong to the IgM and IgG classes of immunoglobulin. The non-treponemal tests are useful:</p>
<p>(i) for screening for active infection
(ii) for monitoring response to therapy
(iii) as an aid in diagnosing congenital infection.</p>
<p>Many of the non-treponemal tests are flocculation tests, such as the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL), Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR), Unheated Serum Reagin (USR) and the Reagin Screen Test (RST). They are easy to perform. The tests are similar in performance and in their relationship to disease although RPR and VDRL (in that order) may be slightly more sensitive and definitely most popular. The tests are all based on direct agglutination of antigen particles by cardiolipin antibodies.</p>
<p>Complement Fixation Tests (CFT) for the detection of ‘reagin’ antibody (Wassermann and Cardiolipin) are no longer done because they are time consuming and labour intensive.</p>
<p>‘Reagin’ antibody titres are usually elevated in acute phases but may lapse in titre during inactive phases; and may be totally absent during late latent stages.</p>
<p><strong>Biological false positives (BFP)</strong> The major disadvantage of non-treponemal tests is that the antigen may react with sera of patients who may not have syphilis. False positive reactions not due to technical error are referred to as biological false positives. They can occur in a wide variety of infectious and non-infectious situations associated with tissue damage.</p>
<p>These conditions include malaria, hepatitis, mumps, leprosy, infectious mononucleosis, rheumatoid arthritis and collagen diseases.</p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Tissue cardiolipin has been replaced by chemically synthesised cardiolipin for the non-treponemal tests.</li>
<li>An ELISA method for detection of reagin antibody is available.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Treponemal tests</strong> These are specific tests that detect antibody to <em>T. pallidum</em> or other treponemes. The tests include <em>Treponema pallidum</em> immobilisation (TPI) test, the fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption test (FTA-ABS) and the <em>Treponema pallidum</em> haemagglutination (TPHA) test.</p>
<p>Other tests such as the Reiter Protein Complement fixation tests have become obsolete.</p>
<p>The specific tests are generally used as confirmatory tests in patients with questionable syphilis or positive RPR or VDRL test. These treponemal tests tend to remain positive for life even long after the treponemes are no longer present in the tissues.</p>
<p><strong>TPI test</strong> This was the first method used to detect antibodies against pathogenic treponemes. It makes use of live treponemes as antigens. The test has been discontinued because</p>
<p>(a) there is a risk of infection during performance of the test
(b) it is cumbersome
(c) it is costly and</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>766 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(d) there are less costly and easier tests available.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fta-abs-test">FTA-ABS test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fta-abs-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an indirect immunofluorescence test which uses smears prepared from Nichol's strain of <em>T. pallidum</em> as antigen. The patient's diluted serum is allowed to react with the antigen. Excess serum is washed off and smear treated with anti human immunoglobulin-fluorescent dye conjugate. After incubation, and then washing, the slide is examined under fluorescent microscope.</p>
<p>The original test used 1:5 dilution of the patient's serum and there were many false positive reactions. It was then modified to use 1:200 dilution of serum and became known as FTA 200. This again failed to completely eliminate false positives. A further modification is the FTA-ABS in which the serum is first absorbed with sorbent (extract of Reiter treponeme) to remove non-specific and group reactive antibodies. The FTA-ABS is very specific and sensitive. The test is positive as early as 1–2 weeks after infection (earlier than RPR or VDRL). It is however a fairly expensive test as it requires special equipments such as fluorescent microscope.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tpha-test">TPHA test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tpha-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a very specific and sensitive test similar to the FTA-ABS test. The antigen (Nochol's strain of <em>T. pallidum</em>) is adsorbed on sheep, chicken or turkey red cells. (These are called sensitised cells). A non-sensitised red cell suspension is used as control.</p>
<p>The patient's serum is first absorbed to get rid of unwanted antibodies and then mixed with the sensitised cells. In the presence of treponemal antibody, the treponemes will adhere to the red cells and settle as orange-red layer in the well of the test plate. The TPHA test is recommended in preference to the FTA-ABS test because it is easier, quicker and cheaper to perform.</p>
<p><em>T. pertenue</em> and <em>T. carateum</em> antibodies are also detected using the serological tests for syphilis.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; For the detailed techniques and interpretation of results of these tests, see Chapter on Common Serological Tests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neurosyphilis">Neurosyphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neurosyphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Screening CSF for syphilitic antibody in cases of neurosyphilis is controversial. In practice, reactive VDRL-CSF (RPR cannot be used) is rare. It is however, the recommended test for patients with clinical evidence of neurosyphilis. FTA-ABS is not recommended while TPHA may be valuable if performed within 4–8 hours of collection of specimen. Screening the serum of neurosyphilitic patient is a better option.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibiotic-sensitivity">Antibiotic sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sensitivity of <em>T. pallidum</em> or other pathogenic treponemes, to penicillin has remained constant since its introduction as the drug of choice for treatment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11ac03f1">◆ GENUS BORRELIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11ac03f1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="characteristics">Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>Borrelia</em> organisms are large (10–30 μm in length), motile and refractile spirochaetes with irregular wide open coils. They are readily stained with ordinary stains and are Gram negative. They are usually seen with fusiform bacilli in Vincent's angina. They can be cultured in tissue cultures and in fluid media enriched with animal proteins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species">Type species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>B. vincenti</em>. Other important species are <em>B. recurrentis</em> and <em>B. duttoni</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="habitat">Habitat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#habitat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>B. vincenti</em> is a normal commensal of the mouth and throat.</p>
<p><em>B. recurrentis</em> is found in body louse (<em>Pediculus corporis</em>) which becomes infected when sucking blood from an infected human host.</p>
<p><em>B. duttoni</em> is borne by soft ticks which live in cracks of walls and floors. They become infected when they feed on an animal or human whose blood contains the organisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>B. vincenti</em> is associated with ulcerative gingivostomatitis and pseudomembranous condition of the throat (Vincent's angina). The spirochaetes are usually seen with large fusiform bacilli and <em>Bacteroides</em>. Malnutrition and viral infections are predisposing factors for <em>B. vincenti</em> to cause disease.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Spirochaetes 767</p>
<p>B. recurrentis causes relapsing fever which is endemic in North and East Africa and in India.</p>
<p>Relapsing fever occurs as fever of sudden onset with symptoms of severe headache, body pains and vomiting which lasts about 3–5 days. The disease may eventually subside after 3–10 relapses occurring at 4–7 days intervals.</p>
<p>During febrile periods, borreliae are abundant in the blood. The infection results in damage to the liver, spleen, kidney and blood vessels, causing haemorrhagic symptoms and jaundice. Overcrowding in unhygienic environment is a predisposing factor for the disease. Transmission to man is by the louse being crushed and rubbed into abraded skin or by louse bite.</p>
<p>B. duttoni causes tick-borne relapsing fever which mainly occurs in the tropical and subtropical areas of the world. The infection does not occur as an epidemic. The symptoms are similar to the louse borne variety but in the former there are usually more relapses. The ticks act as vectors as well as reservoirs. Transmission to man is through tick bites.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>B. Vincenti Pus or exudate from lesions is collected for microscopy.</p>
<p>B. recurrentis and B. duttoni: Blood sample is collected during febrile periods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>B. Vincenti Gram stained smear will reveal Gram negative spirochaetes and fusiform rods. Small Gram negative rods (Bacteroides) may also be present.</p>
<p>The smear can also be stained with 1:15 dilution of carbol fuchsin for 10 minutes. This is quick and simple if Vincent's angina is strongly suspected.</p>
<p>Figure 21.2 shows a throat swab stained smear of Vincent's angina.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3e6923cf.jpeg" alt="img-98.jpeg">
Fig. 21.2 Throat swab smear showing Borrelia vincenti and fusobacteria</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-recurrentis-and-b-duttoni">B. recurrentis and B. duttoni<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-recurrentis-and-b-duttoni" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>A drop of blood examined as a wet preparation under dark ground or phase contrast microscope may reveal borreliae due to their lashing motility.</li>
<li>Blood smears (thick and thin) may be stained with Giemsa or Leishman, or with dilute carbol fuchsin and examined for spirochaetes.</li>
<li>Centrifuge EDTA or heparin anticoagulated blood in a capillary at 2000 rpm for five minutes. Motile borreliae may be found in the plasma layer above the buffy coat layer when viewed under the microscope. Confirm any positive movement by stained preparation.</li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 21.3 shows B. recurrentis in peripheral blood.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-dd3d0373.jpeg" alt="img-99.jpeg">
Fig. 21.3 Borrelia recurrentis in peripheral blood</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>768 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Culture Cultivation of <em>Borrelia</em> organisms is not a routine procedure, though they have been successfully cultured in Kelly's medium.</p>
<p>Serological tests Unlike the treponemes, serological tests for borrelia are not reliable. This is due to the fact that the organisms undergo antigenic variations <em>in vivo</em> and so it is difficult to prepare a satisfactory antigen for the detection of antibodies.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>Borrelia</em> organisms are sensitive to penicillin and tetracycline.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lyme-disease">Lyme disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lyme-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lyme disease is caused by <em>Borrelia burgdorferi</em>. It is characterised by a rash (erythema chronicum migrans) at the site of the bite by an ixodes tick. This is followed by involvement of the central nervous system in the form of meningitis or encephalitis. There may be attacks of arthritis, myocarditis and atrophic dermatitis months or years later. In the acute phase, there may be headache, fever, regional adenopathy and conjunctivitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>B. burgdorferi</em>, like other <em>Borrelia</em> species can be isolated in artificial culture medium such as the Barbona Stoener Kelly (BSK) medium.</p>
<p>BSK medium is a complex tissue culture medium supplemented with bovine serum albumin, peptone, yeast extract, HEPES buffer, pyruvate, glucose, N-acetylglucosamine and rabbit serum.</p>
<p>Lyme disease can be diagnosed serologically using ELISA techniques. The IgG antibody rises slowly during the acute phase and rises to higher levels in later stages of the disease. Following successful treatment, the IgM becomes negative while the IgG gradually disappears.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity The organism is sensitive to penicillin, cephalosporins, erythromycin and tetracycline. Any of these drugs can be used for the effective treatment of Lyme disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-leptospira">GENUS LEPTOSPIRA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-leptospira" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Organisms in the genus <em>Leptospira</em> differ from the other spirochaetes morphologically, in their type of motility and their being easily cultivable. They are not stained easily with ordinary stains but like the treponemes, can be demonstrated by silver impregnation techniques such as Fontana and Levaditi's methods, or better still by dark ground microscopy.</p>
<p>They are thin coiled spirochaetes, about 6–20 × 0.1 μm, with one or both ends hooked (Fig. 21.4). They are found worldwide. Animals are the natural reservoirs of these organisms, and they tend to be host specific.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-940b7d24.jpeg" alt="img-100.jpeg">
Fig. 21.4 <em>Leptospira</em> as seen under dark ground microscope</p>
<p>Type species <em>L. interrogans</em>. Human infections are mostly associated with rats, mice, pigs, cattle and dogs. Table 21.2 shows a list of some serotypes of <em>L. interrogans</em> with their primary carrier hosts, animals infected and distribution.</p>
<p>Pathogenicity Leptospires can cause infections where symptoms vary from mild undifferentiated pyrexia to severe and sometimes fatal illness. Leptospirosis occurs in the natural host without symptoms. Human infection occurs when leptospires in water contaminated by the urine of carrier or infected animals enter the body through damaged skin or through intact mucosa of mouth, nose and conjunctiva. In the severe form, symptoms include continuous fever, headache, muscle pains, redness of eyes and general weakness. Meningitis may also occur. Severe leptospirosis is often fatal. <em>L. interrogans</em> serovar <em>icterohaemorrhagiae</em> causes severe infectious jaundice (Weil's disease) which results in liver damage and kidney failure.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Spirochaetes 769</p>
<p>Table 21.2 Some serotypes of the Genus Leptospira</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Serotype</th><th>Primary carrier host</th><th>Animals infected</th><th>Distribution</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. L icterohaemorrhagiae</td><td>Brown rat</td><td>Most animals including man</td><td>World-wide</td></tr><tr><td>2. L canicola</td><td>Dog, jackals, pig</td><td>Man, cattle, sheep goat</td><td>World-wide</td></tr><tr><td>3. L pomona</td><td>Pig</td><td>Man, cattle, sheep, goat, horse, dog</td><td>Most parts of the world</td></tr><tr><td>4 L griptophosa</td><td>Field mica</td><td>Man, goat, horse, pig</td><td>USA, Europe, Africa, Asia</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>This may be accompanied by severe bleeding in the intestinal walls and lungs. It is often fatal. L. interrogans serovar griptophosa causes 'swamp fever' and is transmitted by mice. L. interrogans serovar canicola causes infectious jaundice which is transmitted mainly by dogs. Infection of leptospires is common among workers in rice fields and sugar-cane plantations, meat sellers, livestock farmers, animal handlers (veterinary officers) and forest workers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Blood and urine are collected for microscopy, and for culture if need be.</p>
<p>Leptospires are present in the blood during the first week of infection and appear in urine as from the second week. Cerebrospinal fluid may be collected if meningitis is suspected.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Leptospires are best observed in wet preparation of blood under the dark ground microscope.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-of-examination">Method of examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-of-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>On a clean slide, place a drop of citrated blood and a drop of water side by side.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Place a cover slip on top.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The blood and water will mix, and soon the blood is lysed. (Lysed cells will not refract light).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Observe the rotating motility of the leptospira under the darkground microscope (Fig. 21.5).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-e3ef33e7.jpeg" alt="img-101.jpeg">
Fig. 21.5 Wet preparation of blood for Leptospira microscopy</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Small fibrin particles in blood can look similar to Leptospira. You must see a rotating movement before giving a positive report.</li>
<li>Use small drops of blood and water so that the preparation does not become too dense as to refract a lot of light.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Examination of urine</strong> Several specimens of urine may be examined as the organisms appear in the urine as from the second week of infection, and then intermittently for 4-6 weeks.</p>
<p>Examine urine within one hour of collection. If this is not possible, collect the specimen into buff-</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>770 Bacteriology</p>
<p>ered saline (pH 7.2). This is because <em>L. interrogans</em> is quickly lysed in acid pH.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Centrifuge about 10 ml of urine at 1000 rpm for five minutes.</li>
<li>Transfer the supernatant fluid to another tube and centrifuge at 2–3000 rpm for 10–15 minutes.</li>
<li>Decant the supernatant fluid and make a wet preparation with the sediment.</li>
<li>Examine under dark ground microscopy for motile leptospires.</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. In leptospiral infections, urine proteins, bilirubin and urobilinogen levels are usually raised. Testing for these substances may be a useful indication before examining for <em>Leptospira</em>.
&gt; 2. Clean slides and cover slips must always be used for the microscopy.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> <em>L. interrogans</em> grows aerobically in liquid or semi-solid media enriched with animal proteins. (Rabbit serum is most satisfactory). Optimum temperature for growth is 28–32°C but for primary isolation, incubation at 37°C is recommended, followed by a transfer to lower temperature as soon as leptospiral colonies appear. The best pH of medium is 7.2–7.6. Maximum growth is obtained in 5–9 days, though growth can be noticed on the 4th day.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-culture-media-for-l-interrogans">Special culture media for <em>L. interrogans</em>:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-culture-media-for-l-interrogans" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Korthof’s liquid medium—buffered salts base with or without peptone, to which rabbit serum is added.</li>
<li>Fletcher’s semi-solid medium—0.2–0.5% nutrient agar and rabbit serum.
Isolation of <em>Leptospira</em> is not usually done on routine basis since faster diagnosis can be made by microscopy or by serological methods.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> <em>L. interrogans</em> consists of several serovars. Each serovar has a specific antigen but shares a group antigen with other strains.</p>
<p>Antibodies are usually detectable in the serum towards the end of the first week of infection, reaching its peak in the third or fourth week and then begin to fall.</p>
<p>Serological tests for <em>Leptospira</em> are of two types—the genus-specific and serogroup specific tests.</p>
<p>Genus-specific tests are positive for any serovar of <em>L. interrogans</em> that is causing the infection. Some of these tests are the complement fixation test (CFT), haemagglutination (HA) test, enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA); macroscopic slide agglutination test, and microscopic agglutination test (MAT).</p>
<p>Three tests are most commonly employed—Macroscopic slide test, ELISA and the microscopic agglutination test (MAT).</p>
<p><strong>Macroscopic slide test</strong> This test is a simple rapid screening test which is not very sensitive. The antigen is a heated, washed suspension of saprophytic <em>L. biflexa</em>, serovar patoc 1 of serovar Patoc which contains a large amount of antigens common to all leptospires.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dilute patient’s serum 1 : 10 (to eliminate prozone effect) in azide saline.</li>
<li>Place one drop of a well mixed antigen on each end of a slide.</li>
<li>Add one drop of patient’s neat serum to one end of the slide and one drop of the 1 : 10 diluted serum to the other end.</li>
