<li>Mix each preparation with the antigen.</li>
<li>Rotate the slide gently at 125 rpm for five minutes.</li>
<li>Strong and moderately strong agglutinations with the neat and diluted serum respectively, indicate present or very recent leptospirosis.</li>
</ol>
<p>Strong or moderate agglutination with the neat serum and no agglutination with the diluted serum indicates the presence of antibodies at early stage.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; A known positive serum must always be tested along with the test sample.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Spirochaetes 771</p>
<p>The test is positive from the first week to several weeks.</p>
<p>ELISA test for <em>Leptospira</em> is used to assess separately the levels of specific IgM and IgG antibodies in order to determine the likely stage of the infection.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopic agglutination test (MAT)</strong> This test detects both IgM and IgG antibodies. It employs either live leptospire antigens or formalised cultures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-using-formalised-cultures">Method using formalised cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-using-formalised-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare antigen by heavily inoculating Korthof's medium with pure leptospiral culture; incubate at 28°C for 5–7 days. Add pure formalin to give a final concentration of 0.2%.</li>
<li>Dilute patient's serum 1:5, 1:50, 1:500 with normal saline.</li>
<li>To a row of six tubes add as shown in Table 21.3:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Incubate all the tubes at 2–4°C overnight.</li>
<li>Examine for agglutination.</li>
<li>Place a drop of suspension from each tube on a slide and examine with the aid of darkground microscope.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: A control tube containing antigen and saline should be included.</p>
<p><strong>Result</strong>: A titre of 1:300 or above is indicative of leptospirosis.</p>
<p>Since agglutinating antibodies of the IgG type remain in the serum for many years, it is important to demonstrate a rise (or fall) of antibody level by testing acute and convalescent samples. This will help to confirm the diagnosis.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong>: Penicillin in high doses is the drug of choice for treatment. The organism is also sensitive to tetracycline.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chlamydia-mycoplasma-rickettsia-and-miscellaneous-bacteria">Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chlamydia-mycoplasma-rickettsia-and-miscellaneous-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-chlamydia">GENUS CHLAMYDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-chlamydia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Chlamydia</em> consists of small obligate intracellular micro-organisms that cause a host of infections in avian and mammalian species, including man. They resemble both bacteria and viruses. Like bacteria they possess both DNA and RNA, and are sensitive to antibiotics. They resemble viruses in being able to reproduce only inside a living cell, and depend on ATP produced by the host cell for their synthetic process. Although, like bacteria, they have a cell wall, this wall lacks muramic acid and peptidoglycan. Table 22.1 shows differentiating features between <em>Chlamydia</em> and viruses.</p>
<p>Because of this resemblance to viruses and bacteria, <em>Chlamydia</em> organisms were called several names during their evolution. For example, before the name <em>Chlamydia</em> was given, they were known as <em>Bedsonia</em>, after Sir Samuel Bedson who did some studies on psittacosis agent.</p>
<p>Table 22.1 Differentiation between <em>Chlamydia</em>, <em>Mycoplasma</em>, <em>Rickettsia</em>, bacteria and viruses</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Chlamydia</th><th>Mycoplasma</th><th>Rickettsia</th><th>Other bacteria</th><th>Viruses</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Growth on cell-free medium</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>2. Cellular organisation</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>3. Cell wall present</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>4. Host cell DNA used for reproduction</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>5. Both DNA and RNA present</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>Either DNA or RNA, not both</td></tr><tr><td>6. Filterable through 450 nm poresize filter</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>7. Sensitivity to antibiotics</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>8. Sensitivity to interferon</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 773</p>
<p>Chlamydiae occur in two forms: elementary bodies, and initial or reticulate bodies. The elementary body is a spherical particle, 200–300 nm in diameter, and it is the extracellular infective form. On entering into a suitable host cell, it enlarges to form the initial body, 600–1200 nm in diameter. This is the metabolically active, non-infective fragile form into which the elementary body changes during the multiplication cycle. The initial body multiplies by binary fission to form new smaller initial or reticulate bodies. When released as elementary bodies by the rupture of host cell, they become infective. Thus, the elementary body survives extra-cellularly while the initial body is adapted for intracellular growth (Fig. 22.1).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-7beab428.jpeg" alt="img-103.jpeg">
Fig. 22.1 Reproduction cycle of Chlamydia</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-and-species">Classification and Species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-and-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chlamydiae were formerly classified into sub group A and sub group B. Those that cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), trachoma and inclusion conjunctivitis and form compact inclusions with glycogen matrix and are susceptible to sulphonamide and D-cycloserine, belonged to sub group A. Sub group B included those chlamydiae that cause psittacosis, and which produce diffuse inclusion with no glycogen matrix and are resistant to sulphonamides and D-cycloserine. However, sub group A is now the species <em>C. trachomatis</em> and subgroup B is <em>C. psittaci</em>.</p>
<p><em>C. trachomatis</em> is subdivided into 15 serotypes: A-K including Ba and L1, L2 and L3. <em>C. psittaci</em> contains many serotypes some of which are not fully identified.</p>
<p><em>C. pneumoniae</em> is the recently recognised member of this group of organisms. It belongs to subgroup B.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics">Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chlamydia are Gram negative but are better stained with Giemsa, Castaneda or immunofluorescence methods. They produce basophilic inclusion bodies in the infected cell. They are heat labile and can be inactivated at 56°C within minutes. They are susceptible to ethanol, ether and low concentrations of formalin and phenol. Chlamydiae can be preserved at –70°C.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>C. trachomatis</em> is found in the urogenital tract of man. <em>C. psittaci</em> is found in many wild and domestic birds. Infection in man is by inhaling the organisms in the dried droppings of birds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-c-trachomatis">1. <em>C. trachomatis</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-c-trachomatis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) <em>C. trachomatis</em>, serotypes A, B, Ba, and C, cause endemic blinding trachoma—a severe eye infection of the conjunctiva and cornea. Untreated cases result in marked inflammation and scarring. The cornea is usually damaged, painful and watering; there is discomfort in light, opacity and eventually blindness. Blindness can be prevented if the case is diagnosed and treated early.</p>
<p>Infection can be transmitted from eye to eye by fingers or fomites e.g. handkerchiefs and towels. Flies may also transmit the infection. Poor conditions of living help in the spread of the disease.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>774 Bacteriology</p>
<p>It is endemic in some parts of Africa, Middle and Far East, India and South America.</p>
<p>(ii) <em>C. trachomatis serotypes D-K cause</em></p>
<p>(a) Inclusion conjunctivitis (IC) — a low grade eye infection that is contracted by self-inoculation after touching infected genital area or infected eye. Infection can also be contracted by exposure to contaminated water in swimming pools.</p>
<p>TRIC (Trachoma-inclusion conjunctivitis) agent is the term often used to describe <em>C. trachomatis</em> strains that cause eye infections.</p>
<p>(b) Congenital inclusion conjunctivitis — This is an infection of new born babies by mothers with <em>C. trachomatis</em>. The infection occurs during delivery and the baby develops conjunctivitis which is often accompanied by neonatal pneumonia.</p>
<p>(c) Nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) — This condition which was also referred to as non-specific urethritis (NSU), is caused by <em>C. trachomatis</em> in about 40% of cases in men. It is associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and cervicitis in women.</p>
<p>(iii) <em>C. trachomatis serotypes L1, L2 and L3</em> — These strains of <em>C. trachomatis</em> cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The condition is sexually transmitted and is common in tropical countries.</p>
<p>A small ulcer develops at the site of infection on the external genitalia following a 3–14 days incubation period. In males, there is inflammation and swelling of the inguinal lymph nodes (inguinal adenitis). The swellings are known as buboes. It may lead to genital strictures and may become more generalised, causing pain, fever and chills. The buboes may enlarge, suppurate and burst to form sinuses discharging pus. In females, the intra-pelvic lymph nodes are involved. It may lead to elephantiasis of the vulva following extensive matting and lymphatic blockage.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li><em>C. psittaci</em> — It causes psittacosis which is a disease of parrots and other psittacine birds. It is a pneumonia or influenza-like illness. The chlamydiae are shed in the droppings or nasal discharge and are released in the form of aerosoles. The disease is characterised by pneumonia, septicaemia and occasionally meningoencephalitis, endocarditis and pericarditis. Inhalation of infected aerosols by man leads to atypical pneumonia.</li>
</ol>
<p>Ornithosis is the disease caused by <em>C. psittaci</em> in pigeons, chickens and other birds.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li><em>C. pneumoniae</em> — <em>C. pneumoniae</em> is associated with atypical pneumonia which is transmitted from man to man. Unlike <em>C. psittaci</em>, there is no known bird or animal reservoir. It is a mild infection which may be associated with pharyngitis, sinusitis and sore throat.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 22.2 shows human infections caused by chlamydiae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> — These include conjunctival scraping, blood, sputum, pus (aspirated from the buboes) and</p>

<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 775</p>
<p>swabs of urethra, endocervix, conjunctiva and nasopharynx.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Chlamydial ocular infections are diagnosed by direct microscopy, cell culture and serology.</p>
<p>Chlamydial genital infection can be diagnosed by cell culture and then by microscopy.</p>
<p>LGV is best diagnosed by direct microscopy, cell culture and serology.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Direct smears are stained with Giemsa, with iodine or by immunofluorescence (IF) to detect inclusion bodies.</p>
<p>Immunofluorescence is the most sensitive method but it requires expensive reagents and equipment.</p>
<p>Giemsa is the standard method being only slightly less sensitive than the IF. The method is described below:</p>
<p><strong>Giemsa staining method</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Cover smear with diluted Giemsa stain *(1:50) for 1 hour.
*This should be freshly prepared everyday.</li>
<li>Rinse slide rapidly in 95% ethanol to remove excess stain. Dry and examine for the presence of typical basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Result</strong> Chlamydia inclusion bodies in epithelial cells appear, under the oil immersion objective, as distinct intracytoplasmic masses of particles ranging from small (300 nm) red-purple stained clumps of elementary body inclusions, to the larger (1 μm) blue to purple stained initial body inclusions with relatively less dense particles. These two types of particles are frequently present in the same inclusion.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
A longer staining period of 1 and 1/2 hours is recommended for tissue culture monolayers.</p>
<p><strong>Differentiation of C. trachomatis inclusion from pseudo-inclusions and bacteria</strong> Several structures including bacteria may resemble C. trachomatis inclusion and lead to error in the interpretation of smears.</p>
<ol>
<li>Pigment (melanin) granules—These are black or black-green in Giemsa stained smears. Clumps of the pigment granules cover the nucleus of the cell resembling trachoma inclusion.</li>
<li>Nuclear extrusions appear as irregular masses in the cytoplasm but they are similar to the nucleus in colour and texture.</li>
<li>Goblet cell granules may appear in clusters, are lighter in colour and not as distinct as the elementary bodies.</li>
<li>Bacteria such as Neisseria, Haemophilus, Moraxella and diphtheroids all stain blue and appear in the cytoplasm and so can be mistaken for inclusion bodies. It is best to examine a Gram stained smear as well as Giemsa stained preparation.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Iodine preparation</strong> C. trachomatis inclusion bodies contain glycogen which stain brown with iodine. This method can be used to screen for C. trachomatis inclusion bodies. It is more suited for materials from neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis than for those from genital infections. It is also useful in detecting inclusions in cell cultures. It is not a permanent preparation.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Air dry smear and fix in absolute alcohol or 10% formal saline.</li>
<li>Cover with Lugol's iodine or with 5% iodine in 10% potassium iodide solution for 3–5 minutes.</li>
<li>Place a cover slip over the slide</li>
<li>Examine as a wet mount.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Immunofluorescence (IF) staining</strong> This method relies on the detection of inclusions by IF with polyclonal antiserum from hyperimmunised animals; or inclusions and elementary bodies with monoclonal antibodies. Commercial kits are available for this purpose. The test is a quick method for diagnosing chlamydial infection. The elementary bodies fluoresce green-yellow and appear small and round.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>776 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Culture The isolation of <em>C. trachomatis</em> can only be undertaken by a laboratory with facilities for tissue culture. Aseptic technique is required throughout the isolation procedures.</p>
<p>There are two generally accepted methods for the isolation of chlamydia: egg and tissue cultures.</p>
<p>(i) It may be grown in the yolk sac of 6–8 day old eggs. The eggs are inoculated aseptically and then incubated at 35°C in a humid atmosphere. Blind passages are carried out for isolation. The process is time consuming (about 1–6 weeks to complete) and cumbersome.</p>
<p>(ii) The tissue culture method is relatively fast (isolation in 3–7 days). All the tissue cultures use centrifugation of the inoculum on to cell mono layers (non-replicating cells), such as irradiated McCoy cells.</p>
<p>The student is referred to the WHO guide to the laboratory diagnosis of trachoma.</p>
<p>Serodiagnosis Serological methods are used to serotype unknown isolate of <em>C. trachomatis</em>, and to measure type specific antibodies in human sera.</p>
<p>Paired sera, secretions and aspirates from patients can be tested by the micro-IF, inclusion IF, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and complement fixation test (CFT). The micro-IF method is the most commonly used. The antigens used in the tests consist of organisms propagated in the yolk sac of fertile chick embryos and their specific antisera are prepared in mice.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>C. trachomatis</em> is sensitive to tetracycline, sulphonamides, chloramphenicol and rifampicin. Topical preparations may also be applied.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-mycoplasma">GENUS MYCOPLASMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-mycoplasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus <em>Mycoplasma</em> is considered by some workers to consist of three groups of organisms—<em>Mycoplasma</em>, <em>Acholeplasma</em> and <em>Ureaplasma</em>. They were previously described under the general title of pleuro-pneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) because they were first described to cause pneumonia in cattle. For the sake of convenience and to avoid confusion, the three groups are discussed in this book under the genus <em>Mycoplasma</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics">Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Mycoplasma</em> organisms are the smallest free living micro-organisms and are very pleomorphic. They range in size from 0.1–2 μm; and occur as cocci, or long filaments which may appear branched. They are true bacteria but resemble viruses in their filterable size. They do not have rigid cell wall, each mycoplasma being composed of a small unit of cytoplasm encased in a 3-layered membrane that contains cholesterol or carotenoid in addition to the usual phospholipids. They do not produce their own cholesterol but require it for their growth. They are inhibited by antibiotics, though not by penicillin. Like viruses, they are filterable due to their small size and non-rigid cell wall.</p>
<p><em>Mycoplasma</em> organisms are poorly stained Gram negative and many other staining techniques are used to stain them. A prominent species is urea-dependent and forms tiny colonies on culture media and so was formerly known as T-strains of <em>Mycoplasma</em>. It is now called <em>Ureaplasma urealyticum</em>.</p>
<p>Type species <em>M. pneumoniae</em>. Other species of medical importance are:</p>
<ul>
<li><em>M. hominis</em></li>
<li><em>Ureaplasma urealyticum.</em></li>
</ul>
<p>Some saprophytic species such as <em>M. laidlawii</em> that do not require cholesterol for growth are now considered under the genus <em>Acholeplasma</em>. The established human <em>Mycoplasma flora</em> are <em>M. salivarium</em>, <em>M. buccale</em>, <em>M. faucium</em> (formerly <em>M. oral</em>), <em>M. fermentans</em> and <em>M. genitalium</em>.</p>
<p>Habitat <em>Mycoplasma</em> organisms are found in soil, plants, sewage and mucous surfaces of animal body. <em>M. hominis</em> and <em>U. urealyticum</em> can be found in the urogenital tract, and upper respiratory tract of humans. <em>M. pneumoniae</em> is also present in the respiratory tract.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 777</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>M. pneumoniae</em> causes pharyngitis, sinusitis, inflammation of the ear, and febrile bronchitis or pneumonia. The infection is accompanied by the formation of cold haemagglutinins, <em>Streptococcus</em> MG agglutinins or anti-tissue antibodies. Complications associated with <em>M. pneumoniae</em> infections include such extra pulmonary conditions as arthritis, hepatitis, central nervous system involvement (meningoencephalitis, cerebral ataxia etc.), muscle inflammation, skin rashes, myocarditis, and gastrointestinal disorders.</p>
<p><em>M. hominis</em>, <em>M. fermentans</em> and <em>U. urealyticum</em> cause pelvic inflammatory diseases, salpingitis, tubo-ovarian abscess, pelvic abscess; septic abortion and puerperal fever. <em>M. hominis</em> is reported to cause pyelonephritis.</p>
<p><em>U. urealyticum</em> and <em>M. genitalium</em> cause nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) or post gonococcal urethritis in men, and cervicitis and PID in women. <em>U. urealyticum</em> is also reported to cause urinary tract infections and arthritis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Sources of specimens for the isolation and diagnosis of <em>Mycoplasma</em> include</p>
<ol>
<li>Respiratory tract</li>
<li>Urogenital tract</li>
<li>Eyes</li>
<li>Warts</li>
<li>Synovial fluid</li>
<li>Blood</li>
<li>Placental membranes and</li>
<li>Foetal tissues</li>
</ol>
<p>For <em>M. pneumoniae</em>, respiratory specimens are most suitable—sputum, throat swabs and tracheal aspirates.</p>
<p>For <em>M. hominis</em> and <em>U. urealyticum</em>, high vaginal swabs, uerebral swabs, cervical swabs and urine are suitable specimens.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Direct microscopy on stained specimen preparations is not very useful as mycoplasmas are poorly stained. The organisms can be seen in preparations made from culture. They are Gram negative, in coccoid and filamentous forms. The filaments are slender, of varying lengths and show branching. No spores are seen. They are better observed when stained by Giemsa, IF or with Diene's stain.</p>
<p>Figure 22.2 shows pleomorphic morphology of <em>Mycoplasma</em>.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-cd3ddbd2.jpeg" alt="img-104.jpeg">
Fig. 22.2 Pleomorphic morphology of <em>Mycoplasma</em></p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> <em>Mycoplasma</em> species grow on solid or liquid media enriched with 20% horse or human serum and yeast extracts. The media are made selective with penicillin and thallium acetate. Colonies appear after 2–3 days aerobic incubation at 35–37°C. They show the typical ‘fried-egg’ appearance of a central opaque granular area of growth extending into the depth of the medium and surrounded by a flat translucent peripheral zone (Fig. 22.3). Incubation may continue for up to three weeks before culture is reported as negative.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-653c8b19.jpeg" alt="img-105.jpeg">
Fig. 22.3 Fried egg appearance of <em>Mycoplasma colonies</em></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>778 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-tests">Identification tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Mycoplasma</em> isolates are identified by biochemical, biological and serological methods. The isolates are separated into fermenters and non-fermenters on the basis of their biochemical (colour) reaction in the standard growth medium: = 1% concentration of carbohydrate under test is incorporated into a diphasic medium (or agar slope) or semi-solid standard medium together with 0.002% phenol red indicator.</p>
<p>Production of acid will result in change of colour to yellow. In most cases only glucose is tested. Urea may also be incorporated to identify <em>U. urealyticum</em>. Many species utilise arginine.</p>
<p>Table 22.3 shows the biological and biochemical reactions of <em>Mycoplasma</em> species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="haemolysis-and-haemadsorption-tests">Haemolysis and haemadsorption tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemolysis-and-haemadsorption-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These two tests require that the isolate be grown on complete <em>Mycoplasma</em> agar and that the resulting young colonies be used for the tests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="haemolysis-test">Haemolysis test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemolysis-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Overlay a plate containing young colonies with a suspension of 1% guinea pig or sheep erythrocytes in saline agar.</li>
<li>Allow the agar to solidify.</li>
<li>Reincubate aerobically overnight at 37°C.</li>
<li>Examine plates at 24 and 48 hours.</li>
</ol>
<p>A clear beta haemolysis around the colonies is produced by <em>M. pneumoniae</em>. This is due to the production of haemolysin which occurs only in aerobic environment. Other human mycoplasmas do produce smaller and rather greenish zones that take longer time to appear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="haemadsorption-had-test">Haemadsorption (HAD) test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemadsorption-had-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Flood the culture plate containing young colonies (or a block excised from it) with 1% suspension of guinea-pig or sheep erythrocytes in saline.</li>
<li>Allow to stand for 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Aspirate the erythrocyte suspension.</li>
<li>Wash the culture plate with phosphate buffered saline (PBS).</li>
<li>Examine the colonies under the microscope (100X).</li>
</ol>
<p>Positive colonies are seen surrounded by erythrocytes. The <em>M. pneumoniae</em> colonies are positive.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Confirm haemolysis and HAD tests by a serological test to exclude <em>Mycoplasma</em> of animal origin, some of which can give positive reactions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serological-tests">Serological tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serological-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is a number of serological tests used to identify <em>Mycoplasma</em> isolates. Serological tests are most reliable for identifying and classifying mycop; asmas. The usual tests recommended are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth inhibition test</li>
<li>Metabolic inhibition test</li>
<li>Immunofluorescence (IF) test</li>
</ol>
<p>Other tests which can be used but are not very practical include complement fixation, indirect IF, agglutination and haemagglutination tests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="growth-inhibition-test">Growth inhibition test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#growth-inhibition-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the simplest and most practical method for the identification of <em>Mycoplasma</em> species. The test is highly specific. It is not however used routinely to identify <em>Ureaplasma</em> species due to the heterogenicity within the species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare antisera against various human <em>Mycoplasma</em> species (by hyperimmunisation of rabbits).</li>
<li>Impregnate individual filter paper discs with each antiserum.</li>
<li>Seed a well dried medium plate with a small quantity of broth culture of the unknown <em>Mycoplasma</em> species by spreading evenly on the plate.</li>
<li>Place impregnated filter paper discs at intervals around the surface of the seeded agar plate. Include a disc that contains no serum as control.</li>
<li>Incubate the culture until growth appears.</li>
</ol>
<p>The antiserum that inhibits the growth of the <em>Mycoplasma</em> around the disc identifies the species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolic-inhibition-mi-test">Metabolic inhibition (MI) test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-inhibition-mi-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is based on the fact that when mycoplasmas utilise their substrate medium they give off a bye-prod</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 779</p>
<p>Table 22.3 Differentiation of Mycoplasma species</p>

<p>780 Bacteriology</p>
<p>uct that changes the pH of the medium, resulting in a change of colour of the indicator used in the medium. A specific antiserum against a mycoplasma species will inhibit its metabolic activity and so there will be no growth. Lack of metabolic activity means no colour change in the medium.</p>
<p>Most human species can be identified this way but strains within the group differ and so good inhibition may not always be obtained with antisera prepared from heterologous strains.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="if-test">IF test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#if-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This method is rapid, sensitive and specific. It makes use of an agar block from the culture plate of the test organism.</p>
<p>The test is based on the principle that when the gamma globulin fraction of a specific antiserum is labelled with a fluorescein dye, and this is mixed with the antigen (Mycoplasma growth), an antigen–antibody reaction occurs. The complex contains the fluorescein dye attached to the antibody molecule. After washing off excess labelled protein, the specific antigen–antibody reaction is observed under a fluorescent microscope.</p>
<p>A yellow–green fluorescence is indicative of a homologous reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="cold-agglutinins">Cold agglutinins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cold-agglutinins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Diagnosis of <em>M. pneumoniae</em> infection can be made based on the production of IgM autoantibodies that agglutinate patient's own red cells and other adult human group O Rh negative red cells at 4°C (cold agglutinins).</p>
<p>The autoantibodies are present in about 35–76% of patients with <em>M. pneumoniae</em> infection and 50% of normal healthy individuals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="rapid-screening-technique-for-cold-agglutinins-using-capillary-blood">Rapid screening technique for cold agglutinins using capillary blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rapid-screening-technique-for-cold-agglutinins-using-capillary-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Place 200 μl of 3.8% sodium citrate solution in a small glass test-tube.</li>
<li>Add an equal volume of patient's capillary blood.</li>
<li>Stopper the tube and rotate it on a tray of ice. Leave on the side for about 15–20 seconds.</li>
<li>Remove the tube and holding it by the stopper at eye level, tilt it so that the citrated blood flows over the cold glass surface.</li>
</ol>
<p>Look for coarse red cell agglutinates.</p>
<p>The presence of coarse agglutinates indicates a cold agglutinin titre of 1:64 or greater. This is suggestive but not diagnostic of <em>M. pneumoniae</em> infection.</p>
<p>No agglutination or fine granular agglutinates indicates a low titre or absence of cold agglutinins.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. An accurate estimation of cold agglutinins can also be done using venous blood.
&gt; 2. Most workers perform the estimation of specific IgM antibody by enzyme immunoassay or modified haemagglutination methods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="antibiotic-sensitivity">Antibiotic sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>Mycoplasma</em> species are usually resistant to penicillin and cephalosporins. <em>U. urealyticum</em> is resistant to tetracycline. Some are sensitive to erythromycin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3c47e225">♦ RICKETTSIACEAE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3c47e225" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="genera-rickettsia-rochalimaea-coxiella">Genera: <em>Rickettsia</em>, <em>Rochalimaea</em>, <em>Coxiella</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genera-rickettsia-rochalimaea-coxiella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>Rickettsiaceae</em> is the family of microorganisms that cause typhus fever and related diseases mostly transmitted by arthropods. They are closely related to the viruses in their inability to grow on artificial culture medium and their being obligate intracellular parasites. They are true bacteria, however, because they have both the DNA and RNA, cell wall, are susceptible to antibiotics, and divide by binary fission. They are smaller than bacteria but not filterable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The family <em>Rickettsiaceae</em> contains three genera-<em>Rickettsia</em>, <em>Coxiella</em> and <em>Rochalimaea</em>.</p>
<p>The genus <em>Rickettsia</em> contains agents of typhus fevers, spotted fevers and scrub typhus. The genus <em>Rochalimaea</em> contains the agent of trench fever. This microorganism differs from rickettsia agents in being usually extracellular in the arthropod host and being able to grow on blood agar. The genus <em>Coxiella</em> contains agent of Q fever which differs from <em>Rickettsia</em> in being smaller, more resistant to</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 781</p>
<p>physical and chemical agents and transmissible without an arthropod vector.</p>
<p>The Rickettsiae can also be subdivided according to the type of diseases they produce, the vectors that transmit them and their geographical distribution.</p>
<p>Table 22.4 is a list of rickettsial fevers and their characteristics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-rickettsia">GENUS RICKETTSIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-rickettsia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Characteristics Rickettsia microorganisms are small Gram negative pleomorphic rods, non - motile and non-capsulated (one species, R. prowazeki has an amorphous capsule surrounding it). They do not grow on cell-free media, but R. quintana species is able to grow on blood agar. The range of temperature of growth is 32–35°C.</p>
<p>Habitat Most of the rickettsiae are found normally in the alimentary canal of insects—lice and mites. R. prowazeki has man as its only natural maintenance host and the human body louse is the vector. The rickettsiae multiply in the gut of the louse and are found in the faeces of the louse. Infection is through contaminated louse faeces being rubbed in by scratching damaged skin. Infection can also occur through inhalation of dried louse faeces, or through the conjunctiva or through blood transfusion.</p>
<p>The trombiculid mite is the anthropod vector of R. tsutsugamushi while the natural reservoirs are rats, mice, voles and quail. Infection is through the bite of an infected larval mite. The rickettsiae are contained in the saliva of the mite.</p>
<p>Rats are the natural reservoirs of R. typhi (R. mooseri) and infection is transmitted by the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis. The rickettsiae multiply in the gut of the flea. Human infection is through inhalation of rickettsial particles in dried flea faeces.</p>
<p>The natural reservoirs for R. conori and R. siberica are dogs, rats, mice and probably rabbits.</p>
<p>The rickettsiae are transmitted by hard ticks. Human infection is through the bite of infected tick.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rickettsial diseases and their agents are listed in Table 22.4.</p>
<p>Here are some terms used to describe some of the rickettsial diseases.</p>
<ol>
<li>Epidemic typhus A louse-borne typhus caused by R. prowazekii. The condition is also referred to as classical typhus. It is a severe and often fatal illness.</li>
</ol>
<p>The disease is most common in East Africa, Central and South America.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Brill-Zinsser disease A relapse of louse-borne fever (recrudescent typhus) later in life. The disease is also caused by R. prowazekii. The attack is usually milder than the original attack.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Endemic (murine) typhus This is murine or flea-borne typhus. It is caused by R. typhi (R. mooseri). The disease is milder than the epidemic typhus. Distribution of murine typhus is worldwide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Scrub typhus This is a mite borne disease caused by R. tsutsugamushi. It is also referred to as Japanese river fever (it was first discovered in Japan) or Kedani mite disease. It is found in East Asia, India, Australia and Pacific islands.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rocky Mountain spotted fever The illness is tick borne and is caused by R. rickettsi. It is also referred to as South American tick typhus. It is found in North and South America.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Siberian tick typhus A tick borne infection caused by R. siberica. It is the same as the Indian tick typhus or the Southern Asian tick typhus. It is found in Siberia, Central Europe and Mongolia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tick-bite fever The disease is also referred to as Boutonneuse fever, eruptive fever, Marseilles fever and African tick typhus. It is tick-borne and caused by R. conori. The disease is mild in children but severe in adults. It is found in the Mediterranean region, India, Pakistan, Black sea, Australia and Sudan.</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 783</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Rickettsial pox This is a mouse-mite borne infection caused by <em>R. akari</em>. The disease resembles chicken pox and is also known as Vesicular or Varicelliform rickettsiosis. It is found in North America, South Africa, Korea and Russia.</li>
</ol>
<p>Pathogenesis of rickettsial infections begins with the invasion and multiplication of the rickettsiae in the endothelial cells of small blood vessels, smooth muscle cells and histiocytes. The tissues most involved are those of the skin, heart, brain and lungs. The invading organisms cause damage of tissues with a local cellular response in the infected cells which become severely inflamed. Capillaries become blocked and there may be bleeding in severe cases.</p>
<p>Most infections are characterised by high continuous fever, severe headache and general body pains and weakness. There is a characteristic macular or maculopapular rash appearing toward the end of the first week. Other signs may include oedema, nose bleeds and involvement of the eyes. Towards the second week the patient may become delirious, confused and eventually comatose.</p>
<p>The case fatality varies from 15–70% and increases with age. Death usually occurs from general toxaemia, encephalitis, pneumonia or myocarditis. The typhus and spotted fever groups give the most severe symptoms. Following rickettsial infection, gangrene of the fingers, toes and other parts of the body may occur. In those patients who recover, the organisms may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues and can be triggered off again in years to come.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because of the difficulties of working, and the risk of infection with rickettsial organism, laboratory diagnosis in a routine laboratory is limited mainly to serological tests. Cultivation of rickettsiae should be undertaken by a laboratory equipped for such work.</p>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Rickettsiae are highly infectious and specimens should always carry biohazard labels.</p>
<p>Specimens include blood, tissues and sputum.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Smears of infected tissues may be examined directly after staining by Giemsa, Castaneda or Macchiavello methods. They can also be examined directly by immunofluorescence. The organisms are pleomorphic, forming bacillary and coccal forms. They are small, measuring less than 0.5 µm in diameter. They are usually seen in tissue smears near cells or free within the cytoplasm.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Rickettsiae can be cultivated in animals, egg-yolk or cell culture. Isolation of the organism should be attempted only by laboratories equipped for the appropriate safety facilities.</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> The immunological response to rickettsial infections is firstly the production of IgM antibodies. This is followed in the later stages of the disease by IgG antibodies. The IgG antibodies remain in circulation for several years. Several serological tests are available for the diagnosis of rickettsial infection. These include ELISA or immunofluorescence using specific rickettsial antigens.</p>
<p><strong>Weil-Felix reaction</strong> Weil-Felix reaction is a non-specific agglutination test in which rickettsial sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain non-motile strains of <em>Proteus vulgaris</em> (OX 19 and OX 2) and <em>Proteus mirabilis</em> (OX K). It is based on cross reaction between rickettsial antibodies and the antigens of the <em>Proteus</em> strains. The Weil-Felix reaction is a simple and useful test to diagnose acute rickettsial infections.</p>
<p>It is an agglutination test performed in the same way as the Widal agglutination test (Refer to Immunology Section of this book for the agglutination test methodology).</p>
<p><strong>Interpretation of results</strong> Titres of 80 and above in unimmunised patients is significant. Titres of 200 and above in vaccinated patients is significant:</p>
<ol>
<li>Weil-Felix reactions in rickettsial disease are shown in Table 22.5</li>
<li>Q fever, rickettsial pox and trench fever, give negative reaction with Weil-Felix test.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>784 Bacteriology</p>
