<table><thead><tr><th>Urinary</th><th>Enteric</th><th></th><th>Topical</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ampicillin</td><td>25 μg</td><td>Ampicillin</td><td>Gentamicin</td><td>10 μg</td></tr><tr><td>Ninrofurantoin</td><td>200 μg</td><td>Co-trimoxazole</td><td>Chloramphenicol</td><td>150 μg</td></tr><tr><td>Nalidixic acid</td><td>30 μg</td><td>Cefotaxime</td><td>Framycetin</td><td>100 μg</td></tr><tr><td>Co-trimoxazole</td><td>25 μg</td><td>Nalidixic acid</td><td>Tetracycline</td><td>50 μg</td></tr><tr><td>Gentamicin</td><td>10 μg</td><td>Ciprofloxacin</td><td>Neomycin</td><td>10 μg</td></tr><tr><td>Cefuroxime</td><td>30 μg</td><td>Chloramphenicol</td><td>Polymixin B</td><td>300 units</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Note: The disc concentrations of antibiotics used for urinary and topical sites are higher than those used for other sites.</p>
<p>(viii) Enterococci should not be tested against cephalosporin and clindamycin because they are clinically ineffective.</p>
<p>The results of all the drugs tested should be recorded in the laboratory whether reported or not. They are useful for statistical and epidemiological purposes; or for situations when the patient does not tolerate or respond to the first-line agents.</p>
<p>The selective reporting helps to prevent indiscriminate use of drugs and to select most appropriate antimicrobial agent for treatment. Moreover, it will minimise the potential development of resistance against the new agents.</p>
<p>Performance of antibiotic susceptibility testing is of particular importance when</p>
<p>(i) the isolated pathogen has an unpredictable sensitivity pattern
(ii) the patient has impaired defence mechanism
(iii) the drugs with which development of resistance is common.
(iv) the infection is life threatening.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-tests-to-monitor-antimicrobial-therapy">LABORATORY TESTS TO MONITOR ANTIMICROBIAL THERAPY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-tests-to-monitor-antimicrobial-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The microbiology laboratory can help to monitor the effectiveness of antimicrobial therapy in two ways:</p>
<p>A. By determining the inhibitory activity of antimicrobial agents on the isolated pathogen</p>
<p>B. By the assessment of patient's response to the antimicrobial-therapy.</p>
<p>The most useful means for assessing the adequacy of antimicrobial therapy are:</p>
<p>(i) Quantitation of the level of the antimicrobial agent in the body fluids, especially serum.
(ii) Determination of serum bactericidal activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-determination-of-inhibitory-activity-of-antimicrobial-agents">A. DETERMINATION OF INHIBITORY ACTIVITY OF ANTIMICROBIAL AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-determination-of-inhibitory-activity-of-antimicrobial-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are tests devised to determine the susceptibility of the isolated pathogen to the antimicrobial agent. They are mainly of two types:</p>
<p>I. Dilution tests
II. Diffusion tests</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-dilution-tests">I. Dilution tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-dilution-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Serial dilutions of antimicrobial agents are made in nutrient broth. Each dilution is inoculated with a standard inoculum of the test organism. After appropriate incubation, the lowest concentration in the tube showing visual (macroscopic) inhibition of growth is the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC). If the broth culture tubes showing no visible evidence of growth in the test for MIC are subcultured onto a solid medium without any an</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>802 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Tibiotic, the minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) is the concentration of antimicrobial agent that produces no colonies (99.9 % killing) on a solid medium. MIC and MBC are expressed as micrograms per millilitre (μg/ml).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-antibiotic-solution">Preparation of antibiotic solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-antibiotic-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The range of the concentration of antibiotic to be used depends on the nature of the antibiotic, its toxicity and maximum achievable blood levels. Most antimicrobials are tested at the range of approximately 100 μg/ml to 0.4 μg/ml or lower. The working solution of each drug should be prepared at a concentration two times the required highest concentration for testing.</p>
<p>Antimicrobial agents are available commercially as powders labelled with their actual activity per milliGram of the powder (e.g. gentamicin-actual activity 550 μg/mg). The working solution of each drug to be tested should be prepared using the formula:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Amount&nbsp;of&nbsp;activity&nbsp;desired&nbsp;</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mtext>g/ml</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mtext>Amount&nbsp;of&nbsp;activity&nbsp;present&nbsp;</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mtext>g/ml</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mtext>Volume&nbsp;required</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>mg&nbsp;powder&nbsp;in&nbsp;the&nbsp;required&nbsp;volume</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Amount of activity desired } (\mu\text{g/ml})}{\text{Amount of activity present } (\mu\text{g/ml})} \times \text{Volume required} = \text{mg powder in the required volume}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.363em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Volume&nbsp;required</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; <p>For example, to prepare 10 ml of 200 μg/ml gentamicin solution, having activity 550 μg/mg,</p>

<p>Most antimicrobials are prepared in distilled water. Some of them need special solvents to dissolve initially (Table 23.7).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="table-23-7-solvents-and-diluents-for-antimicrobial-solutions">Table 23.7 Solvents and diluents for antimicrobial solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-23-7-solvents-and-diluents-for-antimicrobial-solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 803</p>
<p>Preparation of the Inoculum The test organism should be inoculated into the broth medium to be used e.g. Mueller-Hinton broth or brain heart infusion broth, and incubated for 4–6 hours or overnight. The resulting turbidity should be adjusted to 0.5 McFarland turbidity standard, using the same broth medium.</p>
<p>Note
Prepare the turbidity standard by mixing 99.5 ml of 1% v/v sulphuric acid and 0.5 ml of 1.175% w/v barium chloride (BaCl₂·H₂O). Mix and dispense in tubes in 3–4 ml amounts.</p>
<p>Dilute the broth culture 1:200 by mixing 0.1 ml of the inoculum and 19.9 ml of the broth. This is the working inoculum and should contain 10⁵–10⁶ organisms/ml if used within 30 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="broth-tube-dilution-method">Broth (tube) Dilution Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#broth-tube-dilution-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Medium—A medium which will support the growth of the test organism should be used. Mueller-Hinton broth is most commonly used. Todd-Hewitt broth may be used for organisms that do not grow well in Mueller-Hinton broth, e.g., streptococci.</p>
<p>Dilution of the antimicrobial agent Sterilise the drug by filtration before use.</p>
<ul>
<li>Set up and label 13 tubes.</li>
<li>Pipette 1 ml broth into tubes 2–10, 11 and 13</li>
<li>Pipette 2 ml broth into tube 12</li>
</ul>
<p>(Tube 11 is the inoculum control; tube 12 is the broth control and tube 13 is the drug control).</p>
<ul>
<li>Pipette 1 ml of working drug solution into tubes 1, 2 and 13</li>
<li>Prepare doubling dilutions from tube 2 up to 10 using 1 ml amounts (Fig. 23.4).</li>
<li>Pipette 1 ml of the working inoculum into tubes 1 to 11.</li>
<li>Incubate tubes at 37°C for 18–24 hours.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reading-results">Reading results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reading-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Determination of minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) Turbidity or cloudiness in the growth medium indicates growth. Check the controls. Tube 11 should show turbidity while tubes 12 and 13 should show no growth. In the test, the lowest concentration showing no growth is the MIC of the antimicrobial agent for that test organism, and that is 12.5 µg/ml in Fig. 23.4.</p>
<p>Determination of minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) Minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) is the lowest concentration of the antimicrobial agent required to produce a sterile culture. The MBC can be determined by subculturing 0.01 ml of the highest concentration of the agent which shows visible growth (e.g. tube 6.25 µg/ml in Fig. 23.4) and all the tubes showing no visible signs of growth in the MIC tube dilution test, to fresh antibiotic-free media (broth or solid). The MBC is the lowest concentration that results in killing 99.9 %, bacteria, e.g., no turbidity in liquid media or less than five colonies on solid media with a suspension containing 5 × 10⁵ organisms/ml.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="agar-dilution-tests">Agar Dilution Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#agar-dilution-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Agar dilution tests are similar to broth dilution tests except that varying concentrations of the antimicrobial agent are incorporated in series of agar plates onto which a standardised suspension of the test organism is inoculated. The drug dilutions should be 10 times the required concentration. Mix 2 ml of each dilution with 18 ml of molten agar at 50°C per plate. After incubation, the lowest concentration of the agent which shows no growth of the test organism is the MIC.</p>
<p>This procedure is cumbersome and it is not used routinely.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microdilution-test">Microdilution Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microdilution-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The microdilution broth test is similar in principle to the tube dilution test except that the test is performed in a series of wells in a microtitre plate. The plate may contain 80, 96 or more wells; and several drugs can be tested in one plate. This test generates more quantitative information than the disc diffusion test.</p>
<p>Technique Make serial two fold dilutions in 0.1 ml volumes of the antimicrobial agent with Mueller-Hinton broth. Choose the appropriate</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6f46d0cb.jpeg" alt="img-109.jpeg">
Fig. 23.4 Broth dilution test</p>
<p>range of dilutions. The chosen range of concentrations tested for any given drug represents the concentration attainable in patient's blood.</p>
<p>Inoculate each well with the same volume, (e.g. 0.1 ml) of standardised suspension of bacteria under test. The bacterial suspension is prepared in the same way as for the dilution test.</p>
<p>After appropriate incubation, MIC for each drug is determined as the lowest concentration that has inhibited growth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-diffusion-tests">II. Diffusion Tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-diffusion-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-disc-diffusion-test">1. Disc Diffusion Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-disc-diffusion-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The disc diffusion test is one of the most widely used antimicrobial susceptibility (sensitivity) tests</p>
<p>in clinical laboratories. A disc of blotting paper impregnated with a known volume and appropriate concentration of an antimicrobial agent is placed on a sensitivity test agar inoculated with the test organism. The antibiotic diffuses into the surrounding medium, establishing a gradient of concentration around the disc. The concentration of the drug is highest in the agar near the disc. As the distance from the disc increases, there is a reduction in the drug concentration (Fig. 23.5).</p>
<p>The growth of the organism is inhibited up to a distance from the disc where the concentration of the drug is roughly equal to its minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC). The inhibition of growth appears as a circular zone of inhibition on the agar plate (Fig. 23.6). The zone diameter is roughly</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 805</p>
<p>proportional to the sensitivity of the test organism to the drug. This zone of inhibition is influenced by many factors.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-7f3c0830.jpeg" alt="img-110.jpeg">
Fig. 23.5 The principle of disc diffusion test</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-4e14a0c8.jpeg" alt="img-111.jpeg">
Fig. 23.6 Zones of inhibition by disc diffusion test using different antimicrobials (Diagrammatic)</p>
<p>Factors affecting antimicrobial susceptibility tests To achieve reproducible results of susceptibility tests on clinical isolates, it is extremely important to follow recommended procedures. The use of standardised procedures prevents misinterpretation of sensitivity results.</p>
<p>The following factors must be considered for the standardisation of the procedure:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-growth-medium">(I) Growth medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-growth-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) Composition The medium selected for use in susceptibility tests must not contain substances inhibitory to antimicrobials and must be able to support good overnight growth of most facultatively anaerobic bacteria. For example, some agar media contain thymidine which suppresses the action of sulphonamides and trimethoprim. Addition of lysed horse blood can neutralise the inhibitory action of thymidine. The growth medium used must support good overnight growth of both test and control organisms.</p>
<p>(b) pH of the medium The pH of the medium should be between 7.2 and 7.4. A more acid pH decreases the activity of aminoglycosides and erythromycin, while an alkaline pH favours it. Activities of tetracyclines, novobiocin and fusidic acid are also affected by pH.</p>
<p>(c) Concentration of cations in the medium Concentration of divalent cations such as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> affects the susceptibility of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> to aminoglycosides. When the medium is deficient in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the permeability of <em>Ps. aeruginosa</em> cell wall by the aminoglycosides is increased. This results in the production of larger inhibitory zones.</p>
<p>Detection of certain resistant strains of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> to methicillin is improved by addition of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">4%</span></span></span></span></span> sodium chloride to the agar medium.</p>
<p>(d) Depth of the medium Depth of the medium in a petri dish will obviously alter the concentration gradient of the diffusing antimicrobial. If the agar is thick, it will produce relatively smaller inhibitory zones while the thin medium gives larger zones.</p>
<p>For standardisation, the medium should be poured to a depth of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> per plate in a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">90</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> diameter petri dish).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-temperature-of-incubation">(II) Temperature of Incubation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-temperature-of-incubation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Plates should be routinely incubated at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> except for special circumstances, e.g., for the detection of methicillin resistant staphylococci, when the incubation tem</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>806 Bacteriology</p>
<p>perature is 30°C to allow a faster growth rate of resistant strains.</p>
<p>(III) Atmosphere Agar plates should be incubated in an ambient air incubator. Incubation in CO₂ incubator results in the formation of carbonic acid on the surface of the agar causing a decrease in pH which can affect the activity of some drugs.</p>
<p>(iv) Preparation of the inoculum The ideal inoculum is the one which gives evenly spread semi-confluent growth of organisms after overnight incubation. Failure to control the density of the inoculum is a common source of error. Too heavy an inoculum reduces the size of the inhibition zone. On the other hand, too light an inoculum makes it difficult to read the zones of inhibition correctly.</p>
<p>The inoculum should be prepared from a broth culture incubated for 4–6 hours, preferably, when the bacterium is in the logarithmic growth phase. Several similar colonies should be emulsified in a broth medium and incubated for 4–6 hours. The density of the suspension is then adjusted to 0.5 McFarland standard with sterile broth. This suspension has approximately 10⁸ organisms or colony forming units (CFU) per ml.</p>
<p>&gt; Note
&gt; If it is not possible to incubate the broth culture for 4–6 hours, a suspension of desired turbidity (0.5 McFarland standard) may be prepared directly from an overnight culture plate.</p>
<p>(v) Antimicrobial disc For each agent, a filter paper disc, 6 mm in diameter, impregnated with appropriate concentration of that agent should be used.</p>
<p>The size of the inhibition zone also depends on the nature of the antibiotic. For example, a more rapidly diffusible antimicrobial will give a wider zone of inhibition than the one which is less diffusible.</p>
<p>The bulk stock of discs should be stored in sealed containers with desiccants at –20°C, the working stock, also with desiccants, should be kept at 2–8°C, in sealed containers. The containers should be allowed to warm up to room temperature before opening, so that the condensation of moisture is minimum. Accumulation of moisture may lead to deterioration of drugs, and therefore, must be avoided. The discs should be discarded at the expiry date.</p>
<p>The potency of discs should follow the standards shown in the zone of interpretative chart in Table 23.8. The antimicrobials to be selected for sensitivity testing depends on various factors such as the pathogen, specimen and locally available drugs.</p>
<p>Discs of higher antimicrobial content are used for pathogens isolated from the urinary tract. This is because most antimicrobial drugs are eliminated by the kidneys and therefore, their concentration is the highest in the urinary tract.</p>
<p>(vi) Molecular weight of the antimicrobial agent An antimicrobial agent with a low molecular weight will diffuse more rapidly and give a wider zone of inhibition than one with a high molecular weight. Therefore, the interpretation of the antibiotic sensitivity should be standardised by use of control organisms.</p>
<p>(vii) The organism The disc diffusion test is designed for bacteria which grow well after overnight incubation in air. Slow growth can result in abnormally large inhibition zones. Fastidious bacteria, which grow very slowly, or require nutritional or atmospheric supplements, e.g., <em>Myco. tuberculosis</em> should not be tested by disc diffusion method. Dilution tests with proper controls are necessary for such organisms.</p>
<p>(viii) Control organisms Control strains of organisms should be used for different groups of bacteria. Each control strain should have the same growth rate as the test organism, and should be known to respond to treatment with normal doses of the drugs being used. Control organisms are obtained from reputable internationally recognised reference laboratories such as NCTC–National Collection of Type Culture (UK); ATCC–American Type Culture Collection (USA), Pasteur Institute (France).</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>

<p>808 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Control strains usually recommended for this purpose are:</p>
<ol>
<li><em>Escherichia coli</em> NCTC 10418 or ATCC 25922 for tests on Coliform bacilli.</li>
<li><em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> Oxford strain NCTC 6571 or ATCC 29213 for Gram positive cocci and some Gram positive bacilli, for controlling all drugs except polymixins.</li>
<li><em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> NCTC 10662 or ATCC 27853, for drugs against <em>Pseudomonas</em> species.</li>
<li>Others: <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em> NCTC 11931 for <em>Haemophilus</em> isolates, <em>Clostridium perfringens</em> NCTC 11229 for clostridia and <em>Bacteroides fragilis</em> NCTC 9343 for rapidly growing Gram negative anaerobes are used as control organisms.</li>
</ol>
<p>Working cultures of control strains should be grown weekly or monthly from the stock cultures which are preserved either by freeze drying or by freezing in blood at –60°C. They should be maintained on slants of suitable medium. These cultures should be used as controls for appropriate test organisms against the same set of antimicrobials, either on the same plate (Stoke's method) or on a separate plate (Kirby-Bauer method).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disc-diffusion-methods">DISC DIFFUSION METHODS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disc-diffusion-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two methods in common use which take into consideration most variables discussed above.</p>
<ol>
<li>Kirby-Bauer's method</li>
<li>Stoke's method</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kirby-bauer-disc-diffusion-test">Kirby-Bauer Disc Diffusion Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kirby-bauer-disc-diffusion-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the Kirby-Bauer method, the inhibition zone diameters of the test organisms are compared with those of the control strains with reference to the corresponding minimum inhibitory concentrations and interpretive guidelines published by National Committee for Clinical Laboratory Standards (NCCLS) (Table 23.8).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparation-of-the-antimicrobial-disc">Preparation of the antimicrobial disc<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-the-antimicrobial-disc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Antimicrobial discs are commercially available but they can be prepared in the laboratory as follows:</p>
<p>Punch out discs 6 mm in diameter, from a sheet of good quality filter paper (e.g. Whatman No.1). It may be marked with numbers or letters to identify the disks.</p>
<p>Place the discs in a petri dish or any other flat container individually, leaving 2–4 mm between them.</p>
<p>Sterilise in hot air oven at 160°C for one hour.</p>
<p>Prepare a solution of the antimicrobial in the desired strength in such a way that 20 μl (0.02 ml) contains the amount to be present in each disc.</p>
<p>For example, to contain 5 μg per disc, the solution of erythromycin must contain <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1000</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>250</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1000}{20} \times 5 = 250 \ \mu g/ml</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">20</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1000</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">250</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">μg</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Sterilise the solution by filtration.</p>
<p>When the sterilised paper discs are cool, pipette 20 μl of the solution onto each disc aseptically.</p>
<p>Dry the discs in a refrigerator or by keeping inside a dessicator for a few days, or in an incubator at 35–37°C for one hour.</p>
<p>Place the discs in a labelled airtight container and store at 2–8 °C for a month or at –20°C for longer periods.</p>
<p>Check the disc potency by testing against control organisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="inoculation-of-plates">Inoculation of plates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculation-of-plates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Following the preparation, the inoculum should be used within 30 minutes. The sensitivity agar plate is then seeded in one of three ways:</p>
<p>(i) Dip a sterile cotton swab into the inoculum, squeeze off excess fluid against the side of the tube, and then streak all over the plate to obtain a uniform spreading in all directions.</p>
<p>(ii) Place a loopful of inoculum in the centre of the plate and spread all over with a dry cotton swab.</p>
<p>(iii) The plate can be placed on a rotating turntable and inoculated by holding the swab against the plate at appropriate radial positions, starting</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 809</p>
<p>from the centre of the plate moving to the periphery in a straight line while the plate itself rotates on the turntable.</p>
<p>The inoculation should give an even, semiconfluent growth after incubation for 18–24 hours at 37 °C.</p>
<p>Allow 3–5 minutes, but not more than 15 minutes, for the surface of the agar to dry before adding the antimicrobial discs.</p>
<p>Place the appropriate antimicrobial impregnated discs on the surface of the agar, using either forceps or dispensers. The discs should be placed at least 22 mm from each other and at least 14 mm from the edge of the plate. Ideally, a 9 cm diameter plate should contain 6 discs.</p>
<p>Gently press each disc on the agar using forceps to provide uniform contact with the surface.</p>
<p>Prediffusion of the antimicrobials from the discs may be allowed by holding the plates at room temperature for about 30 minutes before placing them in the incubator to initiate the growth of bacteria.</p>
<p>Incubate the plate at 37°C for 16–18 hours.</p>
<p><strong>Quality control</strong> A reference control strain is inoculated in the same way on another plate with the same antibiotic discs and incubated at the same temperature.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The growth of both the test and control organisms should be semi-confluent, neither too heavy nor too light. If not, repeat the test.</p>
<p><strong>Results</strong> At the end of 16–18 hours incubation, measure the inhibition zone. Measure the diameter of the inhibition zone from one edge to the opposite edge. The zones are measured to the nearest millimetre as the complete inhibition of growth appears to the unaided eye. Some workers prefer to measure the radius of the inhibition zone. Either way, the same interpretation of result is achieved.</p>
<p><strong>Interpretation of results</strong> The NCCLS has established limits on zone sizes which are acceptable for the control strains (Table 23.9). These limits decide the accuracy of testing under standardised conditions.</p>
<p>Interpretive standards are provided by NCCLS as susceptible, intermediate and resistant according to the inhibitory zone size for each antimicrobial. Determine the sensitivity test result and corresponding MIC (approx.) from Table 23.8. The zones in the intermediate zones should be resolved by a dilution susceptibility test to determine the MIC, if the therapy with that drug is desired.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stoke-s-method">Stoke's Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stoke-s-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stoke's disc diffusion susceptibility testing method is similar to that of Kirby-Bauer except that the test organism and the control organism are tested against the same discs on the same plate. Testing both the test and control strain on the same plate eliminates many variables which may affect accuracy. This method helps to control the activity of each disc, and the inhibition zone of the organism to be compared directly with that of the control.</p>
<p><strong>Inoculation of the plate</strong> Place a loopful of the inoculum of the test organism in the centre of the plate. Using a sterile dry cotton swab, spread it evenly across the central third of the plate (Fig. 23.7).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-7bb48e38.jpeg" alt="img-112.jpeg">
Fig. 23.7 Stoke's disc diffusion method</p>
<p>Using a similar inoculation technique, seed the inoculum of the control strain, which is prepared in the same way as the test strain, across the upper and lower third of the plate, leaving a gap of 2–3 mm between the test and control strains on each side.</p>
<p>Allow the surface of the plate to dry for 3–5 minutes. Using sterile forceps, place two antim</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>810 Bacteriology</p>
