Positive reaction in presumptive test</p>
<p>Classification of water Suggested bacteriological classification water is shown in Table 24.3. This quality grading of water is based on the coliform and <em>E. coli</em> counts. The final treatment of water that enters a distribution system is an effective disinfection by chlorination. It eliminates all viable coliform bacteria. This water is graded as excellent if no coliform or <em>E. coli</em> bacteria are detected in all the tested samples of 100 ml.</p>
<p>A sample of water is classified as unsatisfactory when 10 coliforms or 1 or more <em>E. coli</em> are detected in 100ml of tested samples.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="membrane-filtration-test">Membrane Filtration Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#membrane-filtration-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> A measured volume of undiluted or diluted water is filtered through a membrane with pore size small enough to retain the indicator bacteria to be counted. The membrane is then placed and incubated on a selective differential medium, allowing the bacteria to grow into colonies on its upper surface. The colonies are recognised by their colour and morphology, and counted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Set up a sterile filtration unit. The unit, which consists of a base supporting a porous disk under a graduated funnel, can be sterilised by autoclaving. Then connect the base to a vacuum pump.</li>
<li>Using a sterile flat-edged forceps, pick and place a sterile membrane filter (available commercially), grid side up, over the porous disk.</li>
</ol>
<p>The usual high quality filter membrane is 47µm in diameter and 0.45µm of pore size. If purchased unsterile, sterilise it by autoclaving at 115°C for</p>
<p>Table 24.3 Bacteriological classification of water</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Quality of supply</th><th>Results from routine samples</th><th></th><th>Tolerance</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Coliform count per 100 ml</td><td>E. coli Count per 100 ml</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1. Excellent</td><td>0</td><td>0</td><td>In all samples</td></tr><tr><td>2. Satisfactory</td><td>1–3</td><td>0</td><td>Provided that coliform organisms do not occur in consecutive samples or in more than 5% of samples</td></tr><tr><td>3. Intermediate</td><td>4–9</td><td>0</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4. Unsatisfactory</td><td>10 coliforms or 1 or more E. coli</td><td></td><td>In any sample</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriological Examination of Water, Milk, Food and Air 823</p>
<p>10 minutes or by boiling in water at 100°C for 10 minutes.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Mix the water sample by inverting the bottle 25–30 times.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aseptically pour or pipette the necessary volume of water into the funnel. The volume of water chosen should be such that the colonies to be counted on the membrane will be between 10–100:
Treated water : 100 ml
Untreated water : 10 ml, or 1 ml + 9 ml of quarter strength Ringer’s solution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Filter the water slowly through the membrane by applying a vacuum of about 500 mm of mercury.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stop the pump as soon as the sample has been filtered so as to prevent contaminated air from being sucked in.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using a sterile flat-edge forceps, place the membrane, with grid side uppermost, on a sterile pad soaked with culture medium (usually MacConkey membrane broth) in a petri dish.
(i) Avoid air bubbles being trapped between the membrane and the pad.
(ii) The pad should be free from toxic substances.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubate the plates containing the membranes at 37°C for 18–24 hours. The plates must be held in a moist chamber. A simple moist chamber can be prepared by keeping a wet cotton wad in a polythene bag.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In a good light, count the characteristic colonies (yellow due to lactose fermentation and 1–3 mm in diameter) and ignore any pink colonies. The yellow colonies are presumptive <em>E. coli</em> colonies.
Record the count as presumptive <em>E. coli</em> count per 100 ml of water.
Confirmed <em>E. coli</em> count is performed on the same line as for the multiple tube method by detecting gas and acid formation at 37°C and indole production at 44°C as in the Multiple tube method.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Advantages of the membrane filtration method</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>It requires less labour and materials.</li>
<li>The method is significantly more accurate because of its smaller sampling error.</li>
<li>Results are obtained much faster.</li>
<li>It is more adaptable and simpler to perform. The only disadvantage is the high cost of the membrane filters</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>TESTS FOR FAECAL STREPTOCOCCI AND CLOSTRIDIUM PERFRINGENS</strong></p>
<p><strong>(a) Count of Faecal Streptococci</strong></p>
<p>When there is difficulty in interpreting the results of presumptive coliform and confirmed <em>E. coli</em> tests, the detection of faecal streptococci is the evidence of faecal origin of the coliform bacilli in water. These faecal streptococci which are also known as enterococci can grow in the media used for the presumptive coliform count where they ferment lactose and produce acid but no gas.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> Subculture from all positive tubes in the presumptive coliform test into tubes containing 5 ml of glucose azide broth. Incubate for 18–48 hours at 45°C. Yellow colour indicates acid production. The tubes showing acid production contain faecal streptococci. Confirm the presence of faecal streptococci by subculturing each positive glucose azide culture to a tube of bile aesculin azide agar and incubate at 45°C. The aesculin bile agar turns black-brown to indicate the presence of faecal streptococci. Using the probability tables, read the MPN of faecal streptococci in 100 ml of sampled water.</p>
<p><strong>(b) Count of Clostridium perfringens</strong></p>
<p>The presence of <em>C. perfringens</em> in water indicates the faecal pollution when only coliforms other than <em>E. coli</em> are cultured from water. Clostridium spores survive in water for long periods even when other bacteria have died. For the test, all vegetative cells are killed by heating the sample of water at 75°C for 10 minutes. A multiple tube test is done using</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>824 Bacteriology</p>
<p>differential reinforced clostridial medium (DRCM). The medium contains cysteine which permits the growth of anaerobic clostridia; and a combination of sodium sulphite and ferric citrate to reveal any growth of sulphite-reducing bacteria by the production of a black precipitate of ferrous sulphide.</p>
<p>Another simpler method is to mix varying quantities of the water sample in litmus milk medium, incubate anaerobically at 37°C for five days and look for the typical stormy fermentation of <em>C. perfringens</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plate-count">PLATE COUNT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plate-count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Plate count is performed to determine the efficiency of water treatment processes. It will detect any form of contaminant present in the water, and so indicate the level of hygienic quality of the water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare 1:10 and 1:100 dilution of water:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Add 1 ml of water to each of four petri dishes; add 9 ml diluent, i.e., Ringer’s solution of quarter strength (1:10 dilution).</li>
<li>With a fresh pipette, mix and add 1 ml of 1:10 dilution each to the four petri dishes and 9 ml of diluent (1:100 dilution).</li>
<li>Add 1 ml of undiluted water to each of four petri dishes.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Add 20 ml of yeast extract agar to each petri dish.</li>
<li>Rotate the plates gently clockwise and anticlockwise several times to mix.</li>
<li>Incubate two plates of undiluted water and two plates with 1:10 dilutions at 37°C for 18–24 hours.</li>
<li>Incubate the remaining 6 plates (2 each of undiluted, 1:10 and 1:100) at 22°C for 72 hours.</li>
<li>Count bacterial colonies numbering between 30 and 300 from the plates.</li>
</ol>
<p>Report as number of colonies/ml of the sampled water. Those bacteria that grow at 22°C are the natural water bacteria while those growing at 37°C are generally regarded as parasitic bacteria and bacteria from soil and sewage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriological-examination-of-milk">BACTERIOLOGICAL EXAMINATION OF MILK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination-of-milk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cow’s milk may contain bacteria derived from the cow’s faeces; or human pathogens derived from milk handlers; or from unsterile utensils and equipments used for milking; or from dust in the environment. Those bacteria may cause human infection when such milk is consumed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="grades-of-milk">Grades of Milk<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#grades-of-milk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Milk is graded and marketed to conform to certain quality standards. The grading depends on the conditions of production.</p>
<ol>
<li>Pasteurised milk This is milk which has been heated to between 63°C and 66°C for 30 minutes, or at 72°C for at least 15 seconds, and immediately cooled to a temperature of not more than 10°C.</li>
</ol>
<p>The milk must pass both the 30 minutes methylene blue reduction test and the phosphatase test (see text).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Sterilised milk This milk is heated at 100°C after it has been bottled for such a period of time that it passes the turbidity test (see text).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ultra heat treated (UHT) milk This is milk that has been heated at 135°C for 1 second and immediately kept in a sterile container. It should not grow more than 1000 colonies/ml when incubated for 48 hours at 35–37°C on yeast extract milk agar.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Untreated milk This milk is unheated and has been tested and found to be treberculin test negative. It must pass the 30 minute methylene blue reduction test.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examination-of-milk">EXAMINATION OF MILK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examination-of-milk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Statutory tests are done to determine the suitability of a milk sample for consumption. These tests include:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriological Examination of Water, Milk, Food and Air 825</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="methylene-blue-test">Methylene Blue Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methylene-blue-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test depends on the dye methylene blue being reduced and so decolourised by bacteria in milk when incubated at 37°C. The rate of reduction is related to the degree of bacterial contamination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dissolve one tablet of methylene blue (commercially available) in 200 ml of cold sterile glass distilled water. Make up to 800 ml with cold glass distilled water. Store in a stoppered flask at 2–8°C in a dark place. Shelf life is about two months. This is 1:300,000 solution of methylene blue.</li>
<li>Mix the milk sample thoroughly.</li>
<li>Pour 10 ml of milk into a sterile, capped tube.</li>
<li>Add 1 ml of methylene blue solution to the milk. The pipette should not touch the milk.</li>
<li>Stopper the tube with a sterile rubber bung and mix the contents by inverting the tube slowly two times.</li>
<li>Place in a 37°C water bath, the water should cover the column of milk.</li>
<li>Set up two controls along with the test as follows:
(i) 1 ml tap water + 10 ml of milk and heat at 100°C for three minutes. This milk should remain white in colour and represent complete decolourisation of methylene blue.
(ii) 10 ml of cooled boiled milk + 1 ml of methylene blue solution. This will show no decolourisation and should remain blue in colour.</li>
<li>Compare the test sample with controls.</li>
</ol>
<p>If the dye is wholly decolourised or decolourised to within 5 mm of milk surface, the milk has failed the test. Satisfactory pasteurised milk and untreated milk should show no decolourisation of methylene blue in 30 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="phosphatase-test">Phosphatase Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phosphatase-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The test is also called the Aschaffenburg–Mullen test. It is used to test for effective pasteurisation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The test depends on the detection of the enzyme phosphatase which is found in raw milk. The enzyme liberates p-nitrophenol from disodium p-nitrophenyl phosphate and thereby produces a yellow colour.</p>
<p>This enzyme is destroyed during pasteurisation. Absence of phosphatase means that effective pasteurisation has taken place. The milk should be tested as soon as received or after refrigeration overnight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="requirements">Requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Buffer solution
Dissolve 3.5 g anhydrous sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃) and 1.5 g sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) in 1 litre of distilled water. Store at 4°C up to three months.</li>
<li>Buffer substrate solution
Dissolve 0.15 g disodium p-nitrophenyl phosphate in 100 ml of the buffer. Store in a dark bottle in refrigerator and use within seven days.</li>
<li>Lovibond comparator with special resazurin stand fitted with APTW disc.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
The test should be performed with specially cleaned 152 × 16 mm test tubes and pipettes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Pipette 5 ml of buffer substrate into the specially cleaned test tubes (1 tube per test).</li>
<li>Stopper the tubes with sterile soft rubber bungs, and place in a water bath for five minutes to bring them to 37°C.</li>
<li>Remove tubes from the water bath, add 1 ml of well-mixed milk sample.</li>
<li>Replace the bung, invert several times and reincubate for two hours at 37°C.</li>
<li>As a control, add 1 ml of milk that has been boiled to 5 ml of buffer substrate and treat as the test.</li>
<li>After exactly two hours, remove tubes from the water bath and mix well.</li>
<li>Read in the Lovibond comparator stand with the control tube on the left hand ramp and the test</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>826 Bacteriology</p>
<p>sample on the right. Match colours in good daylight. Record the reading on the disc.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Results</th><th>Interpretation</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>mg p-nitrophenol/ml of milk</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>&lt;10</td><td>Properly pasteurised</td></tr><tr><td>10–18</td><td>Slightly under-pasteurised</td></tr><tr><td>18–42</td><td>Under-pasteurised</td></tr><tr><td>Over 42</td><td>Grossly under-pasteurised.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The colour intensity can also be measured spectrophotometrically at 610 nm using 20 µg/ml phenol as standard.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="turbidity-test">Turbidity Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#turbidity-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Heat coagulable protein in milk is denatured when milk is heated at 100°C. If ammonium sulphate is added to unboiled milk with undenatured protein, then filtered and boiled, turbidity will occur.</p>
<p>Sterilised milk should show no turbidity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Add 4 g ammonium sulphate to a conical flask.</li>
<li>Add 20 ml milk sample and shake well to dissolve.</li>
<li>Leave for at least five minutes.</li>
<li>Filter into a test tube.</li>
<li>Boil about 5 ml of clear filtrate for five minutes.</li>
<li>Cool the tube in cold water and examine for turbidity.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Result</strong> No turbidity indicates satisfactory sterilisation of milk.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="62de56c7">♦ BACTERIOLOGICAL EXAMINATION OF FOOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#62de56c7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This text is an introduction to food bacteriology. Bacteriological examination of food is performed for three reasons:</p>
<ol>
<li>to establish standards of hygiene by total viable bacterial count of packaged food.</li>
<li>to establish the shelf-life of food by detecting food spoilage bacteria in food.</li>
<li>to detect specific pathogenic bacteria incriminated in an outbreak of food poisoning.</li>
</ol>
<p>It is necessary to prevent bacterial spoilage and contamination of food. This is done by sampling of batches of mass produced food during and after processing. The prevention of food spoilage can be effected by refrigeration which slows down bacterial activity; and by drying which prevents spoilage until the food is exposed to moisture. Prevention is also achieved with salt and sugar. When the preventive measure fails, food contamination may result.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="80dbb860">♦ TESTING THE QUALITY OF FOOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#80dbb860" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Food should be despatched to the laboratory in its original container or transferred to a sterile container. The food should be refrigerated until processed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Aseptically weigh about 10 g of food.</li>
<li>Aseptically homogenise in a sterile diluent. If the food is liquid, it can be mixed by inversion.</li>
<li>Make dilutions of food suspension</li>
<li>Perform colony counts. Employ any standard plate count method, e.g., pour plate or Milles and Misra methods.</li>
<li>Inoculate various media such as MacConkey (for enterobacteria), azide blood agar (for enterococci), neomycin blood agar (for clostridia).</li>
<li>Identify the bacteria isolated.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="19fd9a93">♦ FOOD POISONING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#19fd9a93" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacterial food poisoning results from the consumption of contaminated food. Food poisoning bacteria can be broadly classified into two:</p>
<ol>
<li>Those that infect the body notably, for example, the Salmonella group</li>
<li>Those that produce toxins during their growth in the food. They include Staphy</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriological Examination of Water, Milk, Food and Air 827</p>
<p>lococcus aureus, Clostridium perfringens group A and Clostridium botulinum</p>
<p>To diagnose food poisoning it is necessary to know the symptoms and time of onset. Table 24.4 shows the common signs and symptoms, and incubation periods for the common bacterial food poisoning.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="salmonella-food-poisoning">Salmonella Food Poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salmonella-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source Man, animals and birds. The organism is killed by boiling, so contamination is post cooking. Infection occurs during the process of eating. It is possible that food is improperly cooked. It is common in such foods as meat products, cream, eggs and coconut.</p>
<p>Specimen Faeces and the contaminated food. The food should be taken to the laboratory in its original container or transferred aspetically to sterile containers. Refrigerate the food until processed.</p>
<p>Examination Homogenise the food in sterile diluent.</p>
<p>Inoculate XLD and Hektoen media and selenite F broth. Isolate and identify the bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staphylococcus-food-poisoning">Staphylococcus Food Poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staphylococcus-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source Nose and skin of man. The organism is killed by heat so contamination is post cooking. Infection occurs during eating of the food. The organism produces enterotoxin. The infection is common in such foods as cream, meat, pork, pies etc.</p>
<p>Specimen Faeces of the patient is sent to the laboratory for examination. It may be necessary to take a nasal swab of the catering staff for screening.</p>
<p>Culture Inoculate mannitol salt agar with the patient's specimen. Isolate and identify the organism as Staph. aureus. The isolate can also be phage-typed in order to pinpoint the source.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clostridium-perfringens-food-poisoning">Clostridium perfringens Food Poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clostridium-perfringens-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source Man and animals. Contamination is pre-cooking especially of meat cooked in bulk. Spores of the organisms survive heating. On cooking, the spores germinate and cause diarrhoea when ingested in the food. The organism produces enterotoxin in the gut.</p>
<p>Specimen The remainder of the food and the patient's faeces are sent to the laboratory for culture.</p>
<p>Culture Direct plating of the food on neomycin blood agar; and inoculation of Robertson's cooked meat (RCM) will yield the Cl. perfringens. There is no spore formation in the food. Identify and type the isolate. Also identify the toxin using ELISA.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clostridium-botulium-food-poisoning">Clostridium botulium Food Poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clostridium-botulium-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source Soil and animals. Contamination is pre-cooking. It is common in canned and home preserved food such as meat, vegetables, pickles etc. C. botulinum multiplies in the anaerobic condition of canned food and produces a pre-formed powerful neurotoxin which is ingested with the food. Botulism, a neuroparalytic disease, is symptomised by acute descending paralysis which starts in the facial and respiratory muscles.</p>
<p>Specimen Suspected food, and patient's faecal and vomit specimens.</p>
<p>Culture Isolate the organism on neomycin blood agar and from RCM.</p>
<p>Identify the organism, type it and demonstrate toxin production. The toxin is heat stable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacillus-cereus-food-poisoning">Bacillus cereus Food Poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacillus-cereus-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>B. cereus is isolated from the patient's faeces with a B.cereus selective medium such as phenol red egg-yolk polymyxin agar. It is a saprophyte that contaminates heat treated milk or boiled rice. Food poisoning sets in after consuming the food, especially boiled rice that has been stored for long periods after cooking.</p>
<p>The organism is isolated, identified and typed.</p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> Many other organisms are capable of causing food poisoning. Infected food usually may not show any change in taste, smell or colour.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>828 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Table 24.4 Characteristics of various types of food poisoning</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of food poisoning</th><th>Infection</th><th>Intoxication</th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Causative agent</td><td>Salmonella SP.</td><td>Staph. aureus</td><td>Cl. perfringens</td><td>Cl. botulinum</td><td>Bacillus cereus</td></tr><tr><td>Incubation</td><td>12-24 hours</td><td>2-6 hours</td><td>8-22 hours</td><td>12-72 hours</td><td>0.5-6 hours</td></tr><tr><td>Diarrhoea</td><td>Very common</td><td>Common</td><td>Extremely common</td><td>Absent</td><td>Slight</td></tr><tr><td>Vomiting</td><td>Not common</td><td>Extremely common</td><td>Very rare</td><td>Slight</td><td>Profuse</td></tr><tr><td>Abdominal pain</td><td>Present</td><td>Present</td><td>Present</td><td>Absent</td><td>Absent</td></tr><tr><td>Pyrexia</td><td>Common</td><td>Absent</td><td>Absent</td><td>Absent</td><td>Absent</td></tr><tr><td>Prostration</td><td>Rare in early stages</td><td>Common</td><td>Common</td><td>Severe</td><td>Moderately severe</td></tr><tr><td>Pathogenesis</td><td>Organisms multiply in the small and large intestine and cause epithelial cell damage.</td><td>Organisms grow in food and produce heat-stable enterotoxin.</td><td>Organisms multiply in the gut and release enterotoxin.</td><td>Organisms multiply in food and produce heat-labile potent neurotoxin. Food poisoning may result in respiratory paralysis and death.</td><td>Organisms grow in food, especially rice, and produce emetic enterotoxin.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>Bacteriological Examination of Water, Milk, Food and Air 829</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bacteriological-examination-of-air">BACTERIOLOGICAL EXAMINATION OF AIR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination-of-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the pharmaceutical and certain other manufacturing industries, bacterial quality of air is very important. In the hospital environment, quality surveillance of air provides physical evidence that sanitation and contamination control measures in intensive care units, operating theatres, tissue transplant rooms, burn units and other areas of high risk of infection, are effective. The air supply to these areas needs to be monitored especially after building work has been done within the vicinity. The bacterial count in air entering operating rooms through filters should be less than 3.5 colony forming units/m³ (CFU/m³). The air entering these special areas is HEPA (High Efficiency Particle Arrester) filtered.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="methods">Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="settle-plates">Settle plates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#settle-plates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the simplest way of evaluating the level of air contamination in a room. It is economical and requires no special techniques. Nutrient agar or blood agar plates are left exposed in selected sites for a given time. The plates are then incubated at 37°C for 24 hours for the detection of pathogens, at 20°C for three days for the detection of saprophytic organisms and for 5–7 days at 30°C for moulds. The CFUs are counted irrespective of the type of bacteria. It may be necessary to identify the organism.</p>
<p>The disadvantage of this method is that only the bacteria on heavy particles fall and settle on the plates.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="air-samplers">Air samplers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#air-samplers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A more precise assessment of air contamination is by the use of an air sampler. The common air samplers in the market are the slit type and the centrifugal type.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="slit-air-sampler">Slit air sampler<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slit-air-sampler" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The slit air sampler, e.g., the Casella air sampler, draws air through a narrow slit at a rate of 0.028 m³/minute on to a blood agar (or any other appropriate medium) in a rotating petridish. The rotation which is effected by an electric motor, allows the bacteria to be distributed over the whole surface of the medium. The slit is adjustable, so by varying the size of slit and time of exposure, different volumes of air can be assessed. After incubation, the CFUs are counted and the number of organisms/m³ of air is quantified.</p>
<p>The disadvantage of this method is the cumbersome nature of the equipment. Figure 24.1 shows a dismantled Casella slit air sampler.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-dc6f1b80.jpeg" alt="img-119.jpeg">
Fig. 24.1 Dismantled casella slit air sampler</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="centrifugal-air-sampler">Centrifugal air sampler<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#centrifugal-air-sampler" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A good example of the centrifugal air sampler is the Biotest Reuter centrifugal sampler. It is a completely portable, hand-held instrument that resembles a torch (Fig. 24.2). The sampler works on the principle of impaction. A plastic strip of agar medium is inserted into the slot in the open-end drum. The air is drawn into the head of the sampler and is subjected to centrifugal speed so that it impacts on the strip of agar. The strip is removed and incubated.</p>
<p>With this sampler, the grading of the quality of air in certain areas is as follows:</p>
<p>10 or less CFU s/m³ : transplantation areas
70 or less CFU s/m³ : operating theatres
800 less CFU s/m³ : laboratories, out patient clinics and lecture theatres.</p>
<p>The main advantage is that it is battery operated so that sampling of air in difficult parts of building can be performed. The instrument is supplied with an explanatory manual for use and operation.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>830 Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-69cfc017.jpeg" alt="img-120.jpeg">
Fig. 24.2 Biotest reuter centrifugal sampler</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 25</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="formulae-and-preparation-of-culture-media">Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formulae-and-preparation-of-culture-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most of the culture media described here are commercially available in dehydrated powder form. Preparation is according to the manufacturer's direction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basal-media">BASAL MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basal-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="nutrient-broth">Nutrient Broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutrient-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Nutrient broth forms the basis of most culture media used for cultivation of bacteria. There are three types of nutrient broth: meat infusion broth, digest broth and meat extract broth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-meat-infusion-broth">A. Meat Infusion broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-meat-infusion-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a watery extract of lean meat to which peptone is added. The meat should be fresh and not frozen. It must be fat-free.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lean meat, ox heart or leg</th><th>500 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Water</td><td>100 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Peptone</td><td>10–12 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium chloride, (NaCl)</td><td>5 g</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Mince the meat as finely as possible.</li>
<li>Add minced meat to the water.</li>
<li>Extract at 4°C for 24 hours.</li>
<li>Strain through muslin and squeeze the meat residue. The extract is usually red in colour. Skin off any thin surface layer of fat with a piece of filter paper.</li>
<li>Boil the extract for 15 minutes or steam at 100°C for two hours. The extract becomes brown and turbid because haemoglobin is changed and soluble proteins are coagulated.</li>
<li>Allow to cool down.</li>
<li>Filter through Whatman No.1 filter paper. The extract should be clear and yellowish.</li>
<li>Make up the volume to 1000ml with water.</li>
<li>Add peptone and NaCl and dissolve by heating.</li>
<li>Filter. Due to the presence of lactic acid, the pH will be acidic.</li>
<li>Adjust pH to about 7.5 which will finally come down to 7.4 when cold.</li>
<li>Dispense into bottles or tubes in desired volumes.</li>
<li>Sterilise by autoclaving at 121°C for 15 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-digest-broth">B. Digest broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-digest-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Pancreatic extract is usually used, though it may be replaced with a commercial trypsin extract or powder. Digest broth is very suitable for the cultivation of haemolytic streptococci because it permits luxuriant growth of such bacteria. The enzyme trypsin (in the pancreatic extract) works in alkaline pH, hence the addition of sodium carbonate.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lean meat, ox heart or beef</th><th>750 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Water</td><td>1250 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium carbonate, (Na₂CO₃) 0.8% solution</td><td>1250 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Pancreatic extract</td><td>25 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>832 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Chloroform CHCl₃ 25 ml
Hydrochloric acid HCl conc. 20 ml</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Mince the meat as finely as possible.</li>
<li>Add the meat and Na₂CO₃ to the water.</li>
<li>Heat to 80°C, stirring well.</li>
<li>Cool to 45°C</li>
<li>Add the pancreatic extract and the chloroform and maintain at 45°C for 3–4 hours or incubate at 37°C for six hours with frequent stirring.</li>
<li>When digestion is complete, add the acid and boil for 30 minutes. The acid is to counteract the sodium carbonate and stop digestion.</li>
<li>Filter; adjust pH to 8.0, heat for 30 minutes and filter again.</li>
<li>Adjust pH to 7.6, distribute into bottles and sterilise at 115°C for 20 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>To test end-point of digestion (at step 5), add 1 ml of a saturated solution of potassium hydroxide and 0.1 ml of copper sulphate to about 5 ml of the extract. Pink colour indicates complete digestion, blue means incomplete digestion (Biuret test)</li>
<li>It may be necessary to determine the aminoacid and nitrogen (N₂) content of the broth. The broth may be diluted accordingly to contain 700–750 mg/litre of aminoacid and N₂.</li>
<li>Pancreatic extract
Fresh pig pancreas (minced and fat free) 500 g
Distilled water 1500 ml
Absolute alcohol 500 ml</li>
<li>Mix well in a large stoppered flask</li>
<li>Leave at room temperature for three days. Shake occasionally.</li>
<li>Strain through muslin. Filter.</li>
<li>Add 0.1% pure concentrated HCl</li>
<li>The extract will keep for several months.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-meat-extract-broth">C. Meat extract broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-meat-extract-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is prepared as a mixture of commercial peptone and meat extract.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Meat extract (Lab-Lemco, Oxoid)</th><th>10 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Peptone</td><td>10 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium chloride, NaCl</td><td>5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol>
<li>Mix the ingredients in the water.</li>
<li>Dissolve by heating briefly</li>
<li>Cool and adjust pH to 7.5–7.6</li>
<li>Remove any phosphate formed by filtration through filter paper</li>
<li>Distribute into bottles or tubes in desired amounts</li>
<li>Sterilise by autoclaving at 115°C for fifteen minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peptone-water">PEPTONE WATER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peptone-water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Peptone water is used to test for the production of indole and for the preparation of sugar media used for fermentation reactions of bacteria, especially the enterobacteria group.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="formula">Formula<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formula" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Peptone</th><th>2 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sodium chloride</td><td>1 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>200 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Dissolve peptone and the salt in water, adjust pH to 7.4–7.5.</li>
<li>Dispense in 3 ml amounts in screw-cap bottles.</li>
<li>Sterilize by autoclaving at 121°C for fifteen minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Dissolution of ingredients may be quickened by steaming.</li>
<li>Bijou type screw-cap bottles are ideal containers.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutrient-agar">NUTRIENT AGAR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutrient-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nutrient agar is a basic medium used in the preparation of blood agar, chocolate agar and other more complex media. It can be made into slopes in test tubes or universal containers, or poured into petri</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media 833</p>
<p>dishes, and is used to subculture and maintain non-fastidious pathogens.</p>
<p>Nutrient broth 100 ml
Agar powder 1–1.5 g
Dehydrated media are formulated by the manufacturing firm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.
Cool at 50°C
Mix gently and pour plates or prepare slants.
Alternatively, after sterilisation, tighten the cap of the container and store at room temperature until when required:
Steam to remelt.
Cool to 50°C.
Mix gently and pour plates.
Allow the media to set and then label and store.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; i. Nutrient gelatin is prepared as 12–15% gelatine in nutrient broth, but a higher concentration is recommended for tropical countries. It is used for the determination of gelatin liquefaction.
&gt; ii. Agar is used at 1–1.5% concentration for solidification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-agar">BLOOD AGAR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood agar is an enriched medium used to grow a wide range of moderately exacting organisms. It is also used to detect and differentiate haemolytic bacteria.</p>
<p>The blood meant for blood agar should be haemolysis free and anticoagulated or defibinated. It can be horse, sheep/goat or rabbit blood. Expired citrated human blood can be used, though this practice should not be encouraged as it may contain inhibitory substances that may prevent the growth of some pathogens, e.g., citrate may inhibit the growth of beta-haemolytic streptococci. Before use, culture the blood and incubate overnight to check for its sterility.</p>
<p><strong>Formula</strong> Nutrient agar, or blood agar base as formulated by the manufacturer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Columbia blood agar
base (oxoid) 19.5g
Distilled water 475 ml
Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes
Cool to 50°C
Add defibrinated horse blood 25ml
Mix well but gently.
Pour into plates or tubes as required.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; A more nutritious medium than the ordinary nutrient agar may be used. The Oxoid Columbia blood agar is a good example; it contains both meat and casein peptones and supports the growth of such fastidious organisms as Haemophilus and Neisseria species.</p>
<p><strong>Layered blood agar</strong> Some workers prefer to pour a thin layer of watery agar (2% agar in distilled water) or nutrient agar into sterile petri dishes. When it has set, the molten blood agar is poured on top.</p>
<p><strong>Advantages</strong> Haemolysis is more easily seen; the blood agar layer is more uniform in thickness and less blood is used. However, most laboratories consider this method as time wasting and so use the first method.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="selective-blood-agar">SELECTIVE BLOOD AGAR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-blood-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood agar can be made selective for certain pathogens by the addition of chemicals, dyes or antibiotics, e.g., Gentamicin blood agar for anaerobes and crystal violet blood agar for <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gentamicin-blood-agar">Gentamicin Blood Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gentamicin-blood-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Preparation of gentamicin solution</strong> A vial of gentamicin usually contains 50 mg/ml in 10 ml water.
Dilute 1:25 in sterile distilled water.
Aseptically, distribute in 2.5ml amounts in sterile bijou bottles and store at –20°C.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>834 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-medium">Preparation of medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood agar base: 500 ml</li>
<li>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes</li>
<li>Cool to 50°C</li>
<li>Defibrinated horse blood: 30 ml</li>
<li>Gentamicin solution: 2.5 ml
(This gives a final concentration of 10μg/ml).</li>
<li>Mix well and pour plates.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="crystal-violet-blood-agar-cvba">Crystal Violet Blood Agar (CVBA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#crystal-violet-blood-agar-cvba" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Procedure</strong> To 500 ml sterile blood agar, add 5 ml of 0.02% w/v aqueous solution of crystal violet.</p>
<ul>
<li>Mix well and pour plates.</li>
<li>Label CVBA.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: This medium is ideal for processing throat swab as it inhibits Staphylococcus and most commensals of the upper respiratory tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chocolate-agar">Chocolate Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chocolate-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Procedure</strong> This is the same as for blood agar except that after adding the blood, the medium is heated in a water bath at 75°C or in a Koch steamer until it is chocolatised (about 10–15 minutes).</p>
<ul>
<li>Cool to 45–50°C</li>
<li>Mix gently and pour plates (or tubes).</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>:</p>
<ol>
<li>Final concentration of blood in blood agar usually is 5%.</li>
<li>Serum in serum agar is 5%.</li>
<li>Glucose in glucose agar is 1%. Glucose solution is sterilised by Seitz filteration or at 5 psi for 10 minutes in the autoclave.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrate-fermentation-media">CARBOHYDRATE FERMENTATION MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrate-fermentation-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="peptone-water-sugars">Peptone Water Sugars<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peptone-water-sugars" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Various carbohydrates are added to peptone water to determine which sugars are attacked by bacteria. Gas production can be detected by placing an inverted Durham's tube in the medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>To sterile peptone water, add 1% Andrade's indicator and sterile 10% solution of the required sugar to give a final concentration of 0.5%.</li>
<li>Dispense aseptically in 3–4 ml amounts in sterile bijou bottles containing one inverted Durham's tube each (already sterilised with the bottle).</li>
<li>Steam for 30 minutes for 3 consecutive days (tyndallisation) or autoclave at 5 psi for 10 minutes, in which case the reagents need not be sterile during preparation.</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>:</p>
<ol>
<li>Prepare a 10% stock solution of the required sugar from which sufficient amount is added to the peptone water (0.2 ml for 4 ml Andrade's peptone water).</li>
<li>The medium turns pink during steaming but returns to straw colour or cooling. This is an indication that it is of correct reaction and the indicator is satisfactory.</li>
<li>It is easier to use colour code to identify the sugars:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Glucose</th><th>-Green</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Lactose</td><td>-Red</td></tr><tr><td>Mannite (Mannitol)</td><td>-Mauve</td></tr><tr><td>Dulcite (Dulcitol)</td><td>-Pink</td></tr><tr><td>Salicin</td><td>-Pink and white</td></tr><tr><td>Sucrose</td><td>-Blue</td></tr><tr><td>Xylose</td><td>-Red and green</td></tr><tr><td>Maltose</td><td>-Blue and white</td></tr><tr><td>L-Arabinose</td><td>-Black and yellow</td></tr><tr><td>Trehalose</td><td>-Mauve and green</td></tr><tr><td>Mannose</td><td>-Black and green</td></tr><tr><td>Normal Saline</td><td>-White with blue dot</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>As a general rule, sugar ending with -'ose' are mono-, di- or trisaccharides, those ending with -'ol' are alcohols and those ending with -'in' are glycosides. Exceptions: Inulin and dextrin are polysaccharides.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media 835</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="storage">Storage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#storage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Up to six months in a cool dark place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-andrade-s-indicator">Preparation of Andrade's indicator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-andrade-s-indicator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dissolve 0.5g of acid fuchsin in 100ml distilled water</li>
<li>Add 16ml of 1N sodium hydroxide (NaOH)</li>
<li>Leave overnight.</li>
<li>The colour should be yellow, if not add a little more of 1N NaOH and leave overnight again.</li>
<li>Add 1ml of the indicator to 99ml of peptone water.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hiss-serum-water-sugars">Hiss Serum Water Sugars<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hiss-serum-water-sugars" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This medium is used to detect sugar fermentation by organisms such as neisseriae, corynebacteria and others that require serum for growth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Ox serum: 1 part
Distilled water: 3 parts</p>
<ol>
<li>Adjust pH to 7.5</li>
<li>Add Andrade's indicator 1%</li>
<li>Add the required sugar 0.5%</li>
<li>Tube or bottle, and tyndallise.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="litmus-milk">LITMUS MILK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#litmus-milk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Litmus milk medium is used to detect the fermentation of its contained lactose by micro-organisms such as <em>Clostridium</em> species. Clotting and digestion of the milk is also detected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>To prepare 10% litmus solution
Litmus: 10 g
Distilled water: 100 ml
Boil for 10 minutes. Leave overnight.
Filter and bottle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="litmus-milk">Litmus milk<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#litmus-milk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Centrifuge fresh milk at high speed. The cream forms a surface layer.</li>
<li>Remove the cream.</li>
<li>Add sufficient 10% litmus solution to give the desired tint to the milk.</li>
<li>Dispense into tubes or bottles and tyndallise.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-culture-media-for-various-bacteria">SPECIAL CULTURE MEDIA FOR VARIOUS BACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-culture-media-for-various-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
