<table><thead><tr><th>Peptone</th><th>15 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Yeast extract</td><td>6 g</td></tr><tr><td>Tomato juice*</td><td>200 ml</td></tr><tr><td>10% Lactic acid</td><td>10 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Agar</td><td>9 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>800 ml</td></tr><tr><td>pH</td><td>5.0</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Steam the ingredients to dissolve.</p>
<p>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>Mix and pour plates.</p>
<p>*Tomato juice: 500 g of tomatoes in 1000 ml of distilled water. Boil and filter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="whey-medium">Whey Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#whey-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Add sufficient 10% HCl to skimmed milk at 80°C in order to precipitate the casein. Filter and adjust pH to 6.8 and add 0.5% peptone.</p>
<p>Sterilise at 115°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>This is Whey broth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="whey-agar">Whey agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#whey-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Whey broth</th><th>100 ml</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Agar</td><td>1.5 g</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Sterilise at 115°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>Pour plates.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>844 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b9bb3308">♦ CULTURE MEDIUM FOR LEGIONELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b9bb3308" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="legionella-charcoal-yeast-extract-cye-agar">Legionella Charcoal Yeast Extract (CYE) agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#legionella-charcoal-yeast-extract-cye-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This medium is basically blood agar to which <em>Legionella</em> selective supplement and <em>Legionella</em> growth supplement have been added to promote the growth of <em>Legionella pneumophila</em>. Many workers believe that blood agar gives better recovery of the organism than the CYE. The <em>Legionella</em> growth supplements consist of:</p>
<ul>
<li>L-Cysteine HCl at 400 µg/ml</li>
<li>Ferric pyrophosphate at 250 µg/ml</li>
<li>Sodium selenite at 10 µg/ml</li>
</ul>
<p>Both the cysteine and the ferric ions promote good growth while sodium selenite enhances rate of growth.</p>
<p>The following antibiotics make up the selective supplement:</p>
<ul>
<li>Colistin 15 units/ml</li>
<li>Vancomycin 5.0 µg/ml</li>
<li>Trimethoprim 2.5 µg/ml</li>
<li>Amphotericin B 2.5 µg/ml</li>
</ul>
<p>These antibiotics prevent the growth of contaminating organisms from the clinical specimen.</p>
<p>The Oxoid growth supplements and selective supplements must be used with Legionella CYE agar.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>To 1 vial of growth supplement add 10 ml of warm sterile distilled water.</p>
<p>Mix gently to dissolve the contents. Avoid frothing.</p>
<p>To 1 vial of selective supplement, add 2 ml of sterile distilled water, mix gently to dissolve the contents. Avoid frothing.</p>
<ul>
<li>Blood agar base 100 ml</li>
<li>Bring to the boil to dissolve.</li>
<li>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</li>
<li>Cool to 50°C</li>
<li><em>Legionella</em> growth supplement 1 vial</li>
<li>Legionella selective supplement 1 vial</li>
<li>Mix well and pour plates.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5e7e757c">♦ CULTURE MEDIA FOR MYCOBACTERIUM SPECIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5e7e757c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lowenstein-jensen-medium">Lowenstein-Jensen Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lowenstein-jensen-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is an inspissated egg medium for the isolation of <em>Mycobacterium</em> species, especially the human and bovine tubercle bacilli. It contains the following constituents:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Potassium dihydrogen phosphate (anhydrous)</th><th>2.4 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Magnesium sulphate</td><td>0.24 g</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium citrate</td><td>0.6 g</td></tr><tr><td>Asparagine</td><td>3.6 g</td></tr><tr><td>Glycerol (AR)</td><td>12.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Potato starch (optional)</td><td>30.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Fresh egg mixture (Yellow and whites)</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Malachite green</td><td>0.4 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>600 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The asparagine serves as the sources of nitrogen and the glycerol the source of carbon. Malachite green inhibits unwanted organisms, especially Gram positive organisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparation-of-the-medium">Preparation of the medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-the-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="9b21abec">(a) Preparation of salts—glycerol-asparagine solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9b21abec" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Dissolve the salts and the asparagine and the glycerol in 600 ml distilled water. Steam for 2 hours and store in the refrigerator.</p>
<p>To the above solution, add 30 g potato starch; heat over a flame with constant stirring to give a smooth mixture.</p>
<p>Sterilise in the autoclave at 115°C for 20 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-complete-medium">The complete medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-complete-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Mix the egg suspension with the salts-glycerol-asparagine-potato solution.</p>
<p>Add 20 ml of 2% malachite green solution.</p>
<p>Distribute aseptically into sterile tubes or bottles.</p>
<p>Inspissate at 75°C until solidified.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-preparation-of-egg-fluid">(b) Preparation of egg-fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-preparation-of-egg-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Aseptically, break 20–22 fresh hen’s eggs into a flask containing glass beads. Shake well to homogenise and filter through sterile muslin.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media 845</p>
<p>(c) Preparation of malachite green Aseptically prepare 2% w/v solution of malachite green in sterile distilled water.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Marks and Zaher modification of the LJ medium incorporates hydrochloric acid to reduce the amount of phosphates needed (high phosphate concentration is detrimental to the growth of M. tuberculosis) and uses less malachite green because the dye is more anti bacterial at lower concentration.</li>
<li>Many workers leave out potato starch since the potato starch only helps to reduce the amount of water of condensation, an excess of which can affect the type of growth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pyruvate-lj-medium">PYRUVATE LJ MEDIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pyruvate-lj-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is LJ medium containing 0.5% pyruvate. The pyruvate should be added before inspissation. Other chemicals or substances can be added to the LJ medium for the specific isolation of certain strains of mycobacteria, e.g., P-nitrobenzoic acid (PNB) at 500 µg/ml or Thiacetazone (TCZ) at 1.0 mg/ml can be added to the liquid LJ medium before inspissation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dorset-egg-medium">DORSET EGG MEDIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dorset-egg-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This medium is a simple egg medium, that can support the growth of mycobacteria. It contains:</p>
<ul>
<li>Egg Suspension 800 ml</li>
<li>Nutrient broth (sterile) 200 ml</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Preparation</strong> Mix the egg and nutrient broth aseptically. Inspissate at 75°C to form slopes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="middlebrook-7h10-agar">MIDDLEBROOK 7H10 AGAR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#middlebrook-7h10-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This plate medium or the broth is used for the isolation, cultivation and identification of M. tuberculosis. It consists of the Middlebrook agar and the Middlebrook enrichments.</p>
<p>The agar is composed of:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Ammonium sulphate</th><th>0.5 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>L-Glutamic acid</td><td>0.5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium citrate</td><td>0.4 g</td></tr><tr><td>Disodium phosphate</td><td>1.5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Monopotassium phosphate</td><td>1.5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Glycerol</td><td>5.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Ferric ammonium citrate</td><td>0.04 g</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium sulphate</td><td>0.05 g</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium chloride</td><td>0.0005 g</td></tr><tr><td>Zink sulphate</td><td>0.001 g</td></tr><tr><td>Copper Sulphate</td><td>0.001 g</td></tr><tr><td>Pyridoxine hydrochloride</td><td>0.001 g</td></tr><tr><td>Biotin</td><td>0.0005 g</td></tr><tr><td>Malachite green</td><td>0.001 g</td></tr><tr><td>Agar</td><td>15.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr><tr><td>pH</td><td>6.6</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Dissolve the chemicals first, then add and dissolve the agar. Dispense in 90 ml amounts. Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>Middlebrook OADC enrichment is composed of oleic acid-albumin-dextrose-catalase complex and is available in lyophilised form with a 2-year shelf life. To reconstitute each ampoule, add 20 ml of sterile distilled water. This keeps for up to eight weeks when stored at 2–6°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-the-medium">Preparation of the medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-the-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Melt the Middlebrook agar.</li>
<li>Cool to 50°C.</li>
<li>Add 10 ml of OADC enrichment.</li>
<li>Pour into plates. Label and store away from sunlight because of the adverse effect it has on the medium.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The Middlebrook medium is also available in dehydrated form and should be prepared according to the manufacturer's instructions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture-media-for-pathogenic-neisseria">CULTURE MEDIA FOR PATHOGENIC NEISSERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture-media-for-pathogenic-neisseria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Any culture medium that supports the growth Neisseria gonorrhoeae will also allow the growth</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>846 Bacteriology</p>
<p>of <em>Neisseria meningitidis</em>. Media used for the isolation of gonococci (GC) contain highly purified agars, special peptone and starch. They are enriched with chocolatised horse blood or soluble haemoglobin and GC growth supplements which stimulate growth from small inocula. The GC growth supplements are either in the form of specially prepared yeast extract with dextrose and sodium bicarbonate (available in the state of sterile lyophilised concentrate) or as chemically defined growth factors such as Vitamin B₁₂, L-glutamine, adenine SO₄, Guanine HCl, p-aminobenzoic acid and L-cystine. These are also available as sterile lyophilised concentrate (Vitox supplement).</p>
<p>Antibiotics in several and various combinations are used as selective agents in the media to suppress Gram negative and Gram-positive contaminants and <em>Candida</em>. These are the common antibiotic combinations:</p>
<ul>
<li>VCN, VCNT, VCAT and LCAT.</li>
<li>V = Vancomycin-inhibits Gram-positive organisms</li>
<li>C = Collistin methane sulphonate-inhibits Gram-negative organisms</li>
<li>N = Nystatin-inhibits <em>Candida</em> species</li>
<li>T = Trimethoprim-inhibits the swarming of <em>Proteus</em></li>
<li>L = Lincomycin-inhibits Gram-positive organisms</li>
<li>A = Amphotericin B; Anisomycin-inhibits Candida and other fungi.</li>
</ul>
<p>A laboratory makes its own choice of selective supplement according to preference and other peculiar local factors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6e03480d">♦ MODIFIED THAYER-MARTIN (MTM) MEDIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6e03480d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is about the most widely used culture medium for the isolation of <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>. The antibiotic combination is VCNT instead of the original VCN. The antibiotic supplement and the growth supplement are combined and are available as GC supplement in lyophilised form.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>The formula per vial of the GC supplement is</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Yeast autolysate</td><td>10.0</td><td>g per litre</td></tr><tr><td>Dextrose</td><td>1.5</td><td>g per litre</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium bicarbonate</td><td>0.15</td><td>g per litre</td></tr><tr><td>Vancomycin</td><td>3.0</td><td>mg per litre</td></tr><tr><td>Colistin methane sulphonate</td><td>7.5</td><td>mg per litre</td></tr><tr><td>Nystatin</td><td>12,500</td><td>units per litre</td></tr><tr><td>Trimethoprin</td><td>5.0</td><td>mg per litre</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The medium is easier and more convenient to prepare using any of various brands in dehydrated forms available in the market.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dissolve the contents of 1 vial of GC supplement with 15 ml of sterile distilled water.</li>
<li>Add 250 ml of warm distilled water to 5 g of haemoglobin powder to give a 2% solution. Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</li>
<li>Dissolve 18 g of Oxoid GC agar base in 235 ml of distilled water. Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</li>
<li>Cool to 50°C</li>
<li>Add the contents of 1 vial of GC supplement Mix gently.</li>
<li>Add 250 ml of sterile haemoglobin solution.</li>
<li>Mix gently to avoid much air bubbles being trapped.</li>
<li>Pour into plates.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Thayer-Martin medium can be prepared with the growth supplement (Vitox) separate and with a VCN (original formulation) combination separately.</li>
<li>Fresh horse, sheep or human blood, plain or chocolatised, used at 5% concentration, will give a satisfactory result.</li>
<li>A modification of the Thayer-Martin medium is the Martin-Lewis medium which uses anisomycin instead of nystatin and 2 µg/ml of vancomycin. In this medium, Candida is inhibited for longer period; and the vancomycin at that concentration does not inhibit gonococci.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media 847</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="modified-new-york-city-mnyc-medium-for-pathogenic-neisseria">MODIFIED NEW YORK CITY (MNYC) MEDIUM FOR PATHOGENIC NEISSERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#modified-new-york-city-mnyc-medium-for-pathogenic-neisseria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This medium uses laked horse blood with a VCAT or LCAT antibiotic combination. The MNYC medium base and the supplements are available from Oxoid and other manufacturers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation">Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>GC agar base (Oxoid) 18 g
Distilled water 425 ml
Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</li>
<li>Lake 50ml of defibrinated horse blood.</li>
<li>LCAT or VCAT supplement
Add 10 ml of sterile distilled water to 1 vial of VCAT or LCAT supplement to dissolve.</li>
<li>Vitox supplement
Add the contents of 1 vial of Vitox hydration medium to 1 vial of the Vitox growth supplements.</li>
<li>Cool the agar to 50°C</li>
<li>Aseptically add the lysed horse blood, 1 vial of vitox and 1 vial of antibiotic supplement.</li>
<li>Mix gently and pour into plates, label and store.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>There are many varieties of both the Thayer-Martin medium and the Modified New York City medium produced by different manufacturers.</li>
<li>The growth supplement Vitox is also referred to by such other names like Isovitalex or Supplement B.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="media-used-to-prevent-the-swarming-of-proteus">MEDIA USED TO PREVENT THE SWARMING OF PROTEUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#media-used-to-prevent-the-swarming-of-proteus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-electrolyte-deficient-medium">1. Electrolyte Deficient Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-electrolyte-deficient-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the absence of an electrolyte, Proteus will not warm. A good medium of this nature is the Cystein Lactose Electrolyte Deficient (CLED) medium, which is particularly useful in urine bacteriology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-concentrated-blood-agar-plates">2. Concentrated Blood Agar Plates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-concentrated-blood-agar-plates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood agar plates containing up to or more than 5% agar will prevent Proteus from swarming.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-chloral-hydrate-plates">3. Chloral Hydrate Plates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-chloral-hydrate-plates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Proteus will not swarm on a blood agar plate containing 1.5% to 5% solution of chloral hydrate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-sodium-azide-plates">4. Sodium Azide Plates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-sodium-azide-plates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A 1/5000 solution of sodium azide in 5% blood agar will prevent the swarming of Proteus.</p>
<p>Sodium azide is hazardous and must be handled with care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="culture-media-for-staphylococcus">CULTURE MEDIA FOR STAPHYLOCOCCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture-media-for-staphylococcus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-ludlam-s-medium">1. Ludlam's Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-ludlam-s-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a good selective medium for the isolation of Staphylococcus aureus. Potassium tellurite and lithium chloride act as selective agents. It is made up of:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Meat extract</th><th>10 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Peptone</td><td>10 g</td></tr><tr><td>Dipotassium hydrogen phosphate (K₂HPO₄), anhydrous</td><td>5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Lithium chloride</td><td>5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Mannitol</td><td>10 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Apply heat to dissolve and adjust pH to 9.2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Agar powder</td><td>10 g</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Dissolve and dispense in 100 ml amounts. Sterilise at 115°C for 15 minutes. Store.</p>
<p>For use, melt and add 0.5 ml of sterile 0.25% solution of potassium tellurite.</p>
<p>After 36 hours incubation:</p>
<ul>
<li>Staph. aureus: dark-grey or black shining colonies</li>
<li>Staph. epidermidis: poor growth of pale colonies or no growth.</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>848 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-salt-media">2. Salt Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-salt-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Staphylococci have high salt tolerance (halophilic) and so salt may be incorporated into a medium to inhibit the growth of other organisms.</p>
<p>(a) 8 % salt agar medium Nutrient agar containing 8% sodium chloride.
(b) Salt-cooked meat Cooked meat medium containing 10% sodium chloride.
(c) Mannitol salt agar This medium consists of nutrient agar base to which 1% D-mannitol, 7.5% sodium chloride and 0.003% phenol red indicator have been added. <em>Staph. aureus</em> ferments mannitol and tolerates high salt concentration. The colonies are surrounded by bright yellow zones. The colonies of coagulase negative staphylococci are surrounded by pink zones. The medium is useful for screening carriers of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-dnase-agar-for-staphylococcus-aureus">3. Dnase Agar For Staphylococcus aureus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-dnase-agar-for-staphylococcus-aureus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This medium is used to demonstrate the ability of coagulase positive staphylococci to split DNA. The enzyme DNase, which hydrolyses DNA molecule to mono- and polynucleotides, is produced by <em>Staph. aureus</em>. When an overnight (18 hours) culture of <em>Staph. aureus</em> is flooded with 1N HCl, a positive reaction is indicated by a halo around the colonies.</p>
<p>The constituents of the medium are:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tryptose</th><th>20 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Deoxyribonucleic acid</td><td>2 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium chloride</td><td>5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Agar</td><td>12 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Dissolve the ingredients and adjust pH to 7.4. Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes. Cool to 50°C and pour plates. Label and store.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="544dc8c3">♦ CULTURE MEDIA FOR THE ISOLOATION OF STREPTOCOCCI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#544dc8c3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-crystal-violet-blood-agar">1. Crystal Violet Blood Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-crystal-violet-blood-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is nutrient agar containing 5% horse blood and 1/500,000 crystal violet.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-todd-hewitt-medium">2. Todd-Hewitt Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-todd-hewitt-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This medium is used mainly for typing streptococci (e.g. Lancefield grouping). It contains 2% glucose and has a pH of 7.8.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transport-media">TRANSPORT MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Transport media have been devised to preserve pathogens in clinical specimens which might not otherwise survive or be overgrown by commensals during the transportation of the specimens to the laboratory.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-stuart-transport-medium">1. Stuart Transport Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-stuart-transport-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a non-nutritional semi-solid medium for the preservation of fastidious organisms, especially the <em>Neisseria</em> species. Its constituents per 1000 ml of distilled water are:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Sodium thioglycollate</th><th>0.5 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sodium glycerophosphate</td><td>10.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Cysteine hydrochloride</td><td>0.5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium chloride</td><td>0.1 g</td></tr><tr><td>Methylene blue</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1% aqueous solution)</td><td>2.0 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Agar</td><td>5.0 g</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>Preparation</strong> Dissolve the ingredients (except methylene blue) by heating at 100°C. Adjust the pH to 7.4. Add the methylene blue and mix well. Distribute in screw-capped universal type containers, filling to the brim. Screw down the caps, not too tightly. Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes. Tighten the screw caps. The final medium should be colourless. Label and store.</p>
<p>This medium is available commercially in the powdered or tablet forms. It is then prepared according to the manufacturer's direction.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Many workers prefer to use the medium with activated charcoal swabs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-amies-transport-medium">2. Amies Transport Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-amies-transport-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This medium is modified Stuart's transport medium in which glycerophosphate is replaced with an in-</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media 849</p>
<p>organic phosphate buffer and with charcoal added to the medium. There is proliferation of coliform organisms due to the metabolism of glycerophosphates in the Stuart transport medium which is absent in this medium. The charcoal enhances the survival rate of <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>. The incorporation of calcium and magnesium salts is also believed to enhance the survival of the organism.</p>
<p>The Amies transport medium consists of:</p>
<p>Neutral charcoal 10.0 g
Sodium chloride 3.0 g
Sodium hydrogen phosphate 1.15 g
Potassium dihydrogen phosphate 0.2 g
Potassium chloride 0.2 g
Sodium thioglycollate 1.0 g
Calcium chloride 0.1 g
Magnesium chloride 0.1 g
Agar powder 4.0 g
Distilled water 1000 ml
pH 7.2</p>
<p>Heat to dissolve the ingredients. Dispense in 5 ml amounts in bijou bottles or tubes. Autoclave at 121 °C for 15 minutes. Cool in upright position. Ensure uniform suspension of charcoal particles by turning several times while cooling.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b23af042">♦ CULTURE MEDIA FOR VIBRO CHOLERAE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b23af042" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-thiosulphate-citrate-bile-salt-sucrose-tcbs-medium">1. Thiosulphate Citrate Bile Salt Sucrose (TCBS) Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-thiosulphate-citrate-bile-salt-sucrose-tcbs-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>Vibrio cholerae</em> is inhibited by the more routinely used media for enteric organisms. This is mainly due to the lower pH of these media. The TCBS medium, at pH 8.6, inhibits most of the commonly encountered enteric organisms in faeces. The medium is a complete medium and requires no additives or aseptic addition of blood. The Oxoid TCBS medium consists of:</p>
<p>Yeast extract 5 g
Peptone 10 g
Sodium thiosulphate 10 g</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Sodium citrate</th><th>10 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ox Bile</td><td>8 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sucrose</td><td>20 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium chloride</td><td>10 g</td></tr><tr><td>Ferric citrate</td><td>1 g</td></tr><tr><td>Bromothymol blue</td><td>0.04 g</td></tr><tr><td>Thymol blue</td><td>0.04 g</td></tr><tr><td>Agar</td><td>14 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr><tr><td>pH</td><td>8.6</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Heat to boiling to dissolve the ingredients. Cool to 50°C and pour into plates. Do not autoclave.</p>
<p>The colonies of <em>V. cholerae</em> after 24 hours incubation are yellow due to fermentation of sucrose. The bromothymol blue indicator is yellow in acid pH.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-monsur-agar">2. Monsur Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-monsur-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a good selective medium for the vibrios. The high pH and potassium tellurite is inhibitory to most other bacteria. <em>V. cholerae</em> produces colonies with black centre and a halo around the colonies due to gelatin liquefaction. It consists of:</p>
<p>Peptone 10 g
Sodium chloride 10 g
Sodium taurocholate 5 g
Gelatin 30 g
Sodium carbonate 1 g
Agar 15 g
Distilled water 1000 ml
pH 8.5</p>
<p>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<p><strong>Potassium tellurite solution</strong> Prepare a 0.5% solution. Sterilise at 121°C for 20 minutes</p>
<p><strong>Complete medium</strong> Cool the agar medium to 50°C.</p>
<p>Add 0.1 ml of 0.5% potassium tellurite. Mix and pour into plates</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The medium should be used fresh.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-alkaline-peptone-water">3. ALKALINE Peptone Water<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-alkaline-peptone-water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Alkaline peptone water is peptone water with a pH of 8.4–8.6.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>850 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3fdd4de2">4. Dieudone’s Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3fdd4de2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="solution-i">Solution I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solution-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Blood alkali solution</p>
<p>Mix equal parts of 1N NaOH and defibrinated ox blood. Steam for 1½ hours on each of eight successive days. Leave in flask for about two weeks.</p>
<p>Solution 2</p>
<p>Boiled alkaline mixture 3 parts</p>
<p>3% Molten agar 7 parts</p>
<p>Mix solutions 1 and 2 and pour plates.</p>
<p>The blood alkali solution is left at room temperature in order to get rid of volatile ammonia. Coliform organisms are inhibited due to the high alkalinity of the medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4e76ac01">♦ CULTURE MEDIA FOR SPIROCHAETES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4e76ac01" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most pathogenic spirochaetes are very difficult to grow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-culture-medium-for-treponema">1. Culture Medium for Treponema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-culture-medium-for-treponema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="smith-noguchi">Smith-Noguchi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#smith-noguchi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>This medium is used to grow non-pathogenic strains of treponemes.</p>
<p>Aseptically cut fresh rabbit kidney into small pieces.</p>
<p>Place some of the pieces of kidney in a sterile tube.</p>
<p>Half-fill the tube with sterile ascitic fluid.</p>
<p>Layer the tube with sterile liquid paraffin or petroleum jelly.</p>
<p>To use, melt the petroleum jelly and inoculate with a pasteur pipette into the bottom of the tube.</p>
<p>Turbidity at the bottom of the tube indicates growth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-culture-medium-for-leptospira">2. Culture Medium for Leptospira<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-culture-medium-for-leptospira" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c5c669f7">Noguchi’s medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c5c669f7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Into a 150 × 16 mm tube containing 8 ml of sterile Ringer’s solution, add:</p>
<p>1 ml molten nutrient agar</p>
<p>Mix and add without shaking, 20 drops of fresh rabbit blood</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="852431da">Fletcher’s medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#852431da" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Peptone 2 g</p>
<p>Sodium chloride 1 g</p>
<p>Distilled water 100 ml</p>
<p>Adjust pH to 7.2 and dispense in 10 ml volumes in screw-capped universal containers.</p>
<p>Sterilise at 115°C for 15 minutes</p>
<p>Cool to 50°C</p>
<p>Add 1.5 ml of sterile rabbit serum to each 10 ml of medium.</p>
<p>Test for sterility.</p>
<p>To make semi-solid Fletcher’s medium, add 1 g of agar to 1000 ml of the above medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="47dba4c3">Korthof’s medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#47dba4c3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>This medium is used for both the isolation and maintenance of Leptospira species. It consists of the following solutions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-peptone-salt-solution">1. Peptone salt Solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-peptone-salt-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Peptone</th><th>0.8 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sodium chloride</td><td>0.2 g</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium chloride</td><td>0.04 g</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium chloride</td><td>0.04 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium bicarbonate</td><td>0.02 g</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium dihydrogen phosphate</td><td>0.24 g</td></tr><tr><td>Disodium hydrogen phosphate, anhydrous</td><td>0.7 g</td></tr><tr><td>Deionised distilled water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Steam to dissolve; adjust pH to 7.2. Filter through Whatman No.1 filter paper. Distribute in 100 ml amounts. Sterilise at 115°C for 15 minutes. Store in the refrigerator.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-rabbit-serum-solution">2. Rabbit serum solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-rabbit-serum-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Pooled rabbit serum</p>
<p>Sterilise by Seitz filtration.</p>
<p>Inactivate at 56°C for 30 minutes.</p>
<p>Prepare 5% rabbit serum in distilled water. Sterilise by filtration. Store in 10 ml amounts in the refrigerator.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-haemoglobin-solution">3. Haemoglobin solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-haemoglobin-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>To blood clot (after removal of serum), add equal volume of distilled water.</p>
<p>Freeze and thaw 2 times to lake the blood</p>
<p>Sterilize by Seitz filtration.</p>

Peptone salt solution 10.0 ml
Serum 1.0 ml

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture-medium-for-gardnerella-vaginalis">CULTURE MEDIUM FOR GARDNERELLA VAGINALIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture-medium-for-gardnerella-vaginalis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gardenerella vaginalis is a fastidious organism which is found in the midst of other anaerobic vaginal flora.</p>
<p>Columbia CNA medium This is a selective medium for G. vaginalis. The medium is basically lysed horse blood agar to which antimicrobials colistin and nalidixic acid are added. The two antimicrobials inhibit the usual vaginal flora while the lysed blood under CO₂ incubation encourages the growth of G. vaginalis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-media">IDENTIFICATION MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Identification media are used in the identification procedures for various bacterial species. Some of the media are described under 'Identification methods' (Chapter 10).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="koser-s-citrate-medium-modified">Koser's Citrate Medium (Modified)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#koser-s-citrate-medium-modified" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Koser's citrate medium is a chemically defined medium used in the citrate utilisation test. It is available in the dehydrated form.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="constituents">Constituents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#constituents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Sodium ammonium phosphate</th><th>1.5 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Potassium dihydrogen phosphate</td><td>1.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium sulphate</td><td>0.2 g</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium citrate</td><td>2.5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Bromothymol blue</td><td>0.016 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000 ml.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>pH 6.7
Dissolve and dispense in 2–3 ml amounts in bijou bottles. Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes in the autoclave.
Loosen the caps of the bijoux bottle before sterilisation and tighten after sterilisation.
Store in a cool dark place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="simmon-s-citrate-agar">Simmon's Citrate Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#simmon-s-citrate-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="to-make-1-litre-base-medium">To make 1 litre base medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-make-1-litre-base-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="phenylalanine-agar">Phenylalanine Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phenylalanine-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="malonate-and-phenyl-pyruvic-acid-ppa">Malonate and Phenyl Pyruvic Acid (PPA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malonate-and-phenyl-pyruvic-acid-ppa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="christensen-s-medium-for-urease-test">Christensen's Medium for Urease Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#christensen-s-medium-for-urease-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="motility-indole-urease-miu-medium">Motility Indole Urease (MIU) Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motility-indole-urease-miu-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A semi-solid medium used to detect motility, indole and urease activity.</p>

Distilled water 1000 ml</p>
<ol>
<li>Dissolve the ingredients with heat at about 100°C, Cool to 50°C.</li>
<li>Dissolve 0.25 g of phenol red in 50 ml of absolute ethanol and make up volume to 100 ml with distilled water.</li>
<li>Add 2 ml phenol red solution to the medium and mix well.</li>
<li>Distribute in 95 ml amounts in screw-cap bottles.</li>
<li>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes. When the medium has cooled, tighten the bottle caps.</li>
<li>Store in a cool dark place for up to six months.</li>
</ol>

<ol>
<li>Melt the base medium by heating to 100°C</li>
<li>Allow to cool to 50°C</li>
<li>Aseptically add 5 ml of sterile 40% w/v urea solution. Mix well.</li>
<li>Dispense aseptically in 5 ml amounts in sterile screw-cap tubes.</li>
<li>Allow to cool in upright position.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="use-of-kligler-iom-agar-kia-and-triple-sugar-iron-tsi-agar">Use of Kligler Iom Agar (KIA) and Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#use-of-kligler-iom-agar-kia-and-triple-sugar-iron-tsi-agar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The KIA and TSI agar are media which combine multiple biochemical tests in a single medium. They assist in separation of the enterobacteria from other non-fermentative Gram negative bacteria such as <em>Pseudomonas auruginosa</em>. These media also help in the identification of enteric pathogenes such as <em>Salmonella</em> and <em>Shigella</em>, differentiating them from the coliforms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-kligler-iron-agar-kia">Composition of Kligler iron agar (KIA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-kligler-iron-agar-kia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Beef extract 3.0 g
Yeast extract 3.0 g
Peptone 2.0 g
Lactose 10.0 g
Glucose 1.0 g
Ferrous sulphate 0.2 g
Sodium chloride 5.0 g</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>854 Bacteriology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Sodium thiosulphate</th><th>0.3</th><th>g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Agar</td><td>12.0</td><td>g</td></tr><tr><td>Phenol red</td><td>0.024</td><td>g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000</td><td>ml</td></tr><tr><td>pH 7.4</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Preparation Bring the contents to the boil to dissolve completely. Autoclave at 121°C for 15 minutes. Dispense aseptically in 6 ml amounts in sterile 16 × 160 mm (large) test tubes.</p>
<p>Set to form a butt and a slant, 3 cm each.</p>
<p>Composition of triple sugar iron (TSI) agar
Composition of KIA and TSI is identical except that 10 g of sucrose is added to TSI.</p>
<p>Prepare in the same way as KIA</p>
<p>Inoculation</p>
<p>Inoculate KIA or TSI agar with a well isolated colony, picked with a long straight wire, stabbing into the butt of the tube. The wire should extend within 3–5 mm of the bottom of the tube. Then streak the slant surface with the same wire.</p>
<p>Incubate at 35–37°C for 18–24 hours.</p>
<p>Record the changes throughout the medium</p>
<p>Biochemical principles</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>There are two reaction chambers within the medium tube. The slant portion is exposed to the atmospheric oxygen throughout its surface, and is therefore, aerobic. The lower portion called the butt, is not directly in contact with air, and is therefore, relatively anaerobic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the medium, lactose is present in a concentration 10 times that of glucose (lactose 1%, glucose 0.1%). Therefore, only a small quantity of acid is obtained by fermentation of glucose by the test organism. Under the action of oxygen and bacteria, this small quantity of amino acid is degraded oxidatively to produce alkaline amines. This makes the slant alkaline even if the organism ferments glucose. In the butt portion, however, due to the absence of oxygen, there is no oxidative breakdown and the pH remains acidic. Therefore, acid butt-alkaline slant indicates glucose fermentation.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The lactose fermenting organisms produce sufficient acid to convert both the butt and the slant to acidic pH. This is due to the high concentration of lactose in the medium. Acidic slant is an indication of lactose fermentation.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Ferrous sulphate is an H₂S detector. It reacts with H₂S to produce a black precipitate of ferrous sulphide. The H₂S production is enhanced under acidic conditions. Therefore, blackening of butt and slant also indicates fermentation of glucose and lactose respectively.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Ferric citrate is more efficient than ferrous sulphate and may be used in the medium (0.3 g/L) in place of ferrous sulphate.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>The phenol red indicator is yellow below the pH 6.8. Since the original pH of the medium is 7.4, even a small quantity of acid can produce a colour change from pink to yellow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Production of gas is indicated by trapping of air bubbles in the butt region.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Reactions by some Gram negative organisms in KIA medium</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Organism</th><th>Butt</th><th>Slope</th><th>H₂S</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Esch. coli</td><td>AG</td><td>A</td><td>–</td></tr><tr><td>Shigella species</td><td>A</td><td>NC</td><td>–</td></tr><tr><td>Salmonella species</td><td>A</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>Salmonella</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>paratyphi A</td><td>AG</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>–</td></tr><tr><td>Salmonella</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>paratyphi B</td><td>AG</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>Salmonella</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>typhimurium</td><td>AG</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>Proteus vulgaris</td><td>AG</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>Providentia morganii</td><td>AG</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>–</td></tr><tr><td>Aerobacter aerogenes</td><td>AG</td><td>NC/Alk</td><td>–</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Key: AG = acid and gas; A = acid, Alk = alkaline. NC = no change</p>
<p>Interpretation of reactions in TSI The reaction in TSI are similar to those seen on KIA except that an acidic slant indicates that either or both lactose and sucrose sugars are fermented.</p>
<p>Use of Kohn Two-Tube Medium</p>
<p>Kohn two-tube medium is another system which combines six biochemical reactions. It also indi</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Formulae and Preparation of Culture Media 855</p>
<p>cates whether the organism is motile or not. The medium helps in the identification of enteric and urinary pathogens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-kohn-two-tube-medium">Composition of Kohn two-tube medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-kohn-two-tube-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Medium No. 1</p>
<p>A. Meat extract (lab lemco) 2.0 g
Peptone 15.0 g
Yeast extract 2.0 g
Dextrose 1.0 g
Mannitol 10.0 g
Phenol red 0.05 g
Agar 16.0 g
Distilled water 1000 ml
pH 7.2</p>
<p>Boil to dissolve and autoclave at 115°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>B. 40% urea solution: Sterilise by filtration</p>
<p><strong>Complete medium</strong> Cool the medium A to 60°C. Add 25 ml of the urea solution. Mix well and pour into tubes to set as butt and slant of equal size (approx. 6 ml)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medium-2">Medium 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medium-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Peptone 10.0 g
Tryptone 10.0 g
Sucrose 10.0 g
Salicin 10.0 g
Sodium chloride 5.0 g
Sodium thiosulphate 0.016 g
Disodium phosphate 0.09 g
Bromothymol blue 0.02 g
