<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-test-papers">Preparation of test papers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-test-papers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For indole test Impregnate 5 × 50 mm strips of filter paper with the following reagent:</p>
<p>P-dimethyl aminobenzaldehyde 5 g
Alpha-phosphoric acid 10 ml
Methanol 50 ml
Dry the strips at 50°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3accbd92">For H₂S test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3accbd92" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Impregnate strips of filter paper with saturated solution of lead acetate in the same way as for the indole test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inoculation">Inoculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="medium-1">Medium 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medium-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Stab inoculate deep into the butt and streak the surface using a single colony picked with a straight wire.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="medium-no-2">Medium No. 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medium-no-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Pick up a single colony with a straight wire and stab inoculate with a single straight stab to about one third of the depth of the medium.</p>
<p>Suspend the test papers for indole and H₂S by wedging them between the cotton plug and the rim of the tube.</p>
<p>Incubate both the tubes at 37°C for 18–24 hours.</p>
<p>Record the changes throughout the medium, and in the test papers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biochemical-principles">Biochemical principles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biochemical-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The biochemical principles involved in the Kohn medium No. 1 are similar to those in the KIA except:</p>
<p>(1) Lactose is replaced with mannitol. The acidic or alkaline reaction in the slant, therefore, indicate fermentation or no fermentation of mannitol.</p>
<p>(2) The medium does not contain any ferrous salt. There is no blackening of the medium by H₂S producing bacteria.</p>
<p>(3) The medium contains urea. The organisms such as <em>Proteus</em> produce urease which decompose urea to ammonia. The ammonia makes the medium strongly alkaline which changes the phenol red to a deep pink colour. The enteric pathogens such as <em>Salmonella</em> and <em>Shigella</em> species do not produce urease and can be excluded. The urease production, however, masks the fermentation reactions.</p>
<p>Kohn medium No. 2 is a semisolid medium. It can indicate the following reactions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Fermentation of sucrose, or salicin or both is indicated by the colour change in the bromothymol blue to yellow.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>856 Bacteriology</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>H₂S production is indicated by the blackening of the lower edge of the lead acetate paper.</li>
<li>Indole production is shown as the indole test paper turns pink.</li>
<li>Motility is indicated by the feathery or diffuse growth into the medium from the line of inoculation.</li>
</ol>
<p>Reactions of enteric pathogens on Kohn medium <em>Salmonella</em> species may be suspected if the medium shows acidic butt and slant, production of gas (except <em>S. typhi</em>) production of H₂S (except <em>S. paratyphi A</em>), and motility in medium</p>
<p>The other tests are negative.</p>
<p><em>Shigella</em> species show acidic butt and slant (except <em>Sh. dysentriae</em>) without gas. Indole is produced by most species. All the other tests are negative.</p>
<p>The <em>Proteus</em> group produces urease, turning the medium deep pink.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-microbiology">Medical Microbiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-microbiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Part Two: Medical Virology</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 1
Introduction</p>
<p>Viruses are the smallest infectious agents measuring 20 to 300 nm in diameter. They are obligate intracellular parasites and contain no enzymes necessary for energy metabolism. They are entirely dependant on the host cell for biosynthesis of macromolecules. A virus contains only one of the two nucleic acids, deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA). The nucleic acid is encased in a protein shell, which may again be surrounded by a lipid-containing membrane.</p>
<p>Viruses might have evolved from free living cells, or they might have been components of host cells which separated and started independent existence. They behave like 'living chemicals' and are the best tools to understand the chemistry of life. Viruses infect unicellular organisms such as bacteria and algae, and all higher plants and animals. The range of hosts an individual virus can attack may be extremely limited, or very large. Major differences between bacteria and viruses are listed in Table 1.1.</p>
<p>The medical importance of viruses lies in their capacity to cause a wide variety of human diseases, ranging from minor ailments such as the common cold to highly fatal diseases such as yellow fever.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology-of-viruses">MORPHOLOGY OF VIRUSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology-of-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="size">Size<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#size" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Viruses differ from bacteria by their ability to pass through filters that hold back bacteria. With the exception of some larger viruses, they are usually</p>
<p>Table 1.1 Differences in characteristics of bacteria and viruses</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Bacteria</th><th>Viruses</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Cellular organisation</td><td>+</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>2. Presence of both DNA and RNA</td><td>+</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>3. Reproduction by binary fission</td><td>+</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>4. <p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>860 Medical Virology</p>
<p>too small to be seen with the light microscope, and hence are called ‘ultramicroscopic’. The size of a virus can be measured in a number of ways:</p>
<p>(i) Filtration through collodion membranes of graded porosity.
(ii) Direct observation and measurement in the electron microscope.
(iii) Determination of the sedimentation rate in the ultracentrifuge.
(iv) Comparative measurements with other microorganisms of known sizes (Fig. 1.1).</p>
<p>The size of viruses ranges from 20 nm to 300 nm. The poxviruses are the largest of the viruses (300 nm) which are about the same size as the smallest bacteria. Poxviruses can be seen with the light microscope, but all other viruses are visible only under the electron microscope.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-757073fb.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg">
Fig. 1.1 Comparative sizes of bacteria and viruses</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Structure</p>
<p>Introduction 861</p>
<p>The complete virus particle, virion, consists of a nucleic acid core surrounded by an impenetrable protein coat, the capsid. The capsid is composed of a large number of morphological units called capsomers. The capsid and the nucleic acid core together are known as the nucleocapsid. The capsomers are symmetrically arranged around the core. The capsid performs two main functions: it protects the core, and helps it to enter into the host cell.</p>
<p>The symmetrical arrangement of the capsid around the core is mainly of two types, icosahedral and helical (Fig. 1.2). A few viruses, for example, poxviruses, have a complex structure.</p>
<p>Icosahedral symmetry An icosahedron is a polygon with 12 vertices (corners) and 20 facets (sides), each facet being an equilateral triangle e.g. adenovirus. Icosahedral capsids are usually formed independent of nucleic acid.</p>
<p>Helical symmetry In helical symmetry, the capsomers are bound to the nucleic acid in such a way that the nucleic acid winds spirally to form a helix. Thus, unlike the icosahedral symmetry, the helical symmetry involves interaction between the nucleic acid core and the capsid, e.g. tobacco-mosaic virus, orthomyxoviruses.</p>
<p>Complex structure Some viruses do not exhibit any symmetry, but are complex in structure. For example, poxviruses are brick shaped with ridges on the external surface.</p>
<p>Envelope Some viruses have a covering or an envelope outside the capsid, and are said to be enveloped. The envelope is derived from the host cell membrane when the virus is released from the cell. The envelope is made up of lipids and proteins. The protein subunits may project from the envelope as spikes. A virus may have different types of spikes e.g. influenza virus has two types of spikes on its envelope, haemagglutinin and neuraminidase spikes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemical-constituents-of-viruses">CHEMICAL CONSTITUENTS OF VIRUSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-constituents-of-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Proteins The protective covering, capsid, consists of proteins. These proteins determine the antigenic characteristics of the virus. Some proteins are in the form of enzymes. These enzymes, though present in very small amounts, are essential for the initiation of the replication cycle of the virus within the host cell. For example, some viruses contain RNA polymerase (e.g. orthomyxoviruses), while retroviruses contain reverse transcriptase, the enzyme which makes complementary DNA copy of the viral RNA.</p>
<p>Nucleic acid The nucleic acid of a virus, which is either DNA or RNA, may be single or double stranded, circular or linear in shape, and may or may not be segmented. The nucleic acid contains the genetic information necessary for the replication of the virus. The sequences and composition of nucleotides of viral nucleic acid are specific for</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-b7dd6f9b.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>862 Medical Virology</p>
<p>each virus. These characteristics are useful in classifying the viruses into families.</p>
<p><strong>Lipids</strong> Lipids are present in the envelopes of viruses. As the envelope is formed by budding from the cell membrane of the host cell, it shows a lipid composition. Some viruses, such as herpesviruses, bud through the nuclear membrane of the host cell, and show the lipid composition of the nuclear membrane instead of that of the cell membrane.</p>
<p><strong>Carbohydrates</strong> Viral envelopes also contain glycoprotein coded by the virus itself, unlike the lipids which are derived from the host cell. These glycoproteins help the virus in attachment to the host cell. Because of their antigenic nature, the glycoproteins are also involved in the interactions with antibodies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-medically-important-viruses">CLASSIFICATION OF MEDICALLY IMPORTANT VIRUSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-medically-important-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The scheme for the classification of viruses depends upon their structure, antigenic composition and other properties. Viral families and genera have been designated, though differentiation into species is still incomplete.</p>
<p>Viruses are classified into two major divisions depending on the type of nucleic acid.</p>
<p>I. Deoxyriboviruses, which contain DNA.
II. Riboviruses, which contain RNA.</p>
<p>Both of these are further subdivided mainly on the basis of size and shape of the virion, symmetry of the nucleocapsid and strandedness of the nucleic acid. Major families of viruses are briefly discussed below:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-dna-viruses">I. DNA Viruses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-dna-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-family-parvoviridae">1. Family Parvoviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-family-parvoviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Size : 18–26 nm
Symmetry : Icosahedral
Envelope : Absent
DNA : Single stranded
Example : Parvovirus</p>
<p>Some members of the family cause gastroenteritis while others are associated with haemolytic disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-family-papovaviridae">2. Family Papovaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-family-papovaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Size : 40–55 nm
Symmetry : Icosahedral
Envelope : Absent
DNA : Double stranded
Example:
(i) <em>Papilloma virus</em> which causes cutaneous, genital and laryngeal warts.
(ii) <em>Polyomavirus</em> which produces neurological diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="3-family-adenoviridae">3. Family Adenoviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-family-adenoviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Size : 70–90 nm
Symmetry : Icosahedral
Envelope : Absent
DNA : Double stranded
Example: Adenovirus. There are at least 41 types of adenoviruses that can infect humans. They attack the lymphoid tissue and the mucous membranes. Some adenoviruses can cause acute respiratory disease, and conjunctivitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="4-family-herpesviridae">4. Family Herpesviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-family-herpesviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Size : 100–200 nm
Symmetry : Icosahedral
Envelope : Present
DNA : Double stranded</p>
<p>The virus shows clearly defined structural units with a central depression.</p>
<p>Examples:
(i) <em>Herpes simplex virus</em>: Herpes simplex virus type 1 may cause oral infection (gingivostomatitis) or keratitis. Herpes simplex virus type 2 causes genital lesions.
(ii) <em>Varicella/Zoster</em>: Varicella (chicken pox) is the primary infection. The virus may remain latent in the nerve ganglia, and may be reactivated when the immunity is lowered, resulting in an attack of zoster (shingles).</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Introduction 863</p>
<p>(iii) <em>Cytomegalovirus (CMV)</em>: Usually CMV infections are symptomless. It may cause severe generalised neonatal infection or an infection similar to glandular fever in adults. Generalised infection may occur in immunosuppressed patients, especially in AIDS.</p>
<p>(iv) <em>Epstein-Barr virus</em>: This virus causes infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). It is also associated with Burkitt's lymphoma although its exact role in the development of this malignancy is not certain.</p>
<p>These viruses often cause asymptomatic and latent infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-family-poxviridae">5. Family Poxviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-family-poxviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>|  Size | : 300-450 nm × 170-260 nm
(Brick shaped)  |
| --- | --- |
|  Symmetry | : Unknown  |
|  Envelope | : Present  |
|  DNA | : Double stranded  |</p>
<p>Examples: All poxviruses tend to produce skin lesions. The human pathogens include variola (smallpox), vaccinia (used for small-pox vaccine) and molluscum contagiosum virus. Some animal pathogens can also infect humans e.g. cowpox and monkeypox.</p>
<p><em>Variola</em> (smallpox) is a severe disease with a high mortality rate in non-immunized persons. The virus causes skin lesions through the blood stream which later pustulate. Pustules break down and discharge the virus into environment. The main route of transmission is respiratory. Smallpox vaccine is prepared from the closely related, but much less virulent, vaccinia virus. In 1980, the World Health Organisation announced that smallpox had been eradicated world wide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-family-hepadnaviridae">6. Family Hepadnaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-family-hepadnaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Size</th><th>: 42 nm</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Symmetry</td><td>: Unknown</td></tr><tr><td>Envelope</td><td>: Present</td></tr><tr><td>DNA</td><td>: Partially double stranded</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The virion also contains DNA-polymerase that repairs the single stranded region to make fully double stranded molecules.</p>
<p>Example: <em>Hepatitis-B</em> virus may be transmitted from person to person by inoculation with infected blood e.g. from a contaminated hypodermic syringe and needle. Procedures like tattooing and acupuncture can also be source of infection.</p>
<p>The virus can cause hepatitis, liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. However, the number of silent carriers is very high. Most carriers of the virus remain healthy but a few develop chronic active hepatitis and cirrhosis, which may lead to hepatoma.</p>
<p>Specific human immunoglobulin gives passive immunity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-riboviruses-rna-viruses">II. Riboviruses (RNA Viruses)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-riboviruses-rna-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-family-picornaviridae">1. Family Picornaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-family-picornaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Size</th><th>: 22-30 nm</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Symmetry</td><td>: Icosahedral</td></tr><tr><td>Envelope</td><td>: Absent</td></tr><tr><td>RNA</td><td>: Single stranded</td></tr><tr><td>Examples:</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><em>Rhinoviruses</em>: There are more than 100 serotypes which cause the common cold.</p>
<p><em>Enteroviruses</em>: <em>Poliovirus</em>, <em>Echovirus</em> and <em>Coxsackievirus</em> belong to this genus. These viruses are ingested and multiply in the alimentary tract. They spread to the tissues and organs to which they have affinity, via the blood stream. The viruses are excreted in the faeces.</p>
<p><em>Poliovirus</em> causes poliomyelitis. It is an acute infectious disease and in its serious form affects the central nervous system. It destroys the motor neurons in the spinal cord resulting in paralysis. However, most poliovirus infections are subclinical. There are three serological types (1,2 and 3) of the virus. An oral vaccine prepared from attenuated strains of the three serotypes provides effective immunization.</p>
<p><em>Coxsackievirus</em> is a large subgroup of the enteroviruses, and is subdivided into two groups, <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. They produce a variety of illnesses in humans.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>864 Medical Virology</p>
<p>mans. Herpangina, hand, foot and mouth disease, and acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis are caused by some group A coxsackieviruses. Group B serotypes are associated with myocarditis, pericarditis and meningoencephalitis. In addition, viruses in both groups can be responsible for aseptic meningitis, respiratory and undifferentiated febrile illnesses, hepatitis and paralysis. The paralysis is usually incomplete and reversible.</p>
<p><em>Echoviruses</em> (enteric cytopathogenic human orphan viruses) have about 30 serotypes. Some of them cause aseptic meningitis, febrile illnesses with or without rash, and common cold.</p>
<p>New enteroviruses: There are newly recognised enteroviruses which are given numbers instead of names. Enterovirus type 70 is known to cause acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Enterovirus type 71 can cause meningitis, encephalitis and a respiratory infection. <em>Hepatitis A virus</em> is now renamed as Enterovirus type 72.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-family-reoviridae">2. Family Reoviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-family-reoviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Size</th><th>: 60-80 nm</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Symmetry</td><td>: Icosahedral</td></tr><tr><td>Envelope</td><td>: Absent</td></tr><tr><td>RNA</td><td>: Double stranded</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><em>Example</em>: The family Reoviridae includes the original Reovirus genus, and rotaviruses, and other insect and plant viruses.</p>
<p><em>Reoviruses</em> cause minor febrile illnesses, diarrhoea or enteritis and are not known to cause any severe illness.</p>
<p><em>Rotaviruses</em> are a major cause of diarrhoea in infants and children. Typical symptoms include diarrhoea, fever, abdominal pain and vomiting, leading to dehydration. The name rotavirus is based on the appearance of the virus in electron microscopy. The margin of the capsid appears as the rim of a wheel surrounding radiating spokes from the inner hub-like core.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-family-orthomyxoviridae">3. Family Orthomyxoviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-family-orthomyxoviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Size</th><th>: 100 nm, spherical or pleomorphic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Symmetry</td><td>: Helical</td></tr><tr><td>---</td><td>---</td></tr><tr><td>Envelope</td><td>: Present</td></tr><tr><td>RNA</td><td>: Single stranded, segmented in 8 pieces</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><em>Examples</em>: All orthomyxoviruses are <em>Influenza viruses</em> (types A, B and C). They have, as a part of their surface, projections that exhibit hemagglutinin and neuraminidase activity. Influenza is an acute respiratory tract infection which usually occurs in epidemics. Antigenic variation is observed very frequently in group A serotypes and less frequently in group B serotypes. Type C is antigenically stable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-family-paramyxoviridae">4. Family Paramyxoviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-family-paramyxoviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Size</th><th>: 150-300 nm, spherical or pleomorphic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Symmetry</td><td>: Helical</td></tr><tr><td>Envelope</td><td>: Present</td></tr><tr><td>RNA</td><td>: Single stranded, non-segmented</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><em>Examples</em>:</p>
<p><em>Mumps virus</em>: It causes an acute contagious disease characterised by a non-suppurative enlargement of one or both of the parotid glands. Other organs may also be involved.</p>
<p><em>Measles (Rubeola) virus</em>: It causes an acute, highly infectious disease characterised by a maculopapular rash and fever. It is associated with respiratory involvement.</p>
<p><em>Parainfluenza viruses</em>: Parainfluenza group of viruses can cause serious illnesses such as laryngotracheitis and croup, bronchitis, and pneumonitis, especially in the first year of life.</p>
<p><em>Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)</em>: This paramyxovirus causes the most serious bronchiolitis. RSV produces a characteristic fusion of cells, syncytia, in human cell cultures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-family-rhabdoviridae">5. Family Rhabdoviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-family-rhabdoviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>Envelope : Present
RNA : Single stranded</p>
<p>Example: Rabies Virus—It causes an acute infection of the central nervous systems that is almost always fatal. The transmission of the virus is usually through the bite of a rabid animal such as dog.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-family-bunyaviridae">6. Family Bunyaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-family-bunyaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

Symmetry : Helical

<p>Examples: The majority of these viruses are transmitted to vertebrates by arthropodes. The name is derived from Bunyamwera, a place in Uganda from where the type species, Bunyamwera virus was first isolated. Other members include arboviruses that cause Rift valley fever and those of the Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic group.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-family-coronaviridae">7. Family Coronaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-family-coronaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

Symmetry : Helical

<p>Examples: Human coronaviruses which cause common colds and gastroenteritis in infants.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-family-togaviridae">8. Family Togaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-family-togaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Size : 40-70 nm
Symmetry : Icosahedral
Envelope : Present
RNA : Single stranded</p>
<p>Examples:
Rubella Virus: It causes an acute febrile illness with rash and lymphadenopathy. It affects children and young adults. Infection in the early pregnancy may result in abnormalities of the foetus.</p>
<p>Arboviruses (arthropode-borne viruses): Many arboviruses are from the family Togaviridae. For example, Yellow fever virus which causes an acute, febrile mosquito borne illness. Severe cases may show jaundice, proteinuria and haemorrhage. Other examples of arboviruses in this family include Chikungunya, Semliki Forest and Sindbis viruses.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Family Togaviridae is further divided into two families, Togaviridae and Flaviviridae. Hepatitis C virus is proposed to be included in the family Flaviviridae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-family-arenaviridae">9. Family Arenaviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-family-arenaviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Size : 50–300 nm
Symmetry : Complex, pleomorphic
Envelope : Present
RNA : Single stranded</p>
<p>Example: Members of this family are rodent parasites which occasionally infect man, causing haemorrhagic illness, e.g. Lassa virus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-family-retroviridae">10. Family Retroviridae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-family-retroviridae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Size : 80–100 nm
Symmetry : Unknown
Envelope : Present
RNA : Single stranded</p>
<p>Example: The members of this family contain a unique enzyme, reverse transcriptase, which is an RNA directed DNA polymerase. The family has many tumour producing viruses such as the Sarcoma viruses of birds and mice, and the leukaemia viruses of mice, cats, birds and humans. The human immunodeficiency viruses (HIV), the causative agent of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), is also included in this family.</p>
<p>Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is the causative agent of AIDS, acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. HIV has a cylindrical core with nucleic</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Virology</p>
<p>acid cloned and sequenced. It is a retrovirus, but differs from other retroviruses such as human T lymphotrophic viruses (HTLV) 1 and 2. Cells bearing CD4 antigen (a major component of the viral receptor required for cell entry) are susceptible to HIV infection, but HIV has a particular affinity for the T4 helper lymphocytes. An envelope glycoprotein of the virus, gp 120, specifically binds to the CD4 molecule receptor site on the surface of the T4 lymphocytes. Once the virus is bound to the cell receptor, it can enter the cell. The viral reverse transcriptase enzyme, on entering into the infected cell, makes a DNA copy of the RNA genome (pro-viral DNA). The Pro-viral DNA can thereby bring about the destruction of the cell. The T4 lymphocyte has a central role in many immunological functions, and an infected cell can cause severe damage to the cellular immune system. Reduced immunity results in infections with many opportunistic pathogens and development of certain tumours such as Kaposi's sarcoma.</p>
<p>HIV is transmitted sexually, in blood or blood products and pre-natally. Those most at risk of acquiring HIV infection are homosexuals, injecting drug misusers and those with bisexual orientation. Others include individuals receiving unscreened blood or blood products and infants born of infected women. AIDS is an illness characterised by one or more indicator diseases. Certain diseases, when definitively diagnosed in immunocompromised individuals without the symptoms of any other cause of immune deficiency, are indicative of AIDS. Irrespective of the presence of any other cause of immune deficiency, if there is a laboratory evidence of HIV infection, certain indicator diseases that require presumptive and definitive diagnosis, are diagnostic of AIDS.</p>
<p>Acute HIV infection is usually accompanied by transient non-specific illness characterised by fever, malaise, myalgia, lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis and rash. Most of these conditions are, however, subclinical. In two to six weeks, antibodies to the core and surface proteins are usually detected by enzyme immunoassay (EIA) and confirmed by immunofluorescence or Western-blot technique. A chronic infection of AIDS that follows is asymptomatic in early stages. In some patients, a persistent generalised lymphadenopathy in the form of nodes of 1 cm or more in diameter in two or more non-contiguous extra-inguinal sites, commonly in the cervical and the axillary lymph nodes, usually develops. In the later stages of the illness, there may develop symptoms such as fever, night sweats, diarrhoea and weight loss. Patients may also suffer from 'minor' opportunistic infections such as oral candidiasis, oral hairy leucoplakia, herpes zoster, recurrent oral or anogenital herpes simplex, folliculitis, seborrhoeic dermatitis, impetigo and tinea infections. These conditions which may be signs of major opportunistic infections to come, are now collectively known as symptomatic non-AIDS; they were previously referred to as AIDS-related complex (ARC). The incubation period of HIV infection is long, lasting up to 10 years before the symptoms develop. Classical complications of AIDS are very severe.</p>
<p>Three main organs systems usually affected by AIDS are—the respiratory system, the gastrointestinal tract and the central nervous system. Most of these conditions are due to the reactivation of latent organisms in the patient or exposure to the numerous microbial flora in the environment. The overall management of AIDS involves the continuous monitoring, and treatment of these conditions with drugs that may cause some serious side effect.</p>
<p>The most common infectious agents which cause complications in AIDS patients include the following:</p>
<p>Protozoa: Pneumocystis carnii, Isospora belli, Cryptosporidium species and Toxoplasma gondii.</p>
<p>Fungi: Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioidis immitis.</p>
<p>Bacteria: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare group, Salmonella species, Listeria monocytogenes, Nocardia asteroides.</p>
<p>Viruses: Cytomegalovirus, Herpes simplex viruses, Adenovirus, Hepatitis B virus, Human papilloma virus.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Introduction 867</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-arboviruses">III Arboviruses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-arboviruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Arboviruses are viruses of vertebrates biologically transmitted by insect vectors. They multiply in blood sucking insect vectors such as mosquitoes and ticks, and are transmitted to vertebrates through insect bites. Grouping of arboviruses is based on ecological and epidemiological considerations and therefore, the members have diverse physical and chemical properties. The name 'arboviruses' is thus a biological rather than taxonomical concept.</p>
<p>Human pathogens among arboviruses include <em>Dengue virus</em>, <em>Yellow fever virus</em>, <em>Encephalitis viruses</em>, <em>Chikungunya virus</em>, <em>Sandfly fever virus</em> and <em>Rift valley fever virus</em>, and so on.</p>
<p>Taxonomically, arboviruses belong to families <em>Togaviridae</em>, <em>Bunyaviridae</em>, <em>Reoviridae</em> and <em>Rhabdoviridae</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-unclassified-viruses">IV Unclassified Viruses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-unclassified-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some viruses have not been classified due to insufficient information to permit classification. These include some viruses causing immune complex diseases, those causing slow virus diseases and some other gastroenteritis viruses.</p>
<p>Table 1.2 shows a broad classification of medically important viruses based on their properties.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="replication-of-viruses">REPLICATION OF VIRUSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#replication-of-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Viruses need living cells to multiply. The host cell must provide the synthetic machinery, the precursors and the energy for the synthesis of viral proteins and nucleic acids. The genetic information necessary for this activity is coded in the viral nucleic acid.</p>
<p>The mode of replication of viruses was first studied with bacterial viruses called bacteriophages. Although viruses have evolved a variety of different strategies for their multiplication in the parasitized host cells, the general outline of the replication cycle is similar. It can be divided into four sequential phases, though it is a continuous process and the phases may sometimes overlap.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="phase-i-adsorption">Phase I: Adsorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phase-i-adsorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Adsorption is the first phase of interaction between the virus and the host cells. Viruses may come in contact with the cells by random collision. Adsorption can then take place only if the host cell has specific receptors to which the virus can attach itself. Receptor molecules differ for different viruses, e.g. the picornaviruses need protein receptors while orthomyxo- and paramyxoviruses need oligosaccharide receptors. Specificity of interaction between viruses and the host cell receptor may vary. For example, the lipoprotein receptors for poliovirus are present on the cells of the central nervous system of primates only, and therefore they can infect only primates. On the other hand, togaviruses can adsorb to a wide range of hosts such as birds, mosquitoes, horses and humans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="phase-ii-penetration-and-uncoating">Phase II: Penetration and Uncoating<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phase-ii-penetration-and-uncoating" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The process of penetration begins almost immediately after the adsorption of the virus to the cell surface. During penetration, the virus particle is taken up in the host cell. This is also known as <em>viropexis</em>. The process of penetration is intimately associated with the removal of the virion capsid or viral envelope from the nucleic acid or nucleoprotein core. This is known as <em>uncoating</em>.</p>
<p>The penetration and uncoating can occur in at least two different ways:</p>
<p>(i) Virus particles appear to fuse with or become engulfed by the cytoplasmic membrane and are transported directly into the cytoplasm as naked particles.</p>
<p>(ii) Some viruses may be phagocytosed and appear internally in the cell in vacuoles, which eventually break down, releasing the virus into the cytoplasm.</p>
<p>After uncoating, infectivity of the virus particle is lost till it completes its replicative cycle. This part of the growth cycle is called the eclipse period.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>

<p>Introduction 869</p>
<p>The duration of this period varies depending on individual viruses and the host. It ends with the formation of the first infectious progeny of the virus particles. Viruses are the only infectious agents which require the dissolution of the infecting agent in the process of replication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phase-iii-biosynthesis-of-virus-components">Phase III: Biosynthesis of Virus Components<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phase-iii-biosynthesis-of-virus-components" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This phase includes the synthesis of viral nucleic acid, capsid proteins, and the enzymes necessary in the various stages of virus synthesis. The proteins and regulatory enzymes which are required to shut down the normal cellular metabolism of the host cell and direct the sequential production of viral products are also synthesized during this phase. The biosynthesis may be summarised as:</p>
<p>(i) Transcription of messenger RNA (mRNA) from the viral nucleic acid.
(ii) Translation of mRNA into early proteins which are enzymes needed to initiate and maintain the synthesis of viral components and suppression of cell metabolism.
(iii) Replication of viral nucleic acid.
(iv) Synthesis of late structural proteins which are components of the viral capsid.</p>
<p>The mechanisms for transcription and nucleic acid synthesis differ in various viruses. The viral nucleic acids replicate by Watson-Crick base pairing. Some examples of mechanism of viral nucleic acid replication are:</p>
<p><strong>Viruses with double stranded DNA</strong> The double stranded DNA acts as a template for its own replication and also for transcribing into mRNA the genetic information for the synthesis of capsid proteins and enzymes.</p>
<p><strong>Viruses with single stranded DNA</strong> The DNA strand acts as a template for its complementary strand, thus forming a double stranded DNA.</p>
<p><strong>Single stranded RNA viruses</strong> In viruses such as poliovirus, the RNA can act directly as mRNA for the synthesis of viral proteins and enzymes. This RNA strand can also act as a template for the production of a complementary RNA strand. This strand in turn acts as a template for the viral RNA of new virus particles. In some other RNA viruses, e.g. <em>Influenza virus</em>, the complementary strand acts both as mRNA and as a template for RNA of new virus particles.</p>
<p><strong>Retroviruses:</strong> These viruses have a very special way of replication. The single stranded RNA is converted into an RNA:DNA hybrid by the special enzyme, reverse transcriptase. A double stranded DNA is synthesized from the RNA:DNA hybrid, which then gets integrated into the host cell genome. The double stranded DNA then transcribes synthesis of viral proteins and nucleic acids.</p>
<p>As a general rule, DNA viruses synthesize their nucleic acid in the nucleus, whereas RNA viruses produce their nucleic acid in the cytoplasm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phase-iv-maturation-and-release">Phase IV: Maturation and Release<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phase-iv-maturation-and-release" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Newly synthesized viral genomes and capsid proteins assemble together to form progeny viruses. Icosahedral capsids can condense in the absence of nucleic acid, while viruses with helical symmetry need viral RNA for the formation of the capsid.</p>
<p>At this stage, the progeny of nonenveloped viruses is completely developed. There is no special mechanism for the release of nonenveloped viruses. The infected host cell eventually lyses and releases the newly formed virus particles.</p>
<p>Enveloped viruses are released by the process of budding through the cell membrane. Virus specific envelope glycoproteins are inserted into the cellular membranes. Viral nucleocapsids then bud through these modified sites, acquiring an envelope in the process. Some viruses, such as herpes simplex, bud through the nuclear membrane.</p>
<p>Enveloped viruses are not infectious until they have acquired their envelopes. Therefore, infectious progeny virions do not accumulate within the infected cell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenesis-of-viral-infections">PATHOGENESIS OF VIRAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis-of-viral-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To cause disease, the virus must enter the host, come in contact with susceptible cells, replicate.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Virology</p>
<p>and produce cell injury. While doing so, it must overcome the defence mechanisms of the host.</p>
<p><strong>Entry and primary replication</strong> Viruses enter the host by various portals such as the respiratory or alimentary tract, through skin or by sexual contact. Some viruses replicate and produce disease at the site of entry.</p>
<p><strong>Spread of virus in the body</strong> Many viruses migrate from the site of entry via the blood stream, lymphatics or nervous tissue to reach the organ or tissue for which they have affinity. In these tissues they find susceptible cells with specific receptors on the surfaces.</p>
<p><strong>Cell damage and disease</strong> After entering the host cell, the virus may remain latent without multiplication or cause widespread tissue damage. When the damage results in the death of the cell, it is called cytocidal; when it causes cell lysis, it is called cytolytic. The damage can also manifest as cellular proliferation (e.g. <em>Molluscum contagiosum</em> which causes nodular lesions) or malignant transformation (e.g. oncogenic viruses causing malignancies).</p>
<p>The cellular damage or destruction can be due to:</p>
<p>(i) Viral nucleic acids which often inhibit protein and DNA synthesis of the host cell.
(ii) Large amounts of viral proteins accumulated in the host cell which exert toxic effects and distort its structure.
(iii) There may be a change in permeability of plasma membrane that may lead to autolysis.</p>
<p>(iv) Viral antigens may appear on the cell surface, e.g. hemagglutinin spikes of influenza virus appear on the host cell surface which make red cells adhere to them (Haemadsorption).
(v) Changes in the cytoplasmic membrane by the respiratory syncytial virus bring about fusion of adjacent cell membranes resulting in the formation of big clumps or syncytia.
(vi) Some viruses, e.g. measles, mumps, adenoviruses, cytomegalovirus and varicella, cause damage to the chromosome of the host cell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inclusion-bodies">Inclusion Bodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inclusion-bodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are structures which can be demonstrated in virus-infected cells. They may be aggregations of virus particles or products of virus synthesis. Some inclusion bodies represent degenerative changes produced by the virus with the cells showing altered staining characteristics.</p>
<p>Inclusion bodies have characteristic size, shape, location and staining properties, and can be seen under the light microscope. They may be present in the cytoplasm, as in poxviruses, in the nucleus as in herpesviruses, or in both as in measles virus. They are generally acidophilic and therefore stain pink with Giemsa or Leishman stain. Inclusion bodies, called Negri bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of brain cells of animals infected with rabies virus. Molluscum contagiosum virus produces inclusion bodies as large as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>30</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 - 30~\mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> and can be readily seen under the light microscope.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="methods-of-cultivation-of-viruses">Methods of Cultivation of Viruses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods-of-cultivation-of-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Viruses are obligate intracellular parasites and cannot grow on inanimate media. They need living cells for replication, which can be provided by three different methods:</p>
<ol>
<li>Animal inoculation.</li>
<li>Inoculation of embryonated eggs.</li>
<li>Inoculation of organs, tissue fragments or cell monolayers.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="animal-inoculation">ANIMAL INOCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#animal-inoculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the beginning of this century, inoculation of human volunteers was the only known method of cultivation of viruses and understanding viral disease. In the past few decades, however, animal inoculation has been employed for virus isolation. The laboratory animals used include monkeys, rabbits, guinea pigs, rats, hamsters and mice. The choice of animals and route of inoculation (intracerebral, intraperitoneal, subcutaneous, intradermal or intraocular) depends on the type of virus to be isolated. Handling of animals and inoculation into various routes requires special experience. In addition to virus isolation, animal inoculation can also be used to observe pathogenesis, immune response, epidemiology and oncogenesis. Growth of a virus in the inoculated animal may be indicated by visible lesions, disease or death. Sometimes serial passage into animals may be required to obtain visible evidence of viral growth.</p>
<p>Methods of animal inoculation are described in the section 'Small Laboratory Animals'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inoculation-of-embryonated-eggs">INOCULATION OF EMBRYONATED EGGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculation-of-embryonated-eggs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An embryonated egg provides an aseptic environment containing various types of tissues. A large number of viruses can be grown in the different areas of the embryonated egg (Fig. 2.1). The inoculation of eggs can be performed with relatively simple equipment.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-89c0d614.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>Embryo</li>
<li>Amniotic cavity</li>
<li>Yolk sac</li>
<li>Egg white</li>
<li>Allantoic cavity</li>
<li>Chorioallantoic membrane</li>
<li>Egg membrane</li>
<li>Egg shell</li>
<li>Air sac</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.1 Schematic diagram of a 10-day old egg</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>872 Medical Virology</p>
<p>For inoculation, an 8–11 days old hen’s egg, preferably with a white shell, is used. Duck eggs can be used in some cases. After inoculation, virus replication takes 2–7 days. The contents of the egg are harvested and inspected for evidence of virus growth. Most viruses either produce morphological changes at the site of inoculation or kill the embryo; or produce haemagglutinins as evidence of growth. Egg inoculation is also useful for cultivation of chlamydiae and rickettsiae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-for-cultivation-of-viruses-in-egg">Steps for Cultivation of Viruses in Egg<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-for-cultivation-of-viruses-in-egg" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Candling</strong> Candling is the inspection of an egg over a lamp. A special candling lamp may be used. Alternatively, the egg may be held over a strong incandescent lamp. Candling the egg after 3–5 days of hatching shows whether the egg is fertile or not.</li>
</ol>
<p>Discard the infertile eggs which show a dead embryo. Candle the egg again on the tenth or eleventh day. Mark the air space with a pencil. Select a suitable site for inoculation depending on the type of virus.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p><strong>Drilling the egg shell</strong> The egg shell is disinfected by wiping with dilute alcoholic antiseptic solution. Cut a small hole at the selected site using a sterile motor driven flexible shaft or a dental handpiece. Care must be taken not to damage the egg membrane.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Inoculation</strong> The inoculum is injected through the hole on the shell onto the desired site, using a fine needle. Inject slowly to avoid spillage of the inoculum. Seal the opening of inoculation with a sealing mixture prepared by two parts of molten paraffin (55°C) and one part of petroleum jelly.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Incubate the egg at 36°C.</p>
<p><strong>Routes of inoculation</strong> The egg can be inoculated by four routes:</p>
<p>(a) <strong>Intra-amniotic inoculation</strong>: Drill a hole just above the amniotic cavity, located by candling. Gently insert the needle until the amniotic sac moves. Thrust the needle through the amniotic membrane and inject the fluid slowly. Use a small inoculum (0.1 ml). Seal the opening immediately. This route of inoculation is useful for influenza, parainfluenza and mumps viruses.</p>
<p>(b) <strong>Intra-allantoic inoculation</strong>: Select a site above the allantoic cavity by candling. Follow the same technique as for the intra-amniotic inoculation. Inoculate into the allantoic cavity. Seal the opening.</p>
<p>This is the simplest method of inoculation with a relatively large yield and is suitable for the preparation of vaccines. Influenza and paramyxoviruses grow well in the allantoic cavity.</p>
<p>(c) <strong>Yolk-sac inoculation</strong>: Determine the position of the embryo by candling. Drill a hole in the shell at the centre of the air space at the blunt end.</p>
<p>Insert a long needle and deposit the inoculum just below the centre of the egg. To ensure correct position, pull back the plunger until the yolk-sac is pulled up with it. Seal the opening of inoculation.</p>
<p>Yolk-sac inoculation is also useful for cultivation of fastidious groups of bacteria such as <em>Chlamydia</em> and <em>Rickettsia</em> species which do not grow on inanimate media.</p>
<p>(d) <strong>Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) inoculation</strong>: Mark a small triangle at a site where there are no major blood vessels. This can be located by candling. Cut the shell along the triangle to expose the CAM.</p>
<p>Prepare a new air space at the site of inoculation by reducing the original air sac. Cut a small hole at the blunt end above the air sac. Place the egg horizontally. Apply a gentle suction with a rubber teat. A new air space develops at the top of the horizontal egg at the site of the triangular cut.</p>
<p>Fill a pipette with about 1 ml inoculum and inoculate through the gap in the CAM and the shell. Rock the egg gently to disperse the inoculum evenly over the membrane.</p>
<p>Seal both the openings by replacing the cut triangles with the sealing mixture.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li><strong>Harvesting the fluids</strong> To harvest the virus infected fluids and other structures, the shell must be opened with great care to avoid unwanted dissemination of the virus. Use of safety cabinets is</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Methods of Cultivation of Viruses 873</p>
<p>recommended. Never use a drill to open infected eggs because it will create aerosols.</p>
<p>After the desired incubation period, open the air sac portion at the blunt end which is already marked during candling. Use forceps or a pair of scissors for cutting.</p>
<p>Collect the contents of the egg in a sterile petri-dish.</p>
<p>Aspirate the fluid from the inoculated area with a syringe.</p>
<p>For harvesting CAM, after removing the contents of the egg, pull out the CAM gently with tweezers. Wash in saline 2–3 times.</p>
<p>Inspect it for the presence of lesions or pocks. Figure 2.2 shows the pocks produced by a pox virus. Test the harvested fluids by direct method or other methods for the detection and identification of the virus. These methods are discussed later in the 'Diagnosis of viral infections'.</p>
<p><strong>Note.</strong> The development of tissue culture methods has largely replaced use of embryonated egg for the growth and cultivation of viruses.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c6d3fb2a.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg">
Fig. 2.2 Lesions produced by Vaccinia virus on chorioallantoic membrane</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inoculation-of-organs-tissue-fragments-or-cell-monolayers">INOCULATION OF ORGANS, TISSUE FRAGMENTS OR CELL MONOLAYERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculation-of-organs-tissue-fragments-or-cell-monolayers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The first application of tissue culture in virology was by Steinhardt et al., in 1913. They used it for the maintenance of vaccinia virus in the fragments of rabbit cornea. The major obstacle in the development of tissue culture was contamination by bacteria. It was overcome when antibiotics became available. After this, major progress was achieved by Enders and others in 1949 by growing polio virus in the tissues of non-neural origin. The virus was till then considered to be a strictly neurotropic virus. Since then, a large number of human viruses have been grown and maintained in tissue cultures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-tissue-cultures">Types of Tissue Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-tissue-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are three types of tissue cultures:</p>
<p>(i) <strong>Organ culture</strong> Organ cultures are essentially cultured tissue pieces in which the architecture and physiology of the tissue is retained. Such small bits of organs can be maintained in vitro for a few days. Organ cultures are necessary for the growth of some fastidious viruses, e.g. ferret trachea can be used for the isolation of some rhinoviruses and coronaviruses.</p>
<p>(ii) <strong>Explant culture</strong> This technique is particularly important for the isolation of viruses in the latent stage. The fragments of the tissue are placed in a test tube or a petri dish in a drop of plasma or fibrin clot. These 'explants' are then covered with growth medium. Adenoid tissue explant cultures were used for the isolation of adenoviruses.</p>
<p>(iii) <strong>Cell culture</strong> This is the most widely used technique for growing viruses. By the action of proteolytic enzymes such as trypsin, a tissue is dissociated into its component cells. After washing, cells are suspended in growth medium containing essential amino acids, vitamins, salts, glucose and a buffer. Serum such as foetal calf or newborn bovine serum is added as supplement. Antibiotics are also added to prevent bacterial contamination. A change in pH is indicated by phenol red incorporated in the medium. The cell suspension in this growth medium is dispensed in flasks or tubes. The cells adhere to the surface of the flasks. When incubated under appropriate conditions, they divide and redivide to form a confluent sheet of cells in a single layer. This is known as monolayer. It is</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Virology</p>
<p>achieved by a mechanism known as contact inhibition. This occurs when cells come in contact with surrounding cells which inhibits further multiplication. Formation of a monolayer to cover the surface of the culture vessel usually takes three to seven days depending on the type of cells used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-cell-culture">Types of Cell Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-cell-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Three types of cell cultures are used in virology depending on their origin, chromosomal characters and the number of generations they can be maintained.</p>
<p><strong>Primary cell cultures</strong> These are prepared from an organ which is minced into small pieces, treated with an enzyme and then used for the preparation of a monolayer. They are capable of only limited growth in culture. Only a few serial passages can be made from such primary cell cultures (Fig. 2.3).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-613b354c.jpeg" alt="img-126.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>Cells are obtained from an organ</li>
<li>Pieces of organ are treated with trypsin</li>
<li>The trypsinized cells are grown in the form of monolayers in a nutrient medium in cell culture flasks.</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.3 Primary cell-line</p>
<p>The advantage of using a primary cell culture is that, if sufficient animal organs are available, a large number of cultures can be prepared. The disadvantage is that primary cell cultures can contain latent viruses in the donor animal. The commonly used primary cell cultures are monkey kidney, human embryonic kidney, human aninion and chick embryo cell cultures. Primary cell cultures are useful for isolation of viruses such as enteroviruses, myxo- and paramyxoviruses. They are used for large scale production of vaccines.</p>
<p><strong>Diploid cell cultures (semicontinuous cell cultures or cell strains)</strong> These cultures mostly consist of a single type of cells which may undergo 30–50 passages before ‘senescence’ or death of the culture. The human embryonic lung or kidney fibroblasts make excellent diploid cell strains, e.g. MRC5, W138 are fibroblast strains.</p>
<p>Diploid cultures are maintained by creating a pool of frozen cells stored in liquid nitrogen. Serial passages of primary cell culture are made and large portions of the initial 8–10 passages are stored in liquid nitrogen. Routine cultures may be started later, for example, from the fifteenth passage and the same line can be used up to about the thirtieth passage. When the diploid cell strains start dying, the subcultures can be restarted from the frozen portions (Fig. 2.4). In this way, the cells from the same source can be used for many years giving constant results.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-62b49fd1.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>Cells collected from an organ</li>
<li>Primary culture</li>
<li>Subsequent passages</li>
<li>Some cells stored in liquid nitrogen from each passage.</li>
<li>Liquid nitrogen</li>
<li>Cell lines for laboratory use</li>
<li>When cells from (6) start dying, fresh passages can be started from liquid nitrogen.</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.4 Diploid cell-line</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Methods of Cultivation of Viruses 875</p>
<p>Diploid cell strains are used for selective isolation of some viruses, and for preparation of vaccines. These include herpes simplex, cytomegalovirus, varicellazoster and rhinovirus.</p>
