<p><strong>Continuous cell-lines</strong> As the name suggests, these cells may be serially subcultured indefinitely (Fig. 2.5). The continuous cell lines have a malignant character, and the number of chromosomes is different from that of the original host. The cells are described as heteroploid. These cells have a very fast growth rate and contact inhibition is absent.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-86e9ace6.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>Continuous passage of cells every two weeks.</li>
<li>Cell cultures are split for cell lines for routine laboratory use.</li>
<li>Cells are stored in liquid nitrogen at regular intervals as a stock for future use.</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.5 Continuous cell lines</p>
<p>The continuous cell lines commonly used in the laboratory are HeLa (human cervical cancer), HEp2 (human epithelial), BHK21 (baby hamster kidney), RK13 (rabbit kidney) and Vero (African green monkey kidney). HeLa, HEp2 and Vero cells are used for the cultivation of poliovirus, coxsackie virus, adenovirus and herpes simplex virus. RK13 and BHK21 can be valuable for the isolation and propagation of rubella virus. However, the continuous cell lines cannot be used for the preparation of vaccines because vaccines grown in cancer cells are not considered to be safe.</p>
<p>Table 2.1 shows the types of cell cultures commonly used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tissue-culture-media">Tissue Culture Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tissue-culture-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cells need culture media for their growth. A large number of tissue culture media have been devised for the growth of cells in culture. Some of them are made for special purposes. Others are made for general use. These media contain various concentrations of amino acids, vitamins, growth factors and inorganic salts. Carbohydrates such as glucose, fructose or galactose are added with glutamine as a source of carbon for metabolism of cells. Such media are also available commercially. For example, MEM (minimum essential medium) by Eagle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conditions-for-growth-and-maintenance-of-cell-cultures">Conditions for Growth and Maintenance of Cell Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conditions-for-growth-and-maintenance-of-cell-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Conditions required for cell cultures vary depending upon the type of cells used. Essential vitamins</p>
<p>Table 2.1 Types of cell lines</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of Culture</th><th>Characteristics</th><th>Examples</th><th>Primary Use</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Primary</td><td>Diploid; mixed cell types; 1 or 2 passages</td><td>Primary monkey kidney</td><td>Influenza; parainfluenza; some enteroviruses</td></tr><tr><td>Cell lines</td><td>Diploid; fibroblasts; limited passage (&lt;50–70)</td><td>Human diploid fibroblast (W1-38, MRC-5 or HEL)</td><td>Herpes simplex; cytomegalovirus; varicella-zoster; rhinovirus</td></tr><tr><td>Established cell lines</td><td>Heteroploid; continuous passage in vitro</td><td>HeLa; HEp-2</td><td>Adenovirus; RSV</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>876 Medical Virology</p>
<p>and amino acids are required by all the cell lines. Most components are well preserved at 4°C except for L-glutamine, which should be added freshly at the time of use.</p>
<p>MEM is supplemented with about 10% serum to enhance initial growth. After the monolayer reaches confluence, the serum concentration may be reduced to 0.5% for maintenance of the monolayer. The serum used must be free from infectious agents such as mycoplasma and from antibodies to viruses. Foetal calf serum is most commonly used. Some cell lines need higher concentration of nutrients than others. MEM is the commonest culture medium for cell lines. It contains the following:</p>
<p>Base: Balanced salt solution.</p>
<p>L-amino acids: Arginine, histidine, lysine, tryptophane, phenylalanine, theonine, leucine, valine, isoleucine, methionine, tyrosine and cystine.</p>
<p>L-glutamine is added just before use.</p>
<p>Vitamins: Nicotinamide, pyridoxal, thiamine, pantothenic acid, choline, i-inositol, riboflavin, biotin and folic acid.</p>
<p>Antibiotics: Penicillin (100u/ml), Streptomycin (200µg/ml) and Gentamicin (50µg/ml) are freshly added just before use.</p>
<p>Foetal calf serum: 10% for growth medium, 0.5% for maintenance medium. Add just before use.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The serum, antibiotics and l-glutamine need to be stored at -20°C, others are stable at 4°C.</p>
<p>The optimum temperature for cell growth is 35–37°C, but may be lowered to 33°C for the isolation of viruses such as rhinoviruses or myxoviruses. The incubation should be in the atmosphere of 5–10% carbon dioxide. The pH of the medium should be 7.2 to 7.4. Phenol red is often added to the medium to indicate changes in pH.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contamination-of-cell-cultures">Contamination of Cell Cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contamination-of-cell-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cell cultures may be contaminated with cells from another cell-line, bacteria especially mycoplasmas, viruses or fungi. Sources of contamination can be the environment, improper sterilisation of media and other reagents, or poor aseptic techniques.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="cell-contamination-of-cell-cultures">Cell contamination of cell cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-contamination-of-cell-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A mixed monolayer may result when cell cultures are contaminated with cells from another cell-line. This contamination can be detected by microscopic examination of the cell layer. Cell contamination may be avoided by taking the following precautions:</p>
<p>(i) One should never work with more than one cell strain at a time in a safety cabinet.
(ii) Periodic cell identity checks should be done.
(iii) Sterile pipettes should be used only once.
(iv) Media and reagents should be dispensed and kept frozen in aliquots sufficient only for one task.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microbial-contamination-of-cell-cultures">Microbial contamination of cell cultures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microbial-contamination-of-cell-cultures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Accidental microbial contamination can be minimized by taking precautions:</p>
<p>(i) Media, serum and other solutions should be thoroughly tested for sterility before use.
(ii) The use of laminar flow cabinets will minimize contamination from air.
(iii) Uncontaminated frozen cell-stocks should be always available for replacement.
(iv) Contaminated cultures should be immediately discarded and replaced with new stock cultures.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Treatment of contaminated cultures may be attempted only if the contaminant is isolated and identified; and sensitivity test results are obtained. Usually the contamination is considerable by the time it is detected. Generally it is time consuming and impossible to eliminate. However, identification of the contaminant may help in indicating the source of contamination and further precautions can then be taken accordingly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="materials-for-cell-culture-techniques">Materials for Cell Culture Techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#materials-for-cell-culture-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="glassware">Glassware<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glassware" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Borosilicate glassware which can withstand strong solvents and autoclaving is suitable for cell cultures. While cleaning, residual cell</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Methods of Cultivation of Viruses 877</p>
<p>fragments must be removed from the used cell culture tubes. This is easily achieved if the cell culture tubes are immersed in hypochlorite solution before autoclaving. This is followed by mechanical brushing and several rinses in tap water and two rinses in purified water.</p>
<p>Culture containers Glass and disposable polystyrene plastic containers are routinely used for cell cultures. Large surfaces of cells are produced in a pyrex glass Roux flask. Glass flasks can be readily cleaned and offer good support for most cell lines. Small disposable tissue culture flasks made of polystyrene (Fig. 2.6) are fit for propagating small stocks of viruses.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9100f282.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg">
Fig. 2.6 Disposable plastic tissue culture flasks</p>
<p>Large volumes of cells can be obtained by growing monolayer cultures in cylindrical roller bottles. These bottles, filled with dispersed cells, are placed horizontally in roller drums and slowly rotated. The cells adhere to the inner surface of the bottles and multiply to form monolayers.</p>
<p>Purified water A supply of highly purified water is mandatory for all the solutions coming into contact with the cells. The use of de-ionized single or double distilled water is acceptable.</p>
<p>Membrane filters Cellulose membrane filters are used for the sterilization of culture media and other solutions. The pore sizes should vary from 8 µm to 0.025 µm.</p>
<p>Laminar flow cabinets The laminar flow cabinets minimize the risk of contaminating the cell cultures with airborne microbes. These cabinets have high efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters which sterilize the air flowing through the cabinet. Such cabinets protect the operator from potential pathogens and minimize the number of organisms in the working area.</p>
<p>Incubators A temperature range of 35–37°C is optimum for the growth of cell cultures. Humidified incubators with 5% CO₂ in air are ideal to make up for the loss of water and CO₂ from cultures during incubation.</p>
<p>Microscopes Direct viewing of cells cultured in plastic or glass bottles is possible with an inverted microscope at a magnification of 40X.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preparation-of-primary-cell-culture">PREPARATION OF PRIMARY CELL CULTURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-primary-cell-culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Dulbecco's phosphate buffered saline (PBS)</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Solution A</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sodium chloride</td><td>8.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium chloride</td><td>0.2 g</td></tr><tr><td>Disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na₂HPO₄)</td><td>1.15 g</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KH₂PO₄)</td><td>0.2 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>1000 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Add a few drops of 1% phenol red (see below) until the solution is pale pink (pH 7.3). Distribute in 100 ml amounts and autoclave for 20 minutes at 115°C. Store at 4°C.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Solution B</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Potassium chloride</td><td>0.2 g</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium chloride (CaCl₂)</td><td>2.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium chloride (MgCl₂·6H₂O)</td><td>2.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>100 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Dispense in 2.5 ml amounts and autoclave at 115°C for 20 minutes.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Virology</p>
<p>Complete PBS</p>
<p>Add 0.5 ml solution B to 100 ml solution A (pH 7.4).</p>
<p>Phenol Red (1%)</p>
<p>Phenol red 10.0 g
Sodium hydroxide (0.1 mol/L) 325 ml
Distilled water upto 1000 ml
Distribute in 20 ml amounts.
Autoclave at 115°C for 20 min.</p>
<p>Trypsin solution (0.25% w/v)</p>
<p>Trypsin (1:250) 2.5 g
PBS solution A 1000 ml</p>
<p>Stir the solution vigorously for 4–5 hours at room temperature. Adjust the pH to 7.4. Sterilize by membrane filtration.</p>
<p>Check the sterility by inoculating a small portion in glucose broth.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: Tablets of PBS and various strengths of trypsin solution are commercially available.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare a mixture of sterile phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and antibiotics (penicillin 100 units/ml and gentamicin 50 µg/ml) in a collection bottle.</li>
<li>Place the appropriate tissue in the above fluid mixture. For example, lung or kidney tissue to prepare primary human fibroblast monolayer.</li>
<li>Chop and mince the tissues into small pieces with sterile scissors and wash at least three times with sterile PBS-antibiotics solution.</li>
<li>Warm about 50 ml of 0.25% (w/v) trypsin solution to 37°C. Transfer the minced tissue to it.</li>
<li>Stir it moderately on a magnetic stirrer at 37°C for 2½ hours. During this period, stop the stirrer at one hour interval, allow the non-dispersed tissue to settle, and collect the supernatant fluid in a separate container. Add fresh, prewarmed trypsin solution and repeat the process.</li>
<li>Centrifuge the supernatant fluid after each collection at 200 g for five minutes. Resuspend in 2–3 ml of chilled medium containing 15% (v/v) foetal calf serum. The serum inhibits further action of trypsin.</li>
<li>Pool all the cells collected above. Wash the cells twice in PBS. Dilute the suspension in the growth medium to contain 2 × 10⁵ cells/ml (see below). Dispense into suitable culture vessels.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C in 5–10% CO₂ till the cells spread to form a monolayer.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="counting-viable-cells-in-the-suspension">Counting Viable Cells in the Suspension<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#counting-viable-cells-in-the-suspension" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After trypsinization, washing and dilution, dispersed viable cells are counted using a counting chamber such as the Neubauer. Trypan blue differentiates the dead cells, which take up the stain, from viable cells, which are not stained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagent">Reagent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="trypan-blue-solution">Trypan blue solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trypan-blue-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Trypan blue (vital stain, C.Z. 23850) 0.40 g
Sodium chloride (NaCl) 0.81 g
Dipotassium hydrogen phosphate (K₂HPO₄) 0.06 g
Methyl p-hydroxybenzoate 0.05 g
Water 900 ml</p>
<p>Heat the mixture till it boils, cool and adjust the pH to 7.2–7.3 using 1 mol/L NaOH (approx. 8 drops). Adjust the volume to 1000 ml with distilled water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dilute 0.1 ml of dispersed cell suspension with 0.9 ml of the trypan blue solution in a test tube.</li>
<li>After five minutes, mix well and fill both the sides of a counting chamber.</li>
<li>Count the number of viable (unstained) cells in four large corner squares and the central square of each side (10 squares).</li>
<li>Calculate the number of cells per ml</li>
</ol>
<p>Area of each square = 1 mm²
Depth of the chamber = 0.1 mm
Therefore, volume of fluid in each square = 0.1 cu.mm
The sample volume used for counting = 10 × 0.1 = 1 cu.mm</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Methods of Cultivation of Viruses 879</p>
<p>Therefore the cell concentration/ml = number of cells counted × 10 (dilution factor) × 1000</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>To determine the viability, count both the stained and unstained cells separately in a given area. It is advisable to count at least 100 cells.</li>
</ol>
<p>The percentage of viable cells</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;unstained&nbsp;cells</mtext><mrow><mtext>Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;both&nbsp;stained</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>unstained&nbsp;cells</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{Number of unstained cells}}{\text{Number of both stained} + \text{unstained cells}} \times 100</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1408em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;both&nbsp;stained</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">unstained&nbsp;cells</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;unstained&nbsp;cells</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="subculture-of-continuous-or-semicontinuous-cell-lines-passaging">Subculture of Continuous or Semicontinuous Cell-lines (Passaging)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#subculture-of-continuous-or-semicontinuous-cell-lines-passaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After the monolayer in a culture vessel has become confluent, and before the cell death begins, the continuous and semi-continuous cell lines should be subcultured into fresh culture vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reagent">Reagent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="trypsin-edta-solution">Trypsin-EDTA Solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trypsin-edta-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>EDTA (sodium ethylenediamine tetra-acetic acid) 0.2 g
Trypsin (1:250) 1.0 g
PBS solution A 1000 ml</p>
<p>Stir the solution vigorously at room temperature for 3–5 hours. Adjust the pH to 7.4. Sterilize by membrane filtration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="trypsinisation-technique">Trypsinisation technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trypsinisation-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Before trypsinizing any cell-line, ensure that it is healthy and confluent.</p>
<ol>
<li>Pour off the culture medium aseptically from the culture vessel containing cells.</li>
<li>Wash the cell layer twice with PBS (Solution A) to remove traces of medium.</li>
<li>Add sufficient trypsin-EDTA solution so that it covers the monolayer. Leave for 30–60 seconds at room temperature. The cell sheet appears opaque. At this stage, the cells appear rounded, but not detached, under the inverted microscope.</li>
<li>Remove the excess of trypsin-EDTA solution and place the cells at 36°C for 2–3 minutes or until the cell sheet is detached from the surface of the culture vessel.</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; The optimum time for step 3 and 4 may vary with different cell lines and should be determined for individual cell-line.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Stop the action of trypsin by adding 10 ml of the growth medium. Rinse vigorously several times with a 10 ml pipette to separate and suspend the cells.</li>
<li>Dilute a small sample of the suspension with trypan blue, count the cells, and dilute, if necessary. Semicontinuous cultures are generally transferred from one culture container into two containers of the same volume as the original (1 to 2 split). Continuous cultures can be split 1 to 6 or even 1 to 10.</li>
<li>After counting, the cells may be seeded into culture tubes, microtitre plates, culture flasks, or other culture vessels.</li>
<li>Add appropriate volume of the growth medium to each seeded culture vessel e.g. about 15 ml for the 25 sq. cm. surface flask, 50 ml for the 75 sq. cm. surface flask etc.</li>
<li>Incubate the cells at 37°C at 5–10% CO₂.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="freezing-cells-for-storage">Freezing Cells for Storage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#freezing-cells-for-storage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Trypsinize subconfluent, actively growing cells.</li>
<li>Resuspend the cells in the growth medium and dilute to a desired concentration of 2–8 × 10⁶ viable cells/ml.</li>
<li>Add glycerol to a final concentration of 10% (v/v).</li>
<li>Label sterile ampoules or disposable bottles with the name of the cell line and the number of subculture (passage) (Fig. 2.4 and 2.5). Dispense the cell suspension in aliquots of 1–2 ml. Place the ampoules in a thick walled polystyrene box. Seal the box and place it in a deep freezer at –70°C for about 2–18 hours.</li>
<li>At –70°C, the cell container may be placed in the vapour phase of liquid nitrogen for a long time storage. The cells should not be</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>880 Medical Virology</p>
<p>allowed to thaw before placing them into the liquid nitrogen from the freezer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="revival-of-frozen-cells">Revival of Frozen Cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#revival-of-frozen-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Remove the ampoule or bijoux bottle from the liquid nitrogen only after it has been in the liquid nitrogen for at least 18 hours. Immediately thaw the contents by agitation at 37°C in a water bath.</li>
<li>Open the cell suspension container aseptically and put two drops of the suspension in nutrient broth to check for sterility. Incubate at 37°C for 24 hours.</li>
<li>Add the remaining suspension to 15 ml of a suitable growth medium.</li>
<li>Remove 2 ml of the mixture of cells and growth medium and place it in a tube or petri dish containing a coverslip for mycoplasma screening.</li>
<li>Put the remainder in a small (25 cm²) culture flask.</li>
<li>Incubate overnight and note the percentage of viable cells. Decant the growth medium in the flask and replace it with fresh growth medium. Continue incubation until the cell layer is confluent.</li>
<li>Check the sterility tube and mycoplasma culture. Record the number of cells recovered from the frozen cells.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="detection-of-mycoplasma-in-cell-culture-using-hoechst-stain-kit">Detection of Mycoplasma in Cell Culture Using Hoechst Stain Kit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#detection-of-mycoplasma-in-cell-culture-using-hoechst-stain-kit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> This is a DNA fluorochrome staining technique used for the detection of contamination of cell cultures. Cytoplasmic DNA of contaminants such as mycoplasma fluoresces prominently when viewed under fluorescent microscope. DNA fluorochromes such as DAPI or quinacrine mustard can be used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>1. Carnoy's fluid</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Glacial acetic acid</td><td>10 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Methanol</td><td>30 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>DNA fluorochrome stain</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Hoechst stain No. 33258 500 µg</li>
<li>Merthiolate 100 mg</li>
<li>PBS 1000 ml</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Working solution:</strong> Dilute the stain 1:10 in PBS.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Mounting medium</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Citric acid 1.0507 g</li>
<li>Disodium hydrogen phosphate 1.4196 g</li>
<li>Glycerol 50 ml</li>
<li>Distilled water 50 ml</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Remove 2 ml of the cell suspension in growth medium to be checked for mycoplasma and place it in a petri dish containing a coverslip.</li>
<li>Incubate at 36°C till the cell layer is semi confluent on the coverslip.</li>
<li>Add an equal volume of Carnoy's fixative and leave for two minutes.</li>
<li>Decant or aspirate the fluid and replace Carnoy's fixative for five minutes.</li>
<li>Repeat step 4.</li>
<li>Air-dry the coverslip for 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Add 1.0 ml of the working solution of the stain and leave for 10–30 minutes at room temperature.</li>
<li>Wash the coverslip three times in distilled water.</li>
<li>Allow the coverslip to air-dry.</li>
<li>Mount in the mountant and examine under fluorescent microscope.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Nuclei of the cells in the monolayer exhibit fluorescence under the microscope. Mycoplasma, if present appear as tiny fluorescent dots around the nucleus either singly or in groups. They have a uniform size ranging from 0.1–0.3 µm in diameter and may be pleomorphic, ranging from spherical to filamentous forms.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>: Other bacterial contaminants or yeasts show typical morphological and cultural characteristics.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 3</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Viral Disease</p>
<p>In recent years laboratory diagnosis of viral diseases has undergone a rapid change and plays an important role in overall patient management. Early diagnosis is very important because many antiviral drugs are now available for treatment. This chapter deals with the collection and transport of specimens, and diagnostic methods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="collection-of-specimens-for-virology">COLLECTION OF SPECIMENS FOR VIROLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-specimens-for-virology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Specimens should be collected during the acute stage of illness when viruses are shed in large numbers. The appropriate specimens collected for various viral infections are listed in Table 3.1. Specimens such as swabs or tissues should not be allowed to dry before reaching the laboratory. Such specimens should be placed in about 3–4ml of a viral transport medium (VTM) so that the viruses do not die due to dehydration. The VTM has a buffering system to maintain the pH between 7.2 and 7.4, a low concentration of protective proteins and antibiotics to inhibit bacterial and fungal contaminants. Various types of VTM are commercially available. A simple VTM can be prepared as follows:</p>
<p>Viral transport medium (VTM)
Hank's balanced salt solution : 100 ml
Foetal bovine serum : 2 ml</p>
<p>Gentamicin : 10 mg
Amphoterin B : 50 μg</p>
<p>Commonly used specimens include</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Throat swab: Swab the tonsillar area and the posterior wall of the pharynx with a cotton tipped sterile swab. Place it in 3–4ml of VTM and send it to the laboratory immediately.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respiratory aspiration: Collect the respiratory secretions into a plastic disposable suction aspirator using a fine gauge rubber catheter. In babies, pass it through the nose, and in adults through the posterior pharynx.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nasal washings: Instill about 5 ml saline into each nostril and collect into a screw-capped bottle. Alternatively, a cotton swab may be used. It should be left in the nostril for 15–20 seconds and rotated firmly to collect the newly formed secretions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mucous membrane swabs: Swab the mouth, lips or genital areas and put into VTM.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conjunctival swabs: Collect these swabs using dry cotton swabs. Roll a dry cotton swab gently along the lower conjunctival surface. Collect into VTM.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vesicle fluid: Aspirate several vesicles using a tuberculin syringe and a 15 gauge needle. If possible, choose fresh, plump vesicles. Send the vesicle fluid in a sterile container to the laboratory.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cerebrospinal, pericardial and pleural fluid: Place about 1 ml of fluid in a dry, sterile container.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>882 Medical Virology</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>Saliva, urine, stool: These specimens should be collected in sterile containers. Rectal swab may be used if stool cannot be obtained.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tissue: It should be collected from an appropriate part of the organ, placed in a sterile container containing 3–4 ml of VTM and kept at 4°C until it reaches the virology laboratory.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood: Collect 10 ml of blood in a sterile container containing heparin, EDTA or citrate. For serology, collect blood in a plain sterile tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Postmortem specimens: These should be collected from the suspected sites of disease and transported to the laboratory as soon as possible.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transport-and-storage-of-specimens-for-virology">TRANSPORT AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS FOR VIROLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-and-storage-of-specimens-for-virology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens for viral diagnosis must be considered infectious and should be handled with great care. Regulations for postage and transport must be fully observed. Within the laboratory, the specimens should be handled only in safety cabinets without releasing aerosols. Every virus isolation specimen should be treated as urgent and transported to the virus laboratory without delay. If it is unavoidable to wait for a transport, the specimen in a transport medium should be kept at 4°C, but not at 0°C or in an ice-box.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="table-3-1-specimens-for-diagnosis-of-viral-infections">Table 3.1 Specimens for diagnosis of viral infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-3-1-specimens-for-diagnosis-of-viral-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Syndromes</th><th>Probable viral agents</th><th>Specimens</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Respiratory syndrome</td><td>Adenoviruses, Enteroviruses, Influenza virus, Parainfluenza virus, Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), Rhinoviruses</td><td>Throat swab, nasopharyngeal aspirate (NPA)</td></tr><tr><td>Dermatological and mucous membrane disease</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(i) Vesicular (hand-foot and mouth syndrome)</td><td>Enterovirus, Herpes simplex, Varicella-zoster</td><td>Stool, NPA, vesicle fluid or scraping</td></tr><tr><td>(ii) Exanthematous</td><td>Enterovirus, Measles, Rubella, Parvovirus</td><td>Stool, NPA, Serum</td></tr><tr><td>CNS infections</td><td>Arboviruses, Enteroviruses, Herpes simplex, Mumps virus</td><td>Stool, CSF, NPA</td></tr><tr><td>Gastrointestinal</td><td>Adenoviruses, Rotavirus</td><td>Stool</td></tr><tr><td>Congenital and perinatal</td><td>Cytomegalovirus, Enterovirus, Herpes simplex virus</td><td>Urine, NPA, CSF, blood</td></tr><tr><td>Eye syndrome</td><td>Adenoviruses, Herpes simplex virus, Vaccinia virus, Varicella-zoster virus, (Chlamydiae)</td><td>Conjunctival swab or scraping, NPA</td></tr><tr><td>CMV infection</td><td>Cytomegalovirus (CMV)</td><td>Urine, NPA, blood</td></tr><tr><td>Myocarditis, pericarditis</td><td>Coxsackie B</td><td>Stool, NPA, pericardial fluid</td></tr><tr><td>Hepatitis</td><td>Hepatitis A, B, C, D and E viruses, CMV/Epstein Barr virus</td><td>Stool, serum (except for A and E) Serum</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Viral Disease 883</p>
<p>Care must be taken during transport and storage of specimens that the virus in the specimen should survive. Factors which can destroy viruses are dehydration, heat, freezing at temperatures near 0°C, sudden pH changes, oxidising agents and ultraviolet light.</p>
<p>Aspirates, fluids and tissues should be sent to the laboratory in a sterile, leak-proof container. Swabs should never be left to dry and should be placed in VTM immediately.</p>
<p>When received in the laboratory, the specimens should be refrigerated (4°C) until they are inoculated into cell cultures. A specimen may be kept at 4°C for up to 96 hours. If the delay is longer, it should be stored at –70°C. Specimens expected to contain viruses such as enteroviruses, adenoviruses, or pox viruses should be stored at –20°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnostic-methods">DIAGNOSTIC METHODS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnostic-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several methods by which viral disease can be diagnosed in a clinical laboratory. These laboratory procedures can be divided into three categories:</p>
<p>I. Direct methods Direct methods of viral diagnosis are based on</p>
<p>(i) Detection of virus particles, viral antigen or viral nucleic acid in clinical specimens
(ii) Detection of characteristic changes in the tissues or cells at the site of infection.</p>
<p>II. Isolation and identification of the causative agent Isolation of the infecting virus from appropriate specimens and its identification can establish diagnosis.</p>
<p>III. Serological diagnosis Detection of specific viral antibodies and their quantitation at various stages of the disease is an important tool for the diagnosis of many viral diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-methods-for-detection-of-viruses">DIRECT METHODS FOR DETECTION OF VIRUSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-methods-for-detection-of-viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Direct detection of viruses, including their antigens or nucleic acids in clinical specimens provides rapid diagnosis of some viral diseases, and can be done in various ways:</p>
<ol>
<li>Detection of virus inclusion bodies or free virus particles of large viruses, by examination of cells from inflammatory exudate by light or fluorescent microscopy.</li>
<li>Demonstration of virus particles in the specimen by electron microscopy.</li>
<li>Detection of viral antigens by immunological methods.</li>
<li>Demonstration of virus specific DNA or RNA in cellular exudate extracts by nucleic acid hybridization techniques.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 3.2 summarises detection of viruses by direct methods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-use-of-light-microscopy-for-viral-diagnosis">1. Use of Light Microscopy for Viral Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-use-of-light-microscopy-for-viral-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Viruses with the exception of the poxvirus group, are too small to be seen with even the highest magnification of the conventional light microscope. Poxviruses can be seen as eosinophilic featureless dust-like particles, lying extra-cellularly in the scrapings from the base of the vesicular lesions, in appropriately stained specimens. The viruses can be directly demonstrated as inclusion bodies in infected tissues and smears by light microscopy. Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct size, shape, location and staining properties. These are the sites of virus replication. As a general rule, viruses that assemble in the cytoplasm form intracytoplasmic inclusions, whereas those that assemble in the nucleus yield intranuclear inclusions. Inclusion bodies can be seen by staining methods such as Giemsa, Machiavello and Castaneda, haematoxylin and eosin or Papanicolaou methods. Fluorochromes such as acridine orange give very good results with viral nucleic acids when observed under fluorescent microscope.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="giemsa-staining-for-inclusion-bodies">Giemsa staining for inclusion bodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#giemsa-staining-for-inclusion-bodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Intranuclear inclusion</strong> These can be observed in cells that have been infected by herpes simplex</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Virology</p>
<p>Table 3.2 Direct methods for virus diagnosis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Suspected virus group</th><th>Microscopy</th><th>Immunological methods</th><th>Others</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Herpes simplex virus</td><td>Inclusion bodies, EM</td><td>IF, ELISA, RIA</td><td>NAH</td></tr><tr><td>Poxvirus</td><td>Inclusion bodies, EM</td><td>Gel diffusion, CF</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Molluscum contagiosum virus</td><td>Inclusion bodies, EM</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Influenza virus</td><td>-</td><td>IF, ELISA</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Parainfluenza virus</td><td>-</td><td>IF</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)</td><td>-</td><td>IF, ELISA, RIA</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Adenovirus</td><td>-</td><td>IF, ELISA, RIA</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Cytomegalovirus (CMV)</td><td>Inclusion bodies</td><td>IF, ELISA, RIA</td><td>NAH</td></tr><tr><td>Measles virus</td><td>Inclusion bodies</td><td>IF, ELISA</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Rotavirus</td><td>EM</td><td>ELISA</td><td>NAH</td></tr><tr><td>Adenovirus</td><td>EM</td><td>ELISA</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Hepatitis A virus</td><td>EM</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Hepatitis B virus</td><td>EM</td><td>-</td><td>Serological diagnosis</td></tr><tr><td>Poliovirus</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>Culture and serological diagnosis</td></tr><tr><td>Mumps virus</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Key: EM – Electron microscopy; IF – immunofluorescence; ELISA – Enzyme linked immunosorbent assay; RIA: radioimmunoassay; CF – complement fixation; NAH – nucleic acid hybridization</p>
<p>virus, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, adenovirus and papovaviruses. The inclusion of herpes simplex and varicella-zoster appear similar and show a homogeneous, eosinophilic or slightly basophilic material in the nucleus. Nuclear chromatin, which is basophilic, is pushed against the edge of the nuclear membrane. The infected cells may be mononuclear or multinuclear. Cytomegalovirus produces basophilic nuclear inclusions in an enlarged cell. A clear halo is often observed around the inclusion. Adenoviruses produce a variety of inclusions. In early stages, the</p>
<p>inclusions are eosinophilic which become basophilic as they mature, and fill the nucleus. Eventually they become intensely basophilic and may completely distort the cell. These characteristic cells are called smudge cells. Intranuclear inclusions of papova virus in human warts begin as a granular eosinophilic matter and later condense into rounded basophilic masses.</p>
<p>Intracytoplasmic inclusions These may be seen in cells infected with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), rabies virus and poxvirus group. RSV produces brightly eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclus</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Viral Disease 885</p>
<p>sions. Negri bodies, the intracytoplasmic inclusions of rabies virus, occur as eosinophilic masses in the cytoplasm of nerve cells. The edges of the inclusion are sharply demarcated. Vaccinia infected cells show rather small multiple inclusions called Guarnieri bodies. Inclusion bodies in molluscum contagiosum are very large eosinophilic bodies (20–30μm) which can be easily seen even under the low power of the microscope.</p>
<p>Measles virus produces both intracytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusions in the giant cells formed in the epithelial tissue. These are very large, multinucleated cells and show eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions similar to those produced by Herpes simplex virus. In addition, measles infected cells also contain brightly eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> For Giemsa staining technique, refer to Haematology section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fluorochrome-staining-for-inclusion-bodies">Fluorochrome staining for inclusion bodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluorochrome-staining-for-inclusion-bodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Fix the smear in 25% acetic acid (v/v) in methanol.</li>
<li>Prepare a 1 in 2000 to 1 in 4000 solution of acridine orange in acetate buffer, pH 3.0.</li>
<li>Flood the smear with the stain for 10 minutes.</li>
<li>Wash and mount in acetate buffer, pH 3. Examine in ultraviolet light.</li>
<li>Intranuclear or intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies exhibit fluorescence with various shades of green.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-electron-microscopy-em">2. Electron Microscopy (EM)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-electron-microscopy-em" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A much higher magnification than that obtained by light microscopy is available by electron microscopy. All viruses can be seen by EM. However, an electron microscope is an expensive instrument which is not available in most laboratories. When available, it can be used to identify viruses in pathological specimens, biopsies and laboratory tissue cultures. Viruses can be detected in two ways, by direct method or by immune electron microscopy (IEM).</p>
<p>The material to be examined is suspended and centrifuged at low speed (300g for 10 minutes) to get rid of the debris. The supernatant can contain sufficient virus for EM preparations. This supernatant is centrifuged at high speed (e.g. 20,000g for 10 minutes) to concentrate the virus in the pellet. The concentrated virus is then transferred to a grid for EM. Grids for EM are made of copper and must be coated with a carbon film before use. The grid should be placed on a filter paper before transferring the material on to it. Alternatively, the clarified clinical material may be spun on to a grid placed at the bottom of the centrifuge tube. The grid is then air-dried.</p>
<p>Staining of virus particles is done by a negative staining method using salts of heavy metals such as uranyl acetate or phosphotungstic acid. This electron-dense material causes shadowing of the viruses present on the specimen grid which makes unstained virus particles stand out.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-method">Direct method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place drops of the staining solution on a sheet of parafilm.</li>
<li>The grid is floated upside down on the solution.</li>
<li>After the appropriate staining time, the grid is washed thrice by floating it on distilled water and subsequently air-dried on a filter paper. Watmaker's tweezers are used to manipulate the grids.</li>
<li>The grid is then placed in the electron microscope and scanned for virus particles.</li>
</ol>
<p>The EM can be used for the detection of virus particles from materials such as vesicular exudates from herpesvirus or poxvirus lesions, serum for hepatitis B virus or faecal extracts for rotavirus, Norwalk virus and poliovirus.</p>
<p>The diagnosis made by EM is morphological, based on the appearance of the virus particles. Since viruses from a group have the same morphology, it is not possible to identify them separately, and they cannot be typed by EM. For example, all</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>886 Medical Virology</p>
<p>adenoviruses look alike irrespective of their serotype or pathogenicity. The procedure for quantitation of virus particles by EM is very cumbersome and not very accurate. However, it has a great advantage over light microscopy in that both intra or extracellular particles may be visualised by EM whereas intact cells are required for the detection of inclusion bodies by light microscopy. It is also useful for the detection of non-cultivable viruses. Figure 3.1(a,b,c) shows electron micrographs of some viruses.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6848ad09.jpeg" alt="img-130.jpeg">
<strong>Fig. 3.1a</strong> Electron micrograph of Rabies virus</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f9aef206.jpeg" alt="img-131.jpeg">
<strong>Fig. 3.1b</strong> Electron micrograph of adenovirus</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-89a701ad.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg">
<strong>Fig. 3.1c</strong> Electron micrograph of hepatitis B (three forms) virus</p>
<p><strong>Immune Electron Microscopy (IEM)</strong> Immunological specificity may be added to EM identification in a number of situations. Pre-mixing the virus in a suspension with a homologous antibody usually causes the clumping of virus particles which are then more easily detected. This method is more sensitive than the direct method for EM.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Add the antiserum to a small volume of the specimen and incubate for 1–2 hours at 37°C. Spin on the grid at 20,000g for 10 minutes. Alternatively, the grid may be coated with the antiserum and then allowed to float on the surface of the specimen for 30–60 minutes at room temperature.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The grid is then air-dried and examined by EM. Virus particles aggregated by the antiserum are more easily seen than by direct microscopy.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>IEM is less useful with virus groups which have a large number of serotypes, such as enteroviruses. It is possible to detect only one serotype at a time.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Viral Disease 887</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-detection-of-viral-antigens-by-immunological-methods">3. Detection of Viral Antigens by Immunological Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-detection-of-viral-antigens-by-immunological-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Immunological techniques have been effectively used for the detection of certain viral antigens in tissues, exudates or culture cells. It is useful for identification of hepatitis A virus and rotavirus by direct examination of faecal specimens, because these viruses are not readily grown in cell-cultures.</p>
<p>Four types of immunoassays are commonly used for the viral antigen detection.</p>
<p>(i) Immunofluorescence test (IFT)
(ii) Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA or EIA)
(iii) Radioimmunoassay (RIA)
(iv) Immunoperoxidase staining</p>
<p>(i) Immunofluorescence tests (IFT) The IFT can be performed by two methods, direct and indirect.</p>
<p><strong>Direct Test:</strong> Specific antiserum is conjugated with fluorescein isothiocyanate and allowed to react with the specimen. The presence of antigen is detected by fluorescence when observed under a fluorescence microscope.</p>
<p><strong>Indirect Test:</strong> Unconjugated known specific antiserum is allowed to react with the specimen. The antigen is detected by adding anti-immunoglobulin conjugated with fluorescein isothiocyanate, which binds to the antibody.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="step-i">Step I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>(a) Determination of optimum conjugate strength for direct IFT</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Fix a known antigen, e.g. poliovirus infected cells, to 6 wells on a clean slide using cold acetone.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Make doubling dilutions of the conjugate (Specific antibody-fluorescein) from 1:10 to 1:320.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add 10 μl of the first dilution to the first well, second dilution to the second well, and so on. Incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes in a moist chamber.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Wash in PBS for five minutes twice, and once in distilled water also for five minutes. Allow it to air-dry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examine under a UV microscope.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The optimum working strength of the conjugate is the highest dilution showing strong fluorescence.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>(b) Determination of optimum conjugate strength for indirect IFT</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Fix the known antigen to two rows of six wells on a slide using cold acetone.</li>
<li>To a row of six wells add 10 μl of positive control serum.</li>
<li>To another row of six wells add 10 μl of negative control serum.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes in a moist chamber.</li>
<li>Wash in PBS for five minutes twice and once in distilled water also for five minutes. Allow to air-dry.</li>
<li>Make doubling dilutions of antiglobulin-fluorescein conjugate from 1:10 to 1:320 (1:10, 1:20, 1:40 ... 1:320)</li>
<li>Add 10 μl of each dilution serially to corresponding wells in both the rows.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes in a moist chamber.</li>
<li>Repeat washing as above, and air-dry. Examine by fluorescence microscopy.</li>
<li>The optimum working strength of the antiglobulin-fluorescein conjugate is the highest dilution that shows a strong fluorescence.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="step-ii">Step II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>(a) Detection of viral antigen</strong></p>
<p><strong>Direct Test</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Add 10 μl of the specimen to a clean glass slide, allow it to dry in air and fix in cold acetone for 10 minutes.</li>
<li>Add 10 μl of appropriate optimal dilution of specific antiserum conjugated with a fluorescent dye obtained in step I (a) above.</li>
<li>Incubate in a moist chamber at 37°C for 30 minutes.</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Virology</p>
<ul>
<li>Wash for five minutes twice in PBS and once in distilled water and air dry.</li>
<li>Include a positive and a negative control as for the test in two separate slides, with each batch of tests.</li>
<li>Examine by fluorescence microscopy. Specific immunofluorescence in the test well is a positive result.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indirect-test">Indirect Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indirect-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Fix 10 µl of the specimen to a clean glass slide by cold acetone.</li>
<li>Add 10 µl of non-conjugated specific antibody and incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes in a moist chamber.</li>
<li>Wash in PBS twice for five minutes each and once in distilled water also for five minutes.</li>
<li>Add 10 µl of the optimum working strength of the antiglobulin-fluorescein conjugate obtained in (b) above.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes in a moist chamber. Wash as instructed above, and dry in air.</li>
<li>Include a positive and a negative control for the antigen with each batch of tests.</li>
<li>Examine by a fluorescence microscopy.</li>
<li>A positive result is indicated by specific fluorescence in the test well.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-enzyme-linked-immunosorbent-assay-elisa">(ii) Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-enzyme-linked-immunosorbent-assay-elisa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Two ELISA techniques can be used for antigen detection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-sandwich-method">(a) Sandwich Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-sandwich-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Specific antibody is coated on a solid phase such as a microtitre plate. The antigen in the specimen is captured by the antibody. After washing, the captured antigen is spotted by the same antibody linked to an enzyme. After washing off the excess, presence of enzyme-labeled antibody can be detected by adding the substrate to produce a coloured reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-competition-method">(b) Competition method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-competition-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>To a microtitre plate coated with specific antibody against the suspected antigen, a mixture of the known antigen labeled with enzyme (E) and an extract from a clinical material is added.</p>
<p>On addition of a specific substrate, the labelled antigen produces a colour reaction. If the antigen is present in the clinical specimen it can block some antibody combining sites, thus competing with the labeled antigen. The amount of antigen in the specimen is inversely proportional to the colour intensity.</p>
<p>If there is no antigen in the clinical material (unlabeled), all the antibody sites are occupied by the labeled antigen giving a strong colour reaction. This is a negative result. In Fig. 3.2, the clinical specimen contains antigen which attaches to the antibody, leaving little or no space for the labelled antigen. In this case, colour reaction is weak or absent. This is a positive test result.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8a4c5d80.jpeg" alt="img-133.jpeg">
Fig. 3.2 Competition method for the detection of antigen by ELISA</p>
<p>Microtitre plates of special quality and with flat bottomed wells are most commonly used as a solid phase in ELISA. The colour produced by the reaction of the enzyme label with its substrate is the basis for interpretation of the reaction, which can be read by a photometer. Determination of the exact value of the reaction by the photometer is possible only when sufficient controls are included. There must be a blank control, an antigen control, and a positive and a negative serum control. The nature of the colour produced depends on the enzyme and the substrate used.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Viral Disease 889</p>
<p>Washing is an essential step in an ELISA test. Multiwash and microplate washers can be very helpful to speed up operations and to prevent variations caused by manual operations. Accurate interpretation of the reaction colour of an ELISA test cannot be made by visual estimation. Special apparatus containing filters, photometers, microprocessors and so on are necessary for reproducible results. Some ELISA systems use antigen or antibody coated plastic bead as the solid phase. The advantage of the beads over microtitre plates is that a number of antigens can be used at the same time. After the reaction, the beads are washed in the buffer using a special washer and then, transferred into tubes. The enzyme-substrate reaction is performed in the tubes. Which are read individually in the computerized spectrophotometer.</p>
<p>(iii) Radioimmunoassay (RIA) for virus detection The RIA is based on the same principles as the ELISA, except that a radio-labelled antibody or antigen is used instead of an enzyme-linked antibody. The radioactive label most commonly used is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>125</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{125}\mathrm{I}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">125</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>The underlying principle of RIA is to select the most appropriate proportion of the radio-labelled antigen and its specific antibody so that they remain in a state of equilibrium. The equilibrium of this standard is then disturbed by adding the unlabelled antigen. A standard curve is obtained by measuring the radioactivity of varying known quantities of unlabelled antigen which competes with the labelled antigen for antibody sites. The concentration of viral antigen in the test sample can be determined by computing the resultant radioactivity from the standard curve.</p>
<p>The RIA test, though very sensitive, is used less commonly because of the restrictions imposed on work with radioactive substances. In most cases an ELISA can be used instead of RIA for the same information at lower cost and at less risk for the workers.</p>
<p>(iv) Immunoperoxidase staining The principle of immunoperoxidase staining is identical with that of direct immunofluorescence test except that the antiserum is labelled with an enzyme instead of fluorescein.</p>
<p>The clinical specimen is smeared on the slide, dried and fixed in acetone for 10 minutes. The enzyme-labelled specific antibody is allowed to react with the viral antigen in the smear. After washing, the enzyme substrate is added. A colour change is produced due to the action of the enzyme on the substrate. This change can be read macro- and microscopically.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The endogenous peroxidase which may be present in the infected cells should be 'blocked' before immunoperoxidase staining by treating the smears with hydrogen peroxide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-nucleic-acid-hybridization">4. Nucleic Acid Hybridization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-nucleic-acid-hybridization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cells infected by viruses contain large amounts of viral nucleic acid, either DNA or RNA. The nucleotide sequences of a particular virus or a group of related viruses are unique. Therefore their detection offers a highly specific test for the presence of viruses.</p>
<p>The nucleic acid hybridization technique involves the use of nucleic acid probes. DNA consists of a double helix of two nucleotide chains with complementary bases that pair with one another, guanine with cytosine and adenine with thymine. By application of heat or in the presence of an alkali, this base pairing is broken and the two strands of DNA are separated. On removal of the denaturing conditions, the two strands with a complementary base sequence reunite or reanneal in a highly specific manner.</p>
<p>The basis of the nucleic acid hybridization or probe detection technique is the formation of duplexes between a nucleotide chain of the known viral origin, (the probe), and the chains of the same or similar base pairing (homology) in the clinical material.
