Fig. 9.5 Life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti</p>
<p>entire width of the body (Fig. 9.6(a)). The absence or presence of nuclei at the tip of the tail varies with species (Fig. 9.6b). Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi and Loa loa are sheathed i.e. they have a delicate, close fitting membrane which is derived from the original egg shell. It is visible only where it projects beyond the head or the tail.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-disease">Clinical Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, and less frequently by Brugia malayi. It is characterised by fever and painful inflamed lymphatics. The lymphatic vessels are thickened and finally blocked, especially those of the limbs and genitals. When the lymphatic flow is obstructed due to blockage, it results in swelling, fibrosis and then elephantiasis.</p>
<p>An uncommon complication of chronic infection of W.bancrofti is chyluria. When the lymphatics which transport chyle from the intestine are blocked, the chyle appears in the urine giving it a milky appearance.</p>
<p>Calabar swellings are caused by Loa loa infection as an allergic response to the adult worm migrating in the subcutaneous tissue. The swellings last for a few days and do not contain any worms.</p>
<p>Loa loa adult worms can sometimes be seen migrating the conjunctiva but they do not cause blindness.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-47eaf3fa.jpeg" alt="img-262.jpeg">
Fig. 9.6 (a) General features of microfilaria</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Common Blood and Tissue Helminths 1039</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ff2ff3f2.jpeg" alt="img-263.jpeg">
Fig. 9.6 (b) Diagnostic characteristics of microfilariae</p>
<p>ness. Generally Loa loa infections are symptomless.</p>
<p>Onchocercomas are subcutaneous nodules containing adult Onchocerca volvulus. O.volvulus infections can also cause dermatitis, lymphadenitis and blindness. The blindness or ocular lesions is a result of host's immune response to microfilariae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definitive laboratory diagnosis of filarial infections depends on detecting microfilariae in blood, skin, hydrocoele, urine etc. depending on the infecting species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Blood</strong> Collection time of blood depends on the periodicity of the infecting species. For nocturnal periodicity, the blood should be collected between 10pm to 4 am.</p>
<p><strong>Skin snips</strong> If O.volvulus infection is suspected, multiple blood-free skin snips should be taken from scapula, gluteal or calf areas.</p>
<p>Other specimens include urine, hydrocoele fluid or lymph node biopsies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="techniques">Techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Examination of blood for microfilariae by
(i) Wet preparation
(ii) Thin blood film stained by Giemsa or Fields technique
(iii) Concentration methods.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examination of urine or hydrocoele fluid: Make a wet preparation from the centrifuged deposit of the specimen and examine microscopically for motile microfilariae.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examination of skin snip: Immerse the skin snip in saline on a glass slide, cover it with a coverslip and place it in a moist chamber to avoid drying. Examine under low power objective after 15 minutes, 30 minutes, one hour and overnight incubation for microfilariae emerging from the skin.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> It is necessary to stain microfilariae for identification of species on the basis of morphological characteristics (Fig. 9.6). Giemsa or Fields technique should be used for staining.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Serological diagnosis is of limited value in endemic areas because a high percentage of the population will show positive reaction.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-guinea-worm-dracunculus-medinensis">THE GUINEA WORM (Dracunculus medinensis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-guinea-worm-dracunculus-medinensis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>D.medinensis infection is common in tropical countries where shallow ponds or walk-in wells are used as sources of drinking water.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>1040 Parasitology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="life-cycle">Life Cycle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#life-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Infection is acquired by drinking water containing infected cyclops. Larvae are released from the cyclops into the duodenum, penetrate through the duodenal wall and develop into mature worms in connective tissues. When fertilised by a male, the female migrates to the subcutaneous tissue, especially of the lower limbs while the male dies after the fertilization.</p>
<p>Near the anterior end of the worm, a papule is formed on the skin of the host which changes to a blister and later, ulcerates. On contact with water, the uterus of the female worm protrudes through the blister to release a large number of larvae in the water. The larvae are eventually ingested by cyclops where they undergo development and become infective for humans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="morphology">Morphology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Adult worms</strong> The female is very long, measuring about one metre, while the male is only about 25 mm long. The worms are white in colour.</p>
<p><strong>Larva</strong> The larva is about 500 µm in length. It has a pointed tail. The larva is actively motile and coils and uncoils its tail while moving.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-disease">Clinical Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The female worm can cause severe pain and allergic reactions such as urticarial rash, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea or asthma. These symptoms appear just before appearance of the blister. Complete removal of the worm from this site results in the healing of the blister. However, if the worm is broken or damaged in the skin, a severe inflammatory reaction can be produced. Secondary infection may occur at the site of the blister leading to arthritis, synovitis and rarely, tetanus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Diagnosis of <em>D. medinensis</em> infection depends on</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The appearance of the female worm at the opening of a blister.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The detection of discharged larvae when the blister is covered with water.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The larvae are discharged when the blister comes in contact with the water. Cover the blister with a few drops of water and collect it back with a pasteur pipette after a few minutes. Examine the water microscopically for the larvae which move by coiling and uncoiling (Fig. 9.7).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tissue-nematodes-trichinella-spiralis">TISSUE NEMATODES (<em>Trichinella spiralis</em>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tissue-nematodes-trichinella-spiralis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Trichinellosis has a world wide distribution, but is more common in Europe and United States.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="life-cycle">Life Cycle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#life-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Human infection occurs by ingestion of raw or improperly cooked meat such as pork which contains encysted larvae of <em>Trichinella spiralis</em>.</p>
<p>After ingestion the larvae excyst in the stomach and invade the intestinal mucosa. They mature within 24–48 hours. The female worms after mat</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f1a1f744.jpeg" alt="img-264.jpeg">
Fig. 9.7 Larvae of <em>Dracunculus medinensis</em></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Common Blood and Tissue Helminths 1041</p>
<p>ing begin to deposit motile larvae which are carried by the lymphatics and blood stream to various tissues. A single female produces about 500 larvae in four weeks. In the tissues a cyst wall is developed by the immune response of the host around the larva. The encysted larvae may survive for many years or may die and get calcified. The life cycle ends blindly in the human host (Fig. 9.8). Although the adult worms and larvae are present in the same host, another host is required to complete the life cycle. Pigs, bears, rodents and other animals are natural hosts for Trichinella.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology">Morphology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adult worms <em>Trichinella spiralis</em> are very small worms. The female is 4 mm long and the male is 1.5 mm.</p>
<p>Larvae The coiled larvae are seen encysted in the muscle. The cysts lie longitudinally in the muscle and each measures 0.5 mm × 0.2 mm (Fig. 9.9).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-disease">Clinical Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Symptoms of trichinellosis may be due to the maturation of the worms in the intestine or due to muscle penetration and encystation. Intestinal symptoms resemble those of food poisoning and include diarrhoea, vomiting and abdominal cramps. During the muscle invasion, there may be fever, facial oedema, muscle pain and swelling. The symptoms depend on the muscle involved, the most severe being myocarditis due to heart muscle invasion or neurological disorders due to the invasion of the central nervous system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Trichinellosis is diagnosed by</p>
<ol>
<li>Detection of encysted larvae in muscle</li>
<li>Serodiagnosis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Muscle biopsy, especially from the diaphragm, tongue, larynx, neck, ribs and shoulder</li>
<li>Serum</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="techniques">Techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Examination of the muscle biopsy:</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Compress the tissue between two slides and examine microscopically for larvae encysted in the muscle (Fig. 9.9).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-055a1607.jpeg" alt="img-265.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>1042 Parasitology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-361c9f6c.jpeg" alt="img-266.jpeg">
Fig. 9.9 Encysted larva of T. spiralis in muscle</p>
<p>(ii) Concentration of larvae by artificial digestion technique using acid pepsin solution.
(iii) Haematoxylin and eosin staining of tissue section (refer to Histopathology section)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Serodiagnosis: An agglutination or flocculation test using latex or bentonite particles can be performed for the detection of antibodies to antigens of Trichinella. The antibodies can be detected about two weeks after the onset of infection and last for about 10 months.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="toxocara-species-animal-roundworm">TOXOCARA SPECIES (Animal Roundworm)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxocara-species-animal-roundworm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The roundworms of animals; <em>T. canis</em> (roundworm of dogs) and <em>T. catis</em> (roundworm of cats) can cause visceral larvae migrans, especially in children under three years of age. The infection occurs by ingestion of eggs from food or hand contaminated by dog or cat faeces. The larvae, after being released in the intestine, are unable to mature, invade the intestinal wall and are carried to other organs such as the liver, lung, brain, heart and eyes. Rash and granulomas develop on the skin due to the inflammatory response to the toxicara antigens. The larvae get lodged in the tissues and eventually die. Eosinophilia is very common.</p>
<p>The laboratory diagnosis is made by serodiagnosis using ELISA technique.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ancylostoma-species-animal-hookworms">ANCYLOSTOMA SPECIES (Animal Hookworms)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ancylostoma-species-animal-hookworms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Animal hookworms such as <em>A. brasiliense</em> and <em>A. caninum</em> can cause cutaneous larvae migrans. The infection is caused by the larvae from soil, either by skin penetration or by ingestion. The larvae are unable to develop into adult worms in humans. They migrate superficially under the skin and produce linear tracks as a result of allergic reactions. The intense scratching may lead to secondary infection. Most larvae eventually die in the skin, but rarely may reach the lungs causing pneumonitis. There is marked eosinophilia. The diagnosis depends on the appearances of typical linear tracks on the skin.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quality-control-procedures-in-parasitology">Quality Control Procedures in Parasitology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-control-procedures-in-parasitology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Quality control measures are necessary in Parasitology to help in the assurance of accurate results. The quality control programme should include description of the steps and procedures for the generation and delivery of reliable results. The areas of Parasitology laboratory which need quality control are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Collection, transport and preservation of specimens.</li>
<li>Use of equipments and instruments.</li>
<li>Preparation of reagents and stains.</li>
<li>Techniques used for detection and recognition of parasites.</li>
<li>Reporting and recording of results.</li>
</ol>
<p>Quality control measure involve:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-adequate-supervision">1. Adequate supervision<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-adequate-supervision" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The section supervisor or chief technologist should ensure that the records maintained by the staff for controls of routine procedures, instrument function tests, temperature records, etc. are correct and up to date. If the controls do not fall within acceptable limits, the corrective measures should be taken.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-regulations-for-reception-recording-and-reporting-of-specimens">2. Regulations for reception, recording and reporting of specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-regulations-for-reception-recording-and-reporting-of-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each specimen must be accompanied by a requisition with patient's relevant information, provisional diagnosis and time of collection of specimens. All the specimens received must be recorded in a log book, work-sheet or logged-in a computer.</p>
<p>While reporting a positive finding, the complete genus and species name of the parasite identified must be indicated. The specific stage of the parasite, such as, trophozoites, cysts, larvae, eggs, etc. should be reported. Quantitation of parasites should be done whenever necessary. Cellular elements such as pus cells, red cells, macrophages etc. if present, should be reported.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-procedure-manuals">3. Procedure manuals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-procedure-manuals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A well-written, complete manual for standard operating procedures (S.O.P.) should include:</p>
<p>(i) Instruction for the proper collection and handling of specimens.
(ii) Preparation of reagents and stains
(iii) Methodology for testing the specimens
(iv) Criteria for identification of parasites
(v) Interpretation and reporting
(vi) References</p>
<p>Each member of staff should be familiar with the contents of this manual.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-regular-maintenance-and-checking-of-instruments-and-equipments">4. Regular maintenance and checking of instruments and equipments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-regular-maintenance-and-checking-of-instruments-and-equipments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quality control of instruments and equipments is achieved by the following methods:</p>
<p>(i) A preventive maintenance schedule for all instruments and equipment should be planned.
(ii) The temperature of equipment such as refrigerators, freezers, incubators and</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>1044 Parasitology</p>
<p>water bath should be checked with calibrated thermometers every day and recorded.</p>
<p>(iii) Centrifuges should be calibrated for correct speed.</p>
<p>(iv) The microscopes should be taken care of as mentioned in Section 1. The microscopes should be calibrated using a stage and ocular micrometer for each objective and labelled accordingly (Micrometry).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-checking-of-reagents-and-stains-at-regular-intervals">5. Checking of reagents and stains at regular intervals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-checking-of-reagents-and-stains-at-regular-intervals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Each and every reagent bottle or container must be labelled properly giving information about the name of the reagent, concentration, date of preparation and expiry.</p>
<p>(ii) Stains should be routinely checked for the correct staining properties using known positive specimens. The dates and results of the quality control check should be recorded.</p>
<p>(iii) Fixatives also should be checked to see if they fix the parasites and cellular elements within the recommended time limits.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-adequate-training-of-staff-members">6. Adequate training of staff members<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-adequate-training-of-staff-members" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All members of staff should be aware of the methods of examination, parasites expected to be present in a particular specimen and their identification criteria. Charts and diagrams should be displayed to help in the identification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-observation-of-safety-regulations">7. Observation of safety regulations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-observation-of-safety-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) All the specimens received should be considered to be potentially pathogenic and handled carefully.</p>
<p>(ii) Inflammable, poisonous and other harmful chemicals must be properly stored.</p>
<p>(iii) Contaminated materials should be disposed off in autoclave plastic bags and autoclaved.</p>
<p>(iv) Liquid spills on the bench or on the floor should be properly disinfected and wiped off.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-participation-in-an-external-quality-assurance-programme">8. Participation in an external quality assurance programme:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-participation-in-an-external-quality-assurance-programme" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Participation in a scheme, in which a reference laboratory sends parasitological specimens for examination and reporting by the laboratory staff is the best way of ensuring that parasites are being detected and identified correctly.</p>
<p>The reference laboratory must send back a written evidence of evaluation of the results, and should also suggest corrective actions whenever necessary.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5670edd0.jpeg" alt="img-267.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-microbiology">Medical Microbiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-microbiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Part Four: Medical Mycology</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 1
Introduction</p>
<p>The study of fungi is called mycology. Medical mycology is a specialised area that deals with the study of disease-causing fungi.</p>
<p>Fungi are eukaryotic microorganisms. Like in other eukaryotes, the nucleus is bound by a nuclear membrane, and contains a nucleolus and chromosomes. Fungi do not contain chlorophyll and therefore, cannot use carbon dioxide as a sole source of carbon. They need an external carbon source for their metabolism. They synthesize and release enzymes and break down the substrate on which they are growing. The nutrients thus released are absorbed by the body for its growth and multiplication. Fungi have a rigid cell wall which is chiefly composed of chitin.</p>
<p>Morphologically, fungi can be separated into two basic groups, unicellular yeast forms and multicellular filamentous mould forms. Fungi may reproduce sexually, asexually or both, by producing unicellular or multicellular spores.</p>
<p>There are more than 60000 known species of fungi. Out of these, less than 200 can cause infections in man. Most of the fungi are saprophytic (saprobes), some are parasitic while some are opportunists. However, they can change their mode of life according to the environmental conditions.</p>
<p>Table 1.1 shows a basic classification of medically important fungi.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="moulds-yeasts-and-dimorphic-fungi">MOULDS, YEASTS AND DIMORPHIC FUNGI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#moulds-yeasts-and-dimorphic-fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All fungi have a vegetative or growing phase and reproductive or spore bearing phase. Most fungi exhibit the same morphological characteristics irrespective of the environmental conditions, while a few show great variations in their morphology depending on the environment in which they grow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="moulds">Moulds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#moulds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The term 'mould' is used to describe any fungus whose vegetative growth consists of filaments or hyphae interwoven to form a mat-like mycelium. The hyphae may either be divided by cross walls or septa (septate hyphae) or septa may be absent (non-septate or aseptate hyphae). Septa divide the mycelium into cell-like units. However, these divisions are not complete and the cell-like units bear openings through which cytoplasm, other cellular contents and even nuclei can migrate. Therefore, fungi are functionally unicellular, multinucleate organisms.</p>
<p>Vegetative growth of most filamentous fungi is almost the same.</p>
<p>The vegetative phase is followed by the reproductive phase which exhibits a great diversity. Reproduction in fungi can be very simple, e.g. formation of spores on a non-specialised hypha, or it can</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Medical Mycology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-af514be6.jpeg" alt="img-268.jpeg"></p>
<p>be a very complex developmental process. This diversity in the mechanism of spore formation and the morphology of spores provides the basis for the identification of fungi.</p>
<p>The moulds grow radially on culture media because of the continually extending hyphae. Some grow vertically and project above the surface of the medium. These are aerial hyphae and they participate in the process of reproduction by bearing the spores or the fruiting bodies. The colour, texture, form and rate of the growth are all useful in identification of the fungi.</p>
<p>For the purpose of identification in the laboratory, the moulds or filamentous fungi can be broadly divided into three categories on the basis of their hyphae.</p>
<ol>
<li>Zygomycetes: Fungi belonging to this group grow rapidly, completely filling the petri dish with a gray-white, fluffy mycelium within two to three days. Microscopically, the hyphae are broad, ribbon-like, twisted and non-septate. These fungi are also called phycomycetes, e.g. Mucor, Rhizopus.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Introduction 1049</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Dark or dematiacious saprobes: Fungi in this group produce a dark brown or black pigmentation visible both on the surface and on the reverse side of the colony. Microscopically, the hyphae show distinct yellow to brown intrinsic pigmentation that can be seen without staining. The hyphae are septate, e.g. <em>Cladosporium</em> species, <em>Phialophora</em> species.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyaline saprobes: Fungi of this group have septate hyphae which have a transparent or hyaline appearance. The growth on laboratory media may show a variety of bright colours owing to the production of pigmented spores, e.g. <em>Aspergillus</em> species.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="yeasts-and-yeast-like-fungi">Yeasts and Yeast-like Fungi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#yeasts-and-yeast-like-fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The term ‘yeast’ refers to a group of fungi which have a unicellular vegetative growth form. It is a fairly homogeneous group with common physiological, biochemical and reproductive characteristics. Growth takes place by the enlargement of a single cell and reproduction occurs through a process called budding. On the other hand, yeast-like fungi constitute a rather heterogeneous group of fungi in which only the vegetative growth form resembles a true yeast. The reproduction in yeast-like fungi may be by budding or by other more complex processes. Some yeast-like fungi produce structures which resemble hyphae (pseudo-hyphae).</p>
<p>On culture media, yeasts produce moist, creamy and opaque colonies resembling those of bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dimorphic-fungi">Dimorphic Fungi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dimorphic-fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dimorphism is the ability of some fungi to form both mould-like and yeast-like vegetative forms. These are pathogenic fungi which are yeast-like in the host tissues and mould-like on artificial media at room temperature. However, when grown at 37°C on an enriched medium, a dimorphic fungus may grow in the yeast form. Some dimorphic fungi are pathogenic to man.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reproduction-in-fungi">REPRODUCTION IN FUNGI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reproduction-in-fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The life cycle of a fungus may have asexual, sexual or both the phases. All fungi can reproduce asexually. In yeasts, asexual reproduction occurs by budding. In case of mould, the vegetative mycelium later forms asexual spores called conidia. The conidia may be borne on the vegetative mycelium or on specialised hyphae. conidiophores. The conidia are asexual spores, i.e. their nuclei are formed by mitotic divisions and are always haploid. These conidia are capable of producing new, identical colonies. The mycelium with its conidia is an asexual or anamorphic state.</p>
<p>In a sexual life cycle, the mycelium produces a physical connection to another mycelium of a compatible mating strain. The mating of two mycelial structures results in the formation of a diploid zygote, known as an ascus or a basidium. Haploid sexual spores are formed within or on the surface of these fruiting bodies through meiosis. The mycelium with its fruiting bodies and sexual spores constitutes the sexual or telemorphic state.</p>
<p>In most medically important fungi, the sexual phase is either missing or not yet identified. They are therefore known as deuteromycetes or fungi imperfecti.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classes-of-fungi">CLASSES OF FUNGI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classes-of-fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Medically important fungi can be divided into four classes depending on the type of spores produced.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-zygomycetes">1. Zygomycetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-zygomycetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are fungi with broad and non-septate hyphae, capable of growing rapidly on standard nutrient media. The zygomycetes produce sexual spores, called zygospores, by the fusion of the tips of specialised aerial hyphae. Asexual spores are</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>1050 Medical Mycology</p>
<p>called sporangiospores. These are borne on the specialised hyphae, sporangiophores. Sporangiospores are produced within a sac-like structure, sporangium which is formed at the tip of the sporangiophore.</p>
<p>Zygomycetes are also known as phycomycetes. Several genera in this group can cause opportunistic infections in humans.</p>
<p>Examples: Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-ascomycetes">2. Ascomycetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-ascomycetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In Ascomycetes, the sexual spores are produced within a sac-like structure called ascus. The asexual spores, called conidia are produced externally on the hyphae. The conidia can be of various types, for example, macroconidia and microconidia.</p>
<p>Examples: Species of Trichophyton, Microsporum, Aspergillus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-basidiomycetes">3. Basidiomycetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-basidiomycetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this group of fungi, sexual spores (basidiospores) are formed on the surface of a club-shaped structure called basidium or base. Asexual reproduction is by the formation of conidia.</p>
<p>Examples: All mushrooms, including the poisonous ones, are Basidiomycetes. Fungi of medical importance rarely produce basidiospores except Cryptococcus neoformans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-deuteromycetes">4. Deuteromycetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-deuteromycetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fungi in this group are also known as Fungi Imperfecti. In contrast to the other groups of fungi, these cannot be classified on the basis of their sexual reproduction. This is mainly because their sexual cycle is not yet identified. Most Deuteromycetes resemble Ascomycetes morphologically.</p>
<p>Examples: Species of Epidermophyton, Sporothrix and Candida.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="39689d">♦ ASEXUAL SPORULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#39689d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Asexual sporulation is the type of sporulation observed in most fungi encountered in a clinical laboratory. The type of spores, their morphology and arrangement are important criteria for establishing definitive identification of an organism. The asexual spores may be produced either on a vegetative mycelium or on an aerial mycelium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sporulation-on-vegetative-mycelium">Sporulation on Vegetative Mycelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sporulation-on-vegetative-mycelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Three types of spores are formed directly from the vegetative mycelium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-blastoconidia-or-blastospores">1. Blastoconidia or blastospores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-blastoconidia-or-blastospores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Blastoconidia are budding forms characteristically produced by a vegetative yeast cell, with a subsequent separation of the bud from the parent cell. e.g. Cryptococcus species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-chlamydospores">2. Chlamydospores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-chlamydospores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Terminal or intercalary cells within the hyphae on large and develop thick walls to form chlamydospores. The chlamydospores are resistant to unfavourable environmental conditions and survive even after the remainder of the mycelium has died and disintegrated. The spores germinate when the conditions become favourable for vegetative growth. Chlamydospores are typically produced by Candida albicans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-arthroconidia-or-arthrospores">3. Arthroconidia or arthrospores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-arthroconidia-or-arthrospores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Arthroconidia are formed by thickening of segments of septate hyphae which become detached at their point of septation. Examples of arthroconidia producing fungi are Coccidioides immitis, Geotrichum species.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Introduction 1051</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sporulation-on-aerial-mycelium">Sporulation on Aerial Mycelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sporulation-on-aerial-mycelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Aerial sporulation is generally more elaborate than vegetative sporulation and a large number of spores are produced within or on the surface of a fruiting body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-sporangiospores">1. Sporangiospores<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-sporangiospores" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A sac-like structure, Sporangium, is formed at the tip of an aerial hypha called sporangiophore. Asexual spores produced within the sporangium are called sporangiospores. These structures are characteristic of the Zygomycetes, e.g. Mucor, Rhizopus species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-conidia">2. Conidia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-conidia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Spores produced directly from the surface of an aerial mycelium are called conidia. Conidia may be borne singly, in chains or in clusters on special hyphal segments, the conidiophores. The shapes and sizes of conidia and the way in which they are formed vary and are useful in identification of fungi.</p>
<p>Some fungi produce more than one types of conidia. The small, single celled conidia are called microconidia or microaleuriospores, and the large, often multicellular conidia are called macroconidia or macroaleuriospores. For example, dermatophytes belonging to genera Trichophyton</p>

<p>and Microsporum produce both micro and macroconidia.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-fungal-infections-mycoses">CLASSIFICATION OF FUNGAL INFECTIONS (Mycoses)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-fungal-infections-mycoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clinically, human mycotic infections, mycoses, may be grouped into four categories:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-superficial-mycoses">1. Superficial mycoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-superficial-mycoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Superficial or cutaneous mycoses are fungal infections that involve the hair, skin or nails without invading any living tissue. These infections are chronic and resistant to treatment, but rarely affect the general health of the patient. <em>Dermatophytes</em>, which include species of <em>Trichophyton</em>, <em>Microsporum</em> and <em>Epidermophyton</em>, are the most common causative agents of superficial mycoses called ringworm. Also included in this group are fungi causing tinea nigra, tinea versicolour and piedra.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-subcutaneous-mycoses">2. Subcutaneous mycoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-subcutaneous-mycoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Subcutaneous mycoses are infections confined to the subcutaneous tissue without dissemination to distant sites. For example, infections such as mycetoma, chromoblastomycosis or sporotrichosis are subcutaneous mycoses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-systemic-or-deep-seated-mycoses">3. Systemic or deep-seated mycoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-systemic-or-deep-seated-mycoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Deep or systemic mycoses may produce systemic involvement and sometimes, can be fatal. They are most commonly acquired by inhalation of spores and may spread from the lung to involve any part of the body. The major systemic mycoses are caused by fungi such as <em>Histoplasma capsulatum</em>, <em>Coccidioides immitis</em>, <em>Paracoccidioides braziliensis</em>, <em>Blastomyces dermatitidis</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-opportunistic-mycoses">4. Opportunistic mycoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-opportunistic-mycoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The number of fungi included in this group appears to be ever-expanding. These fungi cause infections primarily in immunocompromised patients, usually due to underlying disease or due to immunosuppressive agents. Most of these fungi are saprophytic, living freely in soil or on decaying organic material. Most commonly encountered opportunistic infections include those caused by <em>Aspergillus</em> species, <em>Candida</em> species and, <em>Cryptococcus neoformans</em>.</p>
<p>Table 1.1 briefly shows morphological and clinical classification of medically important fungi.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="laboratory-techniques-in-mycology">Laboratory Techniques in Mycology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-techniques-in-mycology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The goals of a clinical mycology laboratory are to isolate and identify correctly the suspected aetiological agents of fungal infections. These goals can be achieved by appropriate collection, prompt transportation and correct processing of specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-and-transportation-of-specimens">COLLECTION AND TRANSPORTATION OF SPECIMENS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-and-transportation-of-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sealed, sterile containers should be used for all liquid or moist specimens. As a general rule, the specimens should not be frozen or allowed to dry. They should either be left at room temperature or refrigerated at 4°C. In many instances, specimens not only contain the aetiological agent, but also contain contaminating bacteria. Therefore, antibiotics should be added to decontaminate the specimens. About 20 units of penicillin, 0.04 mg of streptomycin or 0.02 mg of chloramphenicol can be added per millilitre of the specimen.</p>
<p>Table 2.1 shows the clinical specimens and common fungi found of them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-secretions">Respiratory Secretions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-secretions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As most systemic or deep seated fungal infections have a primary focus in the lungs, respiratory secretion is the most common specimen selected for culture. The respiratory secretions include sputum, bronchial washings and tracheal aspirations.</p>
<p>The first early morning sample of sputum is collected after rinsing the mouth vigorously with water. Sputum induction with a heated aerosol saline suspension may be necessary if an adequate specimen cannot be obtained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerebrospinal-fluid-csf-and-other-body-fluids">Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) and other Body Fluids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebrospinal-fluid-csf-and-other-body-fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>CSF is obtained via lumbar puncture when infections of the central nervous system are suspected. At least 3.0 ml of fluid should be collected in a sterile container for adequate mycological studies. Other fluids, such as synovial fluid, should be collected in a sterile container. If it is a bloody specimen, heparin should be used as an anticoagulant.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; CSF should not be refrigerated. It can be left at room temperature or placed in an incubator overnight at 37°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urine">Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The first early morning urine specimens are preferred, but random samples are acceptable. Suprapubic aspirates or catheterized specimens can also be collected. Approximately 25–50 ml of urine should be collected aseptically in a sterile, screw capped container and sent immediately for processing. If a delay of more than 2 hours is an</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
